discharge_summary:
History of Present Illness: 72-year-old man admitted emergently with acute on chronic systolic heart failure (I50.23) complicated by cardiogenic shock and type 2 myocardial infarction. Admission course was notable for acute tubular necrosis (AKI, N17.0), severe protein-calorie malnutrition, hyponatremia, and hepatic dysfunction. Prior history includes permanent atrial fibrillation and chronic ischemic heart disease.

Hospital Course: Patient required hemodynamic support with dobutamine infusion for cardiogenic shock and continuous telemetry. Over a 19.6-day hospitalization he was diuresed judiciously, received careful electrolyte and volume management, and required temporary renal support measures while AKI improved but did not fully normalize. Nutrition was optimized with dietitian involvement and oral nutrition supplements for severe malnutrition. Hyponatremia and hepatic chemistries trended toward baseline with supportive care. Antithrombotic strategy was implemented given atrial fibrillation and ischemic risk.

Key Findings and Procedures: Echocardiography confirmed reduced LVEF consistent with systolic cardiomyopathy. Troponin elevation consistent with type 2 MI. Labs demonstrated acute kidney injury with improving creatinine and persistent electrolyte monitoring needs. Patient received temporary inotropic support (dobutamine) which was successfully weaned. No invasive coronary intervention performed during this admission.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge patient is hemodynamically stable, off inotropic support, euvolemic on oral diuretics, and on continuous telemetry until transfer. He ambulates with assistance and requires help with several activities of daily living due to deconditioning. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing visits for medication management, daily weights, vital signs, wound/skin assessment, assistance with ADLs, and coordination of outpatient labs.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include apixaban, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, oral diuretics, potassium chloride as needed, pantoprazole, acetaminophen, stool regimen (polyethylene glycol, senna), and nutritional supplements. Dobutamine discontinued. Follow-up: Primary care in 3–5 days, cardiology within 7 days, nephrology within 1–2 weeks. Home health to monitor BMP/Na/K and report weight change or dyspnea promptly.

History of Present Illness: 67-year-old man admitted under observation for acute on chronic systolic (congestive) heart failure with progressive dyspnea and lower extremity edema over 10 days. He has known ischemic cardiomyopathy, prior CABG/PCI, chronic kidney disease, and paroxysmal/unspecified atrial fibrillation. He presented with volume overload and was managed with intravenous diuretics.

Hospital Course: Five-day observation stay. Patient received IV loop diuresis with transition to oral torsemide; guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure was optimized (continued carvedilol, initiation/continuation of spironolactone where renal function allowed, and lisinopril adjusted). Rate control for atrial fibrillation achieved with amiodarone; anticoagulation with warfarin continued given cardiac history. Renal function remained stable for baseline CKD. No evidence of acute coronary syndrome; telemetry identified atrial fibrillation without high-risk features. Transthoracic echocardiogram consistent with systolic dysfunction; chest radiograph improved with diuresis.

Key Findings and Procedures: Diagnosis: acute on chronic systolic heart failure (primary). Other pertinent diagnoses: secondary pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ischemic cardiomyopathy, nonrheumatic mitral regurgitation, CKD. Procedures/therapies: IV diuresis, transthoracic echocardiogram, telemetry monitoring, medication optimization and anticoagulation management.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: He is hemodynamically stable and euvolemic at discharge with improved dyspnea. Ambulates with steadying assistance and requires home support for some activities of daily living; independent with light grooming. Home health recommended for monitoring and to assist with medication management and safety.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include torsemide, spironolactone, carvedilol, lisinopril, amiodarone, warfarin (with home INR monitoring), aspirin, simvastatin, omeprazole, multivitamin, and others as listed. Home health to initiate within 48 hours for daily weights, edema checks, vital signs, wound/skin assessment, and medication reconciliation. Follow-up with cardiology in 1 week and primary care in 1 week; anticoagulation clinic/INR within 48–72 hours. Return precautions reviewed.

Length of stay: 5 days (observation).

History of Present Illness: 61-year-old male with longstanding type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral vascular disease presented on observation status with progressive right lower extremity ischemia and gangrene. Past medical history significant for end-stage renal disease on thrice-weekly hemodialysis, prior left above-knee amputation, hypertensive CKD stage 5, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia and anemia of CKD.

Hospital Course: The patient was observed for 4 days. Vascular surgery evaluated and confirmed critical ischemia with nonviable tissue of the right distal lower extremity. He underwent operative debridement/partial amputation of necrotic tissue and placement of dressings with subsequent wound VAC management. He received empiric IV ceftriaxone, analgesia (acetaminophen, hydromorphone PRN), and peri-dialysis heparinization. Hemodialysis sessions were continued without complication. Epoetin alfa was administered for CKD-related anemia per dialysis clinic plan. Cardiology managed rate control for paroxysmal AF; no acute coronary event.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging and vascular exam consistent with severe peripheral arterial disease and gangrene of the right leg. Procedures performed: surgical debridement/partial amputation of necrotic tissue and standard postoperative wound/VAC care. Hemodialysis performed with heparin per protocol. Wound cultures obtained; results pending at discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. Pain is controlled on oral regimen; he is hemodynamically stable and tolerating oral intake. Mobility is limited: baseline left above-knee amputation and current right-sided dressing limit independent ambulation — requires assistive devices/transfer assistance and skilled nursing for wound care and fall-risk precautions.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen and hydromorphone PRN, aspirin and clopidogrel, atorvastatin, calcium acetate, epoetin alfa per dialysis, and heparin for dialysis sessions. Continue IV antibiotic plan transitioned per infectious disease recommendations if oral therapy indicated; wound-culture-directed therapy will be provided. Follow-up: vascular surgery within 7 days, nephrology/dialysis as scheduled, home health nursing for wound care/dressing changes 3x weekly, and cardiology/primary care within 1–2 weeks. Pending culture results will be communicated to outpatient team.

History of Present Illness: 75-year-old man admitted for observation for complicated Type 2 diabetes mellitus with an infected right foot ulcer and progressive peripheral gangrene. He presented with increased drainage, exposed fat of the right forefoot, erythema, and pain. Past medical history notable for hypertension, atherosclerotic coronary disease, diabetic neuropathy, and chronic antithrombotic therapy.

Hospital Course: Patient was observed for 6.8 days. Initial evaluation included xrays and MRI consistent with osteomyelitis of the right ankle/foot and arterial insufficiency to the right lower extremity. Vascular and infectious disease were consulted. He underwent operative surgical debridement of the right foot with intraoperative wound cultures and received empiric IV antibiotics, then was transitioned to targeted oral antibiotic therapy based on cultures. Pain was managed with scheduled acetaminophen and PRN hydromorphone. Insulin therapy was used inpatient with sliding scale and basal coverage; oral hypoglycemic therapy was adjusted prior to discharge. Anticoagulation was continued per cardiology/vascular recommendations.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging consistent with acute osteomyelitis (right ankle/foot). Procedure: operative debridement of right foot wound with intraoperative cultures; wound care included postoperative dressing changes and negative-pressure therapy while inpatient. Positive wound cultures informed antibiotic selection.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge the patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, pain controlled on oral regimen, and able to transfer and ambulate short distances with a rolling walker. Requires assistance with wound dressing changes and activities of daily living due to right lower extremity pain and offloading requirements. Home health services arranged for wound care, medication management, and nursing surveillance.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge medications include apixaban and aspirin (per cardiology), insulin regimen for glycemic control with oral glipizide held/adjusted as outpatient, ciprofloxacin and doxycycline to complete an extended course for osteomyelitis (total planned ~6 weeks per ID), hydrochlorothiazide, stool softener (docusate) and bisacodyl PRN, acetaminophen for analgesia. Follow-up: primary care in 7 days, vascular surgery and wound clinic within 1 week, infectious disease and endocrinology as outpatient, and anticoagulation clinic as indicated. Clear instructions given for strict foot offloading, daily glucose monitoring, and urgent return precautions.

Brief history of present illness: 33-year-old female admitted emergently for symptomatic hyperglycemia with labile glucose levels and symptoms related to diabetic autonomic neuropathy and gastroparesis. She reported poor oral intake, progressive weakness, nausea, and documented nonadherence to outpatient insulin regimen.

Hospital course: Over a 9.8-day stay the patient was managed by the medicine and endocrinology teams. Initial management included frequent point-of-care glucose monitoring, subcutaneous insulin titration (basal-bolus regimen), intermittent IV dextrose and glucagon for symptomatic hypoglycemia events, and VTE prophylaxis with heparin. Gastroenterology-assisted management of gastroparesis included metoclopramide and a short course of erythromycin with dietary modification. Nutrition services implemented a high-protein, small-volume feeding plan and treated mild protein-calorie malnutrition. Pain management for chronic fibromyalgia/neuropathic pain included duloxetine and topical lidocaine as adjuncts. Physical and occupational therapy evaluated deconditioning and assisted with mobility and ADL training.

Key findings and procedures: Laboratory trends demonstrated hyperglycemia with variable excursions requiring insulin adjustments; BMP monitored and electrolytes repleted as needed. No invasive procedures were required. Education on insulin administration, hypoglycemia recognition and treatment, gastric symptom management, and medication reconciliation were completed with patient and caregiver.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health. She is ambulatory with supervision/assistive device for short distances and requires assistance with some ADLs due to generalized weakness and recent deconditioning. Home health RN to assist with insulin administration, glucose monitoring, medication adherence, and wound/skin checks as indicated. Home PT recommended to continue mobility and strengthening.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharged on basal-bolus insulin regimen (as adjusted in hospital), lisinopril for HTN, duloxetine for neuropathic pain, metoclopramide and short erythromycin course for gastroparesis, stool softener/bisacodyl PRN, acetaminophen PRN, multivitamins. Provided glucose gel and hypoglycemia rescue education. Follow up with PCP in 3–7 days, endocrinology in 1–2 weeks, and gastroenterology as outpatient. Labs (BMP, glucose trend, A1c) to be obtained within one week.

Brief history of present illness: 61-year-old male with history of hypertensive chronic kidney disease (CKD), hypothyroidism, myelodysplastic syndrome, asthma, spinal stenosis and peripheral polyneuropathy presented with 5 days of cough, fever and progressive dyspnea. SARS-CoV-2 PCR was positive on admission. He was observed for hypoxemia and supportive care.

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to observation for 2.9 days for hypoxemic COVID-19. He required low-flow supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula (maximum 4 L/min) and was treated with intravenous remdesivir (completed inpatient course), dexamethasone, nebulized albuterol, prophylactic subcutaneous heparin, and supportive IV fluids. A short course of levofloxacin was given for concern of possible superimposed bacterial infection. Cyanocobalamin and gabapentin were continued for chronic conditions. Chest radiograph demonstrated bilateral patchy airspace opacities consistent with viral pneumonitis. Renal function remained at baseline for his CKD; no transfusion was required for his myelodysplastic syndrome during this stay. Mobility was limited by baseline spinal stenosis and neuropathy; he ambulated short distances with a cane and required minimal assistance with transfers.

Key findings and procedures: Positive SARS-CoV-2 PCR; chest x-ray with bilateral opacities; oxygen therapy and administration of remdesivir and dexamethasone were the primary interventions. Vitals stabilized, afebrile for >24 hours, and oxygen requirement weaned to room air prior to discharge.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically improved, hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and on room air. Ambulates with baseline assistive device and requires only minimal assistance with ADLs; home health is arranged for medication reconciliation, safety/fall risk assessment, mobility support and pulse oximetry monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen PRN, albuterol inhaler/neb prn, levothyroxine daily, gabapentin for neuropathic pain, guaifenesin PRN, senna PRN, ramelteon PRN for sleep, and completion of outpatient levofloxacin as prescribed. Remdesivir and inpatient dexamethasone completed. Follow-up with primary care in 48–72 hours, pulmonology in 7–10 days, nephrology in 2 weeks, and hematology as outpatient in 4 weeks. If new or worsening dyspnea or oxygen saturation < 92%, seek ED evaluation or contact home health immediately.

Reason for admission: 36-year-old female admitted to observation for evaluation and management of pleural effusion (ICD-10 J90). Relevant history includes known pericardial effusion (noninflammatory), type 1 diabetes mellitus, prior CABG, atherosclerotic heart disease, history of nicotine dependence, and opioid dependence in remission. She also had documented contact with COVID-19; testing was performed during admission.

History of present illness: Patient presented with progressive dyspnea and right greater-than-left pleuritic chest discomfort. Chest radiograph and point-of-care ultrasound confirmed moderate right pleural effusion without sonographic evidence of complex loculations. Echocardiography demonstrated a small, stable pericardial effusion without tamponade physiology.

Hospital course: Over a 4-day observation stay the patient underwent ultrasound-guided thoracentesis (ICD-10-PCS 0W9B30Z) with removal of approximately 650 mL serous fluid. Fluid analysis was consistent with a transudative effusion. She received diuresis with furosemide with clinical improvement in dyspnea. Diabetes was managed with a basal-bolus insulin regimen and bedside glucose monitoring. Anticoagulation with apixaban was continued given history of CABG and chronic anticoagulant use. Pain was controlled with acetaminophen and short-interval opiates as needed; no procedural complications occurred. COVID-19 testing during admission was negative.

Key findings/procedures: Chest x-ray/ultrasound confirming pleural effusion; echo with stable small pericardial effusion; ultrasound-guided thoracentesis, uncomplicated. Labs stable; no evidence of infection.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with a steady gait, and able to perform most ADLs independently but will require assistance with medication administration/diabetes teaching initially at home. Oxygen not required on discharge.

Medications at discharge: Apixaban, Aspirin, Atorvastatin, Furosemide, Basal-bolus insulin regimen with glucose gel PRN, Docusate, Famotidine, Acetaminophen as needed. (Detailed med list provided separately.)

Follow-up: Pulmonology within 1 week, cardiology within 1–2 weeks, primary care in 3–5 days, and anticoagulation clinic per protocol. Return precautions for fever, worsening dyspnea, chest pain, or bleeding.

Brief history of present illness: 76-year-old female admitted to observation for 36 hours with fever, cough, malaise and subjective weakness. Initial working diagnosis was viral infection (ICD-10: B34.9). Relevant comorbidities on admission include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, solitary pulmonary nodule, chronic pelvic pain/dyspareunia, and mood disorder.

Hospital course: Patient received supportive care with IV fluids (Lactated Ringers), antipyretic therapy (acetaminophen), antiemetic (ondansetron) and electrolyte repletion (potassium chloride, magnesium sulfate) with clinical improvement. Enoxaparin was administered for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis. HydrOXYzine provided pruritus/anxiety control as needed. Polyethylene glycol was used for constipation. Oral vancomycin liquid was administered per consult for suspected C. difficile history (course completed as indicated). No invasive procedures were required. She remained hemodynamically stable, afebrile for >24 hours, and tolerated oral intake prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Physical exam notable for mild dehydration on admission, resolved after IV fluids. Baseline labs showed mild metabolic acidosis which corrected with fluids and supportive care. Chest imaging performed for cough/pulmonary nodule evaluation; no acute cardiopulmonary process requiring inpatient intervention. No procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition, alert and oriented, able to perform transfers with assistance. Ambulates short distances with a walker and requires caregiver support for some activities of daily living. Home health services arranged for nursing visits and physical therapy to assist with medication reconciliation, wound/skin checks, mobility training and fall-risk mitigation.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen as needed, Enoxaparin (prophylactic dosing per discharge instructions), Hydroxyzine as needed, Multivitamins, Ondansetron PRN, Polyethylene Glycol PRN, Potassium Chloride, Sodium Chloride 0.9% flushes (for IV access if applicable), Vancomycin oral liquid as prescribed, Amlodipine for blood pressure control.

Follow-up: PCP appointment in 48–72 hours for clinical reassessment and repeat labs (BMP, CBC). Pulmonology follow-up within 1–2 weeks for solitary pulmonary nodule evaluation. Gynecology and mental health follow-up as outpatient for pelvic pain and mood disorder management.

History of Present Illness: 61-year-old male presented to the ED with 48 hours of progressive right ear pain, decreased hearing, and purulent otorrhea. He reported prior chronic sinus complaints. Past medical history notable for essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and prediabetes. Social history significant for history of nicotine dependence. On presentation he was hemodynamically stable but in discomfort and had right external ear canal debris with purulent drainage. Ear exam suggested tympanic membrane perforation on the right.

Hospital Course: Patient was evaluated by emergency medicine and otolaryngology. Point-of-care otoscopic exam and culture of discharge were obtained. Bedside right ear canal irrigation and removal of debris with topical antibiotic instillation were performed (procedure documented). He received IV ampicillin-sulbactam and analgesia with acetaminophen; DVT prophylaxis with heparin was given while inpatient and discontinued at discharge. Blood pressure and glucose were monitored and remained controlled on home regimens.

Key Findings and Procedures: Right otitis media with associated unspecified perforation of the right tympanic membrane and purulent otorrhea. Chronic sinusitis noted on history. Procedure: right external ear canal irrigation and topical antibiotic application with specimen sent for culture.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged in stable condition, ambulatory at baseline with no new mobility limitations. He requires assistance from home health for IV antibiotic administration, wound/ear care (ear drop instillation and dressing changes), and medication reconciliation. He is independent with activities of daily living but would benefit from short-term nursing visits for education and follow-up.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharged with plan for home health-administered IV ampicillin-sulbactam to complete a 7-day course, ciprofloxacin 0.3% otic drops for right ear as directed, acetaminophen PRN, fluticasone nasal spray, loratadine, pantoprazole, metoprolol succinate XL and nifedipine XR for blood pressure, and instructions on continuing statin therapy per PCP. ENT follow-up within 3–5 days, primary care in 7 days for BP and metabolic review, and audiology if hearing does not improve. Return to ED for worsening pain, fever, increasing drainage, dizziness, or new neurologic symptoms.

History of present illness: 46-year-old female admitted to observation for four days for complications following prior bariatric surgery, presenting with progressive abdominal pain, distention, altered mental status, and one witnessed generalized seizure. Past medical history notable for alcoholic cirrhosis with ascites and prior bariatric procedure. Initial evaluation demonstrated ascites with peritoneal fluid consistent with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and imaging concerning for small-bowel fistula and partial obstruction related to prior bariatric surgery.

Hospital course: Patient was managed in observation status with IV antibiotics for SBP, electrolyte repletion for hypo-osmolality/hyponatremia, and seizure control with levetiracetam. She underwent image-guided peritoneal drainage (procedure 3E0336Z) and a surgical intervention/management procedure (3E0G76Z) for source control of intra-abdominal collections and fistula management. Nutrition support was initiated with parenteral nutrition (amino acids/dextrose formulation) while bowel rest was maintained. Pain was controlled with short-interval opioid analgesia as needed. Encephalopathy was treated with lactulose. Hyponatremia and magnesium were corrected; no recurrent seizures occurred prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: Ascitic fluid analysis positive for SBP; CT abdomen/pelvis consistent with small-bowel fistula and partial obstruction. Image-guided peritoneal drain placed and surgical management performed. Parenteral nutrition and IV/transition-to-oral antibiotics initiated. Seizure disorder addressed and stabilized on levetiracetam.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, pain controlled on oral/PRN regimens, and neurologically at baseline. Ambulates with minimal assistance and requires assistance with complex wound/drain care and parenteral nutrition administration at home. Cognition improved but continues to require monitoring for hepatic encephalopathy.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged with oral ciprofloxacin to complete antibiotic course, levetiracetam, lactulose, escitalopram, folic acid, heparin prophylaxis plan, stool regimen (bisacodyl PRN), and parenteral nutrition via home infusion. Home health nursing arranged for drain/wound care, TPN management, medication administration, and daily weights. Follow-up: surgical clinic within 7–10 days, hepatology/GI within 1–2 weeks, neurology in 2 weeks, and outpatient labs (CMP, CBC, electrolytes) within 48–72 hours and then weekly. Return precautions given for fever, worsening abdominal pain, increased drain output, or neurologic change.

History of Present Illness: 63-year-old male admitted for observation with known metastatic malignancy to bone (C79.51) and progressive focal pain and functional decline. He presented with weakness of the right upper extremity and was found to have imaging consistent with bone metastasis and multiple medical issues including recent ischemic cerebrovascular event. Length of stay: 15 days.

Hospital Course: During admission the patient underwent diagnostic imaging and an image-guided bone biopsy. He received multidisciplinary care including oncology, neurology, and rehabilitation. Medical management included pain control with acetaminophen and gabapentin, correction of electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia and hypokalemia) with appropriate replacement, DVT prophylaxis, and optimization of cardiac and blood pressure medications. Neurology monitored for stroke sequelae and consulted for nonruptured cerebral aneurysm. Physical and occupational therapy worked on transfers, safety, and right upper extremity compensatory strategies.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging confirmed secondary malignant bone disease and prior cerebral infarct. Procedures performed: image-guided bone biopsy and placement of percutaneous central venous access for infusion and blood draws. Relevant labs showed resolving hyponatremia and hypokalemia after replacement. NIHSS score 2; persistent monoplegia of the dominant right upper extremity.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. He is ambulatory with a steady gait and independent with transfers but has persistent right upper extremity weakness limiting fine motor tasks and ADLs; requires assistance with dressing and grooming of the dominant arm. Home health will provide skilled nursing for medication management and wound/vessel access care, and PT/OT for continued strengthening, adaptive equipment training, and ADL support.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, aspirin, atenolol, atorvastatin, gabapentin, docusate, bisacodyl PRN, calcium carbonate, fish oil, and potassium supplementation as directed. Follow-up: oncology within 7 days, primary care and neurology within 1–2 weeks, and home health initiation immediately for skilled nursing and therapy. If new neurologic deficits or worsening pain occur, return to ED.

History of present illness: 60-year-old male with history of relapsed myeloid leukemia and prior allogeneic stem cell transplant (Z94.84) was admitted to observation for persistent fever, neutropenia (D70.9), and progressive dyspnea. He developed hypoxemia and new infiltrate on chest imaging consistent with pneumonia (J18.9) and concurrent bacteremia. Past medical history includes myelodysplastic features, essential hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and prior neurocognitive complaints.

Hospital course: The patient was managed over an 18-day observation stay with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics transitioned to targeted therapy after culture data, antipneumococcal coverage, and supportive care. He received myeloid-directed evaluation including hematology consultation and bone marrow studies confirming disease relapse. Blood cultures were positive during admission and subsequently cleared with therapy. He was treated for febrile neutropenia, had episodes of hypoxemia requiring short-term supplemental oxygen, and developed a neutrophilic skin eruption treated with topical steroid. He remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile for 48 hours prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Initial labs notable for profound neutropenia with ANC below critical threshold, positive blood cultures, and chest radiograph consistent with pneumonia. Procedures included placement of central venous access for antimicrobial administration, diagnostic bone marrow evaluation, and serial blood cultures.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable, afebrile, and ambulatory with minimal assistance due to deconditioning. He requires skilled home health nursing for central line care, IV antibiotic administration/infusion management, and monitoring of vital signs and daily labs (CBC) until neutrophil recovery.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on atovaquone suspension for PCP prophylaxis, oral ciprofloxacin to complete therapy, acetaminophen PRN, folic acid, cyanocobalamin, and topical clobetasol for skin lesions. Home health to provide line care and medication administration. Follow-up appointments: hematology/oncology within 3–5 days, infectious disease within 7 days, and primary care within 7–10 days. Return precautions given for fever, worsening dyspnea, new bleeding, or other acute concerns.

History of Present Illness: 35-year-old female with prior bariatric surgery presented to ED with 48 hours of worsening crampy abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and obstipation. CT abdomen/pelvis demonstrated small bowel obstruction with ascites consistent with adhesive obstruction. She was admitted under observation status for operative management.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent attempted diagnostic laparoscopy that was converted to open exploratory laparotomy with lysis of adhesions (ICD-10-PCS: 0DNA0ZZ, 0DNN0ZZ, 02HV33Z). Small bowel was examined and found viable; no bowel resection was required. Postoperatively she was managed with IV fluids (LR, D5 1/2NS, 0.9% NaCl as indicated), parenteral analgesia (hydromorphone initially, transitioned to oral acetaminophen), famotidine for gastric protection, and subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered during the stay. Her pain was controlled on oral regimen, bowel function returned on postoperative day 2 with flatus and tolerating a regular diet. Vital signs and labs remained stable. Surgical wounds were clean, dry and intact; any temporary drains were removed prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT-confirmed small bowel obstruction due to adhesive disease with associated ascites. Operative lysis of adhesions with conversion from laparoscopic to open approach; no bowel ischemia or resection required.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged hemodynamically stable, afebrile, ambulatory with assistance and able to perform basic ADLs with occasional support. Tolerating oral intake and bowel function resumed. Wound healing appropriate; needs home health for dressing changes and ambulation support.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge meds: acetaminophen 500–1000 mg PO every 6 hours PRN pain (do not exceed 3 g/24 hr), famotidine 20 mg PO twice daily, docusate 100 mg PO twice daily PRN for stool softening. Resume home antithrombotic/antiplatelet therapy as instructed by surgeon/PCP. Home health referral for wound care, medication reconciliation, ambulation assistance and monitoring of bowel function and incision. Surgical clinic follow-up in 7–10 days; PCP follow-up in 3–7 days. Return immediately for fever, increasing abdominal pain, redness/drainage from wound, vomiting or inability to tolerate oral intake.

History of Present Illness: 25-year-old female presented via emergency with fever, rigors, dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. Blood cultures grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Imaging demonstrated multiple bilateral septic pulmonary emboli. Transthoracic echocardiogram and subsequent transesophageal study were consistent with acute infective endocarditis with small mobile vegetations. She developed sepsis with associated coagulopathy and transient hyponatremia during admission. Social history notable for homelessness and active stimulant and opioid use disorder.

Hospital Course: Hospitalized 7 days for sepsis due to MRSA bacteremia with infective endocarditis and septic pulmonary emboli. She was stabilized with IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics transitioned to IV vancomycin after sensitivities returned, and supportive care for hyponatremia. Coagulation parameters and platelet count were monitored and optimized. Withdrawal symptoms were managed with methadone oral solution and clonidine; lorazepam used as needed. A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) was placed for long-term IV antibiotic administration. She received counseling and social work involvement for discharge planning and housing resources.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive blood cultures for MRSA; echo consistent with acute/subacute infective endocarditis; CT chest showing septic emboli. Procedures: PICC placement for IV antibiotics and central access care. Laboratory abnormalities included transient hypo-osmolality/hyponatremia and a coagulation defect which improved with treatment.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile for >48 hours, ambulatory with deconditioning — ambulates with supervision and tolerates activities of daily living with intermittent assistance. Requires skilled nursing for IV antibiotic administration, PICC care, wound/skin checks, and medication management. Home health will assist with mobility training and fall-risk mitigation.

Medications and Follow-up: Continue IV vancomycin via home health per infectious disease-directed regimen; PICC maintenance with 0.9% sodium chloride flushes. Methadone oral solution and clonidine for opioid withdrawal; lorazepam PRN; acetaminophen and short-course morphine IR PRN for pain; stool regimen with docusate and senna; ferrous sulfate for anemia. Labs: baseline and twice-weekly vancomycin levels, CBC and BMP during IV therapy. Follow-up: Infectious Diseases and Cardiology within 1 week, primary care/social work and home health nursing for daily IV therapy and case management.

History of Present Illness: 83-year-old female presented to ED with left lower quadrant abdominal pain, low-grade fever and change in bowel habits. CT abdomen performed in ED demonstrated diverticulitis of the sigmoid colon without perforation or abscess. She was admitted to observation for pain control, hydration and monitoring given comorbid cardiopulmonary and renal disease.

Hospital Course: During a 48-hour observation stay the patient was managed conservatively with IV fluids, bowel rest initially, transition to a soft, low-residue diet as tolerated, scheduled acetaminophen for analgesia and a bowel regimen with polyethylene glycol. She received short-term inpatient DVT prophylaxis per protocol. Pain and oral intake improved; no peritoneal signs or hemodynamic instability developed. Cardiac evaluation (ECG and troponin monitoring) showed no acute ischemia. Oxygenation remained stable on baseline; no escalation of respiratory support was required. Creatinine and electrolytes remained at baseline for her chronic kidney disease.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT abdomen confirming uncomplicated diverticulitis. No drainable collection, no surgical intervention required. Routine labs and cardiac markers without acute ischemic pattern. No procedures performed beyond imaging and standard observation care.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged clinically stable, afebrile, tolerating oral intake and ambulating with baseline assistive device. Baseline mild cognitive impairment and somnolence noted; requires assistance with medication management and occasional ADL support. Home environment appropriate for assistance; home health arranged for nursing and therapy evaluation.

Medications and Follow-up: Continue home medications (acetaminophen PRN, anastrozole, aspirin, atorvastatin, citalopram, furosemide, levothyroxine, mirtazapine, multivitamin, oxybutynin, polyethylene glycol, pramipexole, ramelteon). Discontinue inpatient heparin. Home health to provide nursing visits for medication reconciliation, vital signs, weight checks, and education; PT/OT evaluation for safety as needed. Follow-up with primary care within 3–5 days, GI or general surgery clinic in 7–14 days, cardiology for heart-failure/HTN management within 1–2 weeks and nephrology as outpatient for CKD monitoring. Return to ED for worsening abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, shortness of breath or new neurologic changes.

History of present illness: 67-year-old female admitted emergently with sustained ventricular tachycardia (I47.2) on presentation with palpitations, lightheadedness and progressive dyspnea. Past cardiac history notable for dilated cardiomyopathy, prior myocardial infarction, atherosclerotic coronary disease, and prosthetic heart valve; chronic anticoagulation established prior to admission. She also has COPD with acute exacerbation on presentation.

Hospital course: Patient was monitored on telemetry. Initial management included rate control, antiarrhythmic therapy, and guided diuresis for acute on chronic systolic heart failure. She underwent successful acute cardioversion for unstable VT and was evaluated by electrophysiology. Device therapy planning was initiated. COPD exacerbation was treated with nebulized bronchodilators, azithromycin and short course of systemic steroids with improvement in wheeze and oxygenation. Diuresis with IV then oral furosemide improved volume status. Anticoagulation was continued; no bleeding complications occurred. The patient remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: ECG-confirmed ventricular tachycardia responsive to synchronized cardioversion. Elevated BNP consistent with heart failure exacerbation; chest exam and imaging consistent with COPD exacerbation. Procedures included synchronized electrical cardioversion and electrophysiology consultation with device planning and temporary pacing support as indicated.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition, ambulatory with assistance for increased fall risk and deconditioning. Home health services requested for medication management, wound/device site checks as applicable, assistance with ADLs and reinforcement of activity precautions. Requires inhaler and nebulizer technique reinforcement and evaluation for supplemental oxygen if home oxygen saturation monitoring indicates need.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on home regimen including furosemide, atorvastatin, aspirin, continued chronic anticoagulation, inhaled fluticasone-salmeterol, inhaled ipratropium and levalbuterol/nebulizers as needed, azithromycin short course, famotidine and PRN acetaminophen. Follow-up: cardiology within 7 days, electrophysiology within 2 weeks for device planning, primary care in 1 week, pulmonology as outpatient. Return to ED for recurrent syncope, chest pain, progressive dyspnea, or bleeding.

History of Present Illness: 29-year-old G?P? female at 23 weeks gestation presented on observation status for severe, intractable migraine with nausea/vomiting, superimposed on systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and chronic hypertension complicating pregnancy. Symptoms progressed over several days with inadequate outpatient control despite usual therapy. No focal neurologic deficits, no seizure activity.

Hospital Course: She was observed for 4 days. Initial evaluation included maternal vital sign monitoring, focused neurologic exams, and fetal heart rate checks; fetal assessment remained reassuring. IV fluids (LR) and antiemetics (prochlorperazine) were administered. A short course of IV methylprednisolone was given for headache/inflammatory flare with transition to oral steroid as indicated. Analgesic regimen included acetaminophen-caffeine-butalbital and a planned outpatient taper. Cyproheptadine was used as adjunct migraine prophylaxis. Hydroxychloroquine was continued for SLE. Bronchodilator therapy (albuterol) and inhaled fluticasone were continued for asthma. Blood pressures remained controlled on her baseline regimen; no evidence of preeclampsia or other obstetric complications during stay.

Key Findings and Procedures: Neurologic exam non-focal; no neuroimaging performed due to clinical stability and pregnancy. Routine labs and inflammatory markers without acute abnormality. Continuous maternal-fetal monitoring showed reactive fetal heart tracings. Medication reconciliation completed.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable and afebrile at discharge. Ambulates with minimal limitation from headache; independent with ADLs but requires assistance/resources for medication administration and symptom monitoring at home. Pain improved but not fully resolved; outpatient management plan in place.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge meds: acetaminophen-caffeine-butalbital (per schedule/taper), cyproheptadine, hydroxychloroquine, low-dose aspirin, albuterol inhaler PRN, fluticasone inhaler daily, pantoprazole, prenatal vitamins, prochlorperazine PRN, oxazepam PRN, topical sarna PRN, ranitidine as prescribed. Home health nursing to visit within 48 hours for medication reconciliation, BP and headache assessment, inhaler education, and fetal movement guidance. Follow-up with OB within 3–5 days, neurology in 1 week, and rheumatology as scheduled. Return immediately for severe worsening headache, visual changes, sustained BP elevation, decreased fetal movement, or respiratory distress.

History of present illness: 75-year-old man admitted under observation for symptoms related to a symptomatic cecal mass (diagnosed malignant neoplasm of cecum, ICD-10 C18.0). He presented with abdominal pain, decreased bowel function and partial bowel obstruction/ileus. Pertinent comorbidities include chronic diastolic congestive heart failure, hypertensive heart disease with heart failure, chronic atrial fibrillation on long-term anticoagulation, benign prostatic hyperplasia with urinary retention, and prior episodes of diarrhea.

Hospital course: The patient underwent operative management of the cecal lesion (ICD-10-PCS 0DTF0ZZ). Postoperatively he had a transient ileus that resolved with bowel rest, IV fluids, and gradual diet advancement. He developed a brief postprocedural fever that responded to empiric antibiotics and supportive care. Rate control for chronic atrial fibrillation was achieved with diltiazem and metoprolol; heart failure managed with diuresis (furosemide) with stabilization of volume status. Anticoagulation was managed perioperatively with enoxaparin. Urinary retention was managed with intermittent catheterization and medical therapy (doxazosin, finasteride); voiding improved prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Pathology consistent with malignant neoplasm of the cecum; operative resection performed as above. Imaging and labs trended to baseline; no ongoing sepsis, hemodynamically stable at discharge.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable and afebrile, tolerating oral intake, with return of bowel function. Ambulates with assistance and requires help with medication management and wound care. Home health recommended for nursing wound checks, medication administration/education, vital sign monitoring, fall-risk and toileting assistance given age, diuretic use and anticoagulation.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on acetaminophen, diltiazem (and extended-release as indicated), metoprolol succinate, furosemide, enoxaparin (as bridge), doxazosin, finasteride, potassium chloride, famotidine, ondansetron PRN, oxycodone or hydromorphone PRN for pain, simethicone. Follow-up appointments: surgical clinic in 7–14 days, oncology for staging/therapy planning, cardiology within 1 week for anticoagulation/heart failure management, and primary care in 1 week. Home health to begin immediately for nursing follow-up, medication reconciliation, wound care, and ADL support.

History of present illness: 56-year-old female presented via emergency department after an accidental overdose of beta‑adrenoreceptor antagonist. On arrival she was hypotensive and bradycardic with complaints of lightheadedness and near-syncope. Family reported medication error at home (private residence). Past medical history notable for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, obesity and nicotine dependence.

Hospital course: Length of stay 1.2 days (emergency admission). Patient received supportive care with continuous cardiac monitoring, intravenous fluids (0.9% sodium chloride and lactated Ringers), electrolyte repletion (potassium chloride, magnesium sulfate), and calcium gluconate administration. Serial ECGs demonstrated atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response. Labs revealed mild metabolic acidosis which improved with supportive therapy. Anticoagulation was transitioned from inpatient heparin to apixaban prior to discharge. No intubation or invasive cardiac procedures were required. Patient remained hemodynamically stable and alert with improving heart rate and blood pressure prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Initial ECG: atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response; vitals improved with fluids and monitoring. Labs: transient acidosis and electrolyte abnormalities corrected. Procedures: continuous telemetry monitoring, IV access for medication and fluids. No central lines, cardioversion, or dialysis performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable medical condition, ambulatory with baseline assistance, cognitively intact for home care. Home health nursing recommended for medication reconciliation, daily vital sign and orthostatic checks, and assistance with activities of daily living during early recovery.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on apixaban for atrial fibrillation anticoagulation, flecainide for rhythm management (per cardiology), acetaminophen PRN for pain, and bowel regimen (senna, bisacodyl) as needed. Home health to confirm medication administration and monitor for recurrent bradycardia, hypotension, dizziness or bleeding. Follow-up with cardiology within 7 days and primary care within 3–5 days. Return to ED for recurrent syncope, chest pain, severe dyspnea, or worsening hemodynamics.

Brief HPI: 84-year-old female admitted urgently with chest pain and dyspnea and found to have a non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Significant past history includes chronic systolic heart failure, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral arterial disease. On presentation she was hypotensive and developed features consistent with cardiogenic shock.

Hospital course: Over a 12-day admission she was stabilized in the ICU. Initial evaluation demonstrated elevated cardiac biomarkers and reduced LVEF on transthoracic echocardiography consistent with acute on chronic systolic dysfunction. She underwent coronary angiography with percutaneous coronary intervention. She required brief vasopressor/inotropic support for cardiogenic shock and received transfusion for acute posthemorrhagic anemia. Intermittent atrial arrhythmia was managed with rate control and amiodarone as indicated. She received aggressive diuresis for congestive failure, chest physiotherapy for atelectasis, and prophylaxis/treatment as indicated for exposure to COVID-19. Nutritional and electrolyte abnormalities were corrected; vitamin K (phytonadione) was administered prior to procedures.

Key findings and procedures: NSTEMI with multivessel coronary disease treated by left heart catheterization and percutaneous intervention; acute on chronic systolic heart failure (reduced EF); cardiogenic shock requiring short-term hemodynamic support; packed red blood cell transfusion for acute anemia; central venous access for vasoactive infusions; pulmonary toilet for atelectasis.

Discharge condition and functional status: The patient is clinically improved and hemodynamically stable off vasopressors, with adequate oxygenation on room air. She remains deconditioned and requires assistance with transfers and ADLs; ambulates short distances with a walker and supervision. Home health nursing is arranged for medication reconciliation, daily weights, edema and wound checks, IV line care if still present, and reinforcement of heart-failure self-management.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include aspirin EC, atorvastatin, carvedilol (beta-blocker), furosemide, amiodarone (short course as directed), omeprazole, docusate, bowel regimen, lidocaine 5% patch PRN, magnesium supplementation PRN, and acetaminophen PRN. Cardiology follow-up within 7 days; primary care within 7–10 days; home health nursing to begin immediately.

28-year-old female admitted electively for symptomatic cholelithiasis (ICD-10 K80.70) without cholecystitis or obstruction. Relevant history includes morbid obesity (BMI 40–44.9, E66.01), prior nicotine dependence, and GERD without esophagitis. She presented for planned laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Hospital course: The patient underwent attempted laparoscopic cholecystectomy which was converted to an open cholecystectomy due to limited visualization and technical difficulty related to body habitus (procedure codes 0FT40ZZ, 0FJ44ZZ, BF101ZZ). Intraoperative findings included multiple gallstones with no gross acute cholecystitis. Estimated blood loss was minimal; no intraoperative complications. Postoperatively she was monitored on the surgical ward for 36–48 hours. Pain was managed with IV acetaminophen, scheduled oral acetaminophen, short courses of IV hydromorphone and oral oxycodone PRN, and ibuprofen as tolerated. She received DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin and famotidine for reflux prophylaxis. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Successful removal of the gallbladder containing gallstones; conversion to open procedure documented. Pathology pending. No bile duct injury, no evidence of retained stones on intraoperative assessment.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating oral intake, ambulating with minimal assistance, and performing basic activities of daily living with encouragement for graded activity. She will require home health for incision/wound care and assistance with mobility and activity progression for approximately 1–2 weeks. Weight-bearing and lifting restrictions given (no heavy lifting >10 lbs until follow-up).

Medications at discharge: acetaminophen scheduled, ibuprofen suspension PRN, oxycodone IR PRN for breakthrough pain, famotidine BID for GERD. Heparin discontinued. Encourage smoking cessation.

Follow-up: Surgical clinic in 7–10 days for wound check and suture/staple removal, primary care for BMI/weight management and GERD, and GI as needed. Patient instructed on wound care, signs of infection, VTE warning signs, and when to seek urgent care.

History of Present Illness: 20-year-old female presented to the emergency department with a painful, erythematous postprocedural wound of the left lateral thigh with purulent drainage and systemic symptoms (fever, nausea). Past psychiatric history notable for borderline personality disorder. She reported recent outpatient minor skin procedure at an unspecified facility. Initial evaluation suggested wound infection with possible abscess and concurrent diarrheal illness.

Hospital Course: Patient was admitted emergently for incision and drainage/debridement of the wound (ICD-10 procedure 0C9D0ZZ) with wound culture obtained. Empiric IV ampicillin-sulbactam was initiated. Cultures grew Streptococcus group A (B95.0) and antibiotics were narrowed. The patient developed gastrointestinal intolerance to an initial antibiotic prompting change to oral amoxicillin-clavulanate prior to discharge, which she tolerated. She received fluid resuscitation (Lactated Ringers, 0.9% NaCl) and symptomatic treatment for toxic gastroenteritis/colitis (K52.1). Hemoglobin trended low (anemia, D64.9) but stable without transfusion. No evidence of deep tissue involvement on exam or imaging; afebrile for >48 hours prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Wound incision and drainage/debridement performed at bedside/OR with purulent fluid; wound cultures positive for group A Streptococcus. No retained foreign body. Patient received venous thromboembolism prophylaxis during stay.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient medically stable and afebrile. Pain controlled on oral regimen; ambulatory with normal gait and independent with transfers. Home health recommended for daily wound dressing changes, medication administration/monitoring, and assistance with wound hygiene and activity as needed.

Medications at Discharge: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875/125 mg PO twice daily for 10 days; acetaminophen 500–1000 mg PRN; ibuprofen 200–400 mg PRN; oxycodone IR short course PRN for severe pain; docusate 100 mg daily; continue fluoxetine 20 mg daily and oxcarbazepine as outpatient. Chlorhexidine 0.12% oral rinse PRN. Follow-up: Surgical clinic in 7 days, PCP in 3–5 days, and Infectious Disease if concerns for nonresponse. Return sooner for increasing pain, fever, spreading erythema, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

History of present illness: 66-year-old female with history of mantle cell lymphoma status post recent stem cell transplant complicated by graft-versus-host disease, chronic kidney disease, atrial fibrillation, and diastolic heart failure was admitted to observation for sepsis from a central venous catheter. She developed Enterococcus bloodstream infection (T80.211A) with hypotension and acute on chronic heart failure exacerbation. The catheter was determined to be the source.

Hospital course: Over a 22-day admission the patient underwent removal of the implicated central venous catheter with placement of a new peripherally inserted central catheter for ongoing therapy. Blood cultures grew Enterococcus initially; subsequent cultures cleared after targeted IV antibiotic therapy with daptomycin and supportive care. She required diuresis with intravenous then oral furosemide for volume management and rate control/anticoagulation for persistent atrial fibrillation. Her thrombotic microangiopathy and hematologic issues were managed in coordination with hematology/oncology. Renal function remained chronically impaired but stable without need for dialysis. She remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable at discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Positive blood cultures for Enterococcus; removal of infected central venous catheter; PICC placement for long-term IV antibiotics; imaging and laboratory monitoring consistent with resolving sepsis. Consults: Infectious Disease, Cardiology, Hematology/Oncology, Nephrology.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged clinically improved and hemodynamically stable, afebrile for >48 hours. Functional status: ambulatory with assistance at baseline; requires home health support for medication administration and activities of daily living due to deconditioning and ongoing IV therapy needs.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharged on home IV daptomycin via home infusion for a planned course per ID; apixaban for atrial fibrillation; furosemide, famotidine, acyclovir, allopurinol, folic acid and supportive topical agents as indicated. Home health to provide daily IV antibiotic administration, PICC dressing care/heparin flushes, wound/line assessment, medication reconciliation, vital sign and weight monitoring, and ADL assistance. Follow-up with Infectious Disease in 3–7 days, Cardiology in 1 week, Hematology/Oncology in 1–2 weeks, and primary care with labs (CBC, BMP) twice weekly initially then as directed.

51-year-old female admitted under observation for sepsis (A41.89) secondary to community-acquired pneumonia with acute hypoxic respiratory failure. Past medical history notable for end-stage renal disease on chronic hemodialysis, prior kidney transplant with concern for rejection, COPD, coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and history of ovarian malignancy with metastatic disease. She presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, and progressive hypoxia requiring supplemental oxygen and short period of ventilatory support. Blood/respiratory cultures were obtained; broad-spectrum IV antibiotics were initiated and narrowed based on clinical response.

Hospital course: Patient completed supportive care and a course of antibiotics with clinical improvement. Respiratory status improved from acute hypoxic failure to low-flow oxygen requirement and then to room air at rest. Hemodynamics remained stable without vasopressor support. She continued scheduled hemodialysis without complication. Pain and nausea were controlled. Anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation was held while inpatient for procedural considerations and restarted per cardiology recommendations prior to discharge. No acute surgical interventions were required.

Key findings and procedures: Positive imaging consistent with multilobar pneumonia; transient acute respiratory failure (J96.01) managed conservatively. ICD-10-PCS 5A1D70Z performed for short-term mechanical ventilatory support. Labs showed leukocytosis on admission that trended down; renal function at baseline for ESRD on dialysis. No new acute cardiac ischemia.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and clinically improved to baseline respiratory status with ambulation tolerated with assistance for short distances. Mild deconditioning persists; requires assistance with activities of daily living and medication management. Home health nursing and home physical therapy are arranged for medication reconciliation, wound/vital sign monitoring, dialysis coordination, and mobility training.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on oral antibiotic regimen (azithromycin and cefpodoxime as directed), inhaled bronchodilator (albuterol PRN), home heart and renal medications (metoprolol, furosemide adjustments made per nephrology), acid suppression as needed, analgesics (acetaminophen). Labs (CBC, BMP) within 48–72 hours. Follow-up: PCP in 3–5 days, nephrology/dialysis clinic per schedule, infectious disease within 7–10 days, oncology/transplant clinic as outpatient. Return precautions and education provided.

31-year-old G?P? female admitted urgently at 39 weeks’ gestation for breech presentation. Presenting complaint was decreased tolerance of attempt at external cephalic version and concern for malpresentation; decision made for operative delivery. Past medical history noncontributory for pregnancy complications. No drug allergies documented.

Hospital course: Patient underwent operative delivery for persistent breech presentation (procedure codes 10D00Z1 and 10907ZC documented). Intraoperative and immediate postoperative course were uncomplicated. Estimated blood loss within expected range for the procedure; no transfusion required. Pain was managed postoperatively with multimodal analgesia including acetaminophen, ibuprofen and a short course of oxycodone PRN. Antiemetics (ondansetron, metoclopramide) were used as needed. Bowel regimen initiated (docusate, bisacodyl, milk of magnesia as indicated) with simethicone for gas. Influenza vaccine (quadrivalent) administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Term singleton liveborn infant delivered at 39 weeks; maternal vital signs remained stable. Surgical incision clean, dry and intact; lower abdominal wound without erythema or drainage at discharge. Voiding and bowel function established prior to discharge. Patient ambulated with steady gait and required minimal assistance initially; progressed to independent ambulation with activity as tolerated.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable and medically optimized for discharge. Ambulates independently in home setting with occasional assistance for stair negotiation; able to perform activities of daily living with minimal assistance. Requires home health for wound checks, medication administration/education, pain assessment, and breastfeeding/lactation support.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen, ibuprofen, oxycodone (short course PRN for severe pain), docusate sodium, bisacodyl PRN, milk of magnesia PRN, simethicone, ondansetron and metoclopramide PRN; naloxone provided per institutional opioid-safety protocol. 

Follow-up: OB postpartum visit in 1–2 weeks; wound check by home health nurse within 48–72 hours; newborn pediatrician follow-up within 48–72 hours; return earlier for fever >100.4°F, heavy vaginal bleeding, worsening wound symptoms, uncontrolled pain or respiratory symptoms.

50-year-old female, admitted under observation for 20.7 days for management of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation–associated thrombotic microangiopathy (HSCT-TMA) in the setting of recent allogeneic stem cell transplant with chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and treatment-related pancytopenia. She presented with progressive anemia, thrombocytopenia, rising LDH, schistocytes on peripheral smear, and renal dysfunction consistent with TMA. Active problems on admission included cytopenias, CMV viremia, immunodeficiency post-transplant, electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia, phosphorus abnormality), and secondary infections managed during hospitalization.

Hospital course: The patient was managed by the transplant/hematology team with a multidisciplinary approach over a three-week hospitalization. Care included transfusion support (RBCs/platelets as indicated), antimicrobial and antiparasitic therapy (including targeted therapy for CMV and prophylaxis), optimization of immunosuppression for GVHD, aggressive electrolyte repletion, and close renal and hemodynamic monitoring. Central venous access was maintained for infusions and blood draws with routine heparin flushes. Blood counts and metabolic panels were trended; infectious disease and nephrology were involved. The patient required brief ICU-level monitoring for hemodynamic instability early in stay but improved with supportive care.

Key findings/procedures: microangiopathic hemolysis on peripheral smear, elevated LDH, intermittent renal impairment; central venous access placed/maintained; serial transfusions and IV electrolyte repletion.

Discharge condition and functional status: The patient is medically stable and afebrile at discharge, ambulatory with assistance due to deconditioning, and requires help with medication administration and central line care. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing visits for IV/heparin flushes, wound/line care, medication reconciliation, and assistance with ADLs.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include Atovaquone suspension, budesonide, cetirizine, cyanocobalamin, dexamethasone oral solution, escitalopram, folic acid, heparin flush syringes for line maintenance, lisinopril, magnesium supplementation, montelukast, and multivitamins. Outpatient follow-up with transplant hematology within 3–7 days, primary care in 1–2 weeks, and home health nursing for twice-weekly CBC/CMP and CMV PCR monitoring. Return precautions given for fever, bleeding, dyspnea, or new neurologic symptoms.

Brief history of present illness: 54-year-old female with known Crohn’s disease (small and large bowel) presented on observation status with worsening abdominal pain, increased stool frequency and low-grade fevers. She has a history of obesity status-post bariatric surgery, essential hypertension, hypothyroidism, obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP, asthma, nicotine dependence, alcohol use with anxiety disorder, vitamin D deficiency and depression. Hospital course: Observation stay 4.8 days. Initial evaluation included CBC, CMP, CRP, TSH and vitamin D level. She received IV fluids (LR and 5% dextrose) for dehydration and IV then oral antibiotics (ciprofloxacin and metronidazole) for suspected infectious colitis vs Crohn’s flare with clinical improvement. Mesalamine was continued. She received venous thromboembolism prophylaxis with heparin and symptomatic treatment (acetaminophen, PRN lorazepam). Home medications including levothyroxine, lisinopril and fluoxetine were continued. No surgical interventions were required. Key findings and procedures: Vital signs normalized; abdominal exam improved with decreased tenderness and reduced stool frequency. Labs showed no leukocytosis at discharge; vitamin D deficiency identified and supplementation started. Procedures included peripheral IV infusions for fluids and antibiotics (administration codes documented). Imaging and endoscopic evaluation were deferred to outpatient GI. Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and afebrile at discharge, ambulating with steady gait at baseline and able to perform most ADLs independently. Home health services are arranged for nursing visits for medication administration support (transition from IV to oral antibiotics as needed), wound-free IV access care if outpatient infusion required, monitoring of vitals and stool output, assistance with medication reconciliation, and reinforcement of CPAP adherence. Medications and follow-up: Discharged on oral ciprofloxacin (to complete prescribed course), metronidazole, mesalamine, levothyroxine, lisinopril, fluoxetine, folic acid and vitamin D supplementation; acetaminophen and lorazepam PRN. Follow-up with GI in 1 week for colon/therapy planning, PCP in 1 week, sleep medicine and endocrinology as outpatient. Labs (CBC, CMP, CRP, TSH, vitamin D) to be checked prior to GI visit. If symptoms worsen (fever, severe pain, bleeding), return to ED.

Brief history of present illness: 51-year-old man with long-standing type 1 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic neuropathy and retinopathy, hypertensive CKD and ESRD on maintenance hemodialysis, was admitted for deceased-donor renal transplant and perioperative management. Admission type: observation; length of stay 7.2 days.

Hospital course: The patient underwent renal transplant (ICD-10-PCS 0TY10Z0) with perioperative vascular access/line placement (0FYG0Z0). Induction immunosuppression included rabbit anti-thymocyte globulin (inpatient) and initiation of mycophenolate mofetil. Perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis and short-course levofloxacin and cefazolin were administered. Postoperative analgesia and antiemetic therapy provided; glycemic management adjusted with insulin. He remained hemodynamically stable without evidence of immediate graft rejection or surgical complication. Urine output increased postoperatively and serum creatinine trended down; dialysis was not required prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Operative note documented uncomplicated allograft implantation. Serial labs demonstrated improving renal function and stable electrolytes. No fever, wound infection, or thromboembolic event identified. Immunologic and infectious prophylaxis plans were completed per transplant protocol.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable. Ambulates independently with occasional use of a cane for endurance; able to perform light ADLs but requires assistance with medication administration, wound care, and frequent glucose monitoring. Home health nursing recommended for skilled post-transplant care, wound checks, and lab draws.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include mycophenolate mofetil, continuation of home insulin regimen with instructions for glucose monitoring and insulin adjustment, aspirin, carvedilol, short course of oral levofloxacin (per protocol), acetaminophen PRN, and other usual chronic meds (lipid therapy continued). Home health to administer/verify medications, monitor vitals and wound, and coordinate labs. Follow-up with transplant clinic and nephrology within 48–72 hours, primary care within 1–2 weeks, and daily labs initially with frequency to be guided by transplant team. Return precautions reviewed (fever, graft pain, decreased urine output, wound changes).

History of Present Illness: 75-year-old female presented to the emergency department with 2 days of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, associated nausea and several loose stools. She reported generalized weakness but denied fever, vomiting, or jaundice. Emergency evaluation revealed abnormal serum enzyme elevations prompting further workup.

Hospital Course: Admitted for observation and diagnostic evaluation (length of stay 2.4 days). Initial labs demonstrated elevated hepatic enzymes (R74.8) and mild anemia consistent with iron deficiency (D50.9). CBC, CMP, and coagulation studies were obtained. RUQ ultrasound showed no acute cholecystitis or biliary obstruction. Patient received IV fluids, antiemetic therapy (ondansetron), analgesia (acetaminophen, oxycodone immediate release PRN), bowel regimen and antidiarrheal treatment (loperamide, senna, bisacodyl as indicated). Subcutaneous heparin was administered for DVT prophylaxis. Psychiatry medication (bupropion SR) and antihypertensive (losartan) were continued. Influenza vaccine (quadrivalent) was administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Elevated serum liver enzymes without sonographic evidence of obstructive pathology; RUQ tenderness on exam but no peritoneal signs. No invasive procedures performed. DVT prophylaxis provided. Immunization given.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable at discharge, tolerating oral intake, and pain controlled with oral medications. Ambulates with steadying assistance at baseline and requires help with medication management and grocery/meal preparation due to limited endurance and partial dental loss affecting chewing. Home health nursing recommended for medication reconciliation, wound-free skilled nursing assessments (labs: repeat LFTs and CBC), and assistance with ADLs as needed.

Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen PRN, OxyCODONE IR PRN short course for severe pain, Ondansetron PRN, Loperamide PRN, Senna and Bisacodyl as bowel regimen PRN, Lorazepam PRN, Losartan daily, Pravastatin daily, Wellbutrin SR daily, subcutaneous heparin discontinued at discharge. Saline flush supplies as applicable.

Follow-up Plan: Primary care follow-up within 3–7 days; GI clinic appointment and repeat LFTs/CBC in 1 week. Continue home health nursing for 1–2 weeks or until stable. Return to ED for worsening pain, fever, jaundice, or new bleeding.

History of Present Illness: 63-year-old male admitted under observation for 9.7 days for workup and management of newly diagnosed malignant neoplasm of the head of the pancreas (C25.0) with metastatic disease to the small intestine and other digestive organs. He presented with progressive abdominal pain, weight loss, poor oral intake and severe protein-calorie malnutrition (E43). Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and prior right total hip arthroplasty.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent placement of a central vascular access device for chemotherapy and supportive infusions. He received inpatient initiation of systemic therapy (fluorouracil, irinotecan, leucovorin) with antiemetic and supportive care, intravenous fluids (0.9% NaCl, D5), and heparin flushes for port maintenance. Pain was managed initially with parenteral opioids and later transitioned to scheduled oral morphine SR with immediate-release opioid for breakthrough pain; adjunctive acetaminophen used as needed. Nutrition consult addressed severe malnutrition and oral supplementation was recommended; enteral/parenteral nutrition was deferred pending outpatient oncologic plan. He had transient delirium managed with low-dose haloperidol and supportive measures. No acute cardiopulmonary events; COVID-19 exposure documented without active infection.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging and clinical evaluation consistent with pancreatic head primary with metastatic disease. Procedures: central venous port/CVC placement for chemotherapy and infusion access, infusion therapies administered, and routine port maintenance (heparin flush). Pain control optimized; glycemic control addressed during stay.

Discharge condition and functional status: Stable for discharge. Ambulatory with assistance due to deconditioning; requires home health nursing for port care, medication administration/education, wound assessment, glucose monitoring, and assistance with activities of daily living. Nutrition remains poor and will require close outpatient follow-up and home health weight monitoring.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include morphine SR for baseline pain, immediate-release opioid for breakthrough, acetaminophen PRN, diabetes and lipid medications as listed. Heparin flush supplies arranged for port. Follow-up: oncology within 7 days for continuation of systemic therapy, primary care within 1 week, and home health nursing visit within 48 hours of discharge for port care, medication reconciliation, pain and nutrition assessment.

41-year-old male admitted under observation for acute exacerbation of alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis with associated nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and labile glycemia. History notable for chronic alcohol use, prior partial pancreatic loss, insulin-requiring diabetes with episodes of hypo- and hyperglycemia, moderate protein-calorie malnutrition (BMI ≤19.9) and anemia.

Hospital course: Patient received aggressive IV fluids (LR), antiemetics (ondansetron), PPI (pantoprazole), pancreatic enzyme replacement (Creon) and multimodal analgesia including acetaminophen, pregabalin and short-course opioid for breakthrough pain. Endocrine management included glucose monitoring, intermittent dextrose 50% and glucagon for hypoglycemia events and adjustment of inpatient insulin. Nutrition consult initiated and multivitamins started. Imaging and labs were consistent with chronic pancreatitis without necrosis or infection. There were no procedural interventions. Influenza vaccine given prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: CT abdomen consistent with chronic pancreatitis; labs notable for iron deficiency/microcytic anemia and hypoalbuminemia consistent with malnutrition; intermittent hypoinsulinemia/hypoglycemia managed medically. No endoscopic or surgical procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, with pain controlled on oral regimen and tolerating oral intake with pancreatic enzymes prescribed at meals. Ambulates with steady gait but reports decreased endurance and recent weight loss; requires assistance with meal planning and diabetes medication administration during recovery. Home health is recommended to provide skilled nursing for glucose monitoring/insulin administration, medication reconciliation, nutrition support and weight/vital sign monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include Creon with meals, insulin regimen with glucose meter supplies and glucagon emergency kit, multivitamin, duloxetine, pregabalin, acetaminophen, docusate, pantoprazole, ondansetron PRN, and a short outpatient opioid PRN. Follow-up arranged with GI within 1–2 weeks, primary care within 7 days, and endocrinology and nutrition within 1–2 weeks. Labs (CBC, CMP, amylase/lipase) to be repeated prior to GI visit. Counseling provided for alcohol cessation; home health referral placed.

History of present illness: 67-year-old female admitted to observation for acute onset right lower extremity weakness and numbness. Symptoms began on day of presentation with gait difficulty and paresthesia. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, obesity, and longstanding tobacco use.

Hospital course: Patient observed for approximately 24 hours. Neurologic exam demonstrated focal right lower limb weakness (monoplegia) and decreased sensation. Non-contrast head CT showed no hemorrhage. Clinical impression consistent with lacunar ischemic stroke due to small-vessel occlusion (I63.81). Blood glucose was reviewed and managed; no acute metabolic derangement. Cardiac monitoring during observation showed no arrhythmia. Vascular risk factors were optimized and secondary stroke prevention measures initiated.

Key findings and procedures: Focal right lower extremity weakness and sensory disturbance on exam. CT head without acute hemorrhage. Laboratory evaluation notable for chronic diabetes and hyperlipidemia. No invasive procedures performed. Patient received antiplatelet therapy and statin initiation in hospital.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged stable, neurologically unchanged from admission baseline with persistent right lower extremity weakness requiring standby assistance for ambulation and increased fall risk. Continues independent activities of daily living with difficulty negotiating stairs; home health recommended for skilled nursing and therapy services (PT/OT) to address mobility, gait training, and safety. Home health also to assist with medication administration and blood glucose monitoring.

Medications at discharge: Aspirin 81 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly, insulin as per outpatient regimen with glucose monitoring supplies, Artificial tears preservative-free PRN, Erythromycin 0.5% ophthalmic ointment PRN, and supplies including dextrose 50%, glucose gel, glucagon for hypoglycemia rescue as indicated. Heparin flush and normal saline flush for IV access as needed.

Follow-up: Primary care within 7 days, outpatient neurology within 1–2 weeks, vascular medicine/cardiology as indicated, and endocrinology for diabetes management. Home health to perform neuro checks, fall risk assessment, medication reconciliation, and therapy evaluation.

21-year-old male admitted to observation for recurrent symptomatic hypoglycemia (primary DX E16.2). Presenting complaints included episodic diaphoresis, lightheadedness, and near-syncope. Past medical history notable for autism spectrum disorder, seizure disorder on levetiracetam, chronic glucocorticoid exposure with drug-induced adrenocortical insufficiency, vitamin D deficiency, osteoporosis with prior vertebral fracture, nutritional anemia, eosinophilic gastritis, and psychiatric diagnoses (major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety). Length of stay 3.1 days.

Hospital course: Patient received prompt correction of hypoglycemia with IV dextrose and maintenance IV 0.9% sodium chloride while glucose was monitored. Electrolytes and glucose stabilized; calcium gluconate administered for transient hypocalcemia. He received heparin prophylaxis and topical clindamycin for a localized skin lesion. Hematology recommended cyanocobalamin and folic acid for nutritional anemia; vitamin D repletion initiated. Psychiatric medications were continued (fluoxetine, buspirone) with behavioral precautions. Neurology continued levetiracetam; no seizures occurred during admission. Endocrinology was consulted for suspected secondary adrenal insufficiency related to chronic steroids and recommended outpatient endocrine follow-up and steroid medication reconciliation.

Key findings/procedures: Blood glucose documented <50 mg/dL on presentation with prompt response to IV dextrose.
