Labs notable for anemia and vitamin D deficiency; transient eosinophilia and mild GI symptoms consistent with known eosinophilic gastritis. No imaging or invasive procedures were required.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically stable, hemodynamically stable, and alert/oriented. Ambulates with supervision due to back pain/functional limitation from prior vertebral fracture; requires assistance with medication management and monitoring of glucose at home. Home health nursing recommended for wound/skin care, glucose checks, medication administration support, and PT evaluation for mobility.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on outpatient regimen including levetiracetam, fluoxetine, buspirone, gabapentin for pain, cyanocobalamin, folic acid, vitamin D supplementation, acetaminophen PRN, and heparin prophylaxis discontinued on discharge. Follow-up appointments: PCP within 3–5 days, endocrinology within 1–2 weeks, neurology as scheduled, gastroenterology and hematology as outpatient. Education provided on hypoglycemia recognition, home glucose monitoring, and when to seek urgent care.

41-year-old female admitted under observation for exacerbation of Crohn’s disease with colocutaneous fistula and associated sepsis-like physiology. On presentation she had abdominal pain, diarrhea, hypotension and acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease. Length of stay was 9.2 days. Primary problems: Crohn’s disease of the large intestine with fistula (K50.113), acute tubular necrosis/AKI (N17.0), CKD stage 4 (N18.4), hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease with heart failure, and left fifth metatarsal fracture.

Hospital course: Initial resuscitation included IV fluids and hemodynamic support with close monitoring of electrolytes and acid-base status. She received broad-spectrum antibiotics with de-escalation to oral ciprofloxacin once cultures and clinical status allowed. Surgical and GI teams evaluated the fistula; endoscopic assessment was performed and conservative management pursued with local wound care. Nephrology was consulted for AKI on CKD and recommended adjustment of medications and outpatient follow-up. Cardiology optimized heart-failure regimen and blood pressure control. Orthopedics placed a controlled weight-bearing boot for the left fifth metatarsal fracture; no acute surgical fixation required.

Key findings/procedures: AKI with improvement but creatinine remains above baseline; evidence of metabolic acidosis resolved with treatment; imaging confirmed fistulous tract without indication for immediate operative repair; left fifth metatarsal nondisplaced fracture managed conservatively. Inpatient procedures included central access for resuscitation and diagnostic endoscopy.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient clinically improved, afebrile and hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake. Ambulation is limited by left foot fracture; requires assistance with transfers and ambulation and benefits from home health PT/OT for gait training and fall prevention. Home health nursing requested for medication reconciliation, wound/fistula dressing changes, and monitoring renal function and vitals.

Medications at discharge: metoprolol succinate, ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID x7 days, calcium acetate with meals, folic acid, gabapentin, magnesium oxide, acetaminophen PRN, diphenoxylate-atropine PRN for diarrhea, hydrocortisone enema as directed. DVT prophylaxis discontinued.

Follow-up: GI within 1 week, Nephrology within 3–7 days, Cardiology 2 weeks, Orthopedics 1 week, Primary care within 3–5 days. Home health services arranged for nursing and PT/OT.

History of Present Illness: 36-year-old man admitted under observation for acute upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. He presented with melena, lightheadedness and a hemoglobin drop. Past history notable for nicotine dependence (Z87.891). Admission diagnoses: chronic/unspecified duodenal ulcer with hemorrhage (K26.4), acute posthemorrhagic anemia (D62), and an adverse serum reaction following transfusion (T80.61XA).

Hospital Course: Over a 3-day observation stay the patient was resuscitated with IV crystalloid and received packed red blood cell transfusion for symptomatic anemia. He was started on high-dose IV pantoprazole and transitioned to oral pantoprazole once tolerating PO. During transfusion he developed an acute serum reaction that was identified, treated supportively, and did not require escalation beyond observation. VTE prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was initiated. Bowel regimen with senna was provided. Pain was managed with acetaminophen PRN.

Key Findings and Procedures: Initial labs confirmed acute anemia; hemoglobin stabilized following transfusion. Upper endoscopy with endoscopic hemostasis was performed demonstrating a bleeding duodenal ulcer; successful endoscopic therapy achieved hemostasis. Peripheral IV access was used for medication and fluid administration; routine saline flushes maintained line patency.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, ambulatory with minimal assistance, and able to perform basic activities of daily living independently. Home health services arranged for nursing visits to monitor vitals and wound/IV site, perform daily hemoglobin checks as ordered, administer/flush IV access if needed, and reinforce medication teaching.

Medications and Follow-Up: Discharge meds include pantoprazole (PPI) for ulcer management, heparin as VTE prophylaxis per plan, acetaminophen for pain, senna for bowel regimen, and supplies for saline flushes. Follow-up with gastroenterology in 1 week for reassessment and H. pylori testing/treatment as indicated; primary care within 48–72 hours for anemia follow-up. Return to ED for recurrent hematemesis, melena, syncope, or worsening pain/fever.

History of present illness: 50-year-old man with known hypertensive chronic kidney disease (stage 5/ESRD) and type 2 diabetes mellitus on long-term insulin was admitted emergently with uremic symptoms, oliguria and acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease. He was found to have bacteriuria/UTI and Clostridioides difficile enterocolitis on admission and had a history of prior sudden cardiac arrest with a permanent pacemaker in place.

Hospital course: Patient required initiation/continuation of intermittent in-hospital hemodialysis for volume and metabolic control; vascular access was managed with a dialysis catheter and standard catheter care. He received IV and oral antibiotics guided by cultures for UTI and completed targeted therapy for C. difficile (oral vancomycin regimen completed during admission). Glycemic control was optimized with his home insulin regimen. He remained hemodynamically stable without recurrent arrhythmia. Supportive measures included electrolyte correction, iron and vitamin supplementation, and prophylactic heparin catheter locks as indicated. Nutritional status was addressed with multivitamins and nephrology dietary counseling.

Key findings and procedures: Laboratory and imaging consistent with ESRD and superimposed acute kidney injury; positive urine culture and stool testing positive for C. difficile toxin. Procedures included serial intermittent hemodialysis sessions and vascular access management. No operative interventions were required.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged in stable condition, afebrile and hemodynamically stable. He remains dialysis-dependent and requires outpatient hemodialysis thrice weekly. Functional status: ambulatory with a walker and requires assistance with toileting and medication administration; home health nursing is requested for vascular access assessment, medication administration, wound/catheter care, and ADL assistance for at least the next 2 weeks.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include insulin per home regimen, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate XL, ferrous sulfate, folic acid, thiamine, nephrocaps, multivitamins, prednisone as indicated, tamsulosin, and heparin catheter lock instructions. Hepatitis B vaccine administered in hospital; continue outpatient series. Follow-up: Nephrology clinic within 7 days, infectious disease/primary care as indicated, dialysis unit coordination and home health nursing visit within 48 hours of discharge.

History of present illness: 82-year-old female observed for 6.7 days for management of ileus (ICD-10 K56.7) in the setting of known ulcerative colitis and prior ileostomy. She presented with progressive abdominal distension, decreased oral intake, nausea and decreased ileostomy output. Past history notable for atrial fibrillation on chronic anticoagulation, prior TIA/stroke, moderate protein-calorie malnutrition and low BMI.

Hospital course: Patient was managed non-operatively with bowel rest, intravenous fluids, electrolyte repletion, antiemetics (ondansetron) and pantoprazole. Metoprolol was continued for rate control; rivaroxaban was held temporarily on admission and resumed prior to discharge when clinically appropriate. Ileus was monitored with serial abdominal exams and imaging consistent with nonobstructive ileus; no surgical intervention was required. Nutritional intake improved with initiation of oral supplementation and psyllium for ostomy consistency; loperamide was used to manage increased stoma output as needed. She received education on ostomy care and infection precautions given recent contact exposure history.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging demonstrated nonmechanical bowel dysmotility without radiographic obstruction. Laboratory abnormalities (electrolyte derangements) were corrected during stay. No operative or endoscopic procedures were performed. Vascular access maintained without complication; ostomy intact without evidence of ischemia or infection.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. Functionally she requires assistance with ostomy care, medication management and intermittent assistance with activities of daily living due to decreased endurance and malnutrition; ambulation is steady with supervision.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen as needed, loperamide for stoma output, metoprolol succinate XL daily, ondansetron PRN, pantoprazole daily, psyllium wafers for ostomy output management, rivaroxaban resumed for anticoagulation. Home health to provide ostomy care supplies and teach flushing/maintenance as indicated.

Follow-up: Primary care within 3–5 days, GI follow-up in 1–2 weeks for ulcerative colitis/ostomy management and nutrition service for malnutrition evaluation. Cardiology as outpatient for AF and anticoagulation management. Return precautions reviewed for recurrent obstruction, bleeding, fever or worsening abdominal pain.

History of Present Illness: 65-year-old male admitted under observation for post-procedural gastrointestinal bleeding and coagulopathy. He presented after a recent GI procedure with melena and anemia. Medical history significant for anticoagulant-related hemorrhagic disorder (D68.32), type 2 diabetes with hyperglycemia, peripheral polyneuropathy, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, prior CABG, hypothyroidism, and prior colon polyp.

Hospital Course: Patient was managed over a 2.5-day observation stay. Initial evaluation revealed acute posthemorrhagic anemia (D62) and active postprocedural hemorrhage (K91.840). Resuscitation included IV fluids (0.9% NaCl and Lactated Ringers) and targeted hemodynamic monitoring. Anticoagulation was reversed per hematology recommendations; coagulation studies were trended. Patient received transfusion support as clinically indicated and was observed for re-bleeding. Nausea was controlled with ondansetron; pain managed with acetaminophen. Glucose was treated with insulin and glucose gel as needed; endocrinology input obtained for diabetes management. No further overt GI bleeding while inpatient.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive for acute drop in hemoglobin consistent with postprocedural hemorrhage. Imaging/endoscopic report consistent with site of bleeding post-procedure. Procedure recorded: ICD-10-PCS 0W3P8ZZ. Hemodynamic status stabilized after fluids/transfusion and anticoagulation reversal. No new neurological deficit.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with assist, and independent with basic ADLs but requires home support for medication management and blood glucose monitoring. Fall risk elevated due to anemia and peripheral neuropathy; home health recommended for safety and mobility evaluation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include levothyroxine, metoprolol tartrate, rosuvastatin, pantoprazole, gabapentin, acetaminophen, and diabetes regimen (insulin as prescribed) with instructions for glucose monitoring. Aspirin continuation to be determined by hematology. Home health to provide daily vitals, wound/stool checks, medication reconciliation, and fingerstick glucose for 48–72 hours. Labs (CBC, BMP, coagulation panel) in 48–72 hours. Follow-up with Hematology within 7 days and GI within 7–14 days; PCP follow-up in 1 week.

History of Present Illness: 80-year-old female presented emergently with sudden onset right-sided weakness and expressive aphasia. NIHSS on arrival was 35. Imaging demonstrated an acute embolic infarction of the left middle cerebral artery (I63.412). Past medical history notable for atrial fibrillation, essential hypertension, recent diagnosis of right renal malignancy, anxiety disorder, and prior contact with suspected COVID-19 exposure.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the neuro-ICU for close neurologic monitoring. She underwent urgent endovascular mechanical thrombectomy of the left MCA with partial reperfusion. She required brief endotracheal intubation for respiratory failure and hypoxia with subsequent successful extubation; transitioned to supplemental oxygen and pulmonary support as needed. Anticoagulation was held during the acute intervention and resumed with oral dabigatran once hemorrhagic conversion was excluded on follow-up imaging. She received DVT prophylaxis while inpatient, bowel regimen, topical and ophthalmic agents for symptom control, and high-dose influenza vaccination prior to discharge. Speech and swallow evaluations identified dysphagia with aspiration risk; diet was modified accordingly. PT/OT initiated inpatient with progressive mobilization; patient remains hemiparetic on the right.

Key Findings and Procedures: Acute left MCA embolic infarct confirmed by imaging; endovascular thrombectomy performed; brief mechanical ventilation; central venous access and routine critical care procedures completed. No radiographic evidence of symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage post-procedure.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Medically stable for discharge on hospital day 6.2. Neurologic deficits persist — right-sided hemiplegia with dependence for transfers and most ADLs; expressive aphasia and dysphagia requiring supervised/modified diet. Requires frequent assistance and rehabilitation services at home.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on dabigatran for secondary stroke prevention, acetaminophen PRN, docusate sodium, lidocaine 5% patch PRN, fluticasone nasal spray, erythromycin ophthalmic ointment, and megestrol as indicated for appetite. Home oxygen PRN. Home health referrals placed for skilled nursing (medication/anticoagulation education), PT/OT, and speech therapy. Follow-up: neurology clinic within 1 week, cardiology (anticoagulation/AF) in 1–2 weeks, primary care within 7 days, and oncology/urology as outpatient per prior plan. Basic labs including BMP to assess renal function prior to anticoagulant dose maintenance.

History of present illness: 74-year-old female observed for 14.9 days for progressive prosthetic-related pain around an internal implant with associated poor oral intake, weight loss and progressive weakness. Past medical history notable for essential hypertension, GERD, vitamin B12 deficiency anemia, and chronic constipation. Presentation included intractable pain near prosthetic site, odynophagia/dysphagia and decreased PO tolerance.

Hospital course: During observation stay the patient received multimodal analgesia, antiemetic and bowel regimen optimization, DVT prophylaxis, and nutritional support. Pain was managed with scheduled acetaminophen and as-needed hydromorphone with adjunctive lidocaine 5% patches and viscous lidocaine for oropharyngeal discomfort. Speech-language pathology completed swallow evaluation with recommendations for texture-modified diet and compensatory strategies. Nutrition consult addressed severe protein-calorie malnutrition/cachexia and initiated calorie-dense oral supplements and a plan for B12 repletion. Physical and occupational therapy provided mobility and ADL training; she improved with therapy but required assistance for transfers.

Key findings and procedures: Relevant diagnoses include pain due to internal prosthetic device (T85.848A), severe protein-calorie malnutrition (E43), BMI ≤19.9, cachexia, dysphagia, GERD, essential hypertension, and B12 deficiency anemia. Per chart, ICD-10-PCS procedures recorded include 3E0H76Z and 0DHA7UZ (therapeutic/diagnostic procedures for medication administration and further evaluation). Imaging and labs ruled out acute surgical complications; inflammatory markers trended down.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient stable for discharge to home with home health. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires contact-guard assistance for transfers; independent with some light ADLs but needs help with meal preparation and medication management. Continues on a mechanically-modified diet per SLP recommendations and requires ongoing nutritional monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen (liquid) scheduled, hydromorphone PRN, pantoprazole, aluminum-magnesium hydroxide-simethicone, ondansetron PRN, polyethylene glycol, psyllium, loperamide PRN, hydroxyzine PRN, hyoscyamine, lidocaine 5% patch PRN, lidocaine viscous 2% PRN, multivitamin with minerals. Heparin given inpatient; no outpatient anticoagulation ordered. Begin B12 repletion outpatient per hematology/PCP. Home health orders: skilled nursing for med administration and wound/prosthetic site checks, PT/OT for mobility and ADLs, SLP for dysphagia follow-up, nutrition support. Follow-up with PCP in 3–5 days and prosthesis/surgical team in 1–2 weeks; outpatient labs (CBC, BMP, B12) in 1 week.

History of Present Illness: 56-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for elective management of a nonruptured cerebral aneurysm (ICD-10 I67.1). Past medical history notable for hypothyroidism, remote myocardial infarction with prior pacemaker placement, and epilepsy. She presented for planned endovascular treatment after outpatient evaluation and underwent procedure without evidence of rupture or new deficit.

Hospital Course: Patient had an uncomplicated endovascular aneurysm procedure (03VK3DZ) under general anesthesia. She was monitored in the neuro-observation unit postoperatively. No new focal neurological deficits were identified. Hemodynamics remained stable; pacemaker function confirmed intact. Seizure activity was not observed. Pain and nausea were controlled with short courses of morphine and ondansetron; bowel regimen initiated for opioid-associated constipation.

Key Findings and Procedures: Pre- and postoperative neuro exams were at baseline with no signs of infarction or hemorrhage on immediate post-op CT. Vascular access site (femoral) was clean, without hematoma or active bleeding. Procedure achieved successful occlusion of the target aneurysm per angiographic assessment.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged in stable condition, neurologically at baseline, and ambulatory with minimal assistance for balance and safety. She demonstrates adequate self-care for basic activities of daily living with planned home health support for medication management and access-site checks. Fall precautions and seizure precautions reviewed with patient and caregiver.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Continue home medications including levothyroxine and divalproex ER. Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) prescribed per neurointerventional recommendations—continue as directed. Short course acetaminophen for analgesia; PRN ondansetron for nausea; docusate and bisacodyl for stool regimen. Cardiology follow-up for pacemaker as scheduled within 1 week. Neurosurgery/neurointerventional clinic follow-up in 1–2 weeks for wound check and imaging plan; neurology follow-up for seizure management in 2–4 weeks. Home health arranged for 7–14 days for vital sign monitoring, access-site inspection, medication reconciliation, and assistance with ADLs as needed.

History of Present Illness: The patient is a 58-year-old male admitted for observation with acute episodic vertigo. Symptoms began 24–48 hours prior to presentation with brief positional dizziness, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. He has known vertebral artery aneurysm and chronic hypertension and hypothyroidism.

Hospital Course: On evaluation, vitals were stable and neurologic exam showed no focal deficit. Dix–Hallpike maneuver reproduced vertiginous symptoms with right-sided rotary nystagmus, consistent with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) of the right posterior canal (H81.11). Epley repositioning maneuvers were performed with significant symptomatic improvement. CT head without acute intracranial process. Labs including basic metabolic panel and TSH were unremarkable for acute derangement. The patient received antiemetic therapy and brief vestibular suppressant as needed. He was monitored for 24 hours in observation and demonstrated progressive improvement without recurrent emesis.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive right Dix–Hallpike. Epley canalith repositioning maneuver performed with good response. No focal neurologic deficit; CT head negative for acute process. Comorbid diagnoses addressed: essential hypertension (I10), hypothyroidism (E03.9), history of vertebral artery aneurysm (I72.6).

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged stable and afebrile, ambulatory with assistance due to residual imbalance. Independent with most ADLs but requires home health assistance for mobility safety and fall prevention during recovery. Home health will monitor vitals, assist with transfers, and implement balance training and home safety evaluation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include levothyroxine daily (continue preadmission dose), aspirin 81 mg daily, albuterol inhaler PRN, acetaminophen PRN for pain, senna and bisacodyl as bowel regimen, hydralazine PRN for hypertensive episodes. Medication reconciliation reviewed. Follow-up arranged with primary care within 3–5 days and ENT/vestibular clinic in 1 week; neurology if symptoms persist or new focal deficits develop. Return to ED for severe headache, focal weakness, recurrent prolonged vertigo, syncope, or new neurological signs.

Brief history of present illness: 51-year-old woman admitted emergently for small bowel Crohn's disease complicated by intestinal obstruction and peritonitis. She presented with severe abdominal pain, emesis, fever, hypotension and progressive respiratory distress. Initial evaluation identified small-bowel obstruction with intra-abdominal abscess and bacteremia with Enterococcus, with subsequent severe sepsis and septic shock.

Hospital course: The patient required prolonged hospitalization (44 days) with ICU-level care. She underwent exploratory laparotomy with small-bowel resection and abscess drainage, repeated abdominal washouts/percutaneous drainage procedures, central venous access placement, and tracheostomy after prolonged intubation for acute respiratory failure. She developed acute tubular necrosis and required temporary renal replacement therapy; renal function gradually recovered and dialysis was discontinued prior to discharge. She had acute posthemorrhagic anemia requiring transfusion and a transient coagulopathy that was managed medically. Blood and operative cultures guided targeted antimicrobial therapy; infectious disease recommended a planned outpatient IV antibiotic course. She received nutritional support and physical therapy throughout admission.

Key findings and procedures: CT and operative findings confirmed obstructing Crohn’s stricture with adjacent abscess. Procedures: exploratory laparotomy with small-bowel resection and primary anastomosis, intra-abdominal abscess drainage (surgical and IR), tracheostomy, central line placement, and temporary hemodialysis access and sessions.

Discharge condition and functional status: The patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. She is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and off vasopressors; respiratory status improved to spontaneous breathing via tracheostomy collar with effective secretion clearance but requires ongoing tracheostomy care. Renal function has recovered sufficiently to be off dialysis. Mobility is limited — ambulates short distances with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and most ADLs; home health will provide nursing, wound/trach care, and physical therapy.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include scheduled acetaminophen, oral ciprofloxacin to complete IV-to-oral plan per ID, fluconazole as indicated, insulin regimen for steroid-associated hyperglycemia, inhaled albuterol and ipratropium-albuterol PRN, and short course opioids as needed. Plan: home health nursing for IV/PO antibiotic administration, tracheostomy and wound care, and PT. Clinic follow-up with colorectal surgery in 1–2 weeks, gastroenterology within 2 weeks, infectious disease and nephrology within 1–2 weeks, and pulmonology as needed.

History of Present Illness: 71-year-old female presented to the ED after a fall at home with acute onset of positional vertigo, nausea, and lightheadedness. Symptoms were consistent with episodic rotational vertigo exacerbated by changes in head position. Past medical history notable for hypertension, prior concussion/postconcussional syndrome, and orthostatic symptoms. Initial evaluation identified a fall on same level at unspecified private residence.

Hospital Course: Patient was observed for 2.4 days. Neurologic examination and Dix–Hallpike maneuver were positive for left-sided benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). CT head was negative for acute intracranial process. Orthostatic vitals demonstrated clinically significant postural hypotension. Basic metabolic panel revealed hypo-osmolality with mild hyponatremia, addressed with careful fluid management and electrolyte repletion. Thromboprophylaxis with heparin was administered while inpatient. Brief physical therapy and fall risk assessment were performed; the patient required assistance to ambulate with a steadying device and had limitations with transfers and bathing.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive left Dix–Hallpike; successful canalith repositioning maneuver (Epley) with symptomatic improvement. CT head without acute intracranial abnormality. Laboratory confirmation of hyponatremia; orthostatic hypotension on bedside testing. Fall risk evaluation performed; home safety recommendations provided.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. Ambulates with assistance/steadying device and is at increased fall risk; requires assistance with ADLs, particularly transfers and bathing. Cognition baseline but requires monitoring for postconcussional symptoms and medication effects.

Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen, Benzonatate as needed, Docusate sodium, Heparin (per discharge plan), Hydrochlorothiazide, Lorazepam as needed for severe vertigo/anxiety, Meclizine, Potassium chloride, Ramelteon, Senna, and normal saline flush as prescribed.

Follow-up Plan: Primary care follow-up within 3–5 days; ENT or neurology (vestibular) clinic within 1–2 weeks for persistent symptoms. BMP and sodium recheck in 48–72 hours. Home health to provide PT for gait and balance training, nursing for medication reconciliation, orthostatic vital checks, and home safety assessment. Return to ED for recurrent falls, worsening neurologic symptoms, or syncope.

History of Present Illness: 66-year-old male admitted emergently with sepsis secondary to suspected biliary source. Past history notable for Type 2 diabetes mellitus with neuropathy, chronic hepatitis B, cirrhosis, known pancreatic head mass, essential hypertension, and prior ischemic heart disease. On presentation he was hypotensive and tachycardic with leukocytosis and abnormal liver function tests; imaging demonstrated a liver abscess and biliary dilation consistent with cholangitis.

Hospital Course: Patient required 7 days of inpatient care including aggressive IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressor support briefly for septic shock, glycemic management, and escalation to targeted therapy once cultures/imaging available. Interventional radiology performed percutaneous drainage of a hepatic abscess and biliary decompression (IR drain/ERCP-directed biliary drainage). A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) was placed for continued IV antibiotics. He stabilized off vasopressors, defervesced, and inflammatory markers trended down prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT abdomen consistent with liver abscess and biliary obstruction; blood cultures and drain cultures guided antibiotic choice. Procedures: IR-guided percutaneous hepatic abscess drainage, endoscopic biliary decompression, and PICC placement for outpatient IV therapy.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable and afebrile, hemodynamically stable on room air. Functional status: decreased endurance and deconditioning after prolonged hospitalization—requires assistance with ambulation and requires home health PT for gait and transfers. Ongoing issues: needs daily wound/drain care and PICC management; diabetic neuropathy increases fall risk and need for foot/skin checks.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge meds include IV ceftriaxone to be administered via home infusion through PICC (duration per ID recommendation), entecavir for chronic HBV, aspirin, atorvastatin, gabapentin for neuropathic pain, famotidine, docusate, acetaminophen PRN. Home health arranged for daily nursing (IV antibiotic administration, PICC and drain care, wound assessment, vitals, glucose checks) and PT visits. Follow-up: Infectious Disease within 3–7 days, Gastroenterology/Hepatology within 1 week for biliary/drain reassessment and oncology/surgical clinic for pancreatic mass evaluation. Labs (CBC, CMP, blood cultures if indicated) to be drawn as outpatient per ID orders.

History of present illness: 71-year-old man with known liver cell carcinoma (C22.0) presented to our observation unit with progressive dyspnea, hypoxia and cough after an episode of emesis. He was found to have acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and aspiration pneumonitis. Significant comorbidities include nonischemic cardiomyopathy with left bundle branch block, atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, polymyalgia rheumatica and gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Hospital course: He was observed for 2.8 days. Initial evaluation included chest radiograph and labs consistent with aspiration pneumonitis and hypoxemia; oxygen supplementation and nebulized bronchodilator therapy were started. He received intravenous fluids, empiric antibiotics for aspiration (amoxicillin–clavulanate/Ampicillin–sulbactam course initiated), bronchodilator and anticholinergic nebulizers, and symptomatic analgesia. Cardiac monitoring did not reveal hemodynamically significant arrhythmia; rate control medications were continued for atrial fibrillation. Thyroid replacement was continued. He improved clinically with weaning of oxygen to low-flow nasal cannula and was hemodynamically stable at discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging confirmed aspiration changes without focal lobar consolidation requiring drainage. Laboratory evaluation excluded acute hepatic decompensation; electrolytes and renal function remained stable. Interventions included supplemental oxygen, nebulized ipratropium–albuterol, IV to oral antibiotic conversion, medication reconciliation, and initiation of home health services. Continuous telemetry and supportive care were provided.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Ambulates with assistance due to deconditioning and reports baseline fatigue; requires assistance with some activities of daily living. He remains on low-flow oxygen at rest/intermittently for exertional desaturation and will have home oxygen evaluation and respiratory therapy.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include levothyroxine, carvedilol, aspirin, ezetimibe, gabapentin, short course oral amoxicillin–clavulanate (as above), inhaled ipratropium–albuterol PRN, acetaminophen PRN. Home health nursing to assist with medication administration, oxygen management, vital sign monitoring, and therapy referrals. Outpatient follow-up: oncology within 7 days, pulmonology within 7–10 days, cardiology 1–2 weeks, and primary care in 3–5 days. Return to ER for fever, worsening dyspnea, chest pain, new confusion, or bleeding.

History of Present Illness: 45-year-old male with history of type 1 diabetes mellitus on long-term insulin presented to observation unit after an episode of syncope with documented hypoglycemia. On arrival he was diaphoretic and lethargic; point-of-care glucose was low and responded to oral glucose and subsequent IV dextrose. He reports several days of poor oral intake and intermittent vomiting prior to presentation.

Hospital Course: The patient was observed for 48 hours (LOS 1.9 days). Initial management included correction of hypoglycemia with oral glucose gel, IV D50 and a supplemental dose of glucagon for emergency rescue. He received IV fluids for volume depletion and supportive care. Creatinine was elevated on admission consistent with acute kidney injury on background chronic kidney disease stage 3; renal function trended toward baseline with hydration. Orthostatic vitals were monitored; no recurrent syncope occurred. Blood glucose was stabilized with reinstatement of his home insulin regimen with adjustments and education on sick-day management. Venous thromboembolism prophylaxis was given during hospitalization.

Key Findings and Procedures: Primary diagnosis: Type 1 diabetes mellitus with hypoglycemia without coma (E10.649). Secondary: acute kidney injury, CKD stage 3, syncope. No procedures beyond peripheral IV placement and standard observation monitoring. EKG and basic labs obtained; no acute ischemic changes identified.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is alert, oriented, ambulatory with steady gait, independent with activities of daily living but with recent decreased endurance. He has an elevated fall risk related to recent syncope and hypoglycemia — home health nursing requested for early follow-up. Functional recommendations: assistance with medication administration/insulin dosing review and blood glucose monitoring until stable; home safety/fall risk assessment recommended.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on his adjusted insulin regimen (basal-bolus with sliding scale — see med list provided), glucagon emergency kit, glucose gel PRN, docusate sodium 100 mg BID PRN, senna PRN, amlodipine for blood pressure. Home health: daily nursing visits initially for blood glucose checks, insulin administration education, medication reconciliation, wound/skin assessment for psoriasis, and BMP monitoring. Follow-up: Primary care & endocrinology within 1 week, nephrology within 2 weeks, or sooner for recurrent hypoglycemia.

History of Present Illness: 25-year-old G?P? female presented urgently at 35 weeks gestation with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). She had a history of pre-existing hypertension noted in pregnancy and a prior low transverse cesarean section. Labor progressed and she delivered a single live infant vaginally. Delivery was complicated by a first-degree perineal laceration which was repaired at bedside.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for management of PPROM and labor. Fetal monitoring remained reassuring. She received oxytocin augmentation during labor. Maternal vital signs remained stable; there was no evidence of clinical chorioamnionitis. Blood counts and metabolic panel were within acceptable limits. Pain was managed with scheduled acetaminophen and PRN ibuprofen. Docusate and stool softeners were provided to minimize strain. She received Tdap vaccination prior to discharge. Perineal repair was uncomplicated. She was observed for 48–72 hours postpartum for bleeding, uterine involution, and blood pressure control given her history of hypertension; antihypertensive therapy was continued per obstetric plan.

Key Findings and Procedures: Diagnosis: PPROM (third trimester), postpartum first-degree perineal laceration, history of pre-existing hypertension complicating childbirth, maternal care for cesarean scar, 35 weeks gestation, single liveborn. Procedures: spontaneous vaginal delivery with perineal laceration repair and intra-partum oxytocin administration. No surgical complications.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, with expected lochia and normal uterine involution. Ambulates independently with mild perineal discomfort; performing activities of daily living independently with assistance only for heavier lifting. Breastfeeding established with adequate latch; lactation support arranged.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge medications include acetaminophen and ibuprofen for analgesia, docusate sodium and bisacodyl as bowel regimen, calcium carbonate as needed for reflux, simethicone for gas, topical Dermoplast spray for perineal discomfort, and oxytocin per inpatient protocol (if outpatient infusion not indicated, none prescribed). Tdap given prior to discharge. Home health to provide wound assessment, BP monitoring, lactation support, and assistance with ADLs as needed within 24–48 hours. Follow-up with obstetrics in 7 days, primary care for BP assessment in 3–7 days, and newborn pediatric visit within 48–72 hours.

History of Present Illness: 58-year-old male admitted urgently with acute decompensated heart failure and acute-on-chronic respiratory failure with hypoxia on a background of hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease (I130) and CKD stage 4. Admission precipitated by progressive dyspnea, lower extremity edema, decreased urine output and cellulitis of the left upper limb. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes with diabetic CKD, obesity (BMI ~40), prior vascular graft and device-related complications.

Hospital Course: Hospitalized 22.7 days. Patient responded to diuresis with improvement in volume status and oxygenation. Required supplemental oxygen intermittently and nightly; pulmonary status stabilized on baseline oxygen therapy. Treated for suspected/confirmed cellulitis with IV cefazolin via vascular access and local wound care; infectious complications related to prior vascular device were evaluated and managed in coordination with vascular surgery and infectious disease. Acute kidney injury on CKD 4 improved but did not return to baseline creatinine; nephrology involved for outpatient CKD management. Psychiatry/behavioral health consulted for depressive symptoms; fluoxetine continued. Nutrition consulted for diabetes and weight management.

Key Findings and Procedures: Echocardiogram consistent with diastolic congestive heart failure. Imaging/labs consistent with chronic kidney disease stage 4 with superimposed AKI. Procedures performed included vascular access management (vascular device care and line placement for antibiotic administration) and debridement/wound care of left upper extremity cellulitis.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Discharged hemodynamically stable, saturating adequately on home supplemental oxygen at rest with activity precautions. Ambulates short distances at home with a rolling walker and requires assistance for transfers due to deconditioning. Independent with light ADLs but requires nursing assistance for wound care and IV antibiotic administration.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include cefazolin IV with home health nursing for administration, aspirin, allopurinol, calcitriol, fluoxetine, famotidine, fenofibrate, fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, gabapentin and acetaminophen as needed. Instructions: daily weights, low-sodium diabetic diet, medication reconciliation at first clinic visit. Follow-up appointments: cardiology in 1 week, nephrology in 1 week, primary care/wound clinic in 3–5 days, infectious disease as outpatient. Home health to provide nursing for IV antibiotics, wound care, oxygen assessment, medication management and mobility support.

Chief complaint: Progressive abdominal distension and worsening fatigue in setting of known hepatic graft/stent disease.

HPI: 42-year-old male admitted emergently for evaluation and management of stenosis of a vascular prosthetic device with portal hypertension and symptomatic ascites. Patient has history of Budd-Chiari syndrome, cirrhosis with recurrent ascites and known esophageal varices (no active bleeding), and nicotine dependence. Presentation included progressive abdominal fullness, weight gain, and dyspnea on exertion.

Hospital course: Patient underwent endovascular evaluation with venography and endovascular interventions including targeted angioplasty and revision of the affected vascular graft/stent. Therapeutic large-volume paracentesis was performed with albumin replacement. He received diuretic optimization (furosemide and spironolactone) and initiation/continuation of anticoagulation with apixaban for thrombotic risk related to Budd-Chiari/graft stenosis. Lactulose was used prophylactically for encephalopathy risk. Pain controlled with acetaminophen. Patient remained hemodynamically stable with improving abdominal discomfort and decreasing tense ascites.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging and venography confirmed prosthetic graft stenosis contributing to hepatic outflow obstruction consistent with Budd-Chiari physiology. Procedures: endovascular graft/venous angioplasty and graft revision, therapeutic paracentesis with albumin administration, and procedural monitoring without immediate complications.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition. Functionally he is ambulatory with a cane for long distances, independent with most ADLs but requires assistance for stair negotiation and transportation. Home health nursing recommended for skilled monitoring (daily weights, diuretic titration guidance, medication reconciliation) and education.

Medications at discharge: Apixaban, furosemide, spironolactone, lactulose, acetaminophen PRN, hydralazine, magnesium oxide, Neutra-Phos, simethicone, sodium chloride 0.9% flush as needed. Influenza vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Outpatient hepatology within 1 week, interventional radiology in 2 weeks, primary care in 1 week. Labs (BMP, LFTs, CBC, coagulation) in 3 days and as directed. Home health to monitor daily weights, intake/output, signs of encephalopathy or variceal bleeding, and to coordinate outpatient appointments.

26-year-old male admitted emergently with infected left lower-extremity amputation stump (primary diagnosis T87.44). He required a prolonged 62.8-day hospitalization complicated by acute posthemorrhagic anemia, acute kidney injury, deep vein thrombosis of the left upper extremity, osteomyelitis of the residual limb, poorly controlled type 1 diabetes with autonomic neuropathy and gastroparesis, and cutaneous abscesses. Initial presentation included local erythema, purulent drainage, systemic inflammatory response, and hyperglycemia. Imaging confirmed soft tissue infection with concern for underlying osteomyelitis; wound cultures grew mixed organisms consistent with polymicrobial stump infection.

Hospital course: Patient underwent serial surgical debridements and incision-and-drainage procedures with placement of VAC therapy and removal of devitalized tissue. A PICC line was placed for long-term parenteral antibiotics and he received targeted IV antimicrobial therapy with Infectious Disease oversight. Anticoagulation with apixaban was initiated for upper-extremity DVT. Nephrology was consulted for AKI; renal function improved with supportive measures and medication adjustments. Endocrinology optimized an inpatient insulin regimen and diabetes education. Pain was managed primarily with scheduled acetaminophen and short-term opioid PRN; bowel regimen provided with docusate. Nutrition and glycemic control were addressed given gastroparesis.

Key findings and procedures: serial wound debridement, I&D, VAC placement, PICC insertion, imaging-confirmed osteomyelitis, and management of acute anemia and AKI. Blood products were administered as indicated.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and clinically improved. He remains limited in ambulation and requires assistive device and caregiver support for transfers; home health nursing arranged for wound/VAC care, daily IV antibiotic administration, PICC care, insulin administration, and DVT monitoring.

Medications at discharge include IV antibiotics via home infusion (per Infectious Disease plan), apixaban, insulin regimen with supplies, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, carvedilol, famotidine, docusate, furosemide as needed, and glucose gel. Follow-up: Infectious Disease within 7 days, surgical/plastic surgery in 2 weeks, endocrinology within 1–2 weeks, nephrology PRN, and home physical therapy for mobility/prosthesis evaluation.

HPI: 30-year-old female admitted for observation with progressive dyspnea, orthopnea and lower extremity edema. Past medical history notable for hypertensive heart disease with heart failure, dilated cardiomyopathy, type 2 diabetes on insulin, and recent decrease in urine output prompting evaluation for acute kidney injury.

Hospital course: Patient was managed over an 8.8-day observation stay for acute on chronic systolic heart failure with volume overload and AKI. Diuresis with IV loop diuretics was administered with close electrolyte and renal function monitoring. Cardiology and nephrology were consulted. Echocardiogram demonstrated reduced left ventricular systolic function consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy. Blood glucose was managed with insulin adjustments; she experienced brief hypoglycemia treated with D50 and glucose gel and was given rescue glucagon education. Bronchodilator therapy (ipratropium nebulizer) administered for intermittent wheeze. Corticosteroid replacement was continued for adrenal insufficiency. No arrhythmic events requiring intervention occurred.

Key findings and procedures: Reduced LVEF on echocardiogram, laboratory evidence of acute kidney injury (improving at discharge), chest radiograph consistent with pulmonary vascular congestion which improved with diuresis. Procedures included diagnostic echocardiography and continuous telemetry monitoring. Pharmacologic management included IV diuretics, insulin titration, and guideline-directed initiation/uptitration of ACE inhibitor (lisinopril) and beta-blocker (metoprolol succinate XL) as tolerated.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and euvolemic at discharge with improved breathing and decreased edema. Ambulates independently with exertional limitation due to deconditioning; requires assistance with medication administration and blood glucose monitoring. Home health nursing arranged for skilled follow-up to monitor vitals, daily weights, insulin administration education, medication reconciliation, and reinforcement of low-sodium/heart-failure diet.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on lisinopril, metoprolol succinate XL, home insulin regimen, allopurinol, acetaminophen PRN, stool regimen (docusate, bisacodyl) and inhaler/ipratropium as indicated. Follow-up: cardiology within 7 days, primary care within 7–10 days, nephrology in 2 weeks, and endocrinology as outpatient for insulin titration. Home health nursing to start within 48 hours.

History of present illness: 63-year-old man admitted through the emergency department for progressive abdominal distension, weight loss and worsening functional status. Imaging and fluid analysis during this admission confirmed malignant ascites and metastatic disease to the retroperitoneum/peritoneum (primary ICD-10: C78.6). He also presented with acute posthemorrhagic anemia and severe protein-calorie malnutrition (E43), together with pleural effusion and melena on admission.

Hospital course: Over a 10.5-day admission the patient underwent diagnostic and therapeutic paracenteses with symptomatic relief of ascites, thoracentesis for pleural effusion, and placement of a central venous access device for administration of systemic chemotherapy and parenteral fluids. He received two cycles of inpatient infusional chemotherapy (fluorouracil and irinotecan) and supportive care including IV fluids (0.9% NaCl, D5W), antiemetics, dexamethasone, analgesia (acetaminophen), and electrolyte repletion. He required transfusion support for acute posthemorrhagic anemia and nutritional consultation for severe malnutrition; enteral supplementation was initiated. He was evaluated by physical and occupational therapy for deconditioning.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging consistent with secondary malignant neoplasm of retroperitoneum/peritoneum with malignant ascites and pleural effusion; labs notable for anemia and hypoalbuminemia. Procedures: paracentesis(s), thoracentesis, central venous access placement, and inpatient chemotherapy administration. 

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable for discharge to home with home health services. He remains mildly to moderately deconditioned, requires assistance with transfers and ADLs, and will benefit from nursing support for IV line/port care and medication administration as well as PT/OT visits for mobility and safety training.

Medications and follow-up: Continued on apixaban (per inpatient indication), furosemide as needed for volume management, dexamethasone, acetaminophen PRN, and scheduled antiemetics. He has heparin flush supplies for port care. Outpatient oncology follow-up in 7 days for chemotherapy planning, primary care in 1 week for labs (CBC, CMP, albumin), and home health nursing to monitor wound/port, IV fluids, nutritional status, and coordinate PT/OT.

History of Present Illness: 49-year-old man admitted under observation for decompensated cirrhosis secondary to chronic liver disease (ICD-10 K74.69) with known portal vein thrombosis, ascites, pancytopenia, and acute kidney injury. He presented with increasing abdominal distension, early satiety, fatigue, and oliguria. Past history notable for chronic hepatitis B, schistosomiasis exposure, and moderate protein-calorie malnutrition (BMI ≤19.9).

Hospital Course: Over a 22.7-day observation stay the patient underwent diagnostic evaluation and supportive care. Paracentesis was performed twice for symptomatic ascites with removal of tense fluid and symptomatic relief. A peripherally inserted central catheter was placed to facilitate IV access and infusions. He received diuretic adjustment, albumin replacement post-paracentesis, and careful volume management for AKI with transient rise in creatinine that improved with conservative measures. Pancytopenia and coagulation abnormalities were managed with hematology input; no major bleeding events occurred. Infectious disease recommended initiation/continuation of entecavir for chronic hepatitis B; praziquantel was given for schistosomal disease. Nutritional support with multivitamins and vitamin D and dietary consult were provided. Imaging confirmed portal vein thrombosis; anticoagulation decisions were individualized given coagulopathy.

Key Findings and Procedures: Laboratory: pancytopenia, elevated markers consistent with chronic liver disease; renal function partially recovered. Imaging: cirrhosis with portal vein thrombosis and ascites. Procedures: therapeutic paracenteses x2 and PICC placement for vascular access.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: He is medically stable for discharge to home with home health. Functional status: ambulatory with assistance for transfers and gait instability due to deconditioning; requires assistance with ADLs and meal preparation. Home health to provide skilled nursing for IV access care, daily weights, abdominal girth checks, wound/PICC care, medication reconciliation, and assistance with bedside mobility as needed.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include entecavir, nadolol, pantoprazole, ciprofloxacin as indicated, praziquantel, multivitamins, vitamin D, topical emollient (Sarna), and saline flushes for PICC. Follow-up: hepatology within 1 week, primary care within 3–5 days, infectious disease and hematology as outpatient; home health nursing to coordinate labs (CBC, CMP, INR) and urgent clinic contact for worsening encephalopathy, bleeding, fever, or increased abdominal pain/oliguria.

History of present illness: 28-year-old female admitted electively for operative management of complicated Crohn’s disease with enteric fistula and symptomatic disease of both the small and large intestine. She presented with abdominal pain, intermittent fever, tachycardia and evidence of anemia. Length of stay 8 days.

Hospital course: The patient was optimized preoperatively and taken to the OR for exploratory laparotomy. Intraoperative findings included diseased segments of small and large bowel with a fistulous tract and dense peritoneal adhesions. Procedures performed: resection of affected small and large bowel segments with fistula takedown, lysis of adhesions, creation of diverting ileostomy, placement of abdominal drains and PICC line for postoperative antibiotics. Postoperative course was complicated by acute posthemorrhagic anemia requiring 1 unit PRBC transfusion and transient sinus tachycardia that responded to fluid resuscitation and analgesia. She received broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (ertapenem and ciprofloxacin/metronidazole coverage as indicated), IV steroids with transition to an oral prednisone taper, bowel rest initially with advancing diet as tolerated, prophylactic heparin while inpatient, antiemetics and multimodal analgesia.

Key findings and procedures: Crohn’s disease with fistula involving small and large bowel, peritoneal adhesions, resection of diseased bowel, diverting ileostomy, drain placement, PICC for outpatient IV therapy.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating oral intake, pain controlled on oral analgesics, ambulating with minimal assistance and independent with most basic ADLs. Wound and ostomy sites are intact with minimal drainage.

Medications at discharge: Home IV ertapenem via PICC (daily) for planned 7–14 days, oral metronidazole, prednisone taper, acetaminophen and gabapentin for pain, ondansetron as needed, famotidine, oral ciprofloxacin if directed by infectious disease. DVT prophylaxis discontinued on discharge; follow-up recommendations made.

Follow-up: Home health referral for wound/ostomy and PICC care, home IV antibiotics and PT evaluation. Clinic follow-up with colorectal surgery in 7–14 days, gastroenterology in 4–6 weeks. Labs (CBC, BMP) within 48–72 hours and weekly until stable. Return to ED for fever, worsening abdominal pain, increasing output or bleeding.

History of Present Illness: 29-year-old female presented to the emergency department with acute worsening lower abdominal and pelvic pain. She has a history notable for endometriosis involving the fallopian tube (N80.2), chronic salpingitis (N70.11), and a remote lumbar compression fracture currently in routine healing (M48.56XD). She also carries a diagnosis of unspecified B-cell lymphoma (C85.10). Symptoms included severe cramping pelvic pain and limited mobility due to baseline lumbar discomfort.

Hospital Course: This was an observation/emergency stay (0.8 days). Evaluation included focused abdominal/pelvic imaging and laboratory testing, which showed no evidence of acute surgical abdomen or abscess. Gynecology and pain management were consulted. The patient received IV fluids, analgesia, and antiemetic therapy; peripheral IV was later discontinued. Her pain responded to multimodal oral analgesics and she remained hemodynamically stable throughout observation.

Key Findings/Procedures: Pelvic imaging consistent with known endometriosis of the fallopian tube and chronic salpingitis; no acute intra-abdominal process requiring operative intervention. No invasive procedures performed. Peripheral IV access placed and then removed prior to discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition. She ambulates with some difficulty due to chronic lumbar pain and recent compression fracture; requires assistance with ambulation and some activities of daily living (ADLs). Home health nursing arranged for medication assistance, pain assessment, safe mobility training, and fall-risk precautions.

Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen (liquid) as needed for pain, ibuprofen as directed, acyclovir (per home regimen), calcium carbonate, vitamin D, multivitamin, and sodium chloride 0.9% flush for intermittent IV/catheter care if required by home nursing.

Follow-up Plan: Outpatient gynecology within 7 days for endometriosis management; oncology follow-up in 1–2 weeks for lymphoma care; orthopedics/spine or physiatry in 2 weeks for lumbar fracture management; primary care within 1 week. Home health nursing to provide medication administration, pain/mobility support, and coordinate further outpatient care.

60-year-old female admitted emergently for fever, myalgias, sore throat, and left upper quadrant pain. Initial evaluation notable for positive gammaherpesviral serology consistent with gammaherpesviral mononucleosis (ICD-10 B27.00), splenomegaly on exam and imaging (R16.1), thrombocytopenia and anemia on CBC (D69.6, D64.9), and concern for possible arthropod-borne co-infection (A93.8). Past history includes colonic polyps (Z86.010). She was observed 36 hours for symptom control and diagnostic evaluation.

Hospital course: Patient received supportive care including antipyretics and analgesia (acetaminophen and a single dose ketorolac inpatient) and antiemetic (ondansetron ODT) with good symptomatic response. Doxycycline was initiated empirically pending additional infectious workup given exposure history; no invasive procedures were required. Hemodynamics remained stable, oxygenation normal on room air, and serial exams showed improving oral intake. Platelet count trended upward but remained below institutional normal; hemoglobin was stable without transfusion requirement. No evidence of splenic rupture.

Key findings/procedures: Positive gammaherpesviral testing consistent with infectious mononucleosis; imaging-confirmed splenomegaly; laboratory-confirmed thrombocytopenia and anemia. No procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged clinically improved, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and able to ambulate independently with baseline assistance for heavier tasks due to fatigue. Home health is arranged for nursing visits—monitor vitals, medication administration, wound/IV site checks if vascular access is present, and assistance with medication reconciliation and safe activity progression. Recommend activity restriction (no heavy lifting or contact sports) while splenomegaly present.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen PRN for pain/fever, doxycycline hyclate (complete prescribed course), ondansetron ODT PRN for nausea, and supplies for 0.9% sodium chloride flush if home vascular access required. Follow-up with primary care in 3–5 days, hematology within 1–2 weeks for thrombocytopenia/anemia surveillance, and return sooner for worsening abdominal pain, sudden shoulder pain, new bleeding, syncope, or high fever.

History of present illness: 68-year-old female admitted for observation for critical limb ischemia of the left lower extremity (ICD-10 I70.222) with rest pain. She has known peripheral arterial disease, chronic anticoagulation use, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, COPD, mitral regurgitation, and nicotine dependence. Symptoms on presentation included progressive left foot/ankle pain at rest, pallor, and decreased ambulation due to pain.

Hospital course: Patient was observed for 2.7 days. Vascular surgery performed endovascular revascularization of the left lower extremity (percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of affected segment) without immediate complication. Peri-procedural anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy were managed inpatient; parenteral heparin used per protocol and transitioned back to home oral anticoagulant. Pain and perfusion improved with decreased rest pain, warmer distal skin temperature, and improved Doppler signals.

Key findings and procedures: Pre-procedure: diminished left dorsalis pedis/posterior tibial Doppler signals and rest pain consistent with I70.222. Procedures: endovascular left lower extremity revascularization (angioplasty) and adjunctive percutaneous interventions; peri-procedural hemostasis achieved without bleeding. Labs stable; no acute cardiac or pulmonary events. Smoking cessation counseling provided.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Rest pain significantly improved; ambulates with a cane and requires minimal assistance for transfers. Homebound status anticipated temporarily; home health recommended for wound/vascular checks, medication management, and assistance with activities of daily living while mobility improves.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on apixaban (continue prior anticoagulation), aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily per vascular team recommendation, gabapentin for neuropathic pain as needed, acetaminophen for pain, and inhalers for COPD as previously prescribed. Patient instructed on wound care and foot checks, smoking cessation support, and signs of limb ischemia or bleeding prompting immediate return. Follow-up: vascular surgery within 7 days, primary care within 7–14 days, cardiology as outpatient if indicated. Home health nursing and PT arranged for medication reconciliation, wound surveillance, and gait training.

History of present illness: 85-year-old female admitted under observation for evaluation and treatment of urinary tract infection (ICD-10 N39.0). She presented with acute confusion and decreased oral intake on background of known dementia with behavioral disturbance (F03.91) and baseline urinary incontinence (R32). Urinalysis was consistent with infection and urine culture grew Escherichia coli. Delirium secondary to UTI was suspected (F05). Patient is DNR (Z66).

Hospital course: Patient was observed for 1.9 days. She received intravenous fluids initially, supportive care, and antimicrobial therapy directed at the urine culture with clinical improvement in mentation and volume status. No hemodynamic instability or respiratory compromise occurred. Diarrhea was addressed with supportive measures. Skin was inspected; topical corticosteroid ointments continued for chronic dermatitis as needed. No invasive procedures were required.

Key findings and procedures: Positive urinalysis and urine culture for E. coli. Clinical diagnosis: acute UTI with associated delirium on a background of dementia. Basic labs and clinical monitoring showed improvement; blood cultures were not clinically concerning for sepsis. IV access placement for fluids/antibiotics; no imaging or operative procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged to home in stable, afebrile condition with resolution of acute delirium to near baseline but with persistent baseline cognitive impairment from dementia. Functional needs: requires assistance with activities of daily living, supervision for medication administration and toileting due to incontinence, and fall-risk precautions; home health will provide skilled nursing and home aid support.

Medications and follow-up: Continue prescribed oral antibiotic to complete the course as directed. Home medications on discharge: acetaminophen, aspirin, betamethasone valerate 0.1% ointment, triamcinolone acetonide 0.025% ointment, calcium carbonate, potassium chloride, heparin (as directed for prophylaxis), normal saline flushes, vitamin D. Recommend PCP follow-up within 48–72 hours for medication reconciliation and culture result review. Home health to monitor vitals, mental status, hydration, ADL assistance, and wound/skin care; obtain labs (BMP/CBC) and report abnormalities. Return to ED for fever, recurrent confusion, worsening weakness, or decreased oral intake.

History of Present Illness: 77-year-old male admitted to observation for evaluation and treatment of urinary tract infection with fever, dysuria, nausea and decreased oral intake. Known history of metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma with liver metastases, insulin-treated diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and prior pathological fracture. Admission labs revealed hyponatremia and evidence of infection; urine culture subsequently grew Escherichia coli.

Hospital Course: The patient received IV fluids for symptomatic hyponatremia with progressive correction of serum sodium from 124 mmol/L to 134 mmol/L. Empiric IV antibiotics were initiated (ceftriaxone) and continued pending culture results; therapy was narrowed to oral antibiotic therapy once clinically improved and culture sensitivities were available. Antiemetics and analgesics were administered as needed. He received subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. Orthopedics evaluated the known pathological fracture and recommended nonoperative management with pain control and mobility precautions. No invasive procedures were required.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive urinalysis and urine culture for E. coli; leukocytosis and hyponatremia on admission that normalized with treatment. No surgical interventions performed. Orthopedic consult documented stable pathological fracture without acute surgical indication.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge the patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, mentating at baseline, and ambulatory with a wheeled walker with caregiver assistance. He requires assistance with transfers and some activities of daily living; home health services arranged for skilled nursing and physical therapy to assist with medication management, mobility training, vital sign and glucose monitoring, and safety/fall mitigation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on an oral antibiotic to complete a total 7–10 day course, his home cardiac, statin and diabetes med regimen (including insulin) resumed as prior with adjustments as indicated. Arrange primary care follow-up within 3 days, oncology follow-up in 1 week, and repeat BMP/CBC within 48–72 hours. Return to ED for fever, worsening confusion, dyspnea, new focal pain, or inability to tolerate PO intake.

History of Present Illness: 30-year-old G?P? female admitted urgently for preterm premature rupture of membranes at approximately 23 weeks' gestation with onset of labor within 24 hours of rupture. Pregnancy complicated by documented cervical incompetence, obesity (BMI ~38), and chronic hypertension. Intrapartum course was notable for clinical chorioamnionitis.

Hospital Course: Patient was managed over a 2.4-day hospitalization. On admission she received IV fluids and broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (ampicillin and gentamicin initially; clindamycin added for continued concern for intrauterine infection). Analgesia and antipyretics (acetaminophen, ibuprofen as indicated) were provided. Maternal hemodynamics and fetal status were monitored. The patient delivered a single liveborn infant (23 weeks) during the admission; delivery was attended by obstetrics and neonatology teams. Estimated blood loss was within expected limits for the delivery, and no immediate surgical complications occurred. Patient remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile for >24 hours prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis; PPROM with onset of labor; management included induction/management of labor and delivery, IV antibiotic therapy, and standard postpartum monitoring. Procedural interventions performed per operative and delivery documentation.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is stable for discharge, afebrile, and hemodynamically stable. Ambulates independently with some limitation from recent delivery; able to perform basic activities of daily living but will require home health support for medication reconciliation, blood pressure monitoring, and reinforcement of wound/breast care and newborn care education.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharged on oral analgesics (acetaminophen and ibuprofen PRN), stool softener (docusate), laxative PRN (bisacodyl or milk of magnesia as needed), calcium supplement, and simethicone for gas. Completed inpatient IV antibiotic course; no routine outpatient IV antibiotics prescribed. Home health ordered for daily nursing visit x 3 days for vitals (including BP), medication administration assistance, wound/incision or perineal care as indicated, and education/support with lactation/newborn care. Obstetrics postpartum clinic follow-up in 1 week; primary care for blood pressure management in 1 week; neonatology/NICU follow-up per discharge plan for the infant. Return precautions reviewed.

54-year-old male with known chronic pancreatitis (K86.1), alcoholic cirrhosis, COPD, prior pulmonary embolism, CAD status post PCI, type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism and bipolar disorder presented with 48 hours of worsening epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea and poor oral intake. Imaging (CT abdomen) demonstrated chronic pancreatitis changes without acute necrosis or fluid collection. Lipase was elevated consistent with an acute flare on chronic disease. He was admitted to observation for pain control, fluid resuscitation, glycemic stabilization and medication reconciliation.

Hospital course: Patient received aggressive IV fluids, antiemetics and analgesia with transition from IV hydromorphone to oral hydromorphone and adjunctive gabapentin. Pancreatic enzyme replacement (Creon) was initiated to address exocrine insufficiency. Glycemia was managed with insulin; intermittent hypoglycemia during hospitalization was treated with D50% and glucose gel and glucagon kit provided/education given. Therapeutic enoxaparin was administered given prior PE and current indication; home nursing will continue injections and monitoring. COPD symptoms were managed with albuterol inhaler. Lactulose was continued for hepatic encephalopathy prophylaxis. Cardiac evaluation (ECG, troponins) showed no acute ischemia.

Key findings and procedures: CT abdomen consistent with chronic pancreatitis without acute collections; elevated lipase; chronic liver disease pattern on LFTs; no endoscopic or operative intervention required during this observation stay.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake and able to ambulate with baseline limitations from COPD. Pain is controlled on oral regimen. Home health services are requested for medication management, therapeutic enoxaparin administration and education, glucose monitoring and insulin teaching, and surveillance for encephalopathy or bleeding.

Medications at discharge (selected): aripiprazole, divalproex, insulin regimen, therapeutic enoxaparin (subcutaneous), pancreatic enzymes (Creon), albuterol inhaler, gabapentin, hydromorphone PRN, lactulose, furosemide, hydroxyzine, multivitamin/ascorbic acid, glucagon kit and glucose gel.

Follow-up: Primary care in 3–5 days, GI clinic in 1–2 weeks, cardiology 4–6 weeks, psychiatry as outpatient. Labs (CMP, lipase, CBC, coagulation studies, glucose) within 3–5 days and as instructed by PCP/GI.

56-year-old female admitted urgently for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) in the setting of metastatic soft tissue malignancy with known secondary disease to lung and peritoneum. She presented with acute electrolyte abnormalities and declining renal function, and was found to have concurrent Clostridioides difficile enterocolitis and symptomatic hyponatremia. Length of stay: 5.9 days.

Hospital course: Patient received aggressive intravenous crystalloid resuscitation, urate-lowering therapy with allopurinol, close electrolyte correction, and monitoring of renal function. She required intermittent dextrose 50%/glucose support for insulin-related hypoglycemia; glucagon and glucose gel were available as rescue measures. DVT prophylaxis with heparin was continued. C. difficile infection was treated with guideline-directed therapy and symptomatic care. Hematologic abnormalities (anemia related to recent antineoplastic chemotherapy and leukemoid reaction) were managed conservatively without transfusion. Sodium was corrected gradually with specialist input; no dialysis was required.

Key findings and procedures: Laboratory evidence consistent with TLS (elevated uric acid, electrolyte shifts) and acute kidney injury secondary to TLS; positive testing consistent with C. difficile enterocolitis. No invasive procedures were required beyond central access management; heparin flushes provided for line maintenance.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged clinically stable, afebrile, and hemodynamically stable. Mobility: ambulatory with intermittent assistance due to deconditioning; requires home health support for medication administration, IV line/heparin flush care, and assistance with ADLs as needed. Cognitive status intact for self-care planning.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on allopurinol, insulin regimen with hypoglycemia rescue supplies (dextrose 50%, glucagon, glucose gel), acetaminophen, aspirin, atorvastatin, docusate, mirtazapine, multivitamins, and heparin flush protocol for central line. Home health to monitor daily weights, intake/output, weekly (or more frequent) BMP/CBC/uric acid until renal function stabilizes. Follow-up: oncology within 3–5 days, nephrology within 7–14 days, PCP within 7 days, and GI/infectious disease as outpatient for C. difficile management. Return to ED for worsening shortness of breath, persistent fever, new confusion, or signs of severe electrolyte disturbance.

History of Present Illness: 27-year-old man admitted urgently for severe alcohol withdrawal with delirium and hypoxic respiratory failure (admit day 0). He had recent heavy alcohol and opioid use and presented altered with hallucinations and agitation. Past medical history notable for chronic hepatitis C and hypertension.

Hospital Course: Length of stay 6.2 days. On admission he required short-term invasive ventilatory support for hypoxic respiratory failure and was successfully extubated on hospital day 2. He manifested tremor, delirium with visual hallucinations and impaired attention consistent with alcohol withdrawal delirium. He was treated with a standardized alcohol withdrawal regimen including a phenobarbital taper (alcohol withdrawal dosing days 2–7), thiamine, folic acid, multivitamin supplementation and supportive care. Methadone was initiated for opioid dependence and coordinated with addiction services. He received prophylactic heparin, bowel regimen (docusate, senna, bisacodyl) for opioid/immobility-related constipation, and ramelteon and diphenhydramine as needed for sleep. Influenza vaccine was administered during the stay. Respiratory status improved, oxygenation normalized off supplemental oxygen. Hepatic labs were monitored for alcoholic hepatitis; clinical status improved without encephalopathy at discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Primary diagnosis: alcohol dependence with withdrawal delirium (F10.231). Other active problems included acute respiratory failure with hypoxia (J96.01), opioid dependence (F11.20), toxic encephalopathy, alcoholic hepatitis, chronic hepatitis C. Procedures included short-term invasive mechanical ventilation (extubation hospital day 2) and central venous access for acute care.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, oriented to person/place/time, with resolution of active hallucinations and delirium. Ambulates with supervision due to deconditioning and recent delirium; independent with basic ADLs but requires home health supervision for medication administration and fall-risk monitoring.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds: methadone (concentrated oral solution 10 mg/mL with dosing instructions), phenobarbital taper as outpatient days remaining per protocol, thiamine, folic acid, multivitamin liquid, docusate, senna, bisacodyl PRN, diphenhydramine PRN, ramelteon, heparin stopped at discharge (if outpatient VTE prophylaxis not indicated). Arrange home health nursing for medication administration, daily vitals, fall-risk checks, and coordination with outpatient addiction treatment. Follow-up: addiction medicine/OTP within 48–72 hours, primary care in 7 days, psychiatry/addiction psychiatry within 1 week, hepatology/ID for hepatitis C in 1–2 weeks. Labs (CBC, CMP, LFTs) to be drawn in 7 days. Patient counseled on alcohol abstinence and danger signs prompting ED return.

History of present illness: 53-year-old female presented emergently with progressive dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, lower-extremity edema and weight gain over several days. She has known hypertensive heart disease and diastolic heart failure. Admission diagnosis: acute on chronic diastolic (congestive) heart failure secondary to uncontrolled hypertension (I110, I5033). Comorbidities: type 2 diabetes mellitus, secondary pulmonary hypertension, hypothyroidism, asthma, GERD, restless legs, and nicotine use history.

Hospital course: Over a 2.6-day inpatient stay she received guideline-directed acute heart failure management. She was diuresed with IV then oral furosemide with significant symptomatic improvement and 3–4 kg net fluid loss. Blood pressure was controlled using hydralazine and losartan; transient anticoagulant prophylaxis with heparin was given. Cardiac monitoring and chest radiography showed cardiomegaly with pulmonary vascular congestion consistent with volume overload. Transthoracic echocardiogram during admission confirmed diastolic dysfunction with evidence of elevated pulmonary pressures. Electrolytes and renal function were monitored; potassium supplementation provided as needed. Influenza vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: chest x-ray with pulmonary congestion, TTE confirming diastolic dysfunction/secondary pulmonary hypertension, aggressive diuresis (IV furosemide) and medical BP optimization. No invasive procedures required.
