Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable, euvolemic-appearing at rest, ambulates independently at baseline but reports reduced endurance with exertion. Home health recommended for short-term support: daily weight and blood-pressure monitoring, medication reconciliation and adherence support, and fall-risk/mobility assessment.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include furosemide, losartan, hydralazine, levothyroxine, duloxetine, fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, fluticasone nasal spray, potassium chloride as needed, acetaminophen, lorazepam PRN, folic acid and routine diabetes therapy. Heparin discontinued. Labs (BMP) within 48–72 hours post-discharge to reassess electrolytes/renal function. Outpatient follow-up with PCP in 3–5 days and cardiology in 1 week; cardiology to reassess volume status and medications, repeat BNP/echo as indicated. Home health to contact cardiology/ED for weight gain >3 lb in 24 hours, worsening dyspnea, or syncope.

History of Present Illness: 58-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for management of malignant neoplasm of the cervix (ICD-10 C53.9). She has a history of uterine leiomyoma, recurrent HSV dermatitis, prior urinary tract infections, sciatica, anxiety, and insomnia. She underwent planned operative management with intraoperative findings consistent with cervical malignancy; final pathology pending.

Hospital Course: Hospitalized 4.7 days postoperative for pain control, monitoring, and recovery. Postoperative course was uncomplicated by hemorrhage or thromboembolic event. Pain was managed with multimodal therapy (scheduled acetaminophen, NSAID as tolerated, gabapentin, short-term opioid PRN). Antiemetics and bowel regimen were instituted for opioid-related nausea/constipation. Acyclovir continued for chronic herpes viral lesions. DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was provided during the inpatient stay. Anxiety and sleep disturbance were addressed with brief lorazepam and sleep hygiene measures; psychiatry/behavioral health consulted by phone for medication recommendations.

Key Findings and Procedures: Operative procedure(s) completed without intraoperative complications. Relevant diagnoses during stay: cervical cancer (C53.9), HSV dermatitis, leiomyoma, history of UTIs. Postoperative labs and imaging were within acceptable limits; no acute renal or hepatic dysfunction. Wound intact; no signs of infection.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, with controlled pain on oral medications. Ambulates with a cane intermittently for balance and reports assistance with stair climbing; requires home health for wound checks, medication administration assistance, and mobility/fall-risk assessment. Able to perform basic activities of daily living with intermittent assistance.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, ibuprofen (as tolerated), oxycodone IR PRN, gabapentin, lorazepam PRN for severe anxiety, acyclovir, stool softener and PRN laxatives, potassium chloride powder, magnesium oxide, ondansetron/promethazine PRN, loperamide PRN. Home health referral placed for nursing visits 3x/week for 2 weeks for wound care, medication reconciliation, pain and bowel management, and fall-risk mitigation. Follow-up with gynecologic oncology in 1–2 weeks for pathology review and treatment planning; PCP to follow in 1 week. Return precautions given for fever, uncontrolled pain, bleeding, or calf swelling.

History of present illness: 69-year-old male observed for 11 days for complications related to metastatic colon cancer (C18.9) with known secondary disease to liver and lung. He presented with progressive weakness, weight loss, hypoxia and cough. Imaging and clinical course were notable for pulmonary embolism and aspiration pneumonitis. He had severe protein-calorie malnutrition and deconditioning on admission.

Hospital course: The patient was managed on an observation/medical service. He received therapeutic anticoagulation with apixaban for pulmonary embolism and empiric antibiotics (levofloxacin) for aspiration pneumonitis, with clinical improvement in oxygenation and clearing of inflammatory markers. Nutritional support included multivitamin/mineral supplementation and caloric optimization; bowel regimen was initiated (polyethylene glycol and senna) for chronic constipation. He was evaluated by oncology and palliative care; hematology consulted for an acquired coagulation factor deficiency and anemia. A procedure coded 0FB13ZX was performed without immediate complication. Encephalopathy was monitored and improved with supportive measures. Pain was managed with acetaminophen and lidocaine 5% patches as needed; blood pressure managed with lisinopril.

Key findings and procedures: metastatic colon cancer with liver and pulmonary metastases, pulmonary embolism, aspiration pneumonitis, severe protein-calorie malnutrition, acquired coagulation factor deficiency, anemia and thrombocytopenia. Underwent procedural intervention (ICD-10-PCS 0FB13ZX) during stay without peri-procedural complications.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. He remains deconditioned with reduced endurance and requires assistance with ambulation and most instrumental activities of daily living; cognition improved but intermittent confusion persists. Home health services are arranged for skilled nursing, medication administration/education, wound/procedure-site checks as indicated, nutrition support, and physical therapy to improve mobility.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include apixaban, acetaminophen PRN, levofloxacin (complete course as outpatient if indicated), lidocaine 5% patch PRN, lisinopril, multivitamin/minerals, polyethylene glycol and senna, and normal saline flush for any home IV access. Follow-up: oncology and hematology within 7–14 days, primary care in 7 days, and earlier for fever, worsening dyspnea, new bleeding or progressive confusion. Labs (CBC, CMP, coagulation panel) prior to clinic visits.

History of present illness: 71-year-old man with history of acute myeloblastic leukemia in remission after stem cell transplant complicated by chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), hypertension, prior osteonecrosis, and chronic hepatitis B presented to the ED with productive cough, fever, and progressive dyspnea. Chest x-ray demonstrated right lower-lobe consolidation. He was admitted directly for treatment of pneumonia with hypoxemia (SpO2 nadir 88%).

Hospital course: Over a 48-hour hospitalization the patient was treated with IV meropenem and azithromycin, supplemental oxygen (titrated to maintain SpO2 >92%), and subcutaneous heparin for VTE prophylaxis. Blood and sputum cultures remained negative to date. Supportive therapies included acetaminophen, guaifenesin, benzonatate for cough, and continuation of baseline prophylactic/antimicrobial agents related to his transplant history: posaconazole, acyclovir, atovaquone, and entecavir for hepatitis B suppression. Prednisone for chronic GVHD was continued; topical metronidazole gel was applied for skin lesions. Labs showed mild transaminase elevation and expected post-treatment improvement in inflammatory markers. No invasive procedures were required beyond peripheral IV access and chest radiography.

Key findings/procedures: Chest x-ray with RLL consolidation; negative blood/sputum cultures; SpO2 improved with supplemental oxygen. No bacteremia identified.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient medically stable for discharge on home oxygen (2 L/min nasal cannula at rest, use with activity and at night), ambulatory with a walker and requires assistance with ADLs due to deconditioning. Home health nursing arranged for medication administration, IV antibiotic infusion, wound/skin care for GVHD rash, daily vitals/oxygen checks, and PT evaluation.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include home IV meropenem (home infusion), oral azithromycin as directed, posaconazole delayed-release, acyclovir, atovaquone, entecavir, prednisone, gabapentin, benzonatate PRN, guaifenesin, omeprazole, topical metronidazole, and multivitamin. Labs: CBC/CMP within 48–72 hours and weekly while on IV antibiotics/posaconazole; monitor LFTs. Follow-up: PCP in 48–72 hours, oncology/hematology and pulmonary clinic within 7 days, infectious disease as outpatient for antimicrobial management, repeat chest x-ray in 4–6 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

History of present illness: 76-year-old male presented emergently with bright red lower gastrointestinal bleeding and symptomatic anemia. Past medical history notable for chronic atrial fibrillation, hypertensive heart disease with chronic systolic heart failure, metastatic malignancy to bone and intrapelvic nodes, prior TIA, diabetes, and chronic coagulation abnormality. On admission CT abdomen/pelvis demonstrated extensive colonic diverticulosis without perforation or abscess. Hemodynamically stabilized with resuscitation.

Hospital course: Over a 11-day admission the patient underwent volume resuscitation, blood transfusion(s) for symptomatic anemia, serial hematocrit monitoring, and endoscopic evaluation by GI which localized diverticular bleeding but did not require definitive surgical resection. Anticoagulation was held initially; multidisciplinary discussion (Cardiology, Hematology, GI, and Oncology) guided temporary modification of antithrombotic therapy. Diuresis was optimized for acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure. Arrhythmias were rate-controlled with metoprolol. Pain and bowel regimen were managed; glycemic control achieved with insulin as needed.

Key findings and procedures: CT abdomen/pelvis: diverticulosis without perforation/abscess. Colonoscopy: stigmata of diverticular bleeding; no perforation. Transfusion of packed red blood cells administered. Echocardiogram consistent with reduced EF (chronic). No interventional radiology embolization required.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and medication administration. Heart failure symptoms improved with reduced peripheral edema; daily weight monitoring and diuretic adherence required. Diet: regular with sodium restriction; stool softener and bowel regimen in place to minimize recurrence risk.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on aspirin, enoxaparin (as per Hem/Caridology plan), metoprolol tartrate, furosemide, atorvastatin, insulin regimen, docusate, acetaminophen, bismuth subsalicylate PRN, topical nystatin. Planned outpatient follow-up: GI within 1 week, Cardiology in 2 weeks, Hematology/Oncology as outpatient within 1–2 weeks. Home health to provide daily medication management, wound/skin checks, weight/edema monitoring, and assistance with ADLs. Return precautions given for rebleeding, syncope, chest pain, or worsening dyspnea.

History of Present Illness: 76-year-old woman admitted as a same-day surgical patient for evaluation and management of a right lung lesion consistent with a secondary malignant neoplasm (C78.01) with progressive cough. Past medical history notable for prior renal pelvis malignancy, acquired absence of a kidney, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, monoclonal gammopathy, vascular dementia, prior MI/chronic ischemic heart disease, and nicotine use history.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent image-guided thoracic procedures for tissue diagnosis and pleural management (operative codes 0BBC4ZX, 0BTC4ZZ, 07B74ZX, 8E0W4CZ). Intraoperative and immediate postoperative course were uncomplicated. Pain was managed with scheduled acetaminophen and a short course of ketorolac; lidocaine 5% patches provided adjunctive topical relief. She tolerated oral intake, bowel regimen initiated (docusate, senna), and antiemetic ondansetron used PRN. No acute cardiopulmonary or thrombotic complications occurred. Heparin prophylaxis was provided inpatient and discontinued at discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Pathologic tissue obtained for staging; final pathology pending. Procedural notes confirm successful sampling of right lung lesion and management of associated pleural fluid. No immediate surgical complications, minimal bleeding, and stable chest imaging postprocedure.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and afebrile at discharge. Ambulates with supervision; baseline cognitive impairment from vascular dementia limits independent medication management and complex ADLs. Home health nursing arranged for wound and procedural site checks, medication reconciliation, and fall risk assessment. Physical therapy will provide short-term visits for gait training and transfer safety; occupational therapy for ADL support and adaptive equipment evaluation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, ketorolac (short course), lidocaine 5% patch PRN, albuterol nebulizer PRN, docusate, senna, donepezil, memantine, sertraline, levothyroxine, metoprolol succinate, guaifenesin ER, ondansetron PRN, and routine IV flush supplies as needed. Heparin discontinued. Follow-up: Thoracic surgery/clinic in 7–14 days for wound check and pathologic review; oncology to be contacted for further staging and management pending pathology; primary care within 7 days. Home health to report any fever, increasing dyspnea, wound drainage, or significant decline in function immediately.

Brief history of present illness: 27-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease on chronic dialysis presented on observation status with fever, rigors and positive blood cultures. She was found to have sepsis secondary to Staphylococcus species and acute infective endocarditis related to an infected intracardiac/vascular device (T82.7xxA). Hospital course: Over a 12-day admission she developed severe sepsis without shock. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus species; thrombocytopenia and anemia were addressed with transfusion support as indicated and hematology consultation. She remained dialysis-dependent and received scheduled hemodialysis sessions during the admission. Infectious disease and cardiology were involved; transesophageal echocardiography confirmed valvular vegetation. The infected cardiac/vascular device was extracted with intraoperative debridement and appropriate cultures were obtained. She was treated with targeted IV antibiotics (cefazolin) and supportive care (IV fluids, glycemic control, analgesia). Renal and electrolyte abnormalities were managed with dialysis and medication adjustments (cinacalcet, doxercalciferol, epoetin alfa as part of anemia management). A tunneled dialysis catheter was maintained and heparin dwell protocol instituted per dialysis team.

Key findings and procedures: positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus sp.; TEE demonstrating valvular vegetation; device extraction and debridement; ongoing hemodialysis access management. Procedures performed included device extraction and placement/management of dialysis access; multiple dialysis sessions completed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically improved, afebrile for >48 hours, hemodynamically stable, with improving leukocytosis and platelet count. Ambulates short distances with minimal assistance and is independent with most activities of daily living but requires support for IV antibiotic administration, wound care and transport to outpatient dialysis.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharged on IV cefazolin via home infusion for planned course per Infectious Disease, heparin catheter dwell per dialysis protocol, cinacalcet and doxercalciferol, epoetin alfa as outpatient dialysis-based injections, aspirin, stool softener and PRN acetaminophen. Follow-up: Infectious Disease within 7 days, Nephrology/dialysis team within 3 days, Cardiology in 2 weeks, and Primary Care as needed. Home health to provide IV antibiotic administration, wound dressing changes, vascular access care, medication administration and assistance with ADLs.

History of Present Illness: 64-year-old male admitted via direct emergency for progressive weakness, dizziness and reduced oral intake for several days. Initial evaluation revealed clinical dehydration with associated hyperkalemia. History is notable for type 2 diabetes on long-term insulin, essential hypertension, ulcerative colitis, opioid and alcohol use disorders, and peripheral polyneuropathy.

Hospital Course: Patient received isotonic crystalloid resuscitation (0.9% NaCl) with clinical improvement in volume status. Hyperkalemia was treated acutely with IV dextrose 50% and insulin; magnesium and phosphate replacement were given as indicated. Antiemetic therapy (ondansetron) controlled nausea. Heparin prophylaxis was used while inpatient. Buprenorphine-naloxone therapy was continued for opioid dependence. Bowel regimen adjusted with psyllium and diphenoxylate-atropine for symptomatic control. Glucagon and glucose gel were available for hypoglycemia as needed. Blood glucose and electrolytes were monitored and trended to acceptable ranges prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Significant lab abnormalities on admission included elevated serum potassium and markers consistent with volume depletion; both corrected with therapy. No invasive procedures were required other than peripheral IV access and routine monitoring. No evidence of acute cardiac ischemia on telemetry/ECG during hospitalization.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged in stable medical condition with improved hydration, normalized electrolytes, and stable glycemic control. He ambulates with mild unsteadiness related to baseline polyneuropathy and deconditioning; home health nursing and a short course of physical therapy are arranged to assist with safe mobility and ADL support. Cognitive status intact; able to participate in medication teaching.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include Buprenorphine-Naloxone 8/2 mg per home regimen, home insulin regimen (continue and monitor), ondansetron PRN, diphenoxylate-atropine PRN, psyllium wafer daily, Neutra-Phos as directed, and standard supplies (0.9% NaCl flush, glucose gel). Arrange outpatient follow-up: primary care within 3–5 days, endocrinology for diabetes management, and addiction services/MAT within 1–2 weeks. Outpatient labs (BMP) within 48–72 hours and sooner if symptomatic. Home health nursing to monitor vitals, electrolytes, insulin administration, medication reconciliation, and fall risk mitigation.

HPI: 56-year-old male observed for 3.1 days for acute respiratory distress after an apparent aspiration event. He presented with cough, dyspnea and hypoxia following emesis and was diagnosed with aspiration pneumonitis (J69.0). Significant medical history includes metastatic lung disease (C78.00), prior radiation to the chest with resultant pulmonary manifestations, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, nicotine dependence, and prior mood disorder.

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to observation for respiratory support and monitoring. He received supplemental oxygen with improvement in saturations, bronchodilator nebulizer treatments (ipratropium-albuterol), systemic corticosteroid for airway inflammation, and empiric intravenous antibiotics later transitioned to oral levofloxacin to cover aspiration-related bacterial infection. DVT prophylaxis with heparin was administered. Pain was managed with short-acting oxycodone as needed; chronic pain regimen includes fentanyl patch. Gastroprotection was provided with pantoprazole/omeprazole as indicated. No invasive mechanical ventilation was required. Speech therapy evaluated dysphonia and recommended aspiration precautions and swallow safety measures.

Key findings and procedures: Chest imaging consistent with aspiration pneumonitis versus radiation changes; oxygenation improved to baseline with therapy. Procedures coded include peripheral IV access and bedside respiratory therapy interventions (nebulized treatments, oxygen titration). No acute surgical procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Respiratory status: improved oxygen saturation at rest on room air; mild exertional dyspnea persists. Functional status: ambulatory with baseline assistance for some ADLs; requires support for medication administration and activity pacing. Home health nursing requested for daily medication reconciliation, vital sign and oxygen monitoring as needed, and assistance with ADL support.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on prescribed home meds including levofloxacin (complete course), inhaled ipratropium-albuterol PRN, pantoprazole/omeprazole, docusate, atenolol, fluoxetine, fentanyl patch (per prior regimen), alprazolam PRN, topical betamethasone as needed, and analgesics (oxycodone PRN). Follow-up with primary care within 48–72 hours, pulmonology within 1–2 weeks, and oncology as scheduled. Home health will coordinate swallow precautions and monitor for recurrent aspiration.

91-year-old male admitted under observation for acute influenza (ICD-10 J09X3) with predominant gastrointestinal symptoms. He presented with fever, cough, nausea and diarrhea of 24–48 hours’ duration. Past medical history notable for atherosclerotic coronary artery disease with prior CABG (I25.10, Z95.1), unspecified atrial flutter (I48.92), and chronic thrombocytopenia (D69.6). There was reported difficulty with medication adherence at baseline (Z91.19).

Hospital course: Patient observed for approximately 24 hours. Rapid influenza testing positive; started on oseltamivir and supportive care including acetaminophen for symptom control, nebulized ipratropium-albuterol for wheeze, and subcutaneous heparin for VTE prophylaxis. Hydration and antiemetic measures were provided; bowel regimen initiated with docusate and senna. Thrombocytopenia was noted on admission labs; counts were stable and trended without bleeding signs during stay. Cardiac rhythm showed atrial flutter without hemodynamic instability. No invasive procedures were required. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge per institutional protocol.

Key findings/procedures: Positive influenza A, stable CBC with chronic thrombocytopenia, telemetry without acute ischemic changes, no supplemental oxygen requirement, peripheral IV for fluids removed prior to discharge.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient clinically improved, afebrile, hemodynamically stable and ambulatory with assistance. Cognitive baseline intact; requires home support for medication management and short-distance ambulation due to deconditioning and fall risk. Home health services recommended for nursing visits to monitor vitals, respiratory status, platelet count, and medication reconciliation.

Medications at discharge: Oseltamivir (complete 5-day course as outpatient), acetaminophen PRN, docusate sodium, senna, guaifenesin, ipratropium-albuterol nebulizer PRN, subcutaneous heparin (per local protocol), sodium chloride 0.9% flush supplies as needed, and documentation of influenza vaccine given.

Follow-up: Primary care visit within 48–72 hours for clinical re-evaluation and CBC, cardiology follow-up for atrial flutter/anticoagulation management within 1–2 weeks, and urgent return precautions for fever, worsening dyspnea, bleeding or syncope.

History of Present Illness: 78-year-old male admitted under observation for complications related to newly identified extranodal B-cell lymphoma (ICD-10 C85.19) and developed tumor lysis physiology with acute kidney injury. Admission was also notable for type 2 myocardial infarction and acute on chronic diastolic congestive heart failure exacerbation. Length of stay 10.9 days.

Hospital Course: Patient was managed with aggressive IV fluids, allopurinol and rasburicase consideration for tumor lysis prophylaxis, electrolyte repletion, and close urine output monitoring. Cardiac care included hemodynamic monitoring, guideline-directed medical therapy adjustments for heart failure (carvedilol and losartan held/adjusted as tolerated), and troponin trend consistent with type 2 MI; cardiology consulted. AKI improved with supportive care but did not fully normalize. Thrombocytopenia and anemia were monitored; transfusion was not required. Infectious disease/oncology recommended prophylactic antimicrobials (acyclovir, atovaquone) and filgrastim support per protocol pending outpatient chemotherapy planning. Pain and anxiety were controlled with short courses of lorazepam and topical lidocaine as needed.

Key Findings and Procedures: Relevant labs demonstrated laboratory evidence of tumor lysis syndrome with elevated uric acid/creatinine at presentation and subsequent improvement. Imaging and cardiac testing consistent with non-ST elevation ischemic injury. Procedures included vascular access placement for IV therapy and central access as indicated, and diagnostic procedures per oncology workup (see chart for specific procedure codes 3E04305, 009U3ZZ, 3E0R305).

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with assistance, requires home health skilled nursing for IV medication administration, weekly lab draws (BMP, CBC, uric acid), and assistance with ADLs due to deconditioning. Fall risk moderate; requires cane/walker and caregiver supervision.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include allopurinol, atorvastatin, atovaquone, carvedilol/losartan regimen adjustments as tolerated, famotidine, filgrastim-sndz per oncology plan, acyclovir, and PRN symptomatic meds. Follow-up: hematology/oncology within 3–7 days, cardiology within 7 days, nephrology PRN for persistent AKI. Home health to provide skilled nursing for IV therapy, medication administration, vital signs, and coordination of outpatient appointments.

48-year-old female admitted emergently for acute kidney injury (AKI, N17.9) with associated dehydration and transient neurologic symptoms including aphasia. Admission: patient presented to ED with confusion/aphasia and presyncope; initial evaluation notable for hypotension/orthostatic changes and hypovolemia. Point-of-care glucose low requiring dextrose/glucose gel and glucagon in ED. CT head was without acute intracranial hemorrhage or infarct. EKG demonstrated known left bundle-branch block. Hospital length of stay 1.7 days; patient stabilized with isotonic and dextrose-containing IV fluids, electrolyte repletion, and targeted glycemic support.

Hospital course: Patient received aggressive volume resuscitation (IV normal saline and D10W as needed), potassium and magnesium replacement, and short-term insulin for hyperglycemia management. Heparin prophylaxis was administered while inpatient. Renal function improved with fluids; urine output adequate and no dialysis required. Neurologic deficits improved but residual mild expressive aphasia persisted at discharge. Orthostatic hypotension symptoms improved with increased oral intake and education on positional changes.

Key findings/procedures: AKI secondary to pre-renal azotemia from dehydration with clinical response to fluids. No acute intracranial process on imaging. EKG with LBBB; no arrhythmia requiring intervention. No invasive procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Medically stable for discharge. Ambulates with mild unsteadiness and requires assistance for some ADLs; home health recommended for medication administration, fall-risk precautions, orthostatic BP monitoring, daily weights, and urine output assessment. Cognitive/communication impairment improved but speech therapy evaluation recommended outpatient.

Medications at discharge (selected): Atorvastatin, Clonazepam, Famotidine, Lamotrigine, Magnesium oxide, Potassium chloride (oral replacement as needed), Sertraline, Insulin (subcutaneous regimen), and instructions for oral glucose agents as previously used. IV therapies discontinued; supplies for SC insulin provided.

Follow-up: PCP within 48–72 hours for medication review and BMP; nephrology clinic within 7 days for renal follow-up and repeat labs; cardiology within 2 weeks for LBBB/orthostasis; speech therapy outpatient referral. Home health to monitor vitals, labs, meds, and support ADLs.

Brief history of present illness: 53-year-old male presented emergently with 48 hours of fever, malaise, cough, and decreased oral intake. Significant history includes prior pancreas and kidney transplants (status post, on chronic immunosuppression with mycophenolate), essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and age-related osteoporosis.

Hospital course: This was a short ED observation admission (0.9 day). Initial exam showed fever and tachycardia; patient received acetaminophen, IV iso-osmotic dextrose for dehydration, ondansetron for nausea, and a single empiric dose of piperacillin-tazobactam in the ED prior to infectious assessment. Labs demonstrated mild lymphopenia but no leukocytosis; basic metabolic panel at baseline. Blood and urine cultures were obtained and are pending/returned without growth to date. Chest radiograph showed no focal consolidation. Given clinical improvement and low suspicion for bacterial focal infection, antibiotics were not continued. Heparin prophylaxis was given while in observation. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge per protocol. Immunosuppressive therapy (mycophenolate mofetil) was continued per transplant team recommendation.

Key findings and procedures: vital signs stabilized and patient was afebrile prior to discharge; no focal bacterial source identified; blood/urine cultures negative to date; transplant team concurrence to continue baseline immunosuppression; influenza vaccination administered.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake. Ambulatory and independent with transfers and most activities of daily living; requires assistance from home health for medication reconciliation, monitoring for infection, and reinforcement of transplant-related precautions.

Medications and follow-up plan: Continue home medications including mycophenolate mofetil, amlodipine, carvedilol, aspirin, atorvastatin, famotidine, omeprazole, magnesium oxide, brimonidine ophthalmic, and acetaminophen PRN. No outpatient antibiotics prescribed. Home health nursing arranged for wound/no-wound surveillance, daily vital sign checks and medication management for the next 48–72 hours with reassessment. Follow-up with transplant clinic within 48–72 hours for clinical review and laboratory monitoring (CBC, CMP, and immunosuppressant levels as directed by transplant team). Primary care follow-up in 1 week. Return to ED for fever >100.4°F, increased dyspnea, or other concerning symptoms.

History of Present Illness: 25-year-old woman with known overlap connective tissue disease on hydroxychloroquine and leflunomide presented to the ED with 48 hours of pleuritic, substernal chest pain worse when supine and improved when leaning forward, associated low-grade fever, myalgias and polyarthralgia. She reported recent contact with a person with suspected COVID-19. 

Hospital Course: Admitted directly from the ED (length of stay 1.2 days). Initial evaluation demonstrated diffuse ST-segment elevations with PR depressions on ECG and elevated inflammatory markers (CRP/ESR); serial cardiac troponins were within normal limits. Bedside transthoracic echocardiogram showed no clinically significant pericardial effusion. Diagnosis of acute pericarditis was made in the setting of underlying inflammatory/overlap syndrome and known cryoglobulinemia. She was treated with high-dose ibuprofen, colchicine, and a short prednisone taper given her autoimmune background. Analgesia (ketorolac and short opioid doses) was used for breakthrough pain. She remained hemodynamically stable with improvement in pain and inflammatory markers prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: 12-lead ECG consistent with acute pericarditis (diffuse ST elevation/PR depression), transthoracic echocardiogram without significant effusion, labs notable for elevated inflammatory markers and negative troponin series. IV access and routine laboratory monitoring were performed; no invasive procedures required.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in improved clinical condition, hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with mild pain limiting endurance. Home health arranged to assist with medication administration, daily vital sign and symptom monitoring, and supervision/assistance with ambulation and activities of daily living as needed. Patient educated on red flags (worsening chest pain, dyspnea, syncope, fever).

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on colchicine, ibuprofen (scheduled), prednisone taper, hydroxychloroquine, leflunomide, potassium chloride, magnesium oxide, docusate sodium, senna, short PRN morphine sulfate and ketorolac for breakthrough pain, ramelteon for sleep, and sodium chloride 0.9% flushes as needed for IV line care. Follow-up: cardiology in 1 week, rheumatology in 2 weeks, primary care within 48–72 hours. Return to ED for worsening symptoms.

History of present illness: 54-year-old woman with a history of right knee post-traumatic osteoarthritis presented for elective right total knee arthroplasty (primary diagnosis M17.31). She has comorbid obesity (BMI 33), hypertension, and baseline chronic knee pain limiting ambulation and activities of daily living.

Hospital course: Patient underwent uncomplicated right total knee arthroplasty under general/regional anesthesia. Perioperative IV cefazolin was administered for surgical prophylaxis. Intraoperative blood loss was greater than anticipated, resulting in acute posthemorrhagic anemia (D62); she received one unit packed red blood cells with hemoglobin improvement and remained hemodynamically stable. Postoperatively she received multimodal analgesia including oral acetaminophen, gabapentin, scheduled ketorolac as tolerated, and short-acting IV hydromorphone for breakthrough pain. Aspirin was started for VTE prophylaxis. There was a brief postoperative wound seroma that was managed conservatively and resolved; no return to OR was required. She received influenza quadrivalent vaccine prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Right total knee arthroplasty (ICD-10-PCS 0SRC0J9) with revision/repair procedure code 0SPC04Z documented for intraoperative management of joint structures. Postoperative course notable for acute anemia treated with transfusion; otherwise no infectious complications. Vital signs remained within acceptable limits; final hemoglobin stable; surgical dressing intact with minimal drainage.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable for discharge to home with home health services. Pain is controlled on oral regimen. Ambulates short distances with a rolling walker and requires assistance for stair negotiation and some transfers. Independent with light self-care with intermittent assistance; requires home health PT for gait training and OT for ADL support and wound care.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, gabapentin, ketorolac PRN, aspirin 81 mg daily, stool softeners (docusate, bisacodyl PRN), calcium carbonate, home antihypertensive hydrochlorothiazide, and other usual home meds. Outpatient orthopedic follow-up in 10-14 days for wound check/suture removal; home health to begin PT/OT and daily wound assessment. Return precautions and emergency instructions provided.

Brief HPI: 84-year-old female presented emergently after perioperative exposure to anesthesia with acute hypoxemia and cough consistent with chemical pneumonitis. She had progressive dyspnea and oxygen desaturation shortly after the event, prompting ED evaluation and admission. Past medical history notable for chronic kidney disease, hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, asthma, and prior benign colonic neoplasms.

Hospital course: Patient admitted for observation and respiratory support (length of stay 1.9 days). Initial chest radiograph demonstrated bibasilar and perihilar air‑space opacities consistent with aspiration/chemical pneumonitis. She required supplemental oxygen (up to 4 L NC) and improved to stable oxygenation on 2 L NC. Managed with bronchodilator therapy (nebulized albuterol and ipratropium-albuterol), inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta-agonist regimen, systemic corticosteroid taper, and empiric antibiotic therapy with clindamycin for suspected aspiration. Electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia) were corrected and IV fluids provided. Venous thromboembolism prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was administered. Bronchoscopy with airway toilet and bronchoalveolar lavage was performed for diagnostic sampling; cultures pending at discharge. No acute surgical intervention required.

Key findings/procedures: hypoxemia responsive to low-flow oxygen; chest radiograph consistent with chemical pneumonitis; bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage performed (samples sent for gram stain, culture, and routine respiratory panel). Labs showed transient metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia which were corrected.

Discharge condition and functional status: patient is medically stable and ambulates short distances with a rolling walker with supervision. Requires low-flow home oxygen (2 L NC) intermittently for exertional dyspnea and will need assistance with medication administration and nebulized treatments while home health completes initial teaching and safety/fall assessment.

Medications and follow-up: discharged with albuterol inhaler and neb solution, ipratropium-albuterol neb, fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, clindamycin oral to complete prescribed course, acetaminophen PRN, aspirin, diltiazem ER, hydrochlorothiazide, and instructions for home oxygen. Home health arranged for medication management, oxygen teaching, wound/fall risk and vitals monitoring. Follow-up with primary care in 48–72 hours, pulmonology within 1–2 weeks, and nephrology as outpatient for CKD management. Return sooner for fever, worsening dyspnea, or new confusion.

66-year-old male admitted to observation for acute pancreatitis presenting with acute epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting. Past medical history notable for hyperlipidemia, essential hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, nicotine dependence, and prior dehydration episodes. On arrival he was hypoxemic and hyponatremic with elevated pancreatic enzymes and acute kidney injury. Imaging confirmed pancreatitis without necrosis or infection. Primary diagnosis: acute pancreatitis (K85.90) with comorbid AKI (N17.9), hyponatremia (E87.1) and hypoxemia/atelectasis (J98.11, R09.02).

Hospital course: Patient was managed with aggressive IV fluid resuscitation (Lactated Ringers), bowel rest initially, antiemetics, and analgesia (hydromorphone PRN, acetaminophen). Thromboprophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was given. Oxygen supplementation and respiratory therapy (incentive spirometry) were provided for atelectasis and hypoxemia with marked improvement off supplemental oxygen prior to discharge. Electrolyte abnormalities and serum creatinine trended toward baseline; fluid balance was carefully adjusted to address transient fluid overload and subsequent euvolemia. Glycemic control addressed with insulin while inpatient. No endoscopic or surgical intervention was required.

Key findings/procedures: elevated pancreatic enzymes and CT abdomen consistent with acute interstitial pancreatitis; no necrosis or collection. Supportive measures only. Serial labs showed improving renal function and sodium. No invasive procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable and euvolemic. Ambulates with minimal assistance due to deconditioning and will benefit from home health for skilled nursing and occupational support. Independent with light ADLs but requires assistance with medication management and monitoring; home health to provide short-term skilled nursing visits for IV/medication reconciliation, wound/skin checks as needed, and reinforcement of activity and breathing exercises.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on acetaminophen PRN, docusate, albuterol inhaler PRN, atorvastatin and fenofibrate for hypertriglyceridemia, carvedilol and aspirin for cardiac comorbidity, and insulin regimen as instructed. Outpatient follow-up with primary care in 3–5 days for repeat BMP and metabolic panel, GI clinic in 2 weeks, and nephrology if creatinine remains elevated. Smoking cessation counseling provided. Home health arranged for nursing visits and physical therapy referral as needed.

History of Present Illness: 41-year-old male presented to the emergency department with acute substernal chest pain and diaphoresis. Emergency workup demonstrated ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Past medical history notable for ischemic cardiomyopathy, chronic systolic heart failure, nicotine dependence, and prior coronary disease.

Hospital Course: Patient was admitted emergently and treated with antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation. He underwent urgent percutaneous coronary intervention with placement of a drug-eluting stent to the culprit coronary lesion. He had transient ventricular arrhythmia in the early hospital course managed medically. He developed acute kidney injury on admission which improved toward baseline with IV fluids and optimization of perfusion. Heart failure was treated with diuretics and guideline-directed medical therapy was initiated/adjusted (beta-blocker, ACE inhibitor, nitrates ± hydralazine as tolerated). He received smoking cessation counseling and the influenza vaccine prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: ECG on admission consistent with anterior/inferior STEMI. Coronary angiography identified an occlusive culprit lesion treated with successful PCI and drug-eluting stent (no immediate complications). Transthoracic echocardiogram showed reduced LVEF (~30–35%) with global hypokinesis, consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy. Creatinine peaked during admission and trended down to near-baseline. Brief episodes of ventricular tachycardia were controlled without further intervention.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, chest pain-free, and ambulatory with assistance as needed. He requires home health nursing for early post-PCI monitoring (access site checks), daily weight and edema assessment, medication reconciliation, and reinforcement of heart-failure self-care and activity restrictions. He is independent with most ADLs but fatigues with exertion; anticipated progressive improvement with outpatient cardiac rehabilitation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on aspirin, clopidogrel (DAPT), atorvastatin, carvedilol, lisinopril, furosemide, isosorbide dinitrate ± hydralazine, and other home meds (acetaminophen, fluoxetine) as listed. Heparin stopped; morphine used only acutely. Follow-up: cardiology clinic in 1 week, primary care in 1 week, nephrology PRN for renal follow-up, baseline labs (BMP) within 48–72 hours, and referral to outpatient cardiac rehabilitation. Home health nursing arranged to begin within 24–48 hours.

History of present illness: 25-year-old woman, 39 weeks gestation, presented urgently in presumed premature cervical change with advanced dilation and concern for cervical incompetence. She was GBS-positive on screening and had a history notable for a prior herpesviral infection (unspecified). Labor was managed with augmentation and intrapartum antibiotics for GBS prophylaxis.

Hospital course: Patient underwent spontaneous vaginal delivery of a single live term neonate (39 weeks). Labor was augmented with oxytocin; intrapartum penicillin/ampicillin administered for GBS prophylaxis. Maternal vital signs and bleeding were within expected limits postpartum. She received routine postpartum care including analgesia, antiemetic (ondansetron), stool softeners and laxatives for constipation prevention, topical perineal care (Dermoplast), and standard newborn care coordination. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge. No surgical complications or retained products of conception were identified. Screening for postpartum mood was normal prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Maternal GBS carrier state documented; intrapartum antibiotics given. Oxytocin infusion for labor augmentation noted. Vaginal delivery uncomplicated; estimated blood loss within normal limits. No operative procedures beyond routine delivery interventions.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, with pain controlled on oral medications. She ambulates independently with steady gait but requires assistance with newborn care tasks initially; able to perform personal hygiene and basic ADLs. Home health recommended for early postpartum home visit to assess breastfeeding support, perineal wound healing, pain control, medication reconciliation, and to assist with activity progression and newborn support.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen and ibuprofen as needed for pain, docusate sodium and bisacodyl/milk of magnesia as needed for constipation, ondansetron PRN for nausea, calcium carbonate and simethicone PRN, Dermoplast topical perineal spray. Oxytocin discontinued prior to discharge.

Follow-up: OB clinic appointment in 1–2 weeks for postpartum check (earlier if concerns). Return to ED for fever, heavy bleeding, severe pain, wound changes, or signs of infection. Home health to coordinate visit within 48–72 hours for wound check, medication assistance, breastfeeding support, and vital signs monitoring.

Reason for admission: 47-year-old male admitted emergently for symptomatic secondary thrombocytopenia (ICD-10 D69.59) with associated drug-induced fever and headache. Brief HPI: Patient presented from home with fever, headache, easy bruising and petechiae. History notable for recent antimalarial use and prior infectious disease history. Past medical history significant for essential hypertension, irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea, and nicotine dependence.

Hospital course: Initial evaluation showed thrombocytopenia and mild transaminase elevation. Blood cultures and focused infectious workup were obtained; imaging was nonfocal. Antimalarial therapy was identified as the likely offending agent and was discontinued. He received supportive care including IV fluids (Lactated Ringers), single-dose IV ceftriaxone in ED, and initiation of oral doxycycline for empiric coverage while awaiting cultures. Subcutaneous heparin was administered for VTE prophylaxis during hospitalization. Fever and headache resolved with discontinuation of the culprit drug and symptomatic management (acetaminophen, ondansetron PRN). Platelet count demonstrated an improving trend without need for platelet transfusion. Influenza vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Positive findings included thrombocytopenia with improving platelet trend and transiently elevated AST/ALT. No invasive procedures were required beyond peripheral IV placement and routine blood draws. No blood product transfusion.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and ambulatory at baseline with minimal assistance for ADLs. Home health nursing recommended for initial post-discharge period for medication reconciliation, daily vital sign and bleeding-precautions education, and repeat laboratory draws (platelet count, CBC, CMP) until hematology follow-up.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include: doxycycline 100 mg PO BID (complete course), acetaminophen PRN, polyethylene glycol and senna for bowel regimen, potassium chloride as indicated, amlodipine for BP, ramelteon nightly, ondansetron PRN. Avoid NSAIDs/antiplatelet agents. Hematology follow-up within 3–5 days for platelet management, primary care in 48–72 hours, and repeat labs in 48–72 hours or sooner if bleeding. Return to ED for any new bleeding, syncope, or recurrent fever.

Hospital Discharge Summary

History of Present Illness: 58-year-old female admitted urgently with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and septic physiology in the setting of known biliary prosthesis. Imaging and labs were consistent with obstructive cholangitis due to displacement/complication of a bile duct stent and infectious/inflammatory reaction to an internal prosthetic device. Relevant comorbidities include acute lymphoblastic leukemia not in remission with neutropenia, chronic hepatitis C, hypertension, and chronic anemia.

Hospital Course: Patient received broad-spectrum IV antibiotics with de-escalation based on cultures, volume resuscitation, and supportive care. Hematology/Oncology and GI were consulted. Filgrastim was administered to address neutropenia with good clinical response. She required transfusion for acute posthemorrhagic anemia. Interventional endoscopy (ERCP) was performed to evaluate and manage biliary stent complication; stent manipulation/adjustment was completed without immediate complication. Blood cultures were monitored; no ongoing bacteremia at discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging confirmed biliary obstruction and stent displacement. Labs notable for neutropenia (improved after filgrastim), anemia requiring transfusion, and inflammatory markers elevated on admission with subsequent decline. Procedure performed: endoscopic biliary stent evaluation and management (ERCP and stent manipulation).

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and ambulatory with assistance for longer ambulation. She remains functionally independent for basic activities of daily living but requires home health for medication administration (subcutaneous filgrastim) and monitoring given recent neutropenia and recent procedure.

Medications at Discharge and Plan: Prescribed ciprofloxacin and metronidazole to complete antibiotic course, filgrastim 300 mcg subcutaneously per oncology orders (home health to administer), ferrous sulfate, docusate, gabapentin, lorazepam PRN, antihistamines as needed, and other chronic meds (allopurinol, furosemide, etc.). Follow-up: GI/Interventional Radiology within 7 days for stent reassessment, Hematology/Oncology within 48–72 hours, and primary care within 72 hours. Labs (CBC with differential, CMP) to be drawn by home health per orders.

History of Present Illness: 42-year-old male admitted to observation for progressive weight loss, poor oral intake and functional decline consistent with adult failure to thrive (R62.7). Past medical history notable for metastatic malignancy (C79.9) with known primary bladder cancer (C67.9), severe protein-calorie malnutrition (E43), CKD stage 3 (N18.30), anemia of neoplastic disease (D63.0), benign prostatic hyperplasia, neuropathic symptoms, and prior urinary diversion/other artificial urinary tract opening status (Z93.6) with external collection bag.

Hospital Course: The patient was observed for 6.8 days for optimization of pain control, nutritional status, medication reconciliation and functional rehabilitation. He received IV fluids, serial laboratory monitoring, nutritional consultation with initiation of high-protein supplementation and appetite strategies, and VTE prophylaxis with enoxaparin. Pain regimen was optimized with scheduled acetaminophen, gabapentin and oral hydromorphone for breakthrough pain; lorazepam provided PRN anxiolysis. Bowel regimen (docusate, bisacodyl, milk of magnesia/glycerin suppositories) was implemented for opioid-associated constipation. Heparin flushes and urinary bag care maintained catheter patency.

Key Findings and Procedures: Laboratory studies confirmed anemia and chronic kidney disease stage 3 with stable electrolytes. Nutritional status remained poor but improved incrementally with supplementation. ICD-10-PCS procedure 0T25X0Z was performed during the admission without immediate complication; documentation reflects endoscopic bladder intervention and management of urinary diversion. No acute cardiopulmonary events occurred.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable and afebrile at discharge. Pain is controlled on oral regimen. He remains deconditioned with decreased endurance and requires assistance for transfers and ADLs; home health nursing and PT are arranged for functional restoration and skilled wound/stoma/catheter care. He is independent with a few baseline tasks but needs assistance with medication administration and mobility.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, famotidine, gabapentin, oral hydromorphone PRN, enoxaparin (prophylaxis as directed), stool regimen (docusate, bisacodyl, milk of magnesia/glycerin), aluminum-magnesium hydroxide–simethicone, magnesium sulfate as needed, and heparin flush supplies. Home health nursing, PT, and nutrition services initiated. Outpatient follow-up with PCP within 7 days, oncology/urology in 1–2 weeks, nephrology as outpatient and labs (CBC, BMP) in 48–72 hours.

History of present illness: 76-year-old male admitted directly to the emergency department with acute chest pain and dyspnea. Initial evaluation demonstrated myocardial ischemia consistent with type 2 MI in the setting of known rheumatic mitral and aortic valve disease and chronic diastolic heart failure. He was also noted to have moderate protein-calorie malnutrition, acute post-hemorrhagic anemia, and hyponatremia due to SIADH.

Hospital course: Over a 10.9-day admission the patient underwent diagnostic coronary angiography with percutaneous coronary intervention and stent placement (presence of coronary angioplasty implant noted). He received packed red blood cell transfusion for symptomatic anemia and iron supplementation (ferrous gluconate). SIADH was managed with fluid restriction and adjustment of medications; serum sodium improved. Diuresis with guideline-directed therapy and optimization of heart-failure medications (metoprolol succinate XL, losartan potassium, isosorbide mononitrate ER) led to improved volume status. Nutritional status addressed with dietitian input and initiation of multivitamins/minerals and nutritional counseling. No peri-procedural complications were identified.

Key findings and procedures: diagnostic coronary angiography with stent placement; transfusion for acute post-hemorrhagic anemia; treatment of SIADH and heart failure exacerbation; nutritional intervention for moderate protein-calorie malnutrition.

Discharge condition and functional status: The patient is hemodynamically stable and euvolemic with improved dyspnea. Ambulates with a cane and requires assistance with some instrumental activities of daily living due to deconditioning; cognitive status intact. Home health referral placed for skilled nursing to assist with medication management, monitoring of vitals/weights, blood-draws for CBC and BMP, and guidance on dietary intake and activity progression.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate XL, losartan potassium, isosorbide mononitrate ER, nitroglycerin SL PRN, acetaminophen, loratadine, omeprazole, senna, ferrous gluconate, and multivitamins. Home health to perform saline flushes as indicated for vascular access. Follow-up with cardiology within 7 days, primary care in 3–5 days, CBC and BMP within 48–72 hours and as directed; return to ER for recurrent chest pain, syncope, or worsening dyspnea.

History of Present Illness: 62-year-old female admitted urgently with acute kidney failure with tubular necrosis on background of hypertensive chronic kidney disease stage 5 (N17.0, I12.0, N18.5). She presented with decreased urine output, progressive fatigue, hypotension and encephalopathy concerns. She has known portal hypertension with portal vein thrombosis and ascites, history of pancytopenia and secondary thrombocytopenia. Initial labs showed severe azotemia, metabolic acidosis, and electrolyte abnormalities.

Hospital Course: Over a 2.8-day admission the patient received aggressive fluid resuscitation, correction of electrolyte disturbances, intravenous antibiotics for suspected urosepsis (ciprofloxacin), and bicarbonate therapy for metabolic acidosis. Hemodialysis was initiated emergently for uremia and refractory hyperkalemia; vascular access was placed (ICD-10-PCS 0DJ08ZZ). Hemodynamic status stabilized and mental status improved. Platelet counts and pancytopenia were monitored; transfusion was not required. Ascites management included diuretics adjustment and sodium restriction; no paracentesis required. Liver disease and portal hypertension were addressed with lactulose and rifaximin for encephalopathy prophylaxis.

Key Findings and Procedures: acute tubular necrosis with CKD stage 5, portal vein thrombosis, ascites, and thrombocytopenia. Procedure: vascular access placement for dialysis (0DJ08ZZ) and initiation of inpatient hemodialysis.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged medically stable, hemodynamically stable and neurologically improved. Ambulates with assistance due to deconditioning; requires help with transfers and activities of daily living for 1–2 weeks and home health nursing support for medication administration and monitoring of intake/output and dialysis coordination.

Medications at Discharge: Ciprofloxacin (complete course as outpatient as indicated), ferrous sulfate, levothyroxine, omeprazole, potassium chloride, sodium bicarbonate, lactulose, rifaximin, nystatin topical cream, insulin regimen as outpatient with glucose monitoring, and supplies for outpatient dialysis access care. Dextrose 50%, glucagon and glucose gel provided for hypoglycemia education and rescue use.

Follow-up Plan: Nephrology within 48–72 hours to arrange ongoing dialysis and outpatient access care; hepatology for portal hypertension/varices within 2 weeks; hematology for pancytopenia within 1–2 weeks; primary care within 1 week. Home health to provide nursing visits, medication administration, wound/access care, and coordination of outpatient dialysis and labs (BMP, CBC, LFTs) per nephrology.

57-year-old male admitted emergently for severe persistent asthma with acute exacerbation. He presented with progressive dyspnea, wheeze, chest tightness, and increased sputum production over several days with decreased exercise tolerance. Past medical history significant for congenital aortic valve insufficiency, thoracic aortic aneurysm, essential hypertension, obesity, adrenal disorder (history), and coronary atherosclerotic disease.

Hospital course: Patient received aggressive bronchodilator therapy (continuous and intermittent nebulized albuterol), systemic corticosteroids (prednisone taper), inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta-agonist therapy (fluticasone-salmeterol), supplemental oxygen as needed, and mucolytic/expectorant therapy (guaifenesin, saline nebulizations). He received prophylactic enoxaparin while inpatient. Airway clearance procedure performed (ICD-10-PCS 0CJS8ZZ) with removal of retained secretions. He was monitored for cardiac comorbidity-related issues; troponin and ECG were stable. No signs of infection requiring IV antibiotics; viral testing negative. He responded to treatment with progressive improvement in wheeze, respiratory rate normalization, and oxygenation maintained on room air at rest prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: pulmonary exam notable for diffuse expiratory wheeze early with improvement; chest imaging without acute consolidation; procedure to clear airway secretions (0CJS8ZZ). Labs stable; no acute cardiac ischemia identified.

Discharge condition and functional status: Discharged in stable condition. Respiratory status improved — ambulating independently with limited exertional tolerance and able to perform basic ADLs though requires pacing with activity. Home health services arranged for: inhaler/nebulizer technique training, serial pulse oximetry and symptom monitoring, assistance with medication reconciliation and activity progression.

Medications at discharge: Prednisone (taper), fluticasone-salmeterol 250/50 BID, albuterol 0.083% neb solution PRN, montelukast nightly, benzonatate PRN cough, acetaminophen PRN, atorvastatin, pantoprazole, polyethylene glycol, senna PRN. Enoxaparin discontinued at discharge. Tdap administered during admission.

Follow-up: Primary care within 1 week, Pulmonology clinic in 2–4 weeks, Cardiology as outpatient for valve/aneurysm surveillance. Return precautions given for worsening dyspnea, fever, chest pain, or hypoxia.

Chief complaint: Abdominal pain, distension, nausea/vomiting and obstipation. Brief HPI: 83-year-old male admitted to observation for evaluation and management of presumed intestinal obstruction (K56.609). He presented with progressive abdominal distension, nausea, multiple episodes of emesis, and inability to tolerate oral intake. Past history notable for prior abdominal surgery with altered GI anatomy, chronic ascites, known esophageal varices, and B-cell lymphoma. Admission imaging and clinical exam were consistent with an obstructive process with associated aspiration pneumonitis on chest imaging.

Hospital course: Patient was managed conservatively over 8.8 days with bowel rest, IV fluids (NS/Lactated Ringers), serial abdominal examinations, nasogastric decompression as clinically indicated, and bowel regimen. Broad-spectrum coverage with ceftriaxone and metronidazole was administered for aspiration/possible intra-abdominal infection and discontinued prior to discharge per infectious disease guidance. He received DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin while inpatient. Diagnostic paracentesis was performed for ascites evaluation (no therapeutic drain required). Labs and repeat imaging demonstrated interval improvement in bowel dilation and resolution of obstructive symptoms; aspiration pneumonitis improved clinically with supportive care.

Key findings/procedures: CT abdomen/pelvis showing features consistent with intestinal obstruction; chest x-ray with bibasilar infiltrates consistent with aspiration pneumonitis; diagnostic paracentesis; NG decompression and serial abdominal exams.

Discharge condition and functional status: Discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating clear to low-residue diet advancing as tolerated. Mobility: ambulates with assistive device and requires assistance with basic ADLs and medication management — home health nursing recommended for daily visits initially.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, aspirin, bisacodyl PRN, docusate, lactulose for bowel regimen, fenofibrate, finasteride, levothyroxine, lisinopril, and a short oral course of metronidazole as indicated. Home health to monitor vitals, abdominal exam, intake/output, bowel function, medication reconciliation, and assist with ADLs. Follow-up: General surgery within 7–10 days, gastroenterology within 1–2 weeks (varices/ascites management), oncology to follow B-cell lymphoma, and PCP in 1 week.

62-year-old female admitted emergently for severe neoplasm-related pain secondary to metastatic malignancy to bone (primary diagnosis: neoplasm-related pain, ICD-10 G89.3; secondary: C79.51). Past medical history notable for coronary artery disease with prior MI and angioplasty, hyperlipidemia, GERD/esophagitis, history of neuroendocrine-type malignancy with recent radiotherapy.

History of present illness: Patient presented with escalating, refractory axial and extremity bone pain despite home opioids. Pain was associated with decreased mobility and oral intake. No acute neurologic deficit or new cardiopulmonary complaints.

Hospital course: Admitted for analgesic optimization and short inpatient stabilization (LOS 1.7 days). She received IV fluids (lactated Ringer’s), scheduled multimodal analgesia including IV hydromorphone titration, intermittent ketorolac, transition to transdermal fentanyl patch for baseline analgesia, and lidocaine 5% patches for localized pain. Heparin was administered for DVT prophylaxis. Antiemetic and stool softener (docusate) were provided. Cardiac status remained stable; troponin and ECG without acute ischemia. No invasive procedures performed. Pain improved from severe to moderate on regimen but remains present, requiring ongoing home opioid therapy and close follow-up.

Key findings/procedures: Imaging consistent with known osseous metastatic disease; no acute surgical intervention indicated. Pain controlled to tolerable level after analgesic adjustments. Vitals stable at discharge. No complications from radiotherapy noted during stay.

Discharge condition and functional status: Stable for discharge. Requires assistance with ambulation secondary to pain and deconditioning; home health recommended for skilled nursing visits for pain management, medication administration/education, fall-risk assessment, and assistance with ADLs. Continues to have moderate baseline analgesic requirements.

Medications at discharge (partial list): transdermal fentanyl patch (per pain plan), hydromorphone PRN, acetaminophen, ketorolac PRN, lidocaine 5% patches, aspirin, atorvastatin, losartan, metoprolol succinate, docusate, topical/OTC throat lozenges, Maalox formulation as needed. Follow-up: oncology/palliative care within 3–7 days, primary care in 1–2 weeks, cardiology as outpatient for routine CAD management. Return precautions given for uncontrolled pain, new neurologic deficits, fever, or chest pain.

History of present illness: 64-year-old male admitted under observation for acute kidney injury (N17.9) with oliguria and rising creatinine in the setting of multiple comorbidities including chronic diastolic heart failure, stage CKD, prior liver transplant, chronic lymphocytic leukemia with pancytopenia, and suspected toxic encephalopathy. On arrival he had fatigue, decreased oral intake, and altered mentation. SIADH and volume derangements were considered contributors.

Hospital course: Over a 7.9-day observation stay the patient received careful volume management with judicious IV fluids and diuretic adjustments, antibiotic coverage for presumed infectious trigger (levofloxacin), antiviral prophylaxis (acyclovir), and nutrition optimization. Hematology and transplant teams were consulted for pancytopenia and transplant status. A temporary dialysis catheter was placed (procedure documented: 07DR3ZX) and maintained with heparin flushes; the patient did not require ongoing inpatient hemodialysis. Renal function improved from peak but did not fully return to baseline. Encephalopathy improved with correction of metabolic derangements. Midodrine was used intermittently for symptomatic orthostasis. Pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic measures addressed nausea, constipation/diarrhea, and pain.

Key findings and procedures: acute kidney injury with partial recovery, toxic/metabolic encephalopathy improved, persistent cytopenias requiring hematology follow-up, nutrition assessment consistent with mild protein-calorie malnutrition. Procedure: placement of temporary dialysis/vascular access catheter (07DR3ZX). Relevant cultures and imaging were obtained; no focal surgical source identified.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home. Ambulates with assistance intermittently due to deconditioning and orthostatic symptoms; requires help with some ADLs and supervision for medication administration and catheter care. Home health arranged for daily visits initially for wound/catheter care, vital sign and orthostatic monitoring, weight and fluid intake/output tracking, and medication assistance.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, acyclovir, allopurinol, levofloxacin (if ongoing course), midodrine, PPI/H2 blocker, ondansetron as needed, antihistamines, stool agents, and heparin flushes for catheter. Labs (BMP, CBC) to be drawn 2–3× weekly by home health. Follow-up: nephrology within 3–5 days, transplant clinic within 2 weeks, hematology within 1–2 weeks, and primary care in 1 week. Return promptly for fever, worsening confusion, hypotension, decreased urine output, or catheter concerns.

History of Present Illness: 50-year-old man admitted as a surgical same-day admission for repair of an incisional hernia (primary diagnosis K43.2). He has a history significant for separation of muscle (M62.08), prior abdominal surgery with acquired absence of portions of the digestive tract (Z90.49), essential hypertension (I10), hyperlipidemia (E78.5) and nicotine dependence (F17.210). He presented with symptomatic incisional hernia with progressive pain and bulge.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent operative repair with mesh reinforcement and fascial component release (ICD-10-PCS codes 0WUF0JZ, 0KNL0ZZ, 0KNK0ZZ). The immediate postoperative course was uncomplicated. He required short-term IV fluids (D5 1/2 NS, Lactated Ringers, 0.9% NaCl) and inpatient analgesia (hydromorphone then transitioned to oxycodone IR and scheduled acetaminophen). He received subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis and antihypertensive therapy as needed (labetalol, hydralazine inpatient; home oral lisinopril resumed). No signs of surgical site infection, obstruction, or bowel compromise were identified. Pain and bowel function improved; diet advanced to regular and he tolerated oral intake.

Key Findings and Procedures: Successful open incisional hernia repair with mesh reinforcement and component separation. No intraoperative complications. Postoperative vitals and labs were stable; incision clean, dry and intact with minimal serosanguinous drainage.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable at discharge, ambulatory with assistance, independent with most activities of daily living but requires home health assistance for dressing changes and short-term mobility support. Pain is controlled on oral regimen; ambulation and breathing exercises initiated.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include oxycodone IR PRN for breakthrough pain, acetaminophen scheduled/PRN, pantoprazole 40 mg daily, lisinopril for BP, calcium carbonate PRN antacid. Heparin was inpatient only. Home health to provide wound care, medication reconciliation, vital sign and blood pressure monitoring, ambulation support and smoking cessation counseling. Follow-up: surgical clinic in 10–14 days for wound check/staple removal; primary care in 7 days for BP and lipid management.

History of Present Illness: 56-year-old male admitted as a same-day surgical admission and remained inpatient for 7 days for operative management of a hepatic lesion (primary diagnosis D37.6 — neoplasm of uncertain behavior of liver/gallbladder/bile ducts) associated with obstructive cholestasis and portal hypertension. He presented with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, pruritus, and abnormal liver function tests; imaging demonstrated a dominant hepatic mass with biliary dilation and gastric varices.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent operative resection of the hepatic lesion with intraoperative biliary exploration and placement of a surgical drain. Intraoperative findings confirmed a mass consistent with preoperative imaging and portal hypertension with varices; no uncontrolled hemorrhage occurred. Postoperative course was notable for expected pain managed with acetaminophen, nausea controlled with ondansetron, and glycemic management with basal-bolus insulin and continuation of metformin as tolerated. He received DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin while inpatient. No infectious complications, no re‑operation required. Pathology specimens sent; results pending.

Key Findings and Procedures: Preoperative imaging: hepatic mass with biliary obstruction and signs of portal hypertension. Procedures: partial hepatic resection and intraoperative biliary decompression with drain placement. Labs: postoperative LFTs trending down from admission; stable hemoglobin and coagulation indices.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is clinically stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable at discharge. Ambulates with assistance; requires help with stair negotiation and wound dressing but is independent with most basic ADLs. Home health recommended for wound/drain care, medication administration assistance (insulin if needed), and ongoing glucose monitoring.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on acetaminophen, insulin regimen with oral metformin, lisinopril, omeprazole, fluticasone nasal spray, guaifenesin ER, lorazepam PRN, ondansetron PRN, and other home medications reconciled. Home health nurse to visit within 48 hours for wound/drain care, med reconciliation, glucose checks and nursing assessment; outpatient surgical clinic in 7–14 days, hepatology/oncology follow-up in 2 weeks for further management and staging, and primary care follow-up in 1 week for chronic disease management. Pathology results to be communicated at surgical follow-up.

History of present illness: 66-year-old male admitted to observation for 4.8 days with acute upper respiratory infection (J06.9) presenting with cough, increased sputum, dyspnea on exertion, and low-grade fever. Past medical history significant for end-stage renal disease on maintenance hemodialysis, chronic combined systolic and diastolic heart failure, ischemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes with diabetic CKD, prior GI bleeding, and hypotension episodes.

Hospital course: Patient received supportive care including IV fluids and peripheral IV medication administration (procedure 3E1M39Z), targeted antibiotic therapy with doxycycline for presumed bacterial superinfection, inhaled corticosteroid therapy (fluticasone), analgesia/antipyretic as needed, and continuation of his outpatient cardiovascular and dialysis therapies. He underwent chest radiography showing bibasilar atelectasis without focal lobar consolidation. Hemodynamics stabilized after brief fluid resuscitation; no recurrent GI bleeding was identified. Cardiac rhythm remained atrial fibrillation, rate controlled on digoxin. Dialysis was continued per usual schedule during the stay.

Key findings and procedures: CXR: atelectasis. Continued dependence on renal dialysis. Peripheral IV access established for medication/fluids (3E1M39Z). No acute surgical procedures required.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically stable, afebrile, and hemodynamically stable at discharge. Ambulates with steadying assistance and requires help with some activities of daily living; home health referral placed for assistance with ADLs, medication management, and post-discharge monitoring. Home health to monitor vital signs, respiratory status, access site for dialysis, and wound/skin integrity related to vascular access.

Medications and follow-up plan: Continue home medications including doxycycline (complete course), fluticasone inhaler, digoxin, aspirin, calcium acetate and calcitriol for ESRD/mineral bone disease, stool softener PRN, acetaminophen PRN, and glucose gel for hypoglycemia as needed. Home health to assist with medication reconciliation. Follow-up with primary care within 3–5 days, nephrology within 7 days to coordinate dialysis, and cardiology in 1–2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen. Return to ED for fever, progressive dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, or any signs of GI bleeding.

History of present illness: 50-year-old female admitted emergently for acute on chronic heart failure and worsening renal function in the setting of known hypertensive heart disease with chronic kidney disease and diabetes mellitus. She presented with progressive dyspnea, lower extremity edema, and reduced exertional tolerance. Hospital course: The patient was treated with diuresis (furosemide titrated to effect), rate control for atrial arrhythmias (metoprolol succinate optimized; digoxin continued for rate support), and close monitoring of renal function and electrolytes. Anemia related to chronic kidney disease was addressed with iron supplementation and cyanocobalamin. Acute kidney injury improved toward baseline with careful volume management and avoidance of nephrotoxins. Glucose was managed with scheduled insulin per sliding scale; hypoglycemia rescue agents (glucose gel, dextrose 50%, glucagon) were reviewed with patient/caregiver. No invasive cardiac procedures were performed during this admission. Key findings and procedures: Diagnostic evaluation confirmed acute on chronic diastolic (congestive) heart failure with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation/flutter. Labs notable for anemia of CKD and transient elevation in creatinine consistent with AKI on CKD that trended toward baseline with treatment. Echocardiography and telemetry supported rate-controlled arrhythmia without acute ischemic changes. Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, euvolemic on oral diuretics, and ambulatory with a rollator/assistance for longer distances. Home health recommended for nursing follow-up for medication reconciliation, daily weight and edema assessment, and monitoring of blood pressure, heart rate, and blood glucose. Home health will also assist with education on fluid/salt restriction and recognition of decompensation (worsening dyspnea, orthopnea, rapid weight gain). Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge meds include furosemide, metoprolol succinate XL, digoxin, aspirin, insulin regimen, levothyroxine, pravastatin, fenofibrate, ferrous sulfate, cyanocobalamin, polyethylene glycol, senna as needed. Patient instructed to monitor daily weights and blood pressure; return precautions reviewed (weight gain >3 lb/24 hr, increasing dyspnea, lightheadedness). Follow-up with primary care within 7 days, cardiology and nephrology within 1–2 weeks for optimization of heart failure, rhythm management, anticoagulation consideration, and CKD care.

History of present illness: 30-year-old G? at 19 weeks gestation (monochorionic/diamniotic twin pregnancy) presented to ED with acute onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. Imaging was consistent with cholelithiasis with acute cholecystitis. She was admitted emergently and managed medically and operatively.

Hospital course: Over a 2.7-day hospital stay the patient received IV fluids (0.9% NaCl, lactated Ringer), antiemetics (ondansetron), analgesia (morphine followed by oral oxycodone PRN), antibiotics (ampicillin–sulbactam IV), stool regimen and DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin. Maternal–fetal medicine and general surgery consulted. She was taken to the OR for operative removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) without intraoperative complications. Perioperative care included standard fetal monitoring as appropriate and continuation of her home thyroid replacement for hypothyroidism. No signs of preterm labor were noted; fetal heart tones were present and reassuring postoperatively.

Key findings and procedures: Ultrasound demonstrated gallstones with sonographic features of acute cholecystitis. Procedure performed: cholecystectomy (ICD-10-PCS 0FT44ZZ). Pathology consistent with acute calculous cholecystitis. No intra-abdominal hemorrhage or bile leak identified.
