Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable at discharge, afebrile, tolerating oral intake, ambulating independently with mild activity limitation and pain controlled on oral regimen. She is able to perform basic ADLs but will benefit from short-term home health for incision care, administration of enoxaparin injections and medication reconciliation.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen scheduled, oxycodone IR short course PRN, docusate and polyethylene glycol for bowel regimen, oral antibiotic to complete the course (amoxicillin–clavulanate or as directed by surgeon), potassium supplement PRN, and continuation of levothyroxine. Home health to assist with daily wound checks, enoxaparin administration, vital sign monitoring and education. Follow-up with general surgery in 7–10 days, maternal–fetal medicine (MFM) within 7 days, and endocrinology/OB as outpatient. Return to ED for fever, increasing pain, wound erythema/drainage, vaginal bleeding, decreased fetal movement or signs of DVT.

History of Present Illness: 88-year-old male admitted under observation for progressive erythema, swelling, and pain of the penis and groin for 3–4 days. Associated dysuria and urinary frequency. Past history notable for atrial fibrillation on chronic anticoagulation, prior prostate malignancy, intermittent urinary incontinence, hypertension, and insomnia. On admission noted acute delirium likely secondary to infection and acute illness.

Hospital Course: The patient was observed for 3.8 days. Initial evaluation demonstrated cellulitis of the corpus cavernosum and penis (primary diagnosis) with associated groin cellulitis and a urinary tract infection. He received intravenous antibiotics initially with clinical improvement and was transitioned to oral therapy. Delirium improved with treatment of infection and environmental measures; no sedating opioids were required. Rate control for atrial fibrillation was maintained on metoprolol; anticoagulation with warfarin was continued with INR monitoring. Influenza vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Physical exam notable for penile and inguinal erythema without fluctuance or necrosis. Labs showed mild transaminase elevation and leukocytosis which trended down with therapy. Urine studies consistent with UTI; blood cultures were negative. No surgical intervention required. Wound care performed with topical miconazole for associated dermatitis and daily local wound care.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged stable and afebrile, delirium largely resolved but requires supervision for safety and occasional cueing. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and some ADLs; home health ordered for nursing support, wound care, medication reconciliation, and fall risk mitigation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on cephalexin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS for continued antimicrobial coverage, miconazole 2% cream for local care, home warfarin with INR follow-up, losartan and metoprolol continued, ramelteon for sleep, and normal saline flush as needed per IV line policy. Follow-up arranged with primary care in 48–72 hours, urology in 1–2 weeks, and anticoagulation clinic for INR monitoring. Home health nursing referral placed for wound care, medication management, and safety evaluation.

History of Present Illness: 42-year-old woman with morbid obesity (E66.01) and prior adjustable gastric band presented with progressive epigastric pain, increased reflux, and intolerance to oral intake. Imaging and clinical evaluation suggested band-related complication with associated peritoneal adhesions. She was admitted as a same-day surgical admission for operative management.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent laparoscopic removal of the adjustable gastric band and adhesiolysis. Intraoperative findings included dense peritoneal adhesions and partial band erosion; no bowel resection was required. Procedure codes included laparoscopic band removal and adhesiolysis; intra-abdominal drain was left in situ and removed prior to discharge when output was minimal. Postoperatively she was managed with multimodal analgesia (scheduled acetaminophen, gabapentin; short course oral hydromorphone for breakthrough pain; ketorolac as indicated), DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin, famotidine for acid suppression, and glycemic management with insulin. Blood pressure control resumed with losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. No postoperative complications occurred. Vital signs and labs remained stable; patient tolerated advancing diet and ambulation with assistance.

Key Findings and Procedures: Diagnostic imaging consistent with band complication; operative laparoscopic band removal and adhesiolysis performed without enteric injury. Pathology not required. Minimal blood loss; no transfusion.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, pain controlled on oral medications, ambulating with assistance and able to perform most ADLs independently but requires support with stair negotiation and wound care. Home health recommended for incision checks, medication administration support (including insulin teaching and glucose monitoring), and home safety/ambulation assistance.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include oral acetaminophen, short course oral hydromorphone for breakthrough pain, ketorolac as indicated, gabapentin, famotidine, enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily x7 days (DVT prophylaxis), resume losartan and HCTZ, and home insulin regimen with sliding scale adjustments. Follow-up with bariatric surgery clinic in 10–14 days, PCP in 7 days, endocrinology in 2 weeks, and sleep medicine/CPAP follow-up as outpatient. Return to ED for fevers, worsening abdominal pain, increasing incision erythema/drainage, leg swelling or shortness of breath.

History of Present Illness: 76-year-old female admitted under observation after a fall with neck pain and limited mobility. Imaging on arrival demonstrated an unspecified displaced fracture of the fourth cervical vertebra (C4, S12.300A) with associated displaced fracture of C5 (S12.400A) and an unspecified fracture of T5–T6 (S22.059A). She also had symptoms consistent with a urinary tract infection and a prior history notable for gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), chronic kidney disease, essential hypertension, spinal stenosis, gout, and orthostatic hypotension.

Hospital Course: During a 4.1-day observation stay the patient was managed nonoperatively with rigid cervical immobilization, analgesia (acetaminophen), fall precautions, bowel regimen, and DVT prophylaxis. She received targeted antibiotics for a urinary tract infection with clinical improvement and intravenous fluids as needed. Neurosurgery was consulted and recommended conservative management with cervical collar and close outpatient follow-up. Pain was controlled to a tolerable level and neurovascular exam remained stable without focal deficit.

Key Findings & Procedures: CT and plain radiographs confirmed displaced fractures at C4 and C5 and compression-type fractures at T5–T6. No acute spinal cord compression was identified. Consults: neurosurgery and physical therapy. DVT prophylaxis with heparin was administered while inpatient.

Discharge Condition & Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home but requires assistance with activities of daily living and is limited in cervical range of motion. She ambulates short distances with a rolling walker and requires caregiver assistance for transfers and toileting. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing visits and physical therapy to monitor mobility, pain control, medication administration, and fall-risk mitigation.

Medications & Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, allopurinol, colchicine, cyanocobalamin, ezetimibe, famotidine, folic acid, heparin (per discharge plan for DVT prophylaxis), multivitamin, Neutra-Phos, polyethylene glycol, and saline flush supplies. Follow-up: neurosurgery within 7 days, primary care within 7–10 days, nephrology within 4 weeks, and oncology/urology as outpatient for GIST/UTI care. Home health to coordinate medication reconciliation and progressive PT.

History of Present Illness: 51-year-old female admitted for elective left total knee arthroplasty for symptomatic unilateral primary osteoarthritis of the left knee (M17.12). Past medical history notable for obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, anxiety disorder, GERD, menstrual migraine, and tobacco use. She presented with progressive left knee pain and functional limitation refractory to conservative measures.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent left total knee arthroplasty (ICD-10-PCS 0SRD0J9) under general/spinal anesthesia without intraoperative complications. Postoperatively she required brief treatment for postprocedural hypotension that resolved with fluid bolus and monitoring. Pain was managed with multimodal analgesia (acetaminophen, gabapentin, scheduled tramadol and short-acting opioids as needed). DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin was initiated. She had transient postoperative nausea controlled with ondansetron and scopolamine patch PRN. No respiratory events; CPAP use resumed overnight. Mild leukocytosis was observed and trended downward; no infectious source identified. Physical therapy began POD1; she progressed to ambulation with a rolling walker and demonstrated safe transfers with assistance.

Key Findings/Procedures: Left total knee arthroplasty completed without complication. Postop X-rays satisfactory for implant position. Vitals stable at discharge. Labs notable for resolving leukocytosis. No surgical site infection, neurovascularly intact distal to the operative knee.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Ambulation: ambulating with a rolling walker, weight bearing as tolerated with assistance; requires home health PT for gait training and progressive strengthening. ADLs: requires assistance with household ambulation and some transfers; home health OT recommended for adaptive strategies and wound care instruction.

Medications at Discharge (select): acetaminophen, tramadol, gabapentin, short course PRN hydromorphone, enoxaparin subcutaneous for DVT prophylaxis, albuterol inhaler PRN, omeprazole, clonazepam PRN, docusate/senna, HCTZ, magnesium oxide. Patient instructed on enoxaparin administration.

Follow-up: Orthopedic clinic in 10–14 days for wound check/suture removal and postop assessment. PCP follow-up in 1–2 weeks for med reconciliation and optimization. Home health to provide PT/OT, wound checks, medication assistance, and vital sign monitoring with attention to orthostatic symptoms and wound status.

History of Present Illness: 69-year-old male admitted under observation for acute kidney injury (AKI) with concurrent embolic disease and heart failure. He presented with oliguria, gross hematuria, progressive dyspnea, and anemia. Past medical history notable for congestive heart failure, hypertensive heart disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and prior bleeding risk.

Hospital Course: Patient observed for 7 days. Initial management focused on hemodynamic stabilization, volume optimization, and evaluation of hematuria. IV fluids and careful diuresis were titrated to balance renal perfusion and volume status. Apixaban was held on admission for active hematuria and resumed prior to discharge once bleeding source was controlled and urology concurred. A single packed red blood cell transfusion was administered for symptomatic posthemorrhagic anemia with improvement in hemodynamics. Foley catheterization was performed for urinary retention and hematuria management; catheter care and trial of void were performed before discharge. Renal function peaked during admission and subsequently improved with conservative measures; no dialysis was required. Evaluation included imaging consistent with pulmonary embolism without acute cor pulmonale; anticoagulation plan established. Cardiac status monitored and optimized with beta-blocker and guideline-directed heart failure therapy adjustments.

Key Findings and Procedures: AKI (improving), pulmonary embolism (non‑acute cor pulmonale), acute posthemorrhagic anemia (transfused), bladder outlet obstruction with gross hematuria managed with Foley catheter, medication adjustments for congestive heart failure.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is clinically improved, hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with assistive devices for short distances, independent with most ADLs but requires assistance for medication management and home safety due to recent anemia and deconditioning. Home health recommended for skilled nursing and monitoring.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged with acetaminophen, apixaban, carvedilol, fexofenadine, lidocaine jelly, magnesium oxide, Neutra‑Phos, polyethylene glycol, ramelteon, sarna lotion, senna, normal saline flushes, sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim DS, and tamsulosin. Follow-up: PCP within 3–5 days, nephrology 1 week, urology 1 week, cardiology 2 weeks, and home health to monitor vitals, weights, urine output, wound/catheter care, medication reconciliation, and labs (BMP/creatinine) as ordered.

HPI: 32-year-old female admitted under observation for complications related to known malignant neoplasm of the right ovary with progressive malignant ascites and symptomatic decline. Prior history includes hysterectomy (acquired absence of cervix/uterus), essential hypertension, severe protein-calorie malnutrition, depression, and prior palliative care involvement. She was observed for management of ascites, symptomatic anemia/coagulopathy, pain, and optimization for discharge planning.
Hospital course: Patient remained in observation for 9.7 days. Diagnostic paracentesis with symptomatic large-volume ascites drainage was performed with clinical improvement in respiratory comfort and abdominal pain. Supportive care included intravenous fluids, antiemetics, short course dexamethasone for symptom control, electrolyte repletion (magnesium), and nutritional supplementation. Hemostasis was monitored given documented coagulation defect; transfusion was not required. Pain was managed primarily with acetaminophen and topical lidocaine; opioid-sparing measures prioritized. Anticoagulation was transitioned to apixaban on discharge for outpatient thrombosis prophylaxis per consult recommendations; inpatient enoxaparin/heparin were used for inpatient VTE prophylaxis and line flushes as indicated.
Key findings/procedures: Imaging consistent with malignant ascites and known metastatic disease; paracentesis performed with symptomatic benefit. Labs notable for protein-calorie malnutrition and mild electrolyte abnormalities corrected prior to discharge. Multidisciplinary team included oncology, palliative care, nutrition, and social work.
Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, pain controlled on oral regimen, and ambulatory with assistance for transfers and ambulation. Requires home health skilled nursing for dressing/line care, medication administration oversight (apixaban), daily symptom monitoring, and assistance with ADLs and nutrition support.
Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include apixaban, acetaminophen as needed, dexamethasone short taper, famotidine, magnesium supplement, calcium carbonate, stool regimen (bisacodyl), multivitamin. Arrange home health nursing, oncology/palliative clinic follow-up within 7 days, primary care within 1–2 weeks, and outpatient labs (CBC, CMP, coagulation studies) prior to clinic visit. Patient/caregiver educated on signs of bleeding, worsening dyspnea/abdominal distension, and when to seek urgent care.

71-year-old female admitted to observation for 1.7 days for evaluation and management of acute constipation (K59.00) with concurrent urinary tract infection and multiple chronic comorbidities. History of present illness: patient presented with 3–5 days of decreased bowel movements, abdominal discomfort and bloating. She also reported dysuria and frequency. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, age-related osteoporosis, anxiety and insomnia. Patient had recent contact with COVID-19 but was asymptomatic for respiratory illness while inpatient.

Hospital course: initial evaluation included history and physical, point-of-care labs and urinalysis consistent with UTI. Supportive care and conservative bowel regimen were initiated. She received polyethylene glycol, senna and bisacodyl, and a saline enema with documented stool evacuation and symptom improvement. A single dose of ceftriaxone was given in the ED for presumed UTI; no parenteral antibiotic course was continued on discharge pending outpatient follow-up and culture results. Subcutaneous heparin was given for DVT prophylaxis while in facility. No imaging or invasive procedures were required.

Key findings and procedures: positive urinalysis (pyuria) treated empirically; successful bowel disimpaction with enema and laxative regimen; vitals stable and pain controlled with acetaminophen as needed.

Discharge condition and functional status: patient is medically stable, ambulatory with assistive device at baseline and independent with most activities of daily living but requests assistance with medication management and toileting at home. Home health referral placed for nursing visits to monitor bowel function, urinary symptoms, medication reconciliation, diabetes and thyroid medication monitoring, and fall-risk assessment.

Medications and follow-up: continue home meds including levothyroxine, simvastatin, escitalopram, mirtazapine, ramelteon. Bowel regimen: polyethylene glycol daily, senna nightly, bisacodyl PRN, Fleet enema PRN, aluminum-magnesium hydroxide-simethicone for gas/indigestion PRN. Acetaminophen and ondansetron PRN. Heparin and ceftriaxone were administered inpatient only. Follow-up: primary care within 3–5 days, GI if constipation persists, PCP/urology for urine culture results and targeted antibiotics as indicated, and labs (BMP, TSH, A1c, lipid panel) as outpatient.

Brief history of present illness: 29-year-old G?P? female at 38 weeks gestation presented urgently for premature rupture of membranes at term. She progressed to spontaneous vaginal delivery and sustained a second-degree perineal laceration requiring repair. Relevant comorbidities include hypothyroidism on chronic levothyroxine and antepartum anemia.

Hospital course: The patient had an uncomplicated labor and delivery. Membranes had ruptured prior to onset of labor (O42.92). She delivered a single live infant (Z37.0) without intrapartum complications. Perineal laceration was repaired in the delivery suite. Postpartum course was notable for mild anemia (D64.9/O99.02) monitored without transfusion; hemoglobin remained hemodynamically stable. Endocrine condition (E03.9) continued on home levothyroxine. Pain was controlled with multimodal therapy. No evidence of infection; afebrile throughout hospitalization. Length of stay 1.9 days; discharged in stable condition.

Key findings and procedures: Physical exam post-delivery showed appropriate uterine involution and no excess vaginal bleeding. Perineal wound approximated after repair; no signs of infection. Procedures: spontaneous vaginal delivery with second-degree perineal laceration repair. Relevant orders included IV fluids (Lactated Ringers, 0.9% Sodium Chloride flushes) and routine postpartum monitoring.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable. Ambulates with steady gait and transfers independently; requires intermittent assistance with perineal wound care and strenuous activities. Able to perform basic ADLs and provide newborn care with intermittent support; home health recommended for wound checks, vital sign monitoring, ambulation assistance as needed, and lactation support.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on levothyroxine (continue prior dose), acetaminophen and ibuprofen for analgesia, oxycodone IR PRN for severe breakthrough pain, docusate and bisacodyl/milk of magnesia for bowel regimen, calcium carbonate, simethicone, Dermoplast spray as topical perineal analgesic. Follow-up with obstetrics within 1 week for postpartum evaluation, routine 6-week postpartum visit, and endocrinology/primary care for thyroid management and anemia follow-up as outpatient labs. Home health arranged for 1–2 visits/week initially for wound care and lactation support.

Brief history of present illness: 45-year-old male presented emergently after acute onset of severe gastroenteritis with hypotension and loss of consciousness. On arrival he had a GCS of 3 (E1 V1 M1) and suffered a witnessed cardiac arrest; ACLS was performed with return of spontaneous circulation. Initial working diagnosis was sepsis secondary to Salmonella enteritis with associated infective myocarditis and acute systolic heart failure.

Hospital course: The patient was managed in the ICU for 11.7 days. He required hemodynamic support and close cardiac monitoring. Broad-spectrum antimicrobials were initiated and narrowed to ceftriaxone once cultures (stool/blood) grew Salmonella species sensitive to ceftriaxone. Cardiac evaluation (ECG, troponin, echocardiography) was consistent with myocarditis and reduced left ventricular systolic function; treatment included guideline-directed medical therapy with lisinopril and metoprolol succinate. Anticoagulation was used during hospitalization (heparin/enoxaparin) per institutional protocols. He received bowel regimen agents for opioid/constipation prophylaxis and supportive care including IV fluids and electrolyte management.

Key findings and procedures: admission GCS 3 with successful resuscitation; clinical and laboratory evidence of sepsis (A41.9) and Salmonella enteritis (A02.0); echocardiogram showing acute systolic dysfunction consistent with myocarditis/cardiomyopathy. A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) was placed for prolonged IV antibiotic administration; Heparin flush protocol instituted. No further ischemic myocardial infarction was identified (code for acute coronary thrombosis without MI documented).

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable on room air, afebrile, and ambulatory with assistance due to deconditioning. Neurologic status has improved from arrival; he is awake and able to follow simple commands but requires supervision with activities of daily living and needs home physical therapy for gait and endurance training.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include ceftriaxone IV daily via home health PICC, lisinopril, metoprolol succinate XL, acetaminophen PRN, docusate, senna, folic acid, and enoxaparin per discharge instructions with monitoring. Home health to provide daily RN visits for PICC care/heparin flushes, IV antibiotic administration, vital sign monitoring, medication reconciliation, and PT evaluation. Follow-up with Infectious Diseases within 48–72 hours, Cardiology in 7 days, and Primary Care within 1 week.

Brief history of present illness: 64-year-old man admitted emergently with palpitations, progressive dyspnea, hypoxemia and altered mental status. Initial evaluation revealed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (primary diagnosis I48.0), acute hypoxic respiratory failure and shock. Past history notable for COPD, chronic peripheral vascular disease, hypertension, and alcohol dependence.

Hospital course: The patient required short-term invasive ventilatory support and hemodynamic support for shock. He was treated with rate control for atrial fibrillation, guideline-directed anticoagulation initiation, bronchodilator therapy and targeted treatment for alcohol withdrawal with benzodiazepine taper. Renal function was monitored; he experienced an acute kidney injury that stabilized with fluid optimization and avoidance of nephrotoxins. He improved clinically over a 10-day admission and was weaned from ventilatory support. Delirium resolved with supportive care.

Key findings and procedures: Admission labs and imaging confirmed acute respiratory failure, elevated lactate during initial shock, and acute kidney injury. Procedures performed included endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilatory management (ICD-10-PCS 5A1935Z) and ventilator assistance/management procedures (5A2204Z). Relevant diagnoses on discharge: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (I48.0), acute respiratory failure (J96.00), shock (R57.9), acute kidney injury (N17.9), alcohol withdrawal with delirium (F10.231), COPD (J44.9), hypertension (I10), peripheral vascular disease (I73.9). Restraints were used briefly for safety (Z78.1).

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, alert, and ambulatory with assistance due to deconditioning. He requires support with activities of daily living initially and has reduced exercise tolerance; home health nursing and physical therapy are arranged for assistance with medication management, mobility training, and monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on rate control (metoprolol), oral anticoagulation (apixaban), inhaled bronchodilators (ipratropium/albuterol and tiotropium), short prednisone taper as indicated, and thiamine/multivitamin for alcohol use disorder. Avoid nephrotoxins; renal labs to be checked. Follow-up: cardiology in 1 week (consider echo and rhythm strategy), primary care/nurse visit in 48–72 hours, pulmonary follow-up and home oxygen evaluation as needed, nephrology if creatinine not normalized. Home health to monitor vitals, weights, medication adherence and wound/IV needs.

History of Present Illness: 57-year-old female with relapsed multiple myeloma (C90.02) admitted under observation for evaluation of weakness, recurrent falls and syncope. She has known osseous metastatic disease, prior TIA history, hypertension, hypothyroidism, GERD and hyperlipidemia. Presenting issues included lightheadedness and decreased functional mobility over several days.

Hospital Course: Patient observed 3.8 days. Workup included orthostatic vitals, ECG, basic metabolic panel and CBC to evaluate syncope and volume status. Orthostatic hypotension and deconditioning were identified as contributors to syncope with no acute intracranial or cardiac ischemia. Pain and mobility addressed with analgesics, topical agents and physical therapy. Bowel regimen optimized for opioid- and opioid-sparing constipation. No acute intervention for myeloma required during observation; oncology notified and outpatient therapy planned.

Key Findings and Procedures: Notable diagnoses include relapsed multiple myeloma with secondary malignant bone disease, syncope/collapses with orthostatic component, history of TIA, recurrent falls, GERD, HTN, hypothyroidism and osteoarthritis. Procedure recorded: 00JU3ZZ performed during admission as indicated (operative note on chart). Labs showed no acute electrolyte derangement requiring inpatient treatment. Fall-risk assessment positive; PT evaluated and provided gait training.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable and medically optimized for discharge. Functionally she is deconditioned with limited endurance and requires assistance for ambulation (uses rolling walker) and 1-person assist for some ADLs. Home health recommended for nursing oversight, medication management, fall prevention and skilled PT/OT to address mobility and transfers.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged with home medications including levothyroxine, acyclovir, aspirin, calcium carbonate, famotidine, escitalopram, ezetimibe, lactulose, docusate, acetaminophen, topical diclofenac, lidocaine 2% and fluticasone nasal; lorazepam PRN for anxiety as previously prescribed. Patient instructed to monitor for syncope, new neurologic deficits, fever, bleeding or uncontrolled pain. Follow-up arranged with outpatient oncology within 7 days, PCP within 1–2 weeks, and specialty follow-up (cardiology/neurology) as indicated. Home health to initiate visit within 48 hours of discharge.

72-year-old male admitted emergently with a 3-day history of fever, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice and progressive anorexia. Initial evaluation notable for fever to 38.6°C, leukocytosis, cholestatic pattern on liver function tests, and acute kidney injury (AKI) with rising creatinine. Clinical picture was most consistent with acute cholangitis secondary to obstructing gallstone disease. Relevant past history includes type 2 diabetes, hypertension, nicotine dependence, and fatty liver disease.

Hospital course: Patient was stabilized with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics (ceftriaxone plus metronidazole). He received blood glucose management with insulin and dextrose as needed. Renal function responded to resuscitation but did not fully return to baseline. Interventional GI performed endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with biliary sphincterotomy and stent placement for decompression; procedure noted resolution of obstruction. Pain and nausea were controlled with acetaminophen and ondansetron. No operative cholecystectomy was performed during this admission.

Key findings and procedures: cholestatic LFT elevation consistent with obstructive pattern; AKI secondary to sepsis/volume depletion; ERCP with biliary decompression and stent placement. Blood cultures remained negative/without persistent bacteremia. Imaging confirmed choledocholithiasis without frank hepatic abscess.

Discharge condition and functional status: At discharge the patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating a general diet, and ambulatory with minimal assistance due to deconditioning. Renal function is improving but requires outpatient monitoring. Home health nursing is arranged for IV antibiotic administration, monitoring of renal function and wound/stent care, and assistance with activities of daily living during continued recovery.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include IV ceftriaxone (to complete planned course via home health), metronidazole, insulin regimen as previously adjusted, losartan resumed, acetaminophen PRN, ondansetron PRN, senna and simethicone as needed. Follow-up: GI/hepatobiliary clinic in 1–2 weeks for stent review and plan for elective cholecystectomy; primary care within 48–72 hours for BMP and LFTs; labs repeated twice weekly until renal function stabilizes. Return precautions reviewed.

History of Present Illness: 72-year-old female with symptomatic high-grade right internal carotid artery stenosis (I65.21) admitted as a same-day surgical patient for definitive revascularization. Past medical history notable for essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, peripheral vascular disease, prior nicotine dependence, and presence of an artificial hip joint.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent right carotid surgical intervention without intraoperative complication. Perioperative management included IV heparinization and blood pressure control. Postoperatively she was monitored in the surgical observation unit with serial neurologic checks and hemodynamic monitoring. There were no new focal neurologic deficits; vitals remained stable and pain was controlled with short-course opioid and acetaminophen as needed. DVT prophylaxis and bowel regimen were instituted. Influenza high-dose vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Preoperative imaging confirmed significant right carotid occlusive disease. She received operative extirpation/endarterectomy of the right carotid lesion with intraoperative shunt placement and repair. Estimated blood loss was minimal. No perioperative stroke, myocardial ischemia, wound hematoma, or cranial nerve deficits were identified.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and neurologically intact at discharge. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires minimal assistance for transfers; independent with light ADLs but requires home health assistance for wound care and initial mobility/safety evaluation. Home health to monitor incision, neuro status, blood pressure, and medication adherence.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include aspirin (antiplatelet) daily, atorvastatin daily, levothyroxine daily, acetaminophen PRN, short-course oxycodone PRN for breakthrough pain, docusate for bowel regimen. Continue home antihypertensive regimen; adjust per outpatient follow-up. Discontinue inpatient IV agents. 

Follow-up: Vascular surgery clinic in 7–14 days for wound check and duplex as indicated; primary care within 7 days for medication reconciliation and BP management. Home health to begin within 48 hours for wound care, neuro/vital sign monitoring, medication reconciliation, and PT for gait/ADL training.

History of Present Illness: 29-year-old female with morbid obesity (BMI 40–44.9) admitted as a same-day surgical patient for a planned procedure. Comorbidities include adult asthma (unspecified, uncomplicated), benign intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri), iron deficiency anemia, and sickle-cell trait. She presented in stable condition without acute cardiopulmonary compromise. Procedure performed: surgical intervention documented by ICD-10-PCS 0DB64Z3. Perioperative antibiotics (cefazolin) and standard prophylaxis were administered.

Hospital Course: The patient tolerated the procedure well without intraoperative complications. Postoperative course was notable for adequate pain control with multimodal analgesia (IV acetaminophen, ketorolac, gabapentin, short course of IV opioids PRN), antiemetics as needed (ondansetron, prochlorperazine), and bronchodilator therapy for baseline asthma (albuterol PRN). VTE prophylaxis (enoxaparin) was given per protocol. Hemodynamically stable throughout hospitalization, afebrile, and ambulatory with assistance the day of discharge. No neurologic decline was noted with preexisting benign intracranial hypertension; neurology follow-up arranged.

Key Findings and Procedures: Pre- and postoperative assessments were unremarkable for acute bleeding or infection. Procedure per 0DB64Z3 completed without complication. Perioperative labs notable for chronic iron deficiency anemia history; no transfusion required. Sickle-cell trait reviewed; no vaso-occlusive issues occurred.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition. Ambulation: ambulatory with occasional assistance for stairs/longer distances; able to perform light ADLs independently but requires support for wound checks and medication administration. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing visits to provide wound assessment, medication administration (including subcutaneous enoxaparin if continued), vital sign monitoring, and assistance with mobility as needed.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include oral acetaminophen, gabapentin, amitriptyline as prescribed, albuterol inhaler PRN, famotidine, and a short course of antibiotics as indicated. Continue home VTE prophylaxis per surgical plan if prescribed. Follow-up: surgical clinic in 7–14 days, PCP in 7 days, and neurology/ophthalmology for intracranial hypertension within 2 weeks. Return precautions reviewed; patient and family verbalized understanding.

Patient: 85-year-old female. Admission: Emergency admission for symptomatic anemia secondary to warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (D59.11) in the setting of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Length of stay: 5.6 days.

History of present illness: Patient presented with progressive weakness, dyspnea on exertion, and dark urine. Evaluation revealed severe anemia with hemolytic indices consistent with warm AIHA (positive direct antiglobulin test IgG, elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, reticulocytosis). Acute kidney injury and chronic comorbidities (CLL, essential hypertension, mitral valve disease, prior skin and thyroid malignancies, postprocedural hypothyroidism) were addressed during hospitalization.

Hospital course: Patient was treated with high-dose oral prednisone for warm AIHA with plan for outpatient taper. Supportive care included IV fluids, folic acid supplementation, VTE prophylaxis with heparin while inpatient, and close monitoring of hemoglobin, renal function, and hemolysis labs. Hemoglobin responded modestly to steroids; no transfusion required. Renal function improved toward baseline with hydration but remains monitored given acute kidney injury. No invasive procedures were performed. Vitals remained stable; no bleeding, thrombotic events, or infectious complications occurred.

Key findings and procedures: Positive DAT (IgG), elevated LDH and indirect bilirubin, reticulocytosis, acute kidney injury that partially resolved. No dialysis required. No operative procedures.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge home with home health services. Mobility: ambulatory with a rollator and requires assistance with transfers due to deconditioning and intermittent vertigo; fall risk precautions in place. Home health to provide medication administration assistance, weekly vital sign checks, and support with ADLs and safety assessment.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on prednisone (steroid taper), folic acid, levothyroxine, lisinopril, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, acetaminophen, ramelteon, senna, vitamin D3, artificial tears, heparin (per plan for VTE prophylaxis if continued), and sodium chloride flush supplies as needed. Follow-up: hematology within 1 week for AIHA/CLL management and steroid plan; PCP within 1 week; nephrology in 2 weeks or sooner if renal labs worsen. Labs: CBC and CMP twice weekly initially, then weekly; LDH, bilirubin, and repeat DAT as outpatient. Return precautions and clinic contacts provided.

Brief history of present illness: 63-year-old male with known asthma, chronic systolic heart failure, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia and prior nicotine dependence presented to the ED with 3 days of progressive dyspnea, wheezing, cough and decreased exercise tolerance. He was hypoxemic on arrival and admitted to observation for treatment of an acute asthma exacerbation with concurrent fluid overload from heart failure.

Hospital course: Over a 2.8-day observation stay the patient received frequent nebulized albuterol, scheduled inhaled therapy, systemic corticosteroids, and short course of inhaled combination fluticasone-salmeterol on discharge regimen. IV furosemide was administered with diuresis and clinical improvement in volume status. Oxygen supplementation was used initially and weaned as tolerated. Cardiac medications (carvedilol, hydralazine) were continued/adjusted and diabetes medications were maintained; blood glucose remained stable on oral agents. No evidence of focal pneumonia on chest radiograph; no invasive procedures were required.

Key findings and procedures: exam notable for bilateral wheeze and mild crackles that improved with therapy. Chest radiograph consistent with cardiopulmonary chronic change without focal consolidation. Hypoxemia resolved to acceptable saturations at rest off continuous oxygen; brief nocturnal or exertional oxygen needs will be reassessed by home health. Treatments performed: nebulized bronchodilators, systemic steroids, IV diuresis.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged to home in clinically stable condition with improved respiratory status and euvolemia. Ambulatory with a walker/assistance for greater distances; limited exercise tolerance and requires assistance with some ADLs — home health nursing and respiratory therapy arranged for support and monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on albuterol nebulizer and inhaler, fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, cetirizine as needed, furosemide, carvedilol, hydralazine, atorvastatin, diabetic agents (oral), benzonatate for cough, and supportive glucometabolic supplies. Home health to provide wound/medication reconciliation, inhaler education, pulse oximetry monitoring and oxygen evaluation. Follow-up: PCP in 3–5 days, pulmonology in 1–2 weeks, cardiology as outpatient in 1–2 weeks or sooner for worsening dyspnea.

History of present illness: 51-year-old woman with biopsy-proven intraductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the right breast (ICD-10 D05.11) presented as a same-day surgical admission for definitive surgical management. She has a family history of breast and digestive malignancies (Z80.3, Z80.0).

Hospital course: The patient underwent right breast partial mastectomy (lumpectomy) with sentinel lymph node evaluation under general anesthesia. Perioperative cefazolin was administered for prophylaxis and intraoperative course was uncomplicated. Postoperatively she required short-course IV analgesia (hydromorphone) and antiemetics (ondansetron, metoclopramide) for nausea; these were transitioned to oral agents. She received routine DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin and was given the influenza vaccine prior to discharge. Oral bowel regimen (docusate, polyethylene glycol, bisacodyl as needed) was started to prevent opioid-induced constipation. Wounds were clean, dry, and intact; surgical specimens were submitted for final pathology.

Key findings and procedures: Partial mastectomy of the right breast with sentinel node sampling performed without intraoperative complications. No immediate evidence of hematoma or wound infection. Sentinel nodes sent for pathology. Final pathologic report pending and patient informed regarding expected timeframe for results and further adjuvant therapy discussion.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition on postoperative day 4.5. Pain controlled on oral medication (oxycodone IR plus acetaminophen/NSAID as tolerated). Ambulating independently with mild activity restrictions (no heavy lifting >10–15 lb for 4–6 weeks). Independent with most activities of daily living but requires assistance with dressing changes and incision monitoring.

Home health and follow-up plan: Home health nursing arranged for wound care/dressing changes, incision assessment, reinforcement of activity restrictions, medication administration counseling, and monitoring for signs of infection or venous thromboembolism. Prescriptions: acetaminophen, oxycodone IR (short course), ibuprofen as tolerated, docusate, polyethylene glycol, bisacodyl PRN, ondansetron PRN, metoclopramide PRN. Outpatient surgical oncology clinic follow-up in 7–14 days for wound check and review of final pathology; referral to medical/radiation oncology as indicated after pathology review and tumor board discussion.

46-year-old male admitted emergently with acute chest pain and dyspnea and found to have Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Past history significant for hypertensive heart disease with systolic heart failure, type 1 diabetes mellitus with hyperglycemia, nicotine dependence, and prior cerebrovascular disease. On presentation he was hemodynamically stable but developed acute kidney injury and transient toxic encephalopathy/delirium in the setting of hypovolemia and hyperglycemia. Influenza vaccine was administered during admission.

Hospital course: The patient underwent cardiac evaluation with left heart catheterization and coronary intervention as indicated; he was treated medically with antiplatelet therapy and guideline-directed medical therapy for ischemic cardiomyopathy. Acute systolic heart failure exacerbation was managed with diuretics and optimization of beta-blocker and ACE inhibitor when tolerated. AKI improved with judicious fluid management and avoidance of nephrotoxins; dialysis was not required. Delirium resolved with correction of metabolic abnormalities, reorientation, and withdrawal of offending agents. Glycemic control was achieved with insulin; discharge regimen simplified for home management. Smoking cessation counseling was provided.

Key findings/procedures: Elevated troponin consistent with NSTEMI, reduced left ventricular systolic function on imaging, transient acute kidney injury, toxic metabolic encephalopathy that resolved. Procedures included diagnostic coronary angiography with intervention, vascular access placement, and standard inpatient supportive procedures.

Discharge condition and functional status: He is medically stable for discharge, mentating appropriately, and ambulatory with minimal assistance. Residual exertional dyspnea and mild deconditioning warrant home support. Home health services are arranged for medication reconciliation, daily weight and edema checks, vital signs including orthostatics, wound/vascular access checks as needed, insulin administration assistance and glucose monitoring, and coordination of outpatient labs (including INR monitoring while on warfarin).

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol tartrate, lisinopril, rosuvastatin, insulin regimen, citalopram, and warfarin. Arrange cardiology follow-up within 7 days, primary care within 3–7 days, and nephrology as outpatient if creatinine not normalized. Home health to reinforce discharge instructions and return precautions (worsening chest pain, dyspnea, syncope, fever, or confusion).

65-year-old male admitted directly through the ED for pancytopenia in the setting of recent antineoplastic chemotherapy (primary: D61.810). He presented with fever, progressive dyspnea and hypoxia and tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. Initial course was complicated by acute hypoxic respiratory failure, aspiration pneumonitis, acute pulmonary edema, and superimposed COVID-19 pneumonia. Past medical history notable for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, prior melanoma, ischemic heart disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Hospital course: Patient required supplemental oxygen and frequent nebulized bronchodilator therapy early in admission; he improved with diuresis for pulmonary edema and targeted pulmonary care. He received blood product support (packed RBCs and platelets) for symptomatic anemia/thrombocytopenia and broad-spectrum antibiotics while aspiration pneumonitis and bacterial superinfection were excluded/treated. SIADH was identified and managed with fluid restriction and close electrolyte monitoring. VTE prophylaxis with enoxaparin was provided while inpatient. He was monitored closely by hematology/oncology and cardiology during the admission. Over a 17.9-day stay the patient’s respiratory status and hemodynamics stabilized and cytopenias trended toward recovery.

Key findings/procedures: pancytopenia secondary to chemotherapy, acute hypoxic respiratory failure, COVID-19 pneumonia, aspiration pneumonitis, acute pulmonary edema. Procedures included blood product transfusion(s) and supportive respiratory therapies.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged hemodynamically stable and afebrile. Respiratory status improved to low supplemental oxygen requirement at rest (weaned to room air during ambulation); ambulates with minimal assistance and requires short-term help with medication management and ADLs. Home health will assist with neutropenic precautions, respiratory treatments, and activity progression.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen PRN, acetylcysteine nebulizer, albuterol and ipratropium-albuterol nebulizers, guaifenesin-dextromethorphan PRN, benzonatate PRN, aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, atorvastatin, buspirone, finasteride. Enoxaparin was inpatient only. Labs: CBC twice weekly until hematology follow-up. Follow-up: Hematology/Oncology within 3–5 days, PCP in 48–72 hours, Cardiology 1–2 weeks, and return precautions for fever, worsening dyspnea, bleeding, or falls.

57-year-old female admitted under observation status for 4.8 days with acute kidney failure with tubular necrosis (ATN). She presented with oliguria and progressive creatinine elevation after an apparent hypoperfusion/thermal injury event; history notable for third-degree burn of the left shoulder, known ischemic heart disease, systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, COPD, hypothyroidism, and hereditary hemolytic anemia. Initial evaluation demonstrated elevated BUN/creatinine, metabolic derangement requiring fluid management, and wound injury to the left shoulder requiring local debridement and dressing changes.

Hospital course: Patient was managed conservatively with hemodynamic optimization, intravenous isotonic fluids initially, temporary avoidance of nephrotoxins and ACE/ARB, nephrology consultation, and close monitoring of electrolytes and urine output. Diuresis was employed judiciously to manage volume status in the setting of congestive heart failure. Wound care included local debridement and daily dressing with topical nystatin cream as indicated and consultation with burn/ wound services. Respiratory status was supported with bronchodilator therapy (albuterol neb and inhaler) and continuation of inhaled fluticasone-salmeterol for COPD. Pain controlled with short-course oxycodone PRN plus acetaminophen. No dialysis required; renal function showed partial recovery prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: Elevated BUN/creatinine consistent with ATN, negative indications for immediate renal replacement therapy, wound debridement of left shoulder burn, cardiology and nephrology consultations performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with assistance, able to perform most ADLs with intermittent help. Requires home health for daily wound dressing changes, medication management, and monitoring of vitals/weights and urine output.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include continuing home therapies — metoprolol succinate, atorvastatin, clopidogrel, levothyroxine, fluticasone-salmeterol, albuterol inhaler/neb, ferrous sulfate, folic acid, omeprazole, stool softener/ polyethylene glycol, topical nystatin, acetaminophen and oxycodone PRN. ACEi/ARB were held during AKI and will be reassessed. Labs (BMP) within 48–72 hours and nephrology follow-up within 1 week. Cardiology follow-up in 2 weeks and primary care in 3–5 days. Avoid NSAIDs and other nephrotoxins.

HPI: 54-year-old male admitted to observation for 3.9 days with acute onset of profuse diarrhea, abdominal pain and vomiting. Symptoms began after recent outpatient procedure and recent antibiotic exposure. Past medical history notable for chronic diastolic heart failure, seizure disorder, bipolar disorder, anxiety, history of substance use, and chronic pain. Primary admitting diagnosis was toxic gastroenteritis and colitis (K52.1). Secondary concerns included wound infection after procedure and adverse antibiotic reaction.

Hospital course: Patient was managed with intravenous fluids, electrolyte repletion, bowel rest and targeted antimicrobial therapy (levofloxacin and metronidazole). He received symptomatic treatment with antiemetics, antacids, and short-term opioid analgesia for severe pain. Diuresis was adjusted (furosemide) for volume status monitoring due to underlying diastolic CHF. Heparin prophylaxis was given while inpatient. Seizure meds (lamotrigine) and home psychiatric meds were continued; sedative-hypnotics and anxiolytics were reconciled on discharge. Wound was evaluated by surgery; cultures were obtained and topical/local care initiated. Patient improved clinically with decreased stool frequency, resolved vomiting, stable hemodynamics, and normalized basic electrolytes prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: IV fluids and electrolyte repletion; stool studies and wound cultures sent; no radiographic evidence of acute surgical abdomen; wound debridement not required inpatient. Cardiac monitoring showed no acute ischemia; diastolic CHF managed medically.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge in improved condition. Ambulates with supervision due to deconditioning and intermittent lightheadedness; requires assistance with daily activities initially and dressing/wound care. Home health services arranged for nursing wound care, medication administration review, and physical therapy to address deconditioning and safe ambulation.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on home regimen including furosemide, metoprolol tartrate, lamotrigine, trazodone, zolpidem (as needed), acetaminophen, antacid (aluminum-magnesium hydroxide-simethicone), aspirin, and short course oxycodone PRN. Levofloxacin and metronidazole completed/adjusted per ID recommendations. Follow-up with primary care within 3–5 days, GI in 1–2 weeks, cardiology in 1–2 weeks, and home health nursing in 24–48 hours.

History of Present Illness: 48-year-old male admitted under observation for acute left lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast on admission demonstrated sigmoid diverticulitis with pericolic inflammatory change without abscess or free air. Past medical history notable for hyperlipidemia and active tobacco use.

Hospital Course: Patient observed for 3 days. He was managed nonoperatively with bowel rest initially, IV fluids (0.9% NaCl, D5 1/2 NS as indicated), IV antibiotics (ciprofloxacin and metronidazole), analgesia (acetaminophen, intermittent hydromorphone for severe pain), stool softener (docusate), and DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin. Vital signs and pain improved; WBC downtrended and he remained afebrile for 48 hours. Diet was advanced to clear liquids then a low-residue diet, which he tolerated. No interventional procedures or surgery were required.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT confirmed uncomplicated diverticulitis (no perforation, abscess, or obstruction). No percutaneous drainage or operative intervention performed. Laboratory trend notable for resolving leukocytosis; BMP remained stable; electrolytes and potassium repleted as needed.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged in improved and stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and able to tolerate oral intake. Ambulates independently without assistive device and performs basic activities of daily living at baseline. Home health referral requested for nursing follow-up to assist with medication reconciliation, education on diet progression, symptom monitoring, and smoking cessation counseling.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge medications include oral ciprofloxacin and metronidazole to complete a total prescribed antibiotic course, acetaminophen PRN for pain, docusate sodium daily, and potassium supplementation if indicated. Heparin and IV fluids discontinued. Follow-up arranged with primary care within 3–7 days and colorectal surgery or gastroenterology in 4–6 weeks for outpatient evaluation and planning for colonoscopy after resolution. Patient instructed to return earlier for recurrent fever, worsening abdominal pain, emesis, or inability to tolerate oral intake.

Primary diagnosis: uncomplicated diverticulitis (K57.92). Additional diagnoses: hyperlipidemia, tobacco use.

Brief HPI: The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted for observation for acute exacerbation of chronic sialadenitis with obstructing submandibular sialolith. He presented with submandibular pain and swelling, odynophagia, and decreased oral intake. Relevant comorbidities include COPD, chronic kidney disease stage 3, hypertensive CKD, nicotine dependence, and protein-calorie malnutrition (BMI 19.9).

Hospital course: The patient was observed for 2.2 days. Imaging confirmed a submandibular sialolith with associated ductal inflammation. He underwent minimally invasive surgical removal of the obstructing sialolith (procedure 0CBH0ZZ) without intraoperative complications. Perioperative IV cefazolin was administered. He received supportive care with IV fluids initially and was transitioned to oral intake. Pain was managed with acetaminophen and short course oxycodone as needed. He received Pneumococcal 23-valent vaccine prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Preoperative exam notable for unilateral submandibular gland tenderness and swelling. Labs consistent with known CKD stage 3; electrolytes stable. No evidence of systemic sepsis. Procedure: successful removal of sialolith with control of local infection and hemostasis.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral diet, and pain controlled on oral analgesics. Ambulation: ambulatory with steady gait but limited endurance due to COPD and deconditioning; requires home health assistance with dressing changes and medication management. Independent with basic transfers but requests help with bathing and stair negotiation.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen 500–1000 mg PO q4–6h PRN (max 3 g/day); Oxycodone IR 5–10 mg PO q4–6h PRN severe pain (short course); Pregabalin 50 mg PO BID for neuropathic pain; Fluticasone nasal spray 2 sprays each nostril daily; Ipratropium-albuterol inhaler 2 puffs q4–6h PRN; Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO daily; Diazepam 2–5 mg PO PRN for severe anxiety/muscle spasm. (Perioperative IV cefazolin completed inpatient.) Pneumococcal vaccine administered.

Follow-up: ENT clinic in 7–10 days for wound check and further management; primary care in 1 week for medication reconciliation and nutritional support; nephrology follow-up in 4–6 weeks for CKD management; pulmonology PRN for COPD optimization. Home health arranged for wound care, medication assistance, and short-course PT for endurance and breathing exercises. Return precautions: fever, increasing pain/swelling, purulent drainage, difficulty breathing, or decreased urine output.

History of Present Illness: 67-year-old male presented emergently after a fall down stairs at home with acute left knee pain and swelling. Imaging demonstrated a displaced transverse fracture of the left patella (ICD-10 S82.032A). Past medical history notable for essential hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was admitted for operative management and perioperative optimization.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation of the left patella (procedure 0QSF04Z) under general anesthesia without intraoperative complications. Perioperative antibiotics (cefazolin) and standard VTE prophylaxis (enoxaparin) were administered. Postoperatively he achieved adequate pain control with short-course IV and oral opioids (hydromorphone PRN) and acetaminophen. There were no signs of surgical site infection, neurovascular compromise, or inpatient medical complications. Influenza high-dose quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge. Blood pressure and rhythm remained stable on home antihypertensive therapy (propranolol). Length of stay 3.7 days.

Key Findings/Procedures: Pre- and postoperative radiographs confirmed displaced transverse fracture of left patella with satisfactory reduction and hardware placement on postoperative films. Procedure: open reduction and internal fixation of left patella (0QSF04Z). No acute cardiopulmonary or infectious issues identified.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and tolerating oral intake. Pain is controlled with oral medications. He ambulates short distances with a rolling walker and requires assistance for transfers and stair negotiation; will need home health physical therapy for gait training and strengthening. Wound is clean and dry; home nursing required for wound checks and dressing changes.

Medications at Discharge and Plan: Acetaminophen for analgesia; short, limited PRN oral opioid (hydromorphone) for breakthrough pain; enoxaparin continued for VTE prophylaxis per orthopedic recommendation; stool softener (docusate) and senna as needed; continue propranolol for BP and home statin for hyperlipidemia. Follow-up: Orthopedics clinic in 2 weeks for wound check and radiograph; primary care in 1–2 weeks for medical optimization. Home health referral placed for nursing (wound care, med reconciliation), PT (ambulation, transfers), and fall-prevention education.

History of Present Illness: 83-year-old man admitted emergently with acute shortness of breath and right-sided leg swelling. Imaging confirmed pulmonary embolism (I26.99) with associated deep venous thromboses of the lower extremities. Past hospital course was notable for acute kidney injury and known thoracic aortic aneurysm. He received anticoagulation and supportive care during a 7-day hospitalization.

Hospital Course: Patient was started on therapeutic anticoagulation with apixaban once he was deemed hemodynamically stable and renal function allowed oral anticoagulant use. He received diuresis with furosemide for volume management. Acute kidney injury was monitored and improved with optimization of volume status and avoidance of nephrotoxins. He received influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations prior to discharge. A multidisciplinary team including cardiology, hematology, and physical therapy was involved; vascular surgery was consulted for DVT management but no invasive intervention was required.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT pulmonary angiography consistent with pulmonary embolism without acute RV strain. Lower-extremity duplex demonstrated acute thromboses of the right tibial and left deep veins. Echocardiogram showed no acute right ventricular dysfunction; intracardiac thrombus previously suspected was not amenable to intervention. Laboratory trends showed transient rise in creatinine consistent with AKI that trended toward baseline prior to discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. He is alert, oriented, and ambulates with a rolling walker and assistance; requires help with stair negotiation and may fatigue with exertion. Home health is requested for medication administration oversight, anticoagulation education, fall risk mitigation, and assistance with ADLs as needed.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharged on apixaban for treatment of PE/DVT, furosemide for volume control, losartan for blood pressure, docusate and senna for bowel regimen, and inhaled ipratropium-albuterol PRN. Labs: BMP and CBC in 3–5 days, repeat renal function within 1 week for anticoagulant dosing. Follow-up with PCP and hematology within 7 days; cardiology and vascular clinic as outpatient within 2–4 weeks. Return precautions and anticoagulation precautions reviewed with patient and family.

History of Present Illness: 69-year-old male with known metastatic malignancy presented for observation with progressive dyspnea and hypoxia. Past history notable for metastatic disease to lung (left), liver, brain and bone, malignant pleural effusion, chronic venous thrombosis of the right femoral vein, CKD stage 3, and insulin-dependent diabetes. On arrival he had acute hypoxic respiratory failure and symptomatic pleural effusion.

Hospital Course: Over a 5-day observation stay the patient received supplemental oxygen with improvement in SpO2 to baseline requirements. He underwent diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis with cytology consistent with malignant effusion. Pericardial effusion was monitored by serial echocardiography and remained hemodynamically stable without need for pericardiocentesis. Right femoral DVT was treated with therapeutic enoxaparin inpatient with plan for continued outpatient anticoagulation. Dexamethasone was administered for symptom control related to CNS disease. Diuresis with furosemide improved volume status. Blood glucose was managed with insulin. No invasive surgical procedures other than thoracentesis were required.

Key Findings and Procedures: Chest imaging showed left-sided malignant pleural effusion and progressive metastatic disease. Thoracentesis performed (fluid sent for cytology). Echocardiography demonstrated small-to-moderate pericardial effusion without tamponade physiology. Lower-extremity ultrasound confirmed chronic embolism/thrombosis of right femoral vein.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge on home oxygen as needed and ambulates with assistance due to deconditioning; requires assistance with ADLs and medication administration. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing, medication administration (subcutaneous enoxaparin education/administration if continued), wound/line care as needed, fall-risk monitoring, and physical therapy for mobility and strengthening.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include therapeutic enoxaparin (per hematology plan), dexamethasone oral taper, furosemide, insulin regimen, famotidine, acetaminophen and other chronic meds. Appointments: oncology within 7 days for systemic therapy/radiation decisions, palliative care within 7–14 days, primary care in 1 week, and outpatient imaging (CT chest and brain MRI) as scheduled. Return precautions reviewed for worsening dyspnea, chest pain, bleeding or new neurologic changes.

Reason for admission: 66-year-old man admitted under observation for management of symptomatic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) with associated acute decompensated diastolic congestive heart failure and complications following recent procedures. Hospital course: Patient observed 16.9 days. On presentation he had progressive dyspnea, hypoxemia, and signs of volume overload with chronic atrial fibrillation. Imaging confirmed AVM at other site (primary diagnosis) with periprocedural issues and postoperative intestinal obstruction that required evaluation and procedural management. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertensive heart disease with heart failure, coagulation defect, restless legs syndrome, and urinary retention. Key inpatient interventions and procedures: patient underwent endovascular management of the AVM with targeted occlusive therapy and embolization, and procedural evaluation/management of postprocedural intestinal obstruction including exploratory intervention with resolution of obstruction. Hemostasis and coagulation were closely monitored given underlying coagulation defect; intermittent heparin was used per protocol when indicated. Cardiac management included diuretics and afterload reduction for diastolic CHF; rate control for chronic atrial fibrillation was achieved with appropriate agents; oxygen supplementation and monitoring for hypoxemia were provided. Relevant findings: improved oxygenation and euvolemia on diuretics, stable hemodynamics, resolution of bowel obstruction symptoms, and no recurrent bleeding from AVM at discharge. Discharge condition and functional status: Discharged clinically improved and stable, ambulatory with assistance for transfers and short ambulation due to deconditioning; requires home health nursing for medication reconciliation, wound/procedure-site monitoring, and assistance with ADLs and mobility training. Cognitive status intact for decision-making. Medications at discharge: acetaminophen, gabapentin, insulin regimen for diabetes, hydralazine for blood pressure as needed, docusate and bisacodyl for bowel regimen, lidocaine 5% patch for localized pain, lorazepam PRN for anxiety/restless legs as needed. Anticoagulation plan: outpatient anticoagulation to be coordinated with cardiology/anticoagulation clinic given atrial fibrillation and coagulation disorder. Follow-up: cardiology within 1 week, vascular/interventional radiology in 2 weeks, primary care within 3–5 days, and home health nursing to begin within 48 hours of discharge for wound care, medication administration, and fall-risk mitigation.

History of Present Illness: 40-year-old man with known type 1 diabetes mellitus on insulin, end-stage renal disease on chronic hemodialysis, prior CABG, and chronic pancreatitis presented to the ED with acute chest pain and dyspnea. ECG showed non–ST elevation ischemic changes and serial troponins were elevated, consistent with NSTEMI. He was observed for 3.2 days for risk stratification and management.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to observation, treated with antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel), high-intensity statin, IV fluids held given ESRD, and electrolyte management for hyperkalemia. He underwent diagnostic coronary angiography which demonstrated chronic total occlusion of a native coronary vessel and patent bypass grafts; no percutaneous intervention was performed during this admission. Infectious and pain issues were treated as needed (IV cefazolin for suspected source, acetaminophen/hydromorphone PRN for pain). Diabetes and hypoglycemia were addressed with glucose protocols and education. Dialysis sessions were continued per his regular schedule.

Key Findings/Procedures: Elevated cardiac biomarkers consistent with NSTEMI; ECG changes without ST elevation. Diagnostic coronary angiography performed; no PCI due to chronic total occlusion and prior CABG anatomy. Management of hyperkalemia and adjustment for ESRD; inpatient antibiotics for suspected infection. Procedures also included vascular access management and hemodialysis.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable at discharge, chest pain improved and controlled with oral analgesia. Ambulatory with baseline limitations; requires assistance with activities of daily living related to deconditioning and ongoing dialysis needs. Home health arranged for medication management, assistance with ADLs, coordination of dialysis transport, and wound/vascular access inspection.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on aspirin EC, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, acetaminophen PRN, inhalers (albuterol, fluticasone-salmeterol) and chronic home meds including doxercalciferol and agents for diabetes as per endocrinology. Short course of antibiotics completed. Follow-up: Cardiology clinic in 1 week, nephrology with dialysis unit coordination within 3 days, primary care within 7 days, endocrinology as outpatient. Home health to monitor vitals, medication adherence, vascular access, and coordinate appointments.

77-year-old female admitted under observation for progressive erythema, swelling and pain of the left lower extremity consistent with cellulitis. Significant past medical history includes hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease with systolic heart failure (CHF), chronic kidney disease stage 3, atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, asthma and osteoarthritis. Length of stay: 6 days.

Hospital course: On admission patient received IV fluids, empiric IV antibiotics and analgesia. Blood cultures were not persistently positive; inflammatory markers and WBC trended down with therapy. Acute kidney injury was monitored and improved toward baseline with adjustment of medications and careful fluid management. Heart failure was clinically compensated with diuretics and hemodynamic monitoring; no new arrhythmias were noted. Hypoglycemic episodes were treated promptly with dextrose and glucose gel. Patient converted from IV to oral antibiotics (clindamycin) once clinically improved and tolerating PO intake. Peripheral IV access and medication administration were performed (ICD-10-PCS 0S9D3ZX).

Key findings/procedures: Left lower limb cellulitis confirmed clinically; improved erythema and pain at discharge. Labs notable for transient rise in creatinine consistent with acute on chronic kidney disease which trended down. EKG and telemetry without acute ischemic changes; CHF managed medically. Peripheral IV placement for medication/infusion documented (0S9D3ZX).

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable and ambulates with steadying assistance due to leg pain and deconditioning. Requires home health assistance for wound checks, medication administration support, activity tolerance monitoring and weight/vital sign surveillance related to CHF.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged home on oral clindamycin PO, metoprolol tartrate, levothyroxine, atorvastatin, gabapentin for neuropathic pain as needed, acetaminophen, insulin per home regimen, calcium carbonate, loratadine and topical lidocaine patch PRN. Home health to perform wound care, daily vital signs, glucose checks and medication reconciliation. Follow-up with PCP in 48–72 hours, nephrology in 1–2 weeks (or sooner PRN), and cardiology within 1–2 weeks. Return to ED for fever, worsening erythema, increased shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness or syncope.

History of Present Illness: 70-year-old male admitted as a surgical same-day admission for progressive right lower extremity ischemia with gangrene of the right foot (primary diagnosis I70.261). He has concomitant chronic non-pressure ulcer of the right foot with muscle involvement, history of nicotine dependence, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, SIADH, and B12 deficiency.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent operative management of the right lower extremity (ICD-10-PCS 041M09P) with debridement of devitalized tissue and vascular surgical intervention. Post-operatively he was monitored for hemodynamic stability, wound perfusion, and electrolyte abnormalities. He received IV ceftriaxone for soft tissue infection, perioperative heparin for thromboprophylaxis, analgesia including hydromorphone as needed and scheduled acetaminophen, and gabapentin for neuropathic pain. Hypertension managed with metoprolol and hydralazine; diuresis with furosemide as indicated. Cyanocobalamin was administered for documented B12 deficiency. SIADH was managed conservatively with fluid restriction and monitoring of sodium; electrolytes stabilized prior to discharge.

Key Findings/Procedures: Pre- and post-operative vascular assessment consistent with critical limb ischemia and localized gangrenous change of the right foot. Surgical debridement and vascular procedure performed (see operative note, ICD-10-PCS 041M09P). Wound cultures guided antibiotic therapy. No immediate post-operative systemic complications.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, wounds clean with improving perfusion. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and dressing changes. Home health nursing required for wound care, dressing changes, and administration of IV antibiotics if continued.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include aspirin EC, atorvastatin, metoprolol tartrate, hydralazine, furosemide, gabapentin, acetaminophen, cyanocobalamin, and topical collagenase ointment. Continue ceftriaxone at home only if arranged with home health infusion services. Recommend home health nursing for wound care and medication assistance, home physical therapy for gait and transfer training, vascular surgery follow-up within 1 week, primary care follow-up within 1 week, and BMP within 48–72 hours to monitor sodium and renal function.

History of present illness: 60-year-old male admitted under observation for 7.3 days after accidental ingestion of a loop diuretic (primary diagnosis: T50.1X1A). He presented with altered mental status, hallucinations, hypotension and oliguria. Initial evaluation demonstrated acute kidney injury with tubular necrosis (N17.0), metabolic encephalopathy (G93.41), metabolic acidosis, and electrolyte abnormalities. Past medical history notable for Parkinson disease, dementia, major depressive disorder, hyperlipidemia, anemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Hospital course: Patient received supportive care with isotonic fluids (Lactated Ringers), electrolyte repletion including magnesium sulfate, glucose management (insulin and dextrose as needed), and close hemodynamic monitoring. Nephrology and neurology were consulted. Heparin was used for inpatient VTE prophylaxis. Psychiatric input assisted with management of acute agitation and adjustment of home antidepressant regimen. No operative procedures performed. Over the admission his creatinine peaked and subsequently trended down with improved urine output; metabolic acidosis and hallucinations resolved with correction of electrolytes and removal of offending agent. Mental status improved toward baseline but residual cognitive impairment consistent with pre-existing dementia persists.

Key findings and procedures: Acute tubular necrosis secondary to loop diuretic toxicity; metabolic encephalopathy; transient hallucinations. Serial BMPs showed improving creatinine and normalization of electrolytes. No invasive procedures required.

Discharge condition and functional status: Discharged hemodynamically stable, oriented intermittently to baseline, ambulatory with assistance and requiring supervision for all medication administration and some ADLs due to baseline dementia. Home health nursing arranged for medication administration review, vital sign and weight monitoring, and assessment of urine output and renal function.

Medications at discharge and follow-up: Continued home medications restarted/adjusted: Carbidopa-Levodopa 25/100, Duloxetine DR, Gabapentin, Mirtazapine, Felodipine, Omeprazole, scheduled insulin per home regimen, acetaminophen PRN. Patient and caregiver instructed to avoid loop diuretics. Follow-up: Nephrology appointment in 1 week for BMP and renal assessment, PCP within 3–5 days, neurology and psychiatry as outpatient. Return to ED for recurrent confusion, worsening dyspnea, hypotension, decreased urine output, or new neurologic deficits.

69-year-old male admitted to observation for 5.9 days with fever, right upper quadrant pain and sepsis secondary to a hepatic abscess. Past history notable for intrahepatic bile duct carcinoma with prior biliary stent, recent biliary instrumentation, and chronic anticoagulation. Blood cultures grew Escherichia coli. Admission diagnosis: liver abscess (K75.0) with bacteremia.

Hospital course: He was started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and fluid resuscitation. Interventional radiology performed percutaneous drainage of the hepatic abscess with catheter placement and repeat imaging demonstrated interval decrease in collection. A right-sided PICC was placed for ongoing IV therapy. Hematology consulted for anemia and thrombocytopenia; counts were stable to improved with supportive management. The biliary stent was noted to have mechanical complications likely contributing to infection; gastroenterology was involved. He remained hemodynamically stable, afebrile for >48 hours prior to discharge, and completed transition to ertapenem for outpatient therapy once culture sensitivities finalized.

Key findings and procedures: CT abdomen confirming rim-enhancing hepatic abscess; positive blood cultures for E. coli; percutaneous abscess drainage with catheter placement; PICC insertion for home IV antibiotics. Labs: improving WBC, persistent but stable anemia and mild thrombocytopenia; BMP stable.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulates with a rolling walker at baseline and requires assistance with household transfers — home health will provide skilled nursing, IV antibiotic administration, dressing changes, and assistance with mobility and safety assessments. He is independent with oral intake but requires support for medication management.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on ertapenem IV via home infusion through PICC for planned 4–6 weeks, apixaban continued, docusate, folic acid, acetaminophen PRN, and other chronic meds as listed. Home health to monitor PICC site, perform daily vitals, and coordinate blood draws (CBC, BMP) twice weekly initially.
