Follow-up appointments: Infectious Disease in 1 week, Interventional Radiology or Hepatology in 2 weeks for drain assessment and repeat imaging, and PCP within 7–10 days. Return precautions given for fever, increased pain, bleeding, or worsening mobility.

History of Present Illness: 75-year-old female with history of permanent atrial fibrillation, diastolic congestive heart failure, Parkinson’s disease, and dementia was admitted to observation for symptomatic bradyarrhythmia secondary to sick sinus syndrome (I49.5). She developed acute hypoxic respiratory failure during the admission and had a postprocedural pneumothorax following cardiac device placement. Hospital Course: The patient underwent implantation of a dual-lead cardiac pacemaker for sick sinus syndrome with periprocedural transvenous lead placement. She required brief respiratory support for acute hypoxic respiratory failure and was treated with supplemental oxygen, bronchodilator therapy, and pulmonary toilet. A postprocedural pneumothorax was identified and managed with chest tube placement with subsequent resolution. Cardiology optimized rate control and anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation. Diuretics and guideline-directed therapy for heart failure were adjusted. Parkinson’s and dementia medications were continued with home dosing adjustments and medication reconciliation prior to discharge. Key Findings and Procedures: ECG consistent with sick sinus syndrome and permanent atrial fibrillation; transthoracic echo showed preserved LV systolic function with diastolic dysfunction. Procedures: dual-lead pacemaker implantation, chest tube for pneumothorax, and brief respiratory support. Bloodwork and imaging stabilized prior to discharge. Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and respiratory status improved to room air at rest. She remains deconditioned with impaired mobility and requires assistance for transfers and ambulation; cognitive impairment necessitates supervision for medication administration and home safety. Home Health/Rehab recommended for skilled nursing visits, medication management, wound/port site checks, and assistance with ADLs. Medications at Discharge (selected): Apixaban 5 mg BID (anticoagulation), Metoprolol succinate XL, Diltiazem ER as indicated, Furosemide, Carbidopa–Levodopa, Donepezil, Albuterol inhaler PRN, Acetaminophen, Ferrous sulfate, Cyanocobalamin. Follow-up Plan: Cardiology/pacemaker clinic within 1 week for device check; primary care in 1–2 weeks; pulmonology/primary care as needed for respiratory follow-up; neurology/geriatrics follow-up for Parkinson’s and dementia. Home health to initiate within 48 hours for vitals, wound care, ADL support, and medication reconciliation.

56-year-old female admitted under observation for 4.9 days with altered mental status, fever and hematuria. Past medical history notable for hydrocephalus (status post shunt), gastrostomy dependence, essential hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia and prior seizures. Primary diagnosis: infection/inflammatory reaction due to indwelling urinary catheter (T83.51XA) with E. coli identified on culture; secondary problems included encephalopathy, urinary retention/hematuria and chronic neurologic disease.

Hospital course: Patient presented with encephalopathy and febrile illness. Initial evaluation included CT head (known hydrocephalus without acute shunt malfunction) and laboratory testing showing leukocytosis and positive urine culture for Escherichia coli. Treated with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics with infectious disease consultation. A midline/PICC was placed to facilitate IV therapy. Urinary catheter was exchanged per urology; hematuria and retention were managed conservatively. Neurology evaluated for encephalopathy and initiated/continued seizure prophylaxis with levetiracetam. Patient responded to therapy with defervescence and progressive improvement in mental status though baseline cognitive impairment persists.

Key procedures: peripheral to central line conversion (PICC/midline) for outpatient IV antibiotics, urinary catheter exchange, continuous observation and supportive care. Cultures: urine positive for E. coli; blood cultures negative.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and afebrile at discharge. Mental status improved from presentation but remains intermittently confused compared with baseline; requires assistance with activities of daily living and supervision for medication administration and gastrostomy care. Ambulates short distances with assistance; home health arranged for nursing support.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on IV ertapenem via PICC (home health to administer and manage PICC with heparin/saline flush per protocol). Continued home meds: levetiracetam, pravastatin, tamsulosin, acetaminophen PRN, potassium chloride powder PRN, and bowel regimen (senna, bisacodyl). Labs (CBC, BMP) and repeat urine culture to be obtained within 48–72 hours. Follow-up: primary care in 48–72 hours, infectious disease within 7–10 days, urology as outpatient for catheter management, and neurology outpatient follow-up within 2 weeks. Home health to provide wound/G-tube/PICC care, IV antibiotic administration, medication reconciliation and ADL assistance.

History of present illness: 56-year-old man presented emergently with progressive dyspnea, cough, fever, and hypoxemia. Past medical history notable for chronic systolic heart failure, hypertensive heart disease, COPD with acute lower respiratory infection, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, alcohol dependence with withdrawal, and severe protein-calorie malnutrition (E43). On presentation he was hypoxic and diagnosed with pneumonia and acute respiratory failure.

Hospital course: Patient was admitted to the medical service for management of community-acquired/other pneumonia with acute respiratory failure. He received supplemental oxygen and short-term ventilatory support for respiratory distress with subsequent weaning to nasal cannula. Blood and sputum cultures obtained; empiric broad-spectrum IV cefepime was administered. Diuresis with IV loop diuretics was used for congestive heart failure exacerbation and pleural effusion; diagnostic/therapeutic thoracentesis was performed with symptomatic improvement. Atrial fibrillation was rate-controlled with metoprolol XL. He was treated for alcohol withdrawal per protocol and received nutritional support and appetite stimulant (mirtazapine) for malnutrition. He received DVT prophylaxis with heparin. Psychiatric symptoms were managed with haloperidol as needed.

Key findings and procedures: Chest radiography and CT demonstrated multilobar consolidation with moderate pleural effusion. Thoracentesis performed with improvement in respiratory status. Laboratory evaluation consistent with acute inflammatory process; no gross bacteremia. Procedures included chest fluid drainage and short course ventilatory support.

Discharge condition and functional status: Clinically improved, afebrile for >48 hours, and stable on low-flow supplemental oxygen at rest (requires home oxygen). Ambulates with assistance due to deconditioning and requires help with some ADLs; home health nursing and physical therapy recommended for strength and medication management.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on acetaminophen, albuterol and ipratropium inhaled therapies, fluticasone inhaler, aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol XL, cefepime transitioned to oral antibiotic to complete course, docusate and bisacodyl for bowel regimen, heparin discontinued with outpatient DVT prophylaxis plan as indicated, mirtazapine, and haloperidol PRN. Follow-up with primary care within 3–5 days, pulmonary clinic in 1–2 weeks, cardiology as outpatient, and repeat chest x-ray in 4–6 weeks. Home health to monitor oxygen saturation, daily weights, wound/pleural drainage site, medication adherence, and ADL support.

History of Present Illness: 59-year-old female electively admitted for management of a left renal mass (ICD-10 C64.2). Past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes with retinopathy and hyperglycemia, long-term insulin and oral hypoglycemic use, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP, iron deficiency anemia, and obesity.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent an uneventful left radical nephrectomy (procedure 0TB14ZZ) with intraoperative IV therapy and perioperative antibiotics (cefazolin). Estimated blood loss was minimal; no transfusion required. Postoperatively she was hemodynamically stable, afebrile, pain controlled with multimodal analgesia (acetaminophen, short PRN opioids while inpatient), and bowel function returning. Glycemic management was achieved with scheduled insulin and sliding-scale adjustments; no acute kidney injury detected and hemoglobin remained stable. DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was provided during the admission. Final pathologic staging is pending; specimen sent to pathology.

Key Findings and Procedures: Preoperative imaging consistent with solitary left renal mass; operative report documents complete resection of the left kidney. Procedures performed: open/standard left radical nephrectomy (0TB14ZZ) and intraoperative intravenous therapeutic administration (8E0W4CZ). No intraoperative complications.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge on postoperative day 2.2. Ambulates with minimal assistance in the home setting; able to perform basic ADLs but will benefit from home health support for wound care and activity progression. Uses CPAP at night; oxygenation stable on room air.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Continue home antihypertensive and lipid therapy and home insulin regimen (adjust per outpatient glucose logs). Discharge medications include acetaminophen for analgesia, a short course of oral opioid for breakthrough pain, docusate for constipation, and instructions to stop IV antibiotics. Home health referral arranged for wound checks, medication assistance, glucose monitoring/insulin administration teaching, and activity support (visits daily ×7 then PRN). Labs (BMP and CBC) in 7–10 days. Urology clinic follow-up in 7–14 days for wound check and pathology review. Primary care/endocrinology follow-up within 1 week for diabetes management and medication reconciliation.

Brief history of present illness: 91-year-old man admitted urgently with acute on chronic diastolic congestive heart failure and volume overload with progressive dyspnea and peripheral edema. Background medical history notable for hypertensive heart disease with chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus on insulin, chronic atrial fibrillation, prior coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and do-not-resuscitate status.

Hospital course: Over a 3.7-day hospitalization the patient received aggressive medical management including intravenous and transition to oral diuresis (furosemide) with net negative fluid balance and clinical improvement of respiratory status. Telemetry documented supraventricular tachycardia and episodes of atrial fibrillation managed with rate control and continuation of anticoagulation (apixaban). Acute kidney injury on CKD was monitored; creatinine rose modestly on admission and stabilized with careful volume management and avoidance of nephrotoxins. Insulin regimen was adjusted for hyperglycemia; patient received routine inpatient vaccination (influenza). No invasive cardiac procedures were performed.

Key findings and procedures: Admission chest radiograph consistent with cardiogenic pulmonary interstitial edema that improved with diuresis. Labs demonstrated acute kidney injury that trended toward baseline; BNP elevated on admission decreased with therapy. Continuous telemetry identified supraventricular tachycardia and atrial fibrillation with rate control achieved. No emergent coronary intervention required.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically improved, euvolemic, hemodynamically stable, and ambulates short distances with assistance due to deconditioning and fall risk. He requires assistance with activities of daily living and needs home health support for medication administration and monitoring.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include apixaban, aspirin, furosemide, insulin (adjusted regimen), atorvastatin, allopurinol, and other routine meds. Home health to provide daily weights, vital signs, blood glucose checks, assistance with insulin administration, medication reconciliation, and fall-prevention education. Labs: BMP within 48–72 hours and as needed; outpatient BNP and renal panel in 1 week. Follow-up: primary care in 3–5 days, cardiology in 1 week, nephrology in 1–2 weeks. Patient and family informed of DNR status and goals of care reviewed.

Brief history of present illness: 22-year-old male presented via emergency department with acute exacerbation of anxiety and depressed mood after recent psychosocial stressors. Patient reported worsening anxiety, passive and intermittent active suicidal ideation without imminent plan or intent, and increased alcohol and cannabis use. Past history notable for prior self-harm, nicotine dependence, and history of malignant neoplasm (remote). Primary admitting diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood (F43.23). Other problem list includes alcohol- and cannabis-related disorders with anxiety features, unspecified anxiety disorder, and personal history codes for self-harm and nicotine dependence.

Hospital course: Over a 48-hour admission, patient received psychiatric evaluation, safety planning, brief supportive psychotherapy, substance use counseling, and medication initiation. Risk was assessed as elevated on presentation; no acute medical instability or need for inpatient psychiatric transfer after stabilization. Patient tolerated medication regimen without adverse effects. Influenza vaccination administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Psychiatric assessment confirmed adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety/depressed mood and suicidal ideation without active plan. Collateral history obtained from family when available. No invasive procedures performed. Vital signs and bedside exam remained within acceptable limits for discharge.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable, alert and oriented, ambulatory, and independent with activities of daily living but reports functional impairment related to anxiety (difficulty sleeping and concentrating). Requires home health support focused on medication management, safety monitoring, and short-term psychosocial support. Home health to perform weekly nursing checks for adherence and symptom escalation and liaise with outpatient psychiatry.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications: Sertraline (started; outpatient titration per psychiatry), Hydroxyzine as needed for anxiety, Ramelteon nightly for sleep, Acetaminophen PRN, Influenza Vaccine Quadrivalent administered. Follow-up: outpatient psychiatry within 7 days, primary care in 1–2 weeks, referral to community substance use counseling and crisis resources; return to ED for worsening suicidal ideation or safety concern. Patient and family provided with crisis plan and emergency contact information.

History of Present Illness: 81-year-old male admitted to observation for progressive weakness, confusion, poor oral intake, and new urinary symptoms. Known history of hepatocellular carcinoma with bone metastases, chronic hepatitis C, cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease stage 3, type 2 diabetes with diabetic CKD, hypertension, and severe protein-calorie malnutrition. On presentation he had hypotension responsive to fluids, leukocytosis, and positive urinalysis; blood cultures were negative.

Hospital Course: During the 5-day observation stay the patient was treated for a urinary tract infection with ceftriaxone IV, received IV fluids for hemodynamic support, and was started on lactulose for intermittent hepatic encephalopathy with improvement in mentation. DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was provided. Nutritional status was addressed with multivitamins and caloric supplementation; bowel regimen (docusate, senna) was initiated for constipation. Electrolytes stabilized with oral/IV potassium replacement as needed. Pain and fever managed with acetaminophen and short course of aspirin for cardiac prophylaxis per cardiology. Blood glucose and blood pressure were controlled on home regimens with adjustments (lisinopril continued). A peripheral IV/PICC was placed to facilitate antimicrobial therapy and laboratory draws.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging and labs consistent with known hepatocellular carcinoma and metastasis; malnutrition (E43); CKD stage 3. Urine culture grew a susceptible organism; treated appropriately. Procedure: central venous access (PICC) for secure IV therapy.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and tolerating oral intake though nutritional intake remains inadequate. Cognition improved to baseline but requires supervision with medications. Mobility is decreased—requires assistance with transfers and uses a walker; physical therapy recommended.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharged on home meds adjusted as above plus completion of IV-to-oral antibiotic plan as directed by infectious disease. Lactulose continued for encephalopathy, stool regimen, lisinopril, potassium supplementation, pantoprazole, and routine ophthalmic drops continued. Home health nursing for medication administration, wound/PICC care, daily weight checks, and lab draws is arranged. Follow-up: hepatology/oncology within 1 week, nephrology in 2 weeks, primary care in 3–5 days, and home physical therapy for gait/transfer training. Monitoring labs: CMP, CBC, and INR as outpatient.

History of present illness: 79-year-old man admitted urgently with acute left carotid artery occlusion/stenosis presenting with transient right-sided weakness, aphasia and an episode of amaurosis fugax. Past medical history notable for atrial septal defect, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, prior TIA/stroke, and nicotine dependence.

Hospital course: Patient admitted for urgent cerebrovascular evaluation and management. Imaging confirmed significant left carotid stenosis/occlusion. He was treated in the acute setting with antithrombotic therapy and underwent percutaneous left carotid revascularization (angioplasty with stent placement). Peri-procedural heparin was administered and discontinued per protocol. Blood pressure was managed with IV nicardipine and conversion to oral antihypertensives prior to discharge. He received statin therapy and short-course antiemetic and analgesic medications as needed. No new ischemic deficits developed post-procedure; baseline aphasia and mild right facial weakness persisted but remain stable.

Key findings and procedures: CTA/duplex demonstrating high-grade left carotid stenosis; percutaneous transluminal angioplasty and stent placement of the left carotid artery (procedural code 037L3DZ). Cardiac evaluation notable for known atrial septal defect; telemetry showed no sustained arrhythmia during stay.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and neurologically at baseline for him. Mobility: ambulates with a rolling walker with supervision due to residual right-sided weakness and falls risk. ADLs: requires assistance with some instrumental activities and was recommended home health PT/OT for gait training and ADL support. Home nursing recommended for medication reconciliation, blood pressure monitoring, and wound site checks.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include aspirin and clopidogrel (dual antiplatelet therapy), rosuvastatin, lisinopril (with home BP monitoring), hydralazine as indicated, docusate sodium, acetaminophen PRN, and home nasal/inhaled meds continued per outpatient regimen. Heparin discontinued. Follow-up: vascular surgery/carotid clinic and neurology within 1–2 weeks, primary care in 1 week, home health services initiated for PT/OT and nursing. Smoking cessation counseling provided.

If new or worsening neurological symptoms occur, patient instructed to return to ED immediately.

Brief HPI: 61-year-old female admitted under observation for evaluation and management of colostomy malfunction (K94.03) with associated abdominal pain, decreased ostomy output and peristomal skin irritation. Past medical history notable for severe protein-calorie malnutrition (E43), recent COVID-19 infection (U07.1), prior C. difficile enterocolitis (A04.72), type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, history of pelvic fistulae (N82.0, N82.3), chronic kidney tubulointerstitial disease and documented DNR status (Z66).

Hospital course: Over an 11.7-day observation stay the patient underwent bedside ostomy assessment and appliance revision with local wound care and education. A midline/PICC was placed for IV access to facilitate parenteral fluids and antibiotic therapy. She received IV ertapenem for presumed complex intra-abdominal infection pending culture guidance and oral fidaxomicin for C. difficile. Electrolyte abnormalities (hypomagnesemia) were corrected with magnesium oxide and intravenous supplementation as needed. Glycemic control was managed with short-acting insulin and D10W as required. Heparin prophylaxis was provided. Psychiatry and nutrition consults were obtained; aggressive nutrition support and high-protein diet plan initiated.

Key findings and procedures: Positive C. difficile testing with supportive stool studies; stoma inspected with no evidence of necrosis; peristomal cellulitis treated conservatively. Midline/PICC placed under sterile technique for IV therapy. Labs notable for hypomagnesemia and volume depletion that responded to replacement.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable, afebrile, pain controlled on oral regimen, tolerating oral intake. Functional limitations: decreased endurance and requires assistance with ostomy appliance changes and activities of daily living; home health nursing for wound/ostomy care and medication administration is arranged.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include fidaxomicin (complete course), oral magnesium supplementation, duloxetine, acetaminophen PRN, scheduled insulin regimen, and home analgesics. Continue heparin as outpatient only if ordered by home health. Follow-up with colorectal surgery in 1–2 weeks, PCP in 7 days, infectious disease within 48–72 hours for antibiotic review, nephrology in 1 week for electrolyte reassessment. Home health to provide PICC/midline care, ostomy management, skilled nursing and nutrition support.

History of Present Illness: 67-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for symptomatic left knee osteoarthritis with valgus deformity. She underwent an uncomplicated left total knee arthroplasty (procedure 0SRD0J9). Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications, asthma, and osteoarthritis of the knee.

Hospital Course: Length of stay 3.7 days. Perioperative course was uneventful. She received standard perioperative antibiotics and DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin. Blood loss was minimal; no transfusion required. Pain was managed with multimodal analgesia including acetaminophen and short-course opioids as needed; nausea controlled with ondansetron. Bowel regimen (docusate, bisacodyl, magnesium oxide as needed) instituted. Diabetes was managed with a basal-bolus insulin regimen and bedside glucose monitoring; endocrinology recommendations followed. Influenza vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Preoperative evaluation and imaging confirmed advanced left knee osteoarthritis and valgus deformity. Left total knee arthroplasty performed without intraoperative complications. Postoperative neurovascular exams remained intact; surgical incision clean, dry, and intact. Routine postoperative labs within acceptable limits.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable and afebrile at discharge. Pain is controlled on oral medications. She ambulates with a walker with moderate assistance for distance and requires assistance for stair negotiation and toileting; demonstrates ability to perform transfers with one-person assistance. Wound is clean without erythema or drainage. Glucose levels reasonably controlled on current regimen with nursing support.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, enoxaparin subcutaneous for DVT prophylaxis, insulin regimen with sliding scale as instructed, ondansetron PRN, stool softener (docusate) and laxative (bisacodyl) PRN, multivitamin and calcium supplementation. Home health referral for nursing and physical therapy initiated: RN to perform wound checks, administer/teach enoxaparin and insulin injections, monitor glucose and med reconciliation; PT to provide supervised gait training and home exercise program (3×/week initially). Outpatient orthopedic follow-up in 10–14 days for wound check and suture removal; PCP follow-up in 7 days for diabetes and overall medication review. Labs (CBC, BMP) recommended in 3–5 days or sooner if concerns. Education provided on wound care, signs of infection, DVT/PE symptoms, and fall precautions.

78-year-old female admitted under observation for acute exacerbation of congestive heart failure and acute on chronic kidney injury in the setting of hypertensive heart disease and diabetic chronic kidney disease. She presented with progressive dyspnea, lower extremity edema, orthopnea, and decreased oral intake. Initial evaluation notable for elevated BNP, pulmonary vascular congestion on chest x-ray, creatinine rise from baseline, and electrolyte abnormalities. Past medical history includes hypertensive heart disease with heart failure (diastolic), CKD stage 3-4, type 2 diabetes with neuropathy, atrial fibrillation, prior coronary artery disease, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic anemia.

Hospital course: Patient treated with intravenous and then oral loop diuretics with clinical diuresis and improvement in respiratory symptoms and peripheral edema. Blood pressure and heart rate were managed with adjustment of metoprolol succinate and lisinopril as tolerated. Acute kidney injury partially recovered toward baseline with optimization of volume status and medication adjustments. Blood glucose managed per protocol; hypoglycemia episodes treated promptly with dextrose and oral glucose gel. Anemia addressed with oral ferrous sulfate and evaluation; no transfusion required. Antithrombotic regimen reviewed and continued on apixaban and antiplatelet agents per cardiology recommendations given recent coronary disease history.

Key findings/procedures: CXR consistent with congestive changes that improved with therapy. Labs demonstrated transient rise in creatinine (AKI) and chronic anemia; ECG with atrial fibrillation without ischemic changes. No invasive procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is improved, hemodynamically stable, euvolemic by exam, tolerating oral intake. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and medication management; home health recommended for ADL support, medication reconciliation, vital signs and daily weights.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on apixaban, aspirin, clopidogrel, lisinopril, metoprolol succinate XL, furosemide, atorvastatin, gabapentin, ferrous sulfate, pantoprazole, magnesium oxide, polyethylene glycol and diabetes medications as listed. Arrange home health 2–3x/week for 2 weeks then reassess. Outpatient follow-up: PCP in 7 days, cardiology and nephrology in 1–2 weeks, labs (BMP, CBC, BNP) in 3–7 days. Low-sodium diet, daily weights, and medication adherence counseling provided.

History of Present Illness: 26-year-old male presented to the emergency department with 48 hours of fever, rigors, sore throat and progressive malaise. He was found to be tachycardic with leukocytosis and hypotension responsive to initial fluid resuscitation. Blood cultures were obtained. Past history notable for recurrent sialoadenitis and a known mucocele of the salivary gland. Developmental history includes a long-standing speech and language disorder.

Hospital Course: Admitted under observation for management of sepsis, unspecified organism (A41.9). He received sepsis bundle care including IV fluids, empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics (ampicillin–sulbactam while inpatient), antipyretics and VTE prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin. He demonstrated clinical improvement with normalization of vital signs and decreasing leukocytosis; blood cultures remained without growth at 48 hours. Pain was managed with acetaminophen and short course morphine oral solution as needed. No operative intervention was required for salivary pathology during this stay.

Key Findings and Procedures: Initial labs notable for leukocytosis with left shift and elevated CRP. Chest x-ray without acute consolidation. Blood cultures drawn; no growth at 48 hours. No surgical procedures performed. Wound/skin intact; mucocele noted on exam of the oral cavity—ENT follow-up recommended.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulatory without assistance, and independent with basic activities of daily living. Due to recent sepsis and subjective concentration difficulties, home health nursing is arranged for short-term medication administration oversight, daily vital sign checks for 48–72 hours, and cognitive/functional screening.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on oral amoxicillin–clavulanate to complete a 7–10 day course, acetaminophen as needed, and morphine oral solution for breakthrough pain short course. Continue VTE precautions; heparin discontinued. Follow-up with primary care within 48–72 hours, infectious disease/ENT in 1–2 weeks, and outpatient speech therapy as indicated. Home health to assess medication adherence, wound/oral lesion care, vitals, and cognitive status; return precautions provided.

History of Present Illness: 50-year-old female admitted to observation for 19 days with complications following allogeneic bone marrow transplant (primary: T86.09). She presented with acute-on-chronic graft-versus-host disease involving skin and GI tract (rash, significant noninfective diarrhea), progressive protein-calorie malnutrition, hypogammaglobulinemia, and coagulopathy. Course was complicated by immunosuppression-related viral reactivation and need for close hemodynamic and metabolic support.

Hospital Course: Patient received multidisciplinary care (hematology/oncology, infectious disease, dermatology, nutrition). Supportive measures included IV fluids, glucose support, prophylactic anticoagulation with enoxaparin, antiviral therapy with acyclovir, PCP prophylaxis with atovaquone, topical and systemic treatment for GVHD (clobetasol, budesonide where indicated), and aggressive nutritional supplementation. Laboratory monitoring identified hypogammaglobulinemia and cytopenias; transfusion and blood product support provided as indicated. Central venous access was placed for reliable IV therapy. She remained hemodynamically stable without ongoing fever at discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive findings included clinical GVHD (skin and GI), severe protein-calorie malnutrition (BMI ≤19.9), hypogammaglobulinemia, and coagulopathy. Procedures included placement and use of central venous access for IV therapies and multiple diagnostic labs/imaging to assess infectious and transplant-related complications. Blood product support was provided as clinically necessary.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged clinically stable, afebrile, and hemodynamically intact. Functional status: ambulatory with assistance due to deconditioning and ongoing GI symptoms; requires home assistance for medication administration, wound/skin care, and nutritional support.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acyclovir, atovaquone suspension, budesonide, clobetasol topical, enoxaparin (prophylaxis), acetaminophen PRN, antidepressant regimen continued (escitalopram, bupropion as previously prescribed), and insulin/nutritional supplements as indicated. Home health referral placed for nursing visits to administer/monitor medications, provide skin and wound care, nutrition support, and infection surveillance. Hematology/oncology follow-up within 3–7 days; dermatology and nutrition clinic as outpatient; consider immunology/IVIG evaluation.

62-year-old male admitted urgently for melena with symptomatic anemia. Past medical history notable for chronic systolic heart failure, hypertensive heart disease, atrial fibrillation, peripheral vascular disease, known pancreatic pseudocyst and renal artery aneurysm on prior imaging. On admission he was hemodynamically monitored and found to have acute posthemorrhagic anemia requiring packed red blood cell transfusion and endoscopic evaluation.

Hospital course: Patient underwent diagnostic and therapeutic upper endoscopy with successful identification and endoscopic hemostasis of an upper gastrointestinal source of bleeding. He received transfusion support (packed RBCs) with improvement in hemoglobin and stabilization of vital signs. Hyperkalemia was identified on admission and corrected with medical management. Heart failure and rate control were optimized with diuretics (furosemide, spironolactone), carvedilol and digoxin; lisinopril continued with monitoring of renal function and potassium. Pantoprazole was initiated for GI protection; ondansetron provided PRN antiemetic relief. Imaging (CT abdomen) confirmed a pancreatic pseudocyst and documented a renal artery aneurysm; these findings were stable compared with prior records and outpatient vascular follow-up was arranged.

Key procedures/diagnoses: upper endoscopy with therapeutic hemostasis, packed RBC transfusion, correction of electrolyte abnormalities. Primary diagnosis: melena (K92.1). Secondary issues: acute posthemorrhagic anemia, chronic systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, pancreatic pseudocyst, renal artery aneurysm, hyperkalemia, peripheral vascular disease.

Discharge condition and function: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, ambulating with minimal assistance, and tolerating oral intake. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing to assist with medication reconciliation and administration, daily weight monitoring and heart-failure symptom surveillance, PICC/IV flush care as needed, and outpatient laboratory draws (BMP, CBC) for electrolyte and hemoglobin monitoring.

Medications at discharge: Aspirin, carvedilol, digoxin, ezetimibe, furosemide, lisinopril, ondansetron PRN, pantoprazole, simvastatin, spironolactone, trazodone. Anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation is held pending GI/cardiology reassessment.

Follow-up: GI within 7 days for re-evaluation; cardiology within 7 days to reassess anticoagulation and heart-failure management; vascular surgery for renal artery aneurysm evaluation within 2 weeks; primary care within 1 week. Return precautions given for recurrent bleeding, worsening dyspnea, chest pain, or syncope.

Brief history of present illness: 34-year-old male presented emergently with a several-day history of worsening bloody diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, decreased oral intake and weight loss. He has a known history of ulcerative colitis and presented dehydrated and tachycardic. Admission diagnosis: Ulcerative colitis, unspecified (K51.90) with associated severe protein-calorie malnutrition, anemia of chronic disease, enteropathic arthropathy (right ankle), and abnormal coagulation profile.

Hospital course: Admitted for IV fluids, bowel rest, VTE prophylaxis, and escalation of anti-inflammatory therapy. He received methylprednisolone IV with clinical improvement in stool frequency and pain and was transitioned to an oral prednisone taper prior to discharge. Supportive care included analgesia (acetaminophen), vitamin D supplementation, and nursing-assisted education for smoking cessation. Nutrition consulted and initiated caloric/protein supplementation; anemia addressed with iron evaluation and outpatient plan. Coagulation abnormalities were identified and monitored; no active bleeding or thrombotic event occurred.

Key findings and procedures: Lower gastrointestinal endoscopic procedure documented (ICD-10-PCS 0DBN8ZX) with visualized diffuse colonic inflammation consistent with active ulcerative colitis; biopsies obtained. Labs notable for moderate anemia and abnormal coagulation indices on admission; both trended toward stability with treatment.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically improved, afebrile and hemodynamically stable at discharge. He ambulates with mild limitation from right ankle enteropathic arthropathy and requires intermittent assistance with medication management and home monitoring of stools and weight. Home health nursing is arranged for medication reconciliation, skilled monitoring of labs (CBC, CMP, coagulation studies), wound/skin checks as needed, and assistance with activities of daily living during recovery.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on oral prednisone taper (following IV methylprednisolone), acetaminophen PRN, prophylactic heparin as indicated per home health/clinic plan, vitamin D, and zolpidem PRN for sleep. Plan: GI follow-up within 1–2 weeks, primary care within 5–7 days, nutrition follow-up and outpatient rheumatology/orthopedics for ankle pain as needed. Home health to coordinate outpatient labs (CBC, coagulation profile) within 72 hours and report abnormalities to the treating physician.

Mr. [LastName], a 75-year-old man, admitted electively and hospitalized for 6 days for infection of an internal right knee prosthesis (T84.53XA) complicated by MSSA sepsis, hyponatremia, and bacteremia. Presenting with fever, right knee pain and drainage. Initial blood cultures grew methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus; urine testing consistent with UTI. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes, CKD stage 3, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Hospital course: He was treated with IV fluids, electrolyte correction for hypo-osmolality/hyponatremia, glycemic management, and IV cefazolin. Repeat blood cultures became negative after initiation of therapy. Transesophageal echocardiogram raised concern for possible valve involvement; cardiology consulted. Nephrology and infectious disease were involved. A right-sided PICC was placed for continued outpatient IV antibiotics. Pain was managed with acetaminophen; bowel regimen started for opioid-sparing management. He remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile for >48 hours prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Positive MSSA bacteremia originating from prosthetic knee (T84.53XA), transient hyponatremia (E87.1) corrected, evidence suggestive of endocarditis (I38) under outpatient evaluation. Procedures: PICC placement for long-term antibiotics and irrigation/drainage procedures at the surgical site as indicated.

Discharge condition and functional status: He is medically stable for discharge to home with home health. He ambulates with a rolling walker with assistance; requires help with transfers and wound care dressing changes. Home health to provide skilled nursing for IV cefazolin administration, PICC care/heparin flushes, daily wound assessment, medication management, and physical therapy for gait and strengthening.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include IV cefazolin via PICC (planned 4–6 week course per ID), acetaminophen, atorvastatin, aspirin EC, hydrochlorothiazide, insulin per sliding scale, finasteride, docusate and bisacodyl as bowel regimen. Outpatient follow-up: Infectious Disease within 48–72 hours, Orthopedics 7–10 days for prosthesis management, Cardiology for endocarditis evaluation within 1 week, Nephrology PRN, and primary care within 3–5 days. Home health to monitor labs (CBC, BMP, blood cultures if indicated) and report any fever, increased pain, or PICC complications immediately.

History of Present Illness: 61-year-old man presented via ED with 5 days of fevers, cough, dyspnea and malaise. SARS-CoV-2 PCR positive (U07.1). On arrival he was hypoxic requiring supplemental oxygen. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and prior nicotine dependence.

Hospital Course: Admitted emergently for acute viral pneumonia with hypoxic respiratory failure. Treated with dexamethasone, supportive oxygen, prophylactic enoxaparin, and glycemic optimization with insulin. Received a course of inhalation/respiratory support with low-flow nasal cannula; he improved steadily and was weaned to room air on day 3. Hyponatremia (hypo-osmolality) noted on admission was corrected with careful fluid management and monitoring. He remained afebrile for 48 hours prior to discharge. No invasive ventilatory support or central line placement was required.

Key Findings and Procedures: Initial chest radiograph showed bilateral interstitial/airspace opacities consistent with viral pneumonia. Labs notable for SARS-CoV-2 positive, initial sodium low with gradual normalization, and elevated inflammatory markers that trended down with therapy. Blood glucose required inpatient insulin titration. Influenza high-dose quadrivalent vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: He is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and ambulates with minimal assistance at baseline home mobility. Respiratory status improved; the patient is stable on room air at rest and with light activity but may have exertional dyspnea. Independent with activities of daily living with occasional assistance for stair ambulation; home health should assess mobility, oxygen needs, and fall risk.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on dexamethasone to complete prescribed course, insulin regimen for diabetes, losartan for BP control, atorvastatin, acetaminophen as needed, and enoxaparin prophylaxis per short-term plan. Glucose gel and glucagon provided for hypoglycemia rescue. Plan for primary care follow-up in 3–5 days, pulmonary clinic in 2–4 weeks, and endocrinology as outpatient for insulin titration. Patient counseled on COVID isolation, return precautions, and when to seek urgent care for worsening dyspnea, chest pain, or confusion.

32-year-old GxP patient with pre-existing type 1 diabetes mellitus admitted urgently in labor and underwent repeat low transverse cesarean delivery for previous cesarean scar. Admission complicated by labile glycemic control, gestational hypertension without significant proteinuria, hypothyroidism, and peripartum anxiety/depressive symptoms. Length of stay: 4.1 days. Baby well; mother prepared for discharge to home with home health support.

History of present illness: Patient with long-standing type 1 diabetes presented in active labor. Peripartum course notable for hyper- and hypoglycemic episodes requiring IV dextrose and insulin titration. She also developed postoperative pain and mild wound erythema without systemic signs of infection. Mental health history significant for new/worsening depressive and anxiety symptoms in the peripartum period.

Hospital course: Cesarean delivery (repeat low transverse) performed without intraoperative complications. Postop analgesia and VTE prophylaxis instituted (enoxaparin). Glycemic management included basal-bolus insulin adjustments and short-acting regular insulin coverage with IV D10/D50 used for symptomatic hypoglycemia when needed. Thyroid replacement continued. Wound observed; no abscess or dehiscence. Psychiatry consulted and bupropion XL restarted; supportive counseling provided. Patient educated on newborn care, insulin administration, and recognition/treatment of hypoglycemia.

Key findings and procedures: Repeat low transverse cesarean delivery; perioperative labs showed variable glucose values requiring titration; wound without deep infection; stable hemodynamics; no thromboembolic events.

Discharge condition and functional status: Stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulating with assistance, able to perform most self-care tasks but benefits from home health assistance for wound checks, insulin administration support/teaching, and postpartum mood monitoring. Pain controlled on oral analgesics.

Medications and follow-up: Continue home insulin regimen with adjusted dosing (basal-bolus with regular insulin for coverage) and glucose monitoring q4–6h and PRN for hypoglycemia; enoxaparin for VTE prophylaxis as outpatient for 7 days; bupropion XL resumed; continue levothyroxine; acetaminophen/ibuprofen for pain; stool softener. Arrange home health nursing for wound care, insulin teaching, and glucose checks; OB follow-up in 1 week, endocrinology within 1 week, and postpartum psychiatry/therapy within 7–14 days. Return precautions reviewed.

58-year-old male admitted to observation for symptomatic hypotension attributed to antihypertensive medication effect (primary Dx: I95.2) after a syncopal episode at home. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications, essential hypertension, chronic gastritis, and baseline anemia. Presentation: lightheadedness, presyncopal episode, documented systolic blood pressures in the 80s–90s mmHg; finger-stick glucose was low on arrival and corrected in ED.

Hospital course: Over a 3.1-day observation stay the patient received intravenous isotonic fluid resuscitation (normal saline boluses), glucose correction with D50, oral glucose gel and glucagon as needed for documented hypoglycemia, and insulin adjusted per sliding scale for hyperglycemia after initial correction. Cosyntropin stimulation testing was performed to evaluate possible adrenal insufficiency given persistent hypotension; results were pending at discharge but acute adrenal crisis was not identified. Antihypertensive medications were held while hemodynamics stabilized. Hematology labs showed mild normocytic anemia and abnormalities in blood chemistry that trended toward baseline with supportive care. No invasive procedures were required.

Key findings and procedures: hypotension due to adverse effect of antihypertensive agents, transient hypoglycemia requiring D50 and glucagon, IV fluid resuscitation, cosyntropin stimulation test performed, laboratory monitoring including CBC and BMP, and telemetry monitoring without arrhythmia.

Discharge condition and functional status: hemodynamically stable at discharge with systolic BP consistently >110 mmHg off offending agents; able to ambulate independently in the room and perform basic ADLs. Recommended home health to assist with medication reconciliation, twice-daily vital signs (BP and pulse) and blood glucose monitoring for the next 7–14 days, and assistance with diabetes education and nutrition counseling as needed.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include aspirin 81 mg daily, insulin per adjusted regimen, glucagon emergency kit and glucose gel PRN, and instructions to withhold prior antihypertensive agents pending PCP/primary care review. Outpatient follow-up with PCP within 48–72 hours, endocrinology in 1–2 weeks, and repeat labs (BMP, CBC) in 2–3 days. Return precautions given for recurrent hypotension, syncope, chest pain, or recurrent hypoglycemia.

History of present illness: 29-year-old female presented urgently at 37 weeks gestation for maternal care for suspected poor fetal growth and onset of spontaneous labor. Antenatal record significant for growth concern; patient developed active labor with variable fetal heart rate decelerations consistent with an intrapartum cord complication.

Hospital course: Continuous fetal monitoring and maternal/fetal assessment performed. Labor progressed to a spontaneous vaginal delivery of a single live neonate at 37 0/7 weeks. Delivery was complicated by a cord abnormality identified intrapartum, managed expectantly with resuscitative measures as needed. The patient sustained a second-degree perineal laceration which was repaired in the delivery suite under local anesthesia. Postpartum recovery was uncomplicated. Pain controlled with oral analgesics. Bowel regimen initiated to prevent constipation. Lactation consultant provided feeding support. Varicella vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: suspected fetal growth restriction (O36.5930), intrapartum cord complication (O69.89x0), spontaneous vaginal delivery at 37 weeks (Z37.0, Z3A.37). Perineal examination confirmed a second-degree laceration (O70.1) and primary repair was performed. Vital signs and bleeding stable throughout admission. No infectious or hemodynamic complications.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Ambulation: ambulatory independently on flat surfaces with mild perineal discomfort. Activities of daily living: able to perform self-care and infant care but requires home health assistance for perineal wound care, medication administration guidance, and lactation support. Pain is controlled with oral medications; wound healing appropriate at discharge.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge prescriptions include acetaminophen and ibuprofen for analgesia, docusate sodium and bisacodyl for bowel regimen, milk of magnesia PRN, calcium carbonate PRN, simethicone PRN, Dermoplast spray for topical perineal comfort. Varicella immunization documented. Arrange obstetric follow-up within 1 week for wound check and routine postpartum visit at 4–6 weeks; pediatric follow-up within 48–72 hours. Home health to provide wound care, pain management, breastfeeding support, medication reconciliation, and education. Return precautions: fever, heavy bleeding, worsening pain, or signs of wound infection; seek immediate care for newborn concerns.

History of Present Illness: 66-year-old male with history of acute myeloblastic leukemia in remission after recent allogeneic stem cell transplant who presented emergently with fever, diarrhea, hypotension and concern for transplant-related complications. He was found to have graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), bacteremia with Staphylococcus species, right internal jugular venous thrombosis, and acute kidney injury (AKI).

Hospital Course: Patient was admitted directly to the acute care service for broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, hemodynamic support, diagnostic evaluation and supportive care. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus; infectious disease recommended IV daptomycin. He received antiviral prophylaxis with acyclovir and topical/systemic therapy for GVHD (clobetasol cream and budesonide as indicated). Anticoagulation was initiated for right internal jugular thrombosis and transitioned to apixaban at discharge after stabilization. AKI was managed with fluid optimization and avoidance of nephrotoxins; renal function has partially recovered (creatinine improving but above baseline). Diarrhea and metabolic acidosis were treated supportively. Nutritional status monitored with supplementation including folic acid. He required placement of a central venous catheter for prolonged IV therapy and blood sampling; PICC line was placed without complication.

Key Findings and Procedures: positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus species; imaging confirming right internal jugular venous thrombosis; evidence of GVHD; AKI (stage unspecified) with improving creatinine. Procedures: central venous access (PICC) placement and routine line care; infusion of IV antibiotics.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: He is afebrile and hemodynamically stable at discharge. Ambulates with minimal assistance in the hospital and performs basic ADLs with intermittent support; deconditioning present but improving. Home health nursing recommended for IV antibiotic administration, PICC care, wound/skin/GVHD assessments, and periodic vital sign/weight checks.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on IV daptomycin via home infusion, apixaban for venous thrombosis, acyclovir prophylaxis, topical clobetasol and budesonide for GVHD, insulin as needed for hyperglycemia, and supportive meds (loperamide prn, folic acid). Follow-up arranged with Hematology/Oncology and Transplant clinic within 7 days, Infectious Disease within 3–5 days, Nephrology in 1–2 weeks, and Home Health RN for daily skilled care and lab draws (monitor CBC, CMP, creatinine, drug levels as indicated).

History of present illness: 51-year-old female admitted for planned right breast oncologic resection for biopsy-proven malignant neoplasm of overlapping sites of the right breast (C50.811). Past medical history notable for obesity, GERD, hypothyroidism (on levothyroxine), prior genetic risk for breast cancer, and ventral hernia. She was a same-day surgical admission and remained inpatient 4.5 days for perioperative management.

Hospital course: The patient underwent right mastectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy and axillary sampling under general anesthesia. Intraoperative and immediate postoperative course was complicated by hypotension and an episode of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). She received fluid resuscitation, brief vasopressor support, and rate control with medication with subsequent hemodynamic stabilization. She developed acute posthemorrhagic anemia and received packed red blood cell transfusion(s) with improvement in hemoglobin. She received standard perioperative antibiotics, DVT prophylaxis, antiemetic and multimodal analgesia. No evidence of surgical site infection; drains placed intraoperatively were managed and removed prior to discharge per surgery team. Final pathology pending; tumor noted to be estrogen receptor positive.

Key findings and procedures: right mastectomy, sentinel lymph node biopsy/axillary sampling, intra-/postoperative transfusion for acute anemia, transient SVT treated medically.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and ambulatory with supervision at time of discharge. She requires assistance with dressing changes and short-distance ambulation due to postoperative pain and deconditioning; safe for discharge with home health skilled nursing and physical therapy.

Medications at discharge: levothyroxine (continue home dose), oral analgesics (short course oxycodone PRN and scheduled acetaminophen), stool softener (docusate), antiemetic PRN (ondansetron), and oral antibiotics as prescribed. Influenza vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Follow-up plan: Home health arranged for wound care/dressing changes, vital sign monitoring, medication reconciliation, and PT twice weekly. Surgical clinic follow-up in 7–10 days for wound check and pathology review; medical oncology appointment within 2–4 weeks to discuss adjuvant therapy; cardiology follow-up for SVT evaluation and PCP visit with CBC and metabolic panel within 72 hours to reassess anemia and electrolytes.

History of Present Illness: 77-year-old man presented after a fall down stairs with closed injury to the right lower leg. Imaging demonstrated an unspecified fracture of the lower end of the right tibia (S82.301A). Past medical history notable for heart failure (I50.9), traumatic arthropathy (M12.50), and history of nicotine dependence (Z87.891).

Hospital Course: The patient was observed for 4.3 days. He underwent operative supplemental fixation of the right distal tibia (ICD-10-PCS 0QSG04Z) without intraoperative complication. Postoperatively he was managed with analgesia, DVT prophylaxis, and diuresis for congestive symptoms. He had transient alcohol withdrawal symptoms treated per CIWA protocol with diazepam taper. No signs of surgical site infection or cardiopulmonary decompensation occurred. Pain was controlled to allow participation in early physical therapy. Serial basic labs and chest exam remained stable.

Key Findings and Procedures: Right distal tibial fracture confirmed on radiographs; operative supplemental fixation performed. Post-op x-ray acceptable alignment. No acute cardiopulmonary event. Evaluated by PT/OT for mobility and safety; baseline cognition intact.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and euvolemic for discharge. Ambulation: currently limited weight bearing on the right lower extremity (touch-down to non-weight bearing as instructed). Requires assistive device and caregiver support for transfers and ADLs; home health physical therapy will provide gait training and strengthening. Wound: surgical dressing intact; home health to perform dressing changes and incision checks.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, oxycodone IR PRN for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, enoxaparin for DVT prophylaxis, furosemide and lisinopril for heart failure, docusate and senna as bowel regimen, ondansetron PRN, and a short diazepam taper per discharge plan. Home health to monitor vitals, medication adherence, wound care, and fall prevention. Follow-up: Orthopedics in 7–10 days for wound check and repeat x-ray; Primary care/Cardiology within 7 days for CHF med reconciliation. Smoking cessation counseling provided.

History of Present Illness: 30-year-old G?P? female admitted urgently for term (40 weeks) spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by chorioamnionitis and a second-degree perineal laceration sustained during delivery. She has a history of pre-existing hypertension complicating childbirth that was monitored and managed during admission.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent vaginal delivery with oxytocin augmentation and prompt recognition of chorioamnionitis. She received appropriate intrapartum IV antibiotics (gentamicin and ampicillin) and supportive care with IV fluids and antiemetics. The second-degree perineal laceration was repaired in the delivery room under appropriate anesthesia; hemostasis was achieved. Postoperative course was uncomplicated. Vital signs stabilized, pain controlled with multimodal analgesia, and blood loss was within expected limits. Hypertension was monitored and remained controlled on her outpatient regimen; no antihypertensive escalation was required. Baby delivered live and stable; pediatric care and feeding established.

Key Findings and Procedures: Term singleton live birth at 40 weeks; diagnosis included second-degree perineal laceration, chorioamnionitis, and pre-existing hypertension complicating childbirth. Procedures: vaginal delivery with primary repair of second-degree perineal laceration; administration of IV antibiotics and oxytocin. Relevant labs and clinical exam showed no ongoing sepsis, acceptable hemoglobin, and intact repair on exam.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged in stable condition, afebrile for >24 hours, pain controlled on oral meds. She ambulates independently with mild perineal discomfort and is able to perform most ADLs and care for the newborn but will benefit from home health assistance for wound care, instruction in perineal hygiene, and bowel regimen support.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds — acetaminophen 500–1000 mg q4–6h PRN, ibuprofen 600 mg q6–8h PRN, docusate sodium 100 mg BID, bisacodyl 10 mg PRN, Dermoplast topical spray PRN, famotidine 20 mg BID PRN, calcium carbonate PRN, ondansetron 4 mg PRN. IV antibiotics completed inpatient; no further systemic antibiotics prescribed. Follow-up: OB postpartum visit in 1 week for wound/BP check; sooner if fever, worsening pain, purulent drainage, heavy bleeding, or severe headache/visual changes. Home health to provide wound checks, perineal care education, and postpartum support.

Brief history of present illness: 38-year-old man with history of combined liver and kidney transplant status who presented emergently with fever, diarrhea, progressive dyspnea and declining urine output. Hospital evaluation revealed CMV infection (B25.9) with pancytopenia and rising creatinine consistent with acute kidney injury on chronic graft dysfunction and features of hepatorenal physiology. He required inpatient IV antiviral therapy and renal support.

Hospital course: Over a 5.8-day admission the patient received IV ganciclovir with loading and transition plan for outpatient therapy, broad supportive care for viral enteritis, and targeted management of cytopenias including folic acid and transfusion support as indicated. He developed worsening azotemia requiring temporary hemodialysis via a tunneled central venous catheter placed for vascular access. Infectious disease, nephrology and transplant hepatology were consulted and coordinated care. Pancytopenia and diarrhea improved with therapy; he remained hemodynamically stable without vasopressor support.

Key findings and procedures: Positive CMV PCR with clinical CMV disease; laboratory evidence of pancytopenia (neutropenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia); acute rise in creatinine consistent with AKI on chronic graft dysfunction. Procedures: placement of temporary dialysis catheter and initiation of hemodialysis. Vascular access and line care education completed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Ambulates short distances with minimal assistance and requires home support for activities of daily living and medication administration. Oxygen not required at rest.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include IV/infusion plan for ganciclovir (home infusion arrangement), prophylactic atovaquone, folic acid, analgesics and neuropathic agents (gabapentin), insulin as needed, anticoagulation/heparin per dialysis protocol, and scheduled outpatient immunosuppression adjustments by transplant clinic. Home health nursing arranged for IV antiviral administration, dialysis coordination, wound/line care, medication reconciliation, and lab draws (CBC, CMP, CMV PCR twice weekly initially). Follow-up appointments: transplant nephrology and hepatology within 3–7 days, infectious disease within 1 week, and primary care within 1–2 weeks. Return precautions reviewed.

History of Present Illness: 72-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) for symptomatic severe nonrheumatic aortic stenosis (I35.0). Past medical history notable for hypertensive chronic kidney disease (I12.9), type 2 diabetes with diabetic CKD (E11.22), chronic kidney disease unspecified (N18.9), left bundle branch block (I44.7), first-degree AV block (I44.0), hyperlipidemia (E78.5), obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and family history of ischemic heart disease.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent successful percutaneous replacement of the aortic valve (ICD-10-PCS 02RF38Z) without immediate complication. Postoperative course was uncomplicated over a 2.4-day stay. She remained hemodynamically stable, euvolemic, and afebrile. Continuous telemetry showed no high-grade AV block; no pacemaker was required. Vascular access site was clean, without hematoma or active bleeding. A post-procedure transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated a well-seated prosthetic aortic valve with improved transvalvular gradients and no significant paravalvular leak. Renal function remained stable for baseline CKD; electrolytes monitored and managed while on diuretics.

Key Findings/Procedures: Severe aortic stenosis treated with percutaneous prosthetic aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Relevant comorbid diagnoses as listed above. No immediate conduction disturbances requiring pacing; access site intact.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition. Ambulates with supervision and uses a cane at baseline; requires assistance with medication management and light household tasks—home health to assist with safety/fall risk assessment, activity progression, and medication reconciliation. Skin/wound status: access site clean and dry; home health to perform dressing checks.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel), atorvastatin and ezetimibe for lipid management, losartan, metoprolol succinate XL, bumetanide and spironolactone for volume control, allopurinol, famotidine, docusate, senna, ondansetron PRN, and acetaminophen PRN. Monitor BMP and renal function within 48–72 hours post-discharge and as needed. Cardiology follow-up in 1 week, primary care/renal clinic in 1–2 weeks. Home health to monitor vitals, weights, wound site, medication adherence, and to report chest pain, syncope, fever, worsening dyspnea, or new leg swelling immediately.

History of Present Illness: 53-year-old man admitted electively for symptomatic severe nonrheumatic aortic stenosis complicated by acute on chronic diastolic (congestive) heart failure. He presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema, and decreased exercise tolerance. Past history notable for hypertension with hypertensive heart disease, COPD, prior TIA, obesity, and chronic kidney disease. Hospital Course: The patient underwent open surgical aortic valve replacement with placement of a prosthetic valve. He required short-term postoperative invasive ventilation and ICU monitoring. Postoperatively he developed acute posthemorrhagic anemia requiring transfusion and transient acute kidney injury managed with fluid optimization and avoidance of nephrotoxins; renal function trended toward baseline. He had mild atelectasis treated with incentive spirometry and pulmonary toilet; COPD exacerbation addressed with bronchodilator therapy. He received appropriate VTE prophylaxis and stress ulcer prophylaxis. Psychiatry/social work involved for baseline anxiety/depression and discharge planning. Key Findings and Procedures: Preoperative echocardiography demonstrated severe aortic stenosis with preserved LV systolic function and diastolic dysfunction. Procedures performed: surgical aortic valve replacement (prosthetic), arterial and central line placement, and temporary postoperative mechanical ventilation. Post-op chest radiograph notable for small bibasilar atelectasis. Hemoglobin stabilized after transfusion; creatinine improved from peak value. Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge he is medically stable, hemodynamically euvolemic, and afebrile. Ambulates with a rolling walker and assistance due to deconditioning; requires help with some ADLs and stair negotiation. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing wound checks, IV line care if needed, medication reconciliation, and home physical therapy for gait/balance and progressive mobility training. Medications at Discharge: Aspirin EC 81 mg daily, furosemide 20–40 mg daily as needed for volume overload, albuterol inhaler 2 puffs PRN, escitalopram 10 mg daily (home med resumed), famotidine 20 mg BID, acetaminophen 500 mg PRN, and stool regimen (bisacodyl PRN). Follow-up Plan: Cardiac surgery clinic in 7–14 days, cardiology in 1 week, nephrology as outpatient in 1 week for AKI follow-up, and primary care in 1 week. Return to ED for chest pain, dyspnea at rest, fever, or signs of wound infection.

History of Present Illness: The patient is an 83-year-old woman admitted under observation for acute onset left-eye ptosis and complete external ophthalmoplegia. Presentation included diplopia and progressive eyelid droop over several days. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea with home CPAP, prior cardiac pacemaker, and depression.

Hospital Course: The patient was observed for 4.8 days. Neurology and ophthalmology were consulted. Workup included neuroimaging and laboratory testing which excluded acute hemorrhage or large-vessel ischemia. Laboratory evaluation demonstrated hyponatremia consistent with euvolemic SIADH; sodium improved with fluid restriction and careful monitoring. Blood glucose was managed with sliding-scale and basal insulin while inpatient. Pacemaker interrogation confirmed appropriate function. The patient received supportive eye care (lubricating drops and intermittent patching) and analgesia as needed. No acute respiratory or hemodynamic compromise occurred; telemetry remained stable.

Key Findings and Procedures: Primary diagnosis: left-sided total (external) ophthalmoplegia/third nerve palsy. Significant comorbid diagnoses: SIADH, type 2 diabetes mellitus, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, and presence of cardiac pacemaker. Procedures performed: pacemaker interrogation and continuous cardiac monitoring; intravenous fluid and electrolyte management; bedside ophthalmologic examination and documentation of extraocular movement deficit.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. Ambulates short distances with a rolling walker; requires assistance with transfers and some ADLs due to visual impairment and deconditioning. Fall risk precautions in place; home health instructed to assist with mobility, medication administration, and activities of daily living.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen PRN, amoxicillin-clavulanate (as prescribed), artificial tears and eyelid care, aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, insulin regimen for diabetes, escitalopram, and clonazepam PRN for anxiety/sleep. Home health to monitor vitals, daily weights, blood glucose, and sodium levels; coordinate outpatient neurology/ophthalmology follow-up within 1 week and primary care within 3–5 days. Continue CPAP at home. Return precautions reviewed.

86-year-old female admitted to observation for evaluation and management of symptomatic iron‑deficiency anemia and new abdominal pain. Prior history notable for malignant neoplasm of ascending colon with known hepatic metastases, essential hypertension, bilateral knee osteoarthritis, right hip arthroplasty, chronic nicotine use (history), and baseline cognitive vulnerability. On presentation she had progressive fatigue and decreased oral intake; imaging and endoscopic evaluation confirmed an obstructing-appearing mass in the ascending colon with hepatic lesions consistent with metastases.

Hospital course: Patient was observed for three days for peri-procedural management and symptom control. She underwent operative intervention (right-sided colon resection/segmental excision and regional lymphadenectomy; ICD‑10‑PCS 0FB23ZX) with concurrent liver-directed procedure(s) (ICD‑10‑PCS 3E0U33Z, 3E0U3BZ). Intraoperative course was uncomplicated. Postoperatively she recovered in the observation unit with return of bowel function by postoperative day 2. Pain was managed with short‑course opioid therapy and transition to scheduled nonopioid agents as tolerated. She experienced transient delirium likely multifactorial (medication effect and hospitalization); this improved after holding sedating agents and optimizing hydration and sleep-wake measures. No transfusion was required. Pathology and final oncology staging are pending.

Key findings/procedures: ascending colon malignancy with radiologic hepatic metastases; surgical resection of colon mass with regional lymphadenectomy and liver-directed procedure as above. Relevant ICD‑10 diagnoses at discharge include C18.2 (ascending colon malignancy), C78.7 (secondary liver malignancy), I10, iron‑deficiency anemia, and medication adverse effect noted during stay.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulating with a walker and requires assistance with activities of daily living and home mobility. Wound sites clean, dry, intact; requires home wound checks and medication management.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on aspirin, chlorthalidone, cyanocobalamin, ferrous sulfate, montelukast, omeprazole, short‑term morphine sulfate/oxycodone as needed, sertraline, and routine sodium chloride flushes as indicated. Home health nursing to initiate within 24–48 hours for wound care, med reconciliation, and assistance with ADLs; home PT/OT for mobility and fall‑risk assessment. Surgical clinic follow-up in 7–10 days; oncology follow‑up in 1–2 weeks for staging/treatment planning; PCP in 1 week with CBC and CMP prior to visit.

History of present illness: 31-year-old female presented to the emergency department with 3 weeks of progressive daily headaches, described as throbbing and worse with Valsalva, associated with transient visual obscurations and pulsatile tinnitus. She has a history of asthma and GERD. On arrival she was hemodynamically stable. Neurologic exam demonstrated bilateral optic disc edema consistent with papilledema.

Hospital course: Patient was observed for intracranial pressure management and diagnostic evaluation. Non-contrast head CT showed no acute hemorrhage. Given clinical concern for benign intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri), a diagnostic and therapeutic lumbar puncture was performed with measured elevated opening pressure and removal of CSF, which produced partial symptomatic relief. Acetazolamide was initiated for medical management of increased intracranial pressure. Subcutaneous heparin was administered for inpatient DVT prophylaxis. Bowel regimen (senna and bisacodyl) was provided due to anticipated acetazolamide-related constipation. COVID-19 exposure was noted; patient advised on testing and precautions; home health instructed to use appropriate PPE.

Key findings and procedures: bilateral papilledema on fundoscopic exam; elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture; therapeutic CSF removal (lumbar puncture) performed. No focal neurologic deficit; CT head without acute intracranial hemorrhage.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition on the same day of observation with improving headache and preserved baseline mobility. She is independent with basic ADLs but reports intermittent headache limiting prolonged activity; home health will assist with medication management, visual monitoring, and fall-risk assessment.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include acetazolamide (for intracranial hypertension), acetaminophen PRN for pain, senna and bisacodyl for bowel regimen. Heparin was given inpatient for prophylaxis and is not continued at discharge. Home health nurse to provide medication reconciliation, teach acetazolamide side effects, and perform vision checks. Follow-up with neurology within 7 days and ophthalmology within 48–72 hours for papilledema surveillance. Return immediately for worsening vision, new focal deficits, severe unrelieved headache, or fever.

History of present illness: 75-year-old female admitted emergently with fever, cough, dyspnea and confusion; testing positive for influenza (PCR) and urinalysis consistent with urinary tract infection. Past history notable for prior ischemic stroke with residual aphasia, type 2 diabetes with chronic kidney disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and trigeminal neuralgia.

Hospital course: Length of stay 3.5 days. On admission she was treated with oseltamivir for influenza and initiated on IV ceftriaxone for presumed urosepsis. Empiric fluids (lactated Ringer’s) and supportive care were provided. Blood cultures remained negative; urine culture grew Escherichia coli. She received enoxaparin for VTE prophylaxis and short-acting insulin for inpatient glycemic control. Creatinine was elevated on admission consistent with acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease and improved toward baseline with fluids and avoidance of nephrotoxins. Blood pressure and glucose were stabilized with adjustment of home antihypertensives and insulin. No invasive procedures were required.

Key findings and procedures: Positive influenza PCR; urine culture positive for E. coli; transient AKI with improving creatinine; no bacteremia. Continuous monitoring and supportive care; no imaging or surgical procedures during this admission.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with assistance, and oriented to person though with baseline expressive aphasia. She requires assistance with activities of daily living and medication management; home health services arranged for skilled nursing visits to assist with medication administration, vitals and glucose checks, and ADL support. No supplemental oxygen required at discharge.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharged on completing appropriate oral antibiotic per culture and sensitivity to finish a 7-day total course; oseltamivir to complete 5 days; home regimen including acetaminophen PRN, aspirin, atorvastatin, carbamazepine ER, lisinopril and antihypertensives as previously listed, and insulin with home glucose monitoring. Patient/family instructed on sick-call parameters, return precautions, and hypoglycemia protocol (glucose gel/glucagon available). Labs (BMP) to be checked within 48–72 hours and repeated creatinine with primary care. Follow-up appointments: primary care within 3–5 days, nephrology within 1–2 weeks, and neurology/stroke clinic as outpatient. Home health will coordinate medication reconciliation and wound/continence care as needed.

History of present illness: 61-year-old male admitted for observation for acute upper gastrointestinal pain and melena, found to have a duodenal ulcer (ICD-10 K26.9). Admission complicated by acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease, concerns for kidney transplant rejection, and metabolic acidosis. Past medical history notable for kidney transplant, type 2 diabetes with CKD, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gout, cirrhosis, and prior pericardial effusion.

Hospital course: Patient observed for 6.8 days. He was kept NPO initially, started on IV pantoprazole and transitioned to high-dose oral PPI once tolerating diet. Hemodynamic status remained stable without need for transfusion. Nephrology evaluated for AKI and transplant rejection (T86.11); immunosuppression was adjusted in collaboration with transplant team and mycophenolate sodium DR continued as outpatient. Endoscopic evaluation was performed with therapeutic intervention for the duodenal ulcer; pathology/therapeutic details in the chart. Cardiology consulted for small, noninflammatory pericardial effusion and recommended outpatient follow-up. Glycemic control was managed with insulin in-hospital and discharge plan includes home glucose monitoring and insulin therapy adjustments.

Key findings and procedures: Diagnostic endoscopy with therapeutic intervention for duodenal ulcer; renal function decline addressed by nephrology with medication adjustments; pericardial effusion observed on imaging; metabolic acidosis managed medically. Relevant procedure codes recorded in chart.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating a soft oral diet, and ambulatory with baseline assistance. Home health recommended for medication reconciliation, daily vital signs and blood glucose checks, assistance with activities of daily living as needed, and assistance coordinating outpatient labs and appointments.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on pantoprazole, mycophenolate sodium DR, insulin regimen with glucose supplies, atorvastatin, carvedilol, aspirin, allopurinol, acetaminophen PRN, ondansetron PRN, atovaquone suspension, and other chronic meds.
