Avoid NSAIDs. Follow-up with transplant nephrology within 3–5 days, GI in 1–2 weeks, cardiology in 2–4 weeks, and primary care within 48–72 hours via home health. Labs (BMP, CMP, CBC) to be checked twice weekly until renal function stabilizes; return immediately for recurrent bleeding, chest pain, shortness of breath, or oliguria.

History of present illness: 35-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for symptomatic uterine leiomyomata (intramural and subserosal) with abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pressure. Preoperative imaging confirmed multiple fibroids, largest intramural lesion consistent with ICD-10 D25.1/D25.2.

Hospital course: The patient underwent an open abdominal myomectomy with resection of multiple intramural and subserosal leiomyomas (procedures coded 0UB90ZZ, 0U590ZZ). General anesthesia was uncomplicated. Estimated blood loss was minimal and no transfusion required. Perioperative antibiotics and DVT prophylaxis were given per protocol. Postoperative recovery was uneventful; pain was controlled with short-interval parenteral opioids initially and transitioned to oral oxycodone and acetaminophen. Bowel function returned on postoperative day 1 with stool softener (docusate) and senna started to prevent opioid-induced constipation. Respiratory status remained stable; albuterol inhaler available PRN for baseline asthma. GERD symptoms managed with omeprazole. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key findings/procedures: Intraoperative findings confirmed multiple uterine leiomyomas (intramural and subserosal). Hemostasis achieved; no intra-abdominal complications. Pathology specimens sent; results to be reviewed in clinic.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake, and ambulating with minimal assistance. Pain is controlled on oral medications. Incision site clean and dry with intact dressings; able to perform basic activities of daily living at baseline with plan for short-term assistance at home.

Medications at discharge: Oxycodone IR PRN for moderate pain, acetaminophen scheduled/PRN, docusate sodium and senna for bowel regimen, omeprazole daily for GERD, albuterol inhaler PRN, simethicone PRN for gas. (Inpatient: hydromorphone, lactated Ringers, and saline flushes used.)

Follow-up and instructions: Home health arranged for wound checks, medication management, and assistance with mobility for 1–2 weeks. OB/Gyn clinic follow-up in 10–14 days for incision review and pathology discussion. PCP follow-up for asthma/GERD management within 1–2 weeks. Return immediately for fever >38°C, worsening pain, heavy vaginal bleeding, purulent drainage, or leg swelling.

History of Present Illness: 67-year-old man admitted urgently with melena and presyncope. He presented hypotensive with a drop in hemoglobin consistent with acute posthemorrhagic anemia. He reported recent use of aspirin and NSAID therapy prior to admission. Past medical history notable for multiple sclerosis, coronary artery disease with prior angioplasty and stent, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypocalcemia, and prior GERD.

Hospital Course: The patient was stabilized with intravenous fluids, transfusion of packed red blood cells as indicated, and proton pump inhibitor therapy. He underwent endoscopic evaluation with therapeutic hemostasis (ICD-10-PCS 0DJ08ZZ) with successful control of the bleeding source. Blood pressure stabilized and hemoglobin improved following transfusion. Antiplatelet and NSAID agents were held while GI bleeding risk was addressed. Pain and sleep were managed conservatively.

Key Findings and Procedures: Initial labs showed acute anemia and orthostatic hypotension. EGD identified bleeding lesion which was treated endoscopically with hemostatic measures. No immediate post-procedure complications. Cardiac status remained stable; troponin negative and hemodynamics supported conservative cardiac management.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is clinically stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable on oral intake, and ambulatory with a cane. He has baseline neurologic deficits from multiple sclerosis and limited endurance; requires intermittent assistance with transfers and instrumental ADLs. Home health nursing is arranged for wound/bleeding surveillance, medication reconciliation, monitoring of vitals including orthostatic checks, and coordination of outpatient testing. Physical therapy at home recommended for gait and safety training.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include esomeprazole 40 mg daily, atorvastatin, acetaminophen as needed, alprazolam and ramelteon for sleep as previously tolerated, diphenhydramine PRN, and saline flushes as needed for IV access if used. Aspirin and NSAIDs to be avoided pending GI follow-up. Labs: CBC within 48–72 hours and again in 1 week or sooner if symptomatic. Follow-up arranged with GI in 1 week, primary care in 3–5 days, and cardiology in 2 weeks regarding antiplatelet management. Home health services initiated prior to discharge.

Brief history of present illness: 24-year-old G?P? female presented to the ED postpartum with 48 hours of worsening right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, nausea and poor oral intake. She delivered recently (>42 weeks gestation noted in chart). Past medical history notable for obesity (BMI ~39), panic disorder, major depressive disorder, and nicotine dependence.

Hospital course: Patient admitted from the ED for evaluation and management of presumed acute calculous cholecystitis complicating the puerperium (ICD-10 O99.63, K80.00). Imaging (RUQ ultrasound) demonstrated cholelithiasis with sonographic evidence of acute cholecystitis. Initial resuscitation included IV fluids (Lactated Ringers), analgesia and antiemetics. Empiric antibiotics were started. She underwent operative intervention (laparoscopic cholecystectomy, ICD-10-PCS 0FT44ZZ) on hospital day 1 without intraoperative complications. Postoperative course was uncomplicated; she tolerated diet advancement, ambulated with assistance, and pain was controlled on multimodal analgesia.

Key findings and procedures: Positive RUQ ultrasound for gallstones with wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid. Procedure: laparoscopic cholecystectomy (0FT44ZZ) under general anesthesia. Estimated blood loss minimal. No drain placed.

Discharge condition and functional status: At discharge on hospital day 2 the patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulatory with minimal assistance for home, tolerating regular diet, and able to perform basic activities of daily living with intermittent help as needed. Wound sites clean, dry and intact; verbalized understanding of activity restrictions (no heavy lifting x2 weeks).

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include acetaminophen and ibuprofen for scheduled multimodal analgesia, short course oxycodone IR for breakthrough pain, simethicone and calcium carbonate as needed, and instructions to stop IV medications. Provide smoking cessation resources given nicotine dependence. Arrange outpatient surgical clinic follow-up in 7–14 days for wound check and pathology review. Recommend primary care/OB postpartum follow-up and mental health follow-up for depression/anxiety within 1–2 weeks. Home health services requested for wound checks, medication reconciliation and reinforcement of activity/pain management instructions, and assistance with ADLs as needed. Return precautions reviewed (fever, increasing abdominal pain, wound erythema, shortness of breath, suicidal ideation).

Brief history of present illness: 65-year-old female presented to ED on an observation admission (1.7-day stay) with progressive nausea and vomiting over 24–48 hours leading to decreased oral intake and lightheadedness. Past history notable for prior bariatric surgery (status), hypothyroidism, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, alcohol use disorder (uncomplicated), major depressive disorder and anxiety.

Hospital course: On presentation she was hemodynamically stable but volume depleted. Initial labs demonstrated mild elevation of transaminases and LDH; point-of-care glucose was variable with one low reading treated with dextrose/glucose gel. Electrolytes and renal function corrected with IV fluids (0.9% NaCl) and electrolyte repletion. She received antiemetic therapy and a peripheral IV administration of therapeutic substances (ICD-10-PCS 0DJ08ZZ). Nausea improved with treatment and she tolerated clear liquids progressing to soft diet. No focal abdominal findings on exam and imaging was not suggestive of acute surgical process. Psychiatry and social work were engaged for depression, anxiety and substance use counseling needs.

Key findings and procedures: Primary diagnosis: R11.2 — nausea with vomiting, unspecified. Secondary problems include K31.6 (fistula of stomach/duodenum history), Z98.84 (bariatric surgery status), hypothyroidism, diabetes, elevated transaminases (R74.0), depression/anxiety, and alcohol use history. Procedure: peripheral IV therapeutic administration (0DJ08ZZ); treated with IV fluids, antiemetics, and glucose as needed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged stable and ambulatory with baseline mobility. Requires support with medication management and routine glucose checks; home health arranged for medication administration assistance, hydration monitoring, and safety/home environment assessment.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge meds include home insulin regimen with instructions for glucose monitoring, fluoxetine for depression, aripiprazole as outpatient augmentation as previously prescribed, lorazepam PRN for severe anxiety, acetaminophen PRN, docusate, ferrous sulfate and folic acid. Labs (CMP and LFTs) to be repeated in 1 week. Follow-up with PCP in 3–5 days, GI clinic in 1–2 weeks, and outpatient psychiatry/substance-use counseling as arranged. Home health to begin within 48 hours for medication reconciliation and daily nursing visits as indicated.

History of Present Illness: 80-year-old female admitted urgently with acute abdominal pain and obstructive symptoms. CT abdomen/pelvis demonstrated midgut volvulus. Past history notable for colon polyp, prior right total knee arthroplasty, nicotine dependence, and adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood (F43.23). Primary diagnosis: Volvulus (K56.2).

Hospital Course: The patient was taken to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy. Intraoperative findings included volvulus of the midgut with a segment of compromised small bowel. She underwent detorsion and limited small-bowel resection with primary anastomosis (procedures coded 0DTF0ZZ and 3E0T3BZ). No permanent ostomy was required. Postoperatively she was hemodynamically stable, advanced to clear liquids then regular diet as tolerated, and pain was controlled with a step-down analgesic regimen. She received DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin. Influenza high-dose vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings/Procedures: CT-confirmed volvulus; operative detorsion and limited bowel resection with primary anastomosis; intraoperative enteric decompression; uncomplicated immediate postoperative course without evidence of ongoing ischemia or leak.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge she is stable, afebrile, ambulating short distances with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and ADLs; home health physical therapy recommended for gait and strengthening. Cognitive status intact; mood monitored with plan for outpatient behavioral health follow-up for adjustment disorder. Wound is clean, dry, and intact; home nursing will perform wound checks and monitor incision for signs of infection.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, short course oral hydromorphone PRN, gabapentin for neuropathic pain, ketorolac as indicated, bowel regimen (polyethylene glycol, senna, bisacodyl PRN), tamsulosin, and enoxaparin for continued DVT prophylaxis per surgeon’s instruction. Follow-up with general surgery in 7–10 days, primary care in 7 days, and home health nursing within 48 hours for wound care and medication reconciliation. Home PT/OT arranged; outpatient mental health follow-up for anxiety/depressed mood. Return sooner for fever, increasing abdominal pain, wound drainage, or vomiting.

History of Present Illness: 29-year-old female presented via Emergency Department after a witnessed fall at home with transient loss of consciousness and a witnessed convulsive episode. She was found to have left hip pain and inability to ambulate. Imaging demonstrated a displaced intertrochanteric fracture of the left femur (S72.142A). Past history notable for nicotine dependence and major depressive disorder. Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for operative management. She underwent operative fixation of the left intertrochanteric femur fracture (procedure ICD-10-PCS 0QS704Z). Postoperatively she was monitored for neurologic symptoms; no recurrent convulsions occurred while inpatient. Pain was managed with multimodal analgesia. She received DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin and bowel regimen for opioid use. Psychiatry/behavioral health consulted for depression and medication review; current antidepressants were continued. No inpatient complications occurred. Key Findings and Procedures: Pre- and postoperative imaging confirmed displaced intertrochanteric fracture of the left femur. Operative fixation performed under general anesthesia (see operative note). Neuro exam remained stable post-op; vital signs remained stable and hemoglobin was acceptable without transfusion. Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge the patient is hemodynamically stable, medically optimized, and afebrile. Pain is controlled on oral medications. She ambulates short distances with a front-wheeled walker with assistance and requires help with transfers and most instrumental ADLs; home health PT/OT arranged to progress mobility and teach safe transfers. Wound clean and dry with intact dressings; home health RN to perform dressing changes and suture/staple removal per ortho. Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen, oxycodone IR (PRN), morphine sulfate (as indicated inpatient-to-home transition PRN), gabapentin, enoxaparin for DVT prophylaxis, stool regimen (docusate, senna, bisacodyl PRN), ondansetron PRN, lorazepam/diazepam PRN per neurology guidance, mirtazapine and venlafaxine continued. Follow-up Plan: Home health services for RN, PT and OT initiated. Orthopedic clinic follow-up in 10–14 days for wound check and postoperative plan. Primary care and neurology follow-up within 1–2 weeks for evaluation of syncope/convulsion and medication reconciliation. Patient educated on fall precautions, smoking cessation resources, and signs of DVT/ wound infection.

History of Present Illness: 40-year-old male admitted for observation for acute herpes zoster rash and pain. Symptoms began approximately 5 days prior to presentation with dermatomal vesicular eruption and severe neuropathic pain. Past history notable for prior ischemic stroke with residual cognitive complaints, diagnosed ADHD and anxiety. Clinical concern for possible concomitant Lyme disease based on reported tick exposure; empiric workup and treatment initiated.

Hospital Course: Patient observed for 3.7 days. Dermatology and infectious disease recommendations followed. IV acyclovir was started with transition to oral valacyclovir when tolerating PO and lesions showing improvement. Doxycycline initiated empirically for possible Lyme disease; ceftriaxone administered for coverage pending evaluation. Analgesics included acetaminophen and short course NSAID; clonazepam provided for anxiety-related sleep disturbance. Heparin prophylaxis given during stay. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine administered per protocol. Vitals remained stable, pain improved with antiviral and analgesic therapy, no evidence of zoster-related neurologic complication.

Key Findings and Procedures: Examination documented typical unilateral vesicular rash consistent with zoster without complications. Labs and imaging did not reveal acute systemic involvement. Procedure coded 009U3ZX was performed per chart (therapeutic intervention documented) without complication. No evidence of bacterial superinfection. Cognitive baseline noted as mildly impaired related to prior cerebral infarction; attention/anxiety symptoms addressed by psychiatry consult.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable medical condition, afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Functionally ambulatory at baseline but with mild executive dysfunction; requires assistance with complex medication management and intermittent supervision for instrumental ADLs. Pain adequately controlled on oral regimen; able to perform basic ADLs independently.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on oral valacyclovir for zoster, doxycycline (as outpatient Lyme therapy), oral analgesics (acetaminophen/ibuprofen as needed), clonazepam PRN for anxiety, aspirin as indicated, and omeprazole for GI protection. Home health arranged for medication reconciliation, wound/dressing checks, pain and neurologic monitoring, and assistance with medication administration. Follow-up: PCP within 3–5 days, neurology/stroke clinic in 2 weeks, and infectious disease or dermatology as outpatient if symptoms persist or worsen.

History of Present Illness: 72-year-old female with symptomatic primary osteoarthritis of the left glenohumeral joint (ICD-10 M19.012) and chronic left rotator cuff pathology presented for same‑day surgical admission for elective left shoulder arthroplasty (ICD‑10‑PCS 0RRK00Z). Past medical history notable for morbid obesity (BMI 40–44.9), essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, GERD, asthma, mild cognitive impairment, and a history of cardiac murmur.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent left total shoulder arthroplasty without intraoperative complication. Perioperative cefazolin was administered for prophylaxis. Postoperative course was uncomplicated: pain was controlled with multimodal analgesia, incentive spirometry and pulmonary bronchodilator regimen were continued for reactive airways disease, and DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin was initiated. She had stable hemodynamics and no neurologic events. Pain was managed with acetaminophen and short course of oral opioid as needed; bowel regimen (docusate and bisacodyl) was started. Flu vaccination offered and documented.

Key Findings and Procedures: Intraoperative findings consistent with advanced degenerative change of the left glenohumeral joint and rotator cuff degeneration. Procedure: left shoulder arthroplasty (ICD‑10‑PCS 0RRK00Z). Estimated blood loss minimal. No acute cardiopulmonary issues; baseline ECG and vitals stable.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is stable for discharge on postoperative day 1.5. Ambulates with rolling walker and assistance for household distances; requires moderate assistance with dressing and bathing due to left upper‑extremity precautions (no lifting >5 lb, limited active ROM). Home health referral placed for nursing wound checks, medication reconciliation, and physical therapy for progressive ROM and strengthening.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, aspirin 81 mg daily, enoxaparin for DVT prophylaxis (per protocol), albuterol inhaler and neb as needed, fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, atorvastatin, atenolol, hydrochlorothiazide, calcium carbonate, aluminum‑magnesium hydroxide‑simethicone, docusate, and short course opioid PRN. PCP follow-up in 1 week; orthopedic clinic/wound check and suture removal in 10–14 days and initiation of home PT. Home health nursing will monitor vitals, wound, anticoagulation education, and ADL support.

63-year-old male admitted emergently for symptomatic unilateral inguinal hernia. Past medical history notable for essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, peripheral vascular disease, prior malignant neoplasm of other male genital organs, and a history of ureteral calculus with intermittent urinary retention. Length of stay 2.6 days. Admission exam and imaging were consistent with an uncomplicated unilateral inguinal hernia without obstruction or gangrene.

Hospital course: The patient was taken to the operating room and underwent open inguinal hernia repair with mesh under general anesthesia. Perioperative management included IV cefazolin for prophylaxis, DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin while inpatient, multimodal analgesia (IV then oral opioids and acetaminophen), antiemetic prophylaxis, and PPI therapy. He experienced transient urinary retention postoperatively requiring short-term catheterization, which resolved prior to discharge. No intraoperative complications; he remained hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and ambulatory with assistance at baseline prior to discharge. Routine postoperative labs were without acute abnormality and there was no evidence of wound infection or graft/mesh complication.

Key findings & procedures: operative open inguinal hernia repair with mesh placement; perioperative IV antibiotics and DVT prophylaxis; transient postoperative urinary retention managed conservatively. Pathology/oncology history noted; no acute malignant process identified during admission.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Ambulates with a rolling walker/walking assistance for short distances; able to perform basic activities of daily living with supervision. Home health services recommended for wound checks, medication administration assistance, mobility support, and monitoring for urinary retention or signs of infection.

Medications & follow-up plan: Resume home antihypertensive and lipid therapy as prescribed. Discharge meds include acetaminophen scheduled, short course oxycodone IR PRN for severe pain, ciprofloxacin prescribed for suspected urinary issue per urology guidance, omeprazole, magnesium oxide for bowel regimen. Follow-up with surgical clinic in 7–14 days for wound check and suture removal, primary care within 7 days, and urology within 2 weeks for evaluation of prior ureteral calculus/retention. Return precautions given for fever, increasing pain, wound erythema/drainage, inability to void, or calf swelling.

71-year-old male admitted to observation for 8.5 days with acute scrotal pain and swelling. History of progressive right-sided testicular pain, dysuria and fever prior to presentation. Past medical history notable for irritable bowel syndrome, migraine, and nicotine dependence. Initial evaluation revealed clinical epididymo-orchitis (primary diagnosis N45.3) with associated hyponatremia, microscopic hematuria, and mild transaminitis.

Hospital course: On admission patient was stabilized, given analgesia and IV fluids with careful sodium correction. Scrotal ultrasound confirmed epididymal inflammation without torsion. Urinalysis demonstrated pyuria and microscopic hematuria; urine culture subsequently grew a uropathogen sensitive to doxycycline. He was treated with doxycycline hyclate with clinical improvement in pain and local swelling. Hyponatremia (hypo-osmolality) was managed with fluid restriction and monitored electrolytes; sodium trended toward baseline prior to discharge. Transaminase and LDH elevations were nonprogressive and attributed to acute illness; these trended down with supportive care. VTE prophylaxis with low-dose heparin was provided while inpatient. No surgical intervention was required.

Key findings and procedures: scrotal ultrasound (inflammation of epididymis, no torsion); urine studies positive for infection; serial BMPs and LFTs monitored. No invasive procedures performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulatory at baseline with mild gait instability secondary to fatigue and recent hyponatremia. He requires intermittent assistance with medication management and home monitoring of symptoms; home health nursing is arranged for medication reconciliation, daily vitals/electrolyte monitoring for 48–72 hours, and education on wound/scrotal care and activity restrictions.

Medications at discharge: doxycycline hyclate (complete course as prescribed), acetaminophen PRN, acetaminophen-caffeine-butalbital PRN for headaches, sumatriptan PRN, docusate sodium and senna PRN for constipation, multivitamins, sodium chloride nasal spray, Readi-Cat 2 as used for imaging, and routine saline flush supplies. Heparin discontinued on discharge.

Follow-up: Urology clinic in 1 week; primary care within 48–72 hours for BMP and LFT recheck; return precautions for recurrent pain, fever, worsening urine symptoms, or confusion.

Patient: 35-year-old female. Admission: Urgent admission for abnormal fetal heart rate patterns in active labor (ICD-10 O76) at 39 weeks gestation (Z3A39) with single live birth (Z370). Brief history of present illness: Patient presented in active labor with recurrent fetal heart rate decelerations concerning for fetal intolerance of labor. Delivery was expedited resulting in an assisted vaginal delivery with second-degree perineal laceration sustained during delivery (O701) which was repaired in the operating room.

Hospital course: Over a 2.6-day inpatient stay the patient was hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and progressed appropriately through immediate postpartum recovery. Estimated blood loss was within expected limits for a vaginal delivery. Pain was controlled with oral analgesics. Bowel function was supported with stool softener and laxative therapy. No signs of wound infection or postpartum hemorrhage were observed. Lactation counseling was provided and initial breastfeeding established. Neonate transferred to newborn care and remained stable; pediatric follow-up arranged.

Key findings and procedures: Abnormal fetal heart tracing necessitating expedited delivery. Procedures included assisted vaginal delivery and repair of a second-degree perineal laceration (ICD-10-PCS: 10D07Z6, 0KQM0ZZ). IV fluids (Lactated Ringers) and routine postpartum monitoring were administered.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged in stable condition, ambulatory with steady gait, able to perform basic activities of daily living with minimal assistance, and able to care for newborn with planned home health support for the first week. Pain is controlled on oral medications; surgical site clean, dry, and intact.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen and ibuprofen for analgesia (scheduled/PRN), docusate sodium daily, bisacodyl PRN for constipation, milk of magnesia PRN, calcium carbonate and sodium citrate as needed for reflux, simethicone PRN for gas, Dermoplast spray PRN for perineal discomfort. (IV fluids and sodium chloride flush were administered inpatient.)

Follow-up: Postpartum OB clinic/wound check in 7–14 days and routine postpartum visit at 6 weeks. Home health ordered for wound care, medication reconciliation, pain management, infant-care support and breastfeeding assistance. Return earlier for fever, increasing pain, foul drainage, heavy bleeding, or difficulty voiding.

History of Present Illness: 85-year-old female admitted under observation for acute cough, shortness of breath and fever. Chest radiograph demonstrated a right lower lobe infiltrate with small associated pleural effusion. Past medical history notable for atrial fibrillation on anticoagulation, asthma/COPD overlap with prior exacerbations, coronary artery disease, hypertension, dementia, anemia, GERD, and depression.

Hospital Course: Observed 3.6 days. Patient was treated for community-acquired pneumonia (J18.9) with empiric IV ceftriaxone and azithromycin on admission with clinical improvement; transitioned to oral cefpodoxime and completion of macrolide therapy on discharge. Bronchodilator therapy (albuterol inhaler, ipratropium nebulizer, fluticasone-salmeterol) and a short prednisone taper were given for acute asthma exacerbation. Hypertensive urgency was managed with adjustment of home antihypertensives (carvedilol and losartan) and diuresis with furosemide for mild volume overload/pleural effusion. Apixaban was continued for atrial fibrillation. Urine culture showed bacteriuria without systemic sepsis; treated per culture sensitivity and clinical context. No invasive procedures performed.

Key Findings/Procedures: CXR consistent with right lower lobe pneumonia and small effusion. Afebrile for >48 hours, respiratory rate improved, oxygen saturation maintained >92% on room air at rest. Laboratory trends showed resolving inflammatory markers and stable hemoglobin above baseline anemia management threshold.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Discharged in stable medical condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable. Cognitive baseline: chronic mild-to-moderate dementia with continued need for supervision. Mobility: ambulates short distances with a walker and requires assistance with transfers and most ADLs; home health recommended for safety, medication management, and skilled nursing for respiratory treatments and vitals monitoring.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include apixaban, carvedilol, losartan, atorvastatin, furosemide, cefpodoxime (finish course), azithromycin (if applicable), prednisone taper, albuterol inhaler PRN, ipratropium neb, fluticasone-salmeterol, omeprazole, citalopram. Follow-up with primary care within 48–72 hours, pulmonology/ID in 1–2 weeks, cardiology as outpatient for AF, and home health nursing for wound/medication reconciliation, nebulizer treatments, vitals and ADL support.

History of present illness: 67-year-old male with known epilepsy presented after a witnessed generalized tonic–clonic seizure at home. Associated urinary hesitancy and dysuria prompted evaluation for urinary tract infection. Past medical history notable for peripheral nerve malignancy, chronic polyneuropathy and chronic pain, long-term systemic steroid use, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

Hospital course: Patient was observed for 6–7 days. On arrival he received a loading dose of IV levetiracetam with transition to oral levetiracetam maintenance. Empiric IV ceftriaxone was administered for a positive urinalysis/clinical concern for UTI with clinical improvement and down-trending inflammatory markers. Continuous cardiac monitoring showed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation without hemodynamic instability. Head CT showed no acute intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect. Blood glucose was monitored and treated as needed; he received DVT prophylaxis while inpatient. No recurrent clinical seizures occurred during hospitalization; pain and spasticity were managed with duloxetine and baclofen. Influenza vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: CT head negative for acute process; UA consistent with UTI; IV levetiracetam loading and transition to PO; IV ceftriaxone course initiated; telemetry monitoring; standard observation-level nursing and medication administration.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable, afebrile, and seizure-free for >72 hours. Ambulates with a cane and requires assistance with transfers and some ADLs; home health is arranged for medication administration, fall-risk precautions, toileting assistance, and monitoring of neurologic status and wound/skin integrity.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include: levetiracetam (maintenance dosing), duloxetine, baclofen, acetaminophen PRN, docusate sodium and lactulose as bowel regimen, finasteride, and outpatient insulin regimen as appropriate. He is to complete a short course of oral antibiotics started in hospital as directed. Follow-up: neurology within 1–2 weeks, primary care within 48–72 hours, urology for BPH/UTI, oncology and/or neuro-oncology as outpatient for management of peripheral nerve neoplasm, and cardiology within 1 week to address atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation planning. Home health services to begin within 48 hours for medication management, ADL assistance, vital sign and fall/seizure monitoring.

History of Present Illness: 56-year-old female admitted under observation for acute bleeding and altered mental status. Presented with overt bleeding and confusion while on anticoagulation; found to have hemorrhagic disorder due to extrinsic circulating anticoagulants (D68.32). Admission course was complicated by metabolic encephalopathy, acute kidney injury, and exacerbation of chronic systolic heart failure.

Hospital Course: Anticoagulants were held on admission. She received targeted reversal and supportive care with blood product administration and hemodynamic stabilization. Encephalopathy improved with correction of metabolic derangements and medication adjustments. Acute kidney injury managed with fluid optimization and close monitoring of electrolytes; no dialysis required. Heart failure treated with diuretics and afterload reduction, with improvement in volume status. Pain and hemorrhoidal symptoms addressed conservatively. Psychiatry/behavioral medication (haloperidol) used briefly for agitation. VTE prophylaxis and anticoagulation strategy were individualized; therapeutic enoxaparin was used at discharge per hematology recommendation with plan for close outpatient monitoring.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive laboratory evidence of coagulopathy consistent with extrinsic anticoagulant effect. Imaging and consults (CT head, chest radiograph, cardiology and nephrology involvement) completed. Procedures included central venous access for monitoring/administration, blood product transfusion(s), and bedside diagnostic evaluations.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home with home health services. Cognition improved but intermittent confusion persists; requires supervision for medication administration and safety. Ambulates with steadying assistance due to deconditioning; requires home PT for gait training and OT for ADL support.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include therapeutic enoxaparin (per hematology), aspirin, atorvastatin, acetaminophen, morphine/oxycodone-alternative (as needed) for pain, famotidine, stool regimen (docusate and bisacodyl), and calcium carbonate. Heparin flushes for line as indicated. Follow-up: Hematology within 3–7 days for anticoagulation management and anti-Xa/INR monitoring; Nephrology within 7–14 days for AKI reassessment and BMP; Cardiology in 2 weeks for heart failure management; PCP in 3 days. Home health to provide nursing for labs/medication management, PT/OT, and fall-risk supervision.

History of Present Illness: 59-year-old female admitted to observation for progressive rectal pain and bleeding attributed to symptomatic hemorrhoids. She reported associated constipation and a recent episode of urinary frequency/dysuria. Past medical history notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and iron deficiency anemia. Stool and urine studies raised concern for diverticular bleeding and urinary tract infection; urine culture later grew E. coli. Noted allergy/resistance to penicillins (documented).

Hospital Course: Patient was observed for 2.1 days. Initial evaluation included focused anorectal exam, CBC, basic metabolic panel, urinalysis and cultures, and IV fluids. She received IV ceftriaxone in the ED for UTI coverage pending cultures, analgesia (acetaminophen as needed), and bowel regimen including magnesium citrate and a bowel preparation as appropriate for evaluation. Hemoglobin remained stable without transfusion. Pain was controlled with oral analgesics and conservative anorectal measures. No evidence of active ongoing major GI hemorrhage; diverticulosis without perforation or abscess was confirmed on imaging reports.

Key Findings and Procedures: Key diagnoses on discharge include other hemorrhoids (symptomatic), residual hemorrhoidal skin tags, diverticulosis without perforation with prior bleeding, UTI due to E. coli, iron deficiency anemia, and chronic medical comorbidities (HTN, hyperlipidemia, obesity). A bedside anorectal procedure for symptomatic hemorrhoidal thrombosis was performed without complication. Urine culture sensitivities returned showing E. coli; penicillin resistance documented.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Ambulates with a steady gait but reports limited endurance with prolonged standing; independent with most ADLs but will benefit from assistance with home toilet transfers and medication management. Home health nursing arranged for wound/skin care, stool/bleeding monitoring, vital sign checks, and medication reconciliation.

Medications and Follow-up: Continue atorvastatin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, pantoprazole, acetaminophen PRN. Complete antibiotic therapy per outpatient prescription based on culture sensitivities; hold penicillin-class agents. Iron therapy to be started by PCP. Follow up with primary care within 3–7 days and colorectal surgery/GI within 2 weeks or sooner for persistent bleeding or pain.

History of present illness: 30-year-old female admitted under observation with biliary acute pancreatitis (K85.10) complicated by portal vein thrombosis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury, shock, hyperosmolality/hypernatremia, and nontraumatic abdominal compartment syndrome. Length of stay 27 days with prolonged intensive care needs.
Hospital course: Patient required initial intubation and mechanical ventilation for ARDS with subsequent successful extubation. She developed hemodynamic instability requiring brief vasopressor support and was treated for sepsis physiology. Acute kidney injury necessitated temporary renal replacement therapy and then gradual renal recovery. Portal vein thrombosis was managed with therapeutic anticoagulation. Electrolyte disturbances and hyperglycemia were corrected. Nutritional support included pancreatic enzyme replacement and enteral nutrition as tolerated. Wound care and monitoring were performed for abdominal compartment concerns; no infected necrosis identified.
Key findings and procedures: Imaging consistent with biliary pancreatitis without necrosis; Doppler confirmed portal vein thrombosis. Procedures performed included endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation, central venous access placement, percutaneous drain placement, and temporary renal replacement therapy. Cultures and serial imaging showed no pancreatic necrosis or persistent intra-abdominal infection.
Discharge condition and functional status: At discharge patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, ambulates with assistance, and requires intermittent assistance with activities of daily living. Renal function improved but not to baseline; creatinine trending down. Oxygen independent at rest. Home health recommended for skilled nursing, wound/ostomy/drain care, medication administration, and assistance with ADLs.
Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, pancreatic enzyme replacement (Creon 12), furosemide as needed, therapeutic anticoagulation (heparin transitioned to outpatient regimen), insulin with glucose monitoring, levothyroxine, multivitamin, ondansetron, topical antibiotic ointment, and short course oxycodone PRN. Follow-up appointments: GI/HPB clinic within 1 week for biliary source management and plan cholecystectomy; hematology within 1–2 weeks for thrombosis management; nephrology follow-up for AKI; primary care within 3–5 days. Labs (CMP, CBC, coagulation, lipase, renal function) within 48–72 hours and repeat abdominal imaging per GI recommendations.

History of present illness: 74-year-old female presented to the ED with acute onset bright red rectal bleeding and presyncope. Past history notable for hypertension, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, diverticulosis, colon polyps, hemorrhoids, and osteoporosis. Initial labs showed acute posthemorrhagic anemia (D62). She was observed for hemodynamic stability and management of lower GI bleed (primary diagnosis K55.21, angiodysplasia of colon with hemorrhage).

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to observation for 2.1 days. On arrival she received IV fluids (Lactated Ringers) and hemodynamic monitoring. Hemoglobin stabilized without blood transfusion. Gastroenterology performed diagnostic colonoscopy with targeted endoscopic therapy to the identified angiodysplastic lesion; cold snare polypectomy and focal coagulation were performed and biopsies were obtained. No active brisk bleeding after therapy. Pain and nausea were controlled (ondansetron PRN). Thyroid and chronic cardiac medications were held and resumed as tolerated. No procedural complications occurred. Pathology pending for polyp sample.

Key findings/procedures: Positive colonoscopic identification of angiodysplasia in the colon with minimal residual bleeding after endoscopic coagulation and polypectomy. Procedure performed without immediate complications.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable at discharge, ambulatory with a rolling walker and tolerating oral intake. Requires assistance with medication management and light instrumental activities of daily living; home health nursing recommended for medication reconciliation, wound/skin checks and monitoring for recurrent bleeding or symptomatic anemia.

Medications at discharge: Levothyroxine  (home dose), carvedilol (home dose), amlodipine, escitalopram, calcium carbonate, potassium citrate, vitamin D3, multivitamin, ondansetron PRN. Continue outpatient avoidance of NSAIDs and antiplatelet/anticoagulants until GI follow-up unless otherwise directed.

Follow-up plan: GI clinic within 7 days for procedure review and pathology results; PCP follow-up within 7–10 days. Repeat CBC in 48–72 hours with results to GI/PCP. Home health nursing to begin within 48 hours for medication assistance and bleeding surveillance.

Brief HPI: 19-year-old female presented to the ED with acute onset hematemesis and odynophagia. She has a history of soft-tissue malignancy (remote) and known liver disease. On presentation she was hemodynamically stabilized and admitted to observation for evaluation of upper GI bleeding and anemia.

Hospital course: Over a 3-day observation stay the patient received IV fluids, PPI therapy, and supportive care. Hematology consulted for thrombocytopenia and acute posthemorrhagic anemia. She received iron repletion with ferric gluconate and was monitored for transfusion criteria; bleeding was controlled endoscopically. Platelets were monitored; no emergent platelet transfusion was required. Influenza vaccination was administered prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Endoscopic evaluation (esophagogastroduodenoscopy) identified esophagitis and stigmata consistent with variceal/upper GI bleeding. Therapeutic hemostasis was performed endoscopically with appropriate measures and biopsies were taken of inflamed mucosa. Relevant diagnoses at discharge: esophagitis (K20.9), esophageal varices without current bleeding, hematemesis, thrombocytopenia, acute posthemorrhagic anemia, and chronic liver disease.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, with improving symptoms. She tolerates a soft oral diet and ambulates with minimal assistance. Home health services are arranged for skilled nursing visits to administer scheduled IV iron infusions, perform wound/line care and 0.9% sodium chloride flushes, monitor vitals and laboratory trends, and assist with medication administration and ADL support as needed.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include pantoprazole 40 mg PO daily, acetaminophen 500–650 mg PRN for pain/fever, and scheduled ferric gluconate per outpatient/home infusion plan. Avoid NSAIDs and alcohol. Follow-up: GI clinic within 1 week for variceal/liver management and review of pathology; hepatology within 1–2 weeks; hematology within 1 week. Labs (CBC, CMP) to be obtained in 48–72 hours and reviewed by primary team. Return to ED for recurrent bleeding, syncope, chest pain, or worsening dyspnea.

HPI: 46-year-old female admitted emergently for acute neurologic change and found to have a cerebral infarction due to embolism of the left posterior cerebral artery (I63.432). She has history notable for metastatic disease to the lungs, nonrheumatic mitral regurgitation, essential hypertension, hypothyroidism, and prior malignancy. NIHSS on evaluation was 0. Length of stay 2 days.

Hospital course: CT head and brain MRI confirmed an acute left PCA infarct without large vessel occlusion. Cardiac evaluation (echocardiogram) showed nonrheumatic mitral insufficiency without obvious thrombus. She was monitored in the stroke service, received VTE prophylaxis with enoxaparin while inpatient, and was started on secondary prevention with aspirin and high‑intensity statin therapy. Blood pressure and glucose were managed and optimized; home antihypertensive (quinapril) continued. No acute intervention (thrombolysis or thrombectomy) was indicated. Symptoms improved and she remained neurologically stable.

Key findings/procedures: MRI brain demonstrating left PCA infarct; transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrating mitral regurgitation; routine labs and cardiac rhythm monitoring without arrhythmia detected. NIHSS 0 at discharge.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Neurologically at baseline with no focal motor deficits; ambulates independently but reports intermittent dizziness and mild balance impairment. Independent with basic ADLs but has increased fall risk. Home health referral is requested for skilled nursing medication reconciliation and BP/glucose monitoring, and PT for balance and gait training.

Medications at discharge (selected): Aspirin 81 mg daily; Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly; Quinapril 10 mg daily (continue home dose as tolerated); Docusate sodium PRN; Senna PRN for constipation; Acetaminophen PRN for pain. Enoxaparin was used inpatient for VTE prophylaxis and is not continued at discharge. Continue home levothyroxine and insulin regimen as previously prescribed; adjust per outpatient results.

Follow-up: Primary care in 3–7 days for med reconciliation and BP/glucose check; neurology clinic within 1–2 weeks; oncology follow-up per treating team within 2 weeks; cardiology as outpatient for MR and HTN management. Recommended labs prior to follow-up: BMP, CBC, lipid panel, TSH, HbA1c. Home health to provide nursing and PT services as above.

History of present illness: 52-year-old female admitted urgently with acute severe epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting. Labs on admission demonstrated markedly elevated lipase; RUQ ultrasound/CT consistent with choledocholithiasis and acute biliary pancreatitis (primary diagnosis: K85.10). She has a history of cholelithiasis with chronic cholecystitis (K80.45), GERD, depression, alcohol and nicotine use disorder, and bilateral knee osteoarthritis.

Hospital course: The patient was managed with NPO, aggressive IV fluid resuscitation (Lactated Ringers), antiemetics (ondansetron), acid suppression (omeprazole), and multimodal analgesia (inpatient morphine/hydromorphone, transitioned to oral oxycodone/acetaminophen). Prophylactic VTE measures were used. On hospital day 1 she underwent urgent ERCP with sphincterotomy and common bile duct stone extraction; no perforation or retained large fragments. Given persistent cholecystitis/cholelithiasis, she underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy on hospital day 3 without intraoperative complications. Cultures were not positive; ciprofloxacin was prescribed empirically given concern for cholangitis. Psychiatric history was addressed and home medications (fluoxetine) continued.

Key findings and procedures: Elevated lipase consistent with pancreatitis, imaging-confirmed choledocholithiasis; procedures performed: ERCP with stone extraction and sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy. No pancreatic necrosis or infected collections identified.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, pain controlled on oral analgesics, tolerating a low-fat soft diet. Mobility: ambulates with assistive device at baseline due to bilateral knee osteoarthritis; requires assistance with stair negotiation and limited endurance—home health recommended for short-term ADL support and ambulation safety. Incisions clean and dry; home health to perform wound checks and suture/staple removal as needed.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, oxycodone IR (short course), ciprofloxacin PO x7 days, omeprazole, docusate, fluoxetine, folic acid and multivitamins, ondansetron PRN. Follow-up: General surgery in 7–14 days, PCP in 3–7 days, gastroenterology as needed, and outpatient addiction/behavioral health referral for alcohol use. Return for fever, worsening abdominal pain, increased incision drainage, or inability to tolerate PO intake.

History of Present Illness: 80-year-old male with end-stage renal disease on chronic hemodialysis presented under observation status for evaluation of presumed infection involving a vascular device (ICD-10: T827XXA). He reported redness and tenderness at his dialysis access site with intermittent fevers prior to admission. Past medical history notable for stage 5 CKD on dialysis, hypertensive CKD, myelodysplastic syndrome, prior prostate malignancy, and dependence on renal dialysis.

Hospital Course: During the 1.8-day observation stay, blood cultures and wound cultures were obtained and the access site was inspected. He received empiric broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (vancomycin and cefepime) and supportive care including IV fluids and acetaminophen for symptomatic control. Dialysis treatments continued through his chronic access without interruption. Laboratory monitoring and clinical reassessment demonstrated clinical improvement: he remained hemodynamically stable, afebrile for >24 hours, and pain was controlled. No acute surgical intervention was required during this admission.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive local signs of infection at the vascular access; cultures sent. Peripheral IV access placed for antibiotic administration. Ongoing dialysis via existing access documented. Imaging was not required during observation.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, with improved local signs of infection and adequate pain control. Functionally, he is independent with transfers and ambulation with a rolling walker for longer distances, but requires assistance with wound care and medication management at home. Home health nursing arranged for wound/site assessments, IV antibiotic administration and coordination with dialysis.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Continue IV antibiotics as outpatient per Infectious Disease plan (home IV vancomycin with trough monitoring). Other discharge medications: torsemide, sevelamer carbonate, folic acid, multivitamins, sodium citrate as prescribed, acetaminophen PRN. Follow up with Nephrology within 7 days, Infectious Disease within 48–72 hours, and Primary Care in 1 week. Home health nursing arranged for vascular access wound care, IV antibiotic administration, medication reconciliation, and dialysis coordination.

Patient: 52-year-old male. Admission: Observation admit x2 days for postprocedural complication (primary diagnosis K91.89) with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and intermittent nausea. Past history notable for obstructive sleep apnea and nicotine dependence. Presented with worsening RUQ pain after recent surgical procedure; no active bleeding or hemodynamic instability on arrival.

Hospital course: Patient observed for 48 hours. Evaluation included serial abdominal exams, basic labs, and abdominal imaging to assess for postprocedural complication. He received IV fluids (D5 1/2NS, 5% dextrose as indicated), analgesia (hydromorphone IV for acute pain, transitioned to oxycodone immediate release PRN on discharge), and antimicrobial therapy with IV ciprofloxacin and metronidazole, transitioned to oral ciprofloxacin and metronidazole prior to discharge. DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was administered during stay. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was given prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging and clinical assessment did not demonstrate need for operative intervention; no evidence of perforation or ongoing hemorrhage. Patient had improvement in pain and tolerating oral intake at discharge. No signs of systemic infection or organ dysfunction. Observation status, short-stay improvement noted.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge; ambulatory with mild limitation from pain and requires assistance with medication administration and activity pacing—home health recommended for medication management, pain monitoring, and assistance with activities of daily living as needed. Continue CPAP at home for obstructive sleep apnea. Fall risk counseling provided due to opioid use.

Medications at discharge: Ciprofloxacin (oral) and Metronidazole (oral) to complete prescribed course; acetaminophen scheduled; oxycodone IR PRN for breakthrough pain; senna for bowel regimen; simethicone for gas; continue nicotine dependence history counseling. Heparin and IV medications discontinued. Wound/incision care instructions provided if applicable.

Follow-up: Primary care follow-up within 48–72 hours; surgical/procedural clinic or GI follow-up in 7–14 days or sooner for recurrent/worsening symptoms. Seek immediate care for fever, worsening abdominal pain, vomiting, or signs of bleeding.

History of Present Illness: 48-year-old female presented to the ED with progressive right lower extremity erythema, swelling and pain consistent with cellulitis. Significant past medical history includes Crohn’s disease with ileostomy, prior granulomatous skin disorder, and intermittent hypotension. She was admitted under observation for IV antibiotic therapy and monitoring.

Hospital Course: Patient observed for 2.8 days. On admission she received IV vancomycin and cefazolin, isotonic fluids, antiemetic therapy (ondansetron) and DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin. Clinical status improved over the observation period with reduction in erythema, decreased pain, improved mobility, and hemodynamic stability. Leukocytosis trended toward normal. Blood and wound cultures showed no growth during admission. No surgical intervention or incision and drainage was required. Patient was converted to oral antibiotics prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Right lower extremity exam showed resolving erythema and edema without fluctuance; distal pulses intact. Ostomy site inspected and remained intact without local infection. No operative procedures performed.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable and afebrile at discharge. Pain is controlled on oral medications. Ambulates with minimal assistance and is independent with basic ADLs but requires support for ostomy care and daily dressing changes. Home health recommended for wound/ostomy care, medication administration assistance, vital sign monitoring, and ongoing skin assessment given prior hypotension and cellulitis.

Medications at Discharge: Cephalexin PO (oral antibiotic), Sulfamethoxazole/Trimethoprim DS PO (adjunct oral coverage), acetaminophen and ibuprofen PRN for pain, oxycodone IR short course PRN, ondansetron PRN for nausea. Inpatient IV antibiotics (vancomycin, cefazolin) and heparin discontinued.

Follow-up Plan: Primary care follow-up within 48–72 hours. Infectious disease or wound clinic follow-up within 7 days and ostomy clinic/GI follow-up for Crohn’s disease and ileostomy management within 1–2 weeks. Return immediately for fever, progressive erythema, new drainage, worsening pain, dizziness or syncope, or other signs of systemic infection.

History of Present Illness: 56-year-old man presented to the ED with progressive left ankle and foot pain, erythema, and drainage. Past medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus with recent hyperglycemia, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, obstructive sleep apnea, and chronic liver disease with ascites. Imaging (MRI) and clinical examination were consistent with osteomyelitis of the left ankle/foot with associated cellulitis.

Hospital Course: Admitted directly from ED for IV antibiotics and operative management. He underwent surgical irrigation, debridement and incision and drainage of the infected left foot wound with intraoperative cultures obtained. A PICC line was placed for long-term IV therapy. Empiric IV nafcillin was started and later tailored to culture sensitivities. He received DVT prophylaxis, diuresis for ascites with furosemide, glycemic management with sliding scale and scheduled insulin, and continuation of home levothyroxine. Respiratory status remained stable on home CPAP. No acute hepatic decompensation occurred; paracentesis was not required during this admission.

Key Findings and Procedures: MRI consistent with osteomyelitis; wound cultures positive for gram-positive organisms sensitive to nafcillin. Procedures: surgical debridement/irrigation and drainage of left foot abscess; PICC placement for outpatient IV antibiotics.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, pain controlled on oral opioids as needed. Ambulates with a rolling walker for short distances and requires assistance with stair negotiation. Wound is clean with sterile dressing; patient requires skilled nursing for dressing changes and PICC care. Home health recommended for wound care and assistance with ADLs.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on IV nafcillin via home infusion for planned 6-week total antibiotic course; insulin regimen adjusted with supplies and teaching provided. Continued: levothyroxine, nadolol (portal hypertension management), furosemide, atorvastatin, PPI for GERD, and short course oral analgesics. Follow-up: Infectious Disease in 1 week, Wound clinic/podiatry in 3–5 days, Primary Care within 1 week, Hepatology in 2 weeks. Home health nursing to provide PICC care, wound dressing changes, medication administration, and glucose monitoring.

History of Present Illness: 78-year-old female admitted urgently with chest pain and dyspnea. Evaluation revealed a non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with elevated troponin and ischemic changes on ECG. Significant comorbidities include Parkinson disease with autonomic dysfunction, prior pulmonary embolism, atherosclerotic coronary disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and prior breast malignancy.

Hospital Course: Patient was admitted to telemetry for medical management of NSTEMI (length of stay 2.9 days). She received therapeutic heparin in hospital, was initiated/continued on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel), and started on high-intensity statin therapy (atorvastatin). Cardiology evaluated and recommended conservative management without urgent percutaneous coronary intervention given overall clinical status and comorbidities. No arrhythmias or recurrent ischemia occurred. Orthostatic hypotension and autonomic instability were addressed; home blood-pressure support medications (midodrine, fludrocortisone) were continued/optimized. Parkinson medications (carbidopa-levodopa immediate and controlled release, entacapone) and levothyroxine were continued. Influenza vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Diagnostic evaluation consistent with NSTEMI (elevated cardiac enzymes, ECG changes). No invasive coronary intervention performed during this admission. Hemodynamically stable at discharge; no acute heart failure exacerbation documented.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable but demonstrates baseline gait impairment and orthostatic symptoms from autonomic dysfunction and Parkinson disease. She requires assistance with transfers and instrumental ADLs and has increased fall risk. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing, medication reconciliation, and monitoring of orthostatic vital signs; physical and occupational therapy for gait and safety recommended.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge med list includes aspirin EC, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, carbidopa-levodopa (ODT and CR), entacapone, midodrine, fludrocortisone, levothyroxine, hydralazine as needed for BP, docusate, albuterol inhaler, acetaminophen. Heparin stopped. Follow-up: cardiology within 7 days, primary care within 3–5 days, neurology as outpatient; labs (BMP, CBC, troponin trend, TSH) in 1 week; outpatient PT/OT through home health.

58-year-old female admitted emergently for progressive dyspnea and volume overload following a recent procedure. On presentation she was hypoxemic with large right pleural effusion, ascites, and evidence of volume overload. Past medical history notable for alcoholic cirrhosis with ascites, Barrett’s esophagus, obesity, essential hypertension, major depressive disorder, and chronic noninfective gastroenteritis. Primary diagnosis: Other complications of procedures (T81.89XA) with associated pleural effusion (J90), pancytopenia (D61.818), alcoholic cirrhosis with ascites (K70.31), and fluid overload.

Hospital course: Patient underwent ultrasound-guided diagnostic and therapeutic right thoracentesis with symptomatic improvement in dyspnea. Therapeutic paracentesis was performed for tense ascites with symptomatic relief. She received 25% albumin, diuretic therapy (IV then transitioned to oral furosemide), IV fluids as indicated, ferric gluconate for iron deficiency, magnesium supplementation, lactulose for encephalopathy prophylaxis, and supportive care. Hematology evaluated pancytopenia; no acute transfusion requirement was identified during admission. Psychiatry provided medication reconciliation and continuation of sertraline/paroxetine regimen for depression; sleep support with ramelteon initiated. VTE prophylaxis with heparin was administered while inpatient. Chest radiography and bedside ultrasound confirmed decreased effusion post-procedure.

Key findings and procedures: large right pleural effusion drained by thoracentesis; therapeutic paracentesis for ascites; labs notable for anemia and thrombocytopenia consistent with pancytopenia; imaging consistent with effusions and cirrhotic changes.

Discharge condition and functional status: patient is stable for discharge, hemodynamically stable and ambulatory short distances with a rolling walker; limited endurance and deconditioning requiring assistance with transfers and some ADLs. Home health recommended for skilled nursing visits for medication administration, daily weights/edema monitoring, vital signs, and assistance with ADL and mobility.

Medications and follow-up: discharged on furosemide, lactulose, pantoprazole, paroxetine, ramelteon, acetaminophen PRN, magnesium oxide, oxycodone PRN for procedure pain. Labs to be rechecked (CBC, CMP) within 48–72 hours. Outpatient follow-up: PCP within 7 days, hepatology in 1–2 weeks, pulmonology within 1 week for CXR and effusion reassessment, hematology 1–2 weeks, and psychiatry/primary care for depression management. Home health to coordinate medication reconciliation and monitoring.

History of Present Illness: 52-year-old male admitted urgently with acute right upper quadrant pain, nausea and elevated lipase. Imaging and labs were consistent with calculus of the gallbladder with obstruction and biliary acute pancreatitis (ICD-10 K80.63, K85.10). Past medical history notable for obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (uses CPAP), and tobacco use.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent urgent laparoscopic cholecystectomy with intraoperative cholangiogram on admission day 1. No retained common bile duct stones were identified during the procedure. Postoperative course was notable for transient elevation in pancreatic enzymes consistent with biliary pancreatitis managed conservatively with bowel rest, IV fluids, and gradual diet advancement. He received perioperative antibiotics (ciprofloxacin and metronidazole), DVT prophylaxis with heparin while inpatient, and multimodal analgesia transitioning from IV to oral. He had mild right-sided pleural effusion/atelectasis treated with incentive spirometry and ambulation. A transient thrombocytopenia was observed and trended to stable range prior to discharge.

Key Findings/Procedures: Diagnostic imaging consistent with obstructing cholelithiasis and biliary pancreatitis. Procedures: laparoscopic cholecystectomy with intraoperative cholangiogram (ICD-10-PCS 0FT44ZZ, 0F798DZ, 0FC98ZZ). No intraoperative complications. Wounds clean, dry, intact.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge the patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating a regular diet, and pain controlled on oral analgesics. Ambulates independently in the home environment but reports decreased endurance and requires assistance with longer ambulation/stairs; home health recommended for short-term assistance with wound checks, safe ambulation, medication management, and breathing exercises for atelectasis prevention. Independent with basic ADLs but will benefit from home PT evaluation.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on oral ciprofloxacin and metronidazole to complete prescribed course, acetaminophen and oxycodone for breakthrough pain (short course), docusate and bisacodyl for bowel regimen, ondansetron and prochlorperazine as needed, potassium chloride and Neutra-Phos as directed. Heparin discontinued. Follow-up with general surgery in 1–2 weeks, PCP in 7 days with labs (CBC, CMP, LFTs) in 48–72 hours, and GI if symptoms of obstructive jaundice recur. Return to ER for fever, increasing abdominal pain, jaundice, or wound concerns.

Mr. X is a 79-year-old man admitted to observation for 48 hours with acute onset dysuria, fever, and confusion. Past medical history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections (history of UTI), type 2 diabetes with CKD, prior TIA/CVA without residual deficit, hyperlipidemia, and episodes of hypotension. Initial evaluation was notable for tachycardia, altered mental status consistent with toxic encephalopathy, and laboratory evidence concerning for acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease. Urinalysis was suggestive of infection; urine culture pending at discharge.

Hospital course: The patient received initial IV ceftriaxone with clinical improvement in fever and urinary symptoms and partial resolution of encephalopathic features. Intravenous fluids (lactated Ringer’s and iso‑osmotic dextrose) were administered with careful monitoring of hemodynamics given baseline hypotension. Renal function stabilized without need for dialysis. Acyclovir was given empirically early for possible viral encephalitis but discontinued after clinical reassessment and low suspicion. No invasive procedures were required. He remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile for >24 hours prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Positive urinalysis; AKI on CKD that improved with fluids and infection control; no radiographic source identified; blood cultures were negative to date. No catheter placement or surgical intervention performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: He is discharged medically stable, alert and oriented to person and place with improved mentation but intermittent confusion; ambulates with a cane and requires home assistance for medication management and safety supervision due to fall and hypotension risk. Home health recommended for medication reconciliation, vital sign and fluid status monitoring, and assistance with ADLs as needed.

Medications and follow-up: Transitioned to oral ciprofloxacin to complete antibiotic course (adjusted for renal function), resume home medications (aspirin, metoprolol, atorvastatin, cilostazol, ophthalmic regimen as listed). Labs (BMP and repeat renal function) within 48–72 hours; follow-up with PCP within 48–72 hours and nephrology within 1–2 weeks. Urine culture result to be communicated and antibiotic adjusted if indicated. If recurrent confusion or worsening urine output, seek ED care.

Brief HPI: 67-year-old male admitted under observation for acute hypercapnic respiratory failure (ICD-10 J96.02) on a background of COPD with acute exacerbation, known right upper-lobe lung malignancy, chronic diastolic heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with progressive dyspnea, cough, and hypoventilation and was found to have fever, hypotension, and radiographic right upper-lobe consolidation with pleural effusion.

Hospital course: The patient required a brief period of ventilatory support with invasive ventilation followed by successful wean to noninvasive ventilation (BiPAP) and then to supplemental oxygen. He received IV antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia, diuretics for acute on chronic heart failure exacerbation, and cautious fluid management for acute kidney injury with improvement of renal function. Respiratory therapy provided bronchodilator treatments, inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta-agonist initiation, and secretion clearance. Therapeutic thoracentesis was performed with symptomatic improvement. Hemodynamics stabilized; hypotension resolved with supportive care.

Key findings and procedures: ABG consistent with hypercapnic respiratory failure; chest radiograph/CT with RUL consolidation and pleural effusion; diagnostic/therapeutic thoracentesis performed; temporal invasive ventilation with subsequent BiPAP support and downward titration of supplemental oxygen.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is clinically stable at discharge on low-flow supplemental oxygen (2 L/min at rest, up to 4 L/min with exertion) and nocturnal BiPAP. He remains deconditioned and requires assistance with ambulation and some ADLs; physical therapy recommended. Home health services arranged for skilled nursing, respiratory therapy, and PT to support recovery, oxygen titration, medication reconciliation, and wound/procedure site monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include albuterol inhaler PRN, fluticasone-salmeterol Diskus, azithromycin (complete prescribed course), benzonatate PRN, digoxin, diltiazem ER, aspirin, fenofibrate, fish oil, chlorhexidine oral rinse, bupropion SR and other home meds. Home oxygen and nocturnal BiPAP prescribed. Follow-up: pulmonary clinic 1 week, primary care 3–5 days, cardiology 2 weeks, oncology as scheduled. Home health nursing to visit within 48 hours for assessment and medication reconciliation.

History of Present Illness: 85-year-old man admitted emergently with fever, lethargy and hypotension. Blood cultures and labs consistent with sepsis (A41.9). Pertinent history includes intrahepatic bile duct carcinoma (C22.1), choledocholithiasis with acute cholecystitis (K80.63), permanent atrial fibrillation on chronic warfarin (I48.21, Z79.01), and baseline mobility limited by deconditioning.

Hospital Course: Over a 3.5-day admission he received aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics with transition to ciprofloxacin for presumed biliary source after cultures and clinical response. He required temporary hemodynamic support for postprocedural hypotension which resolved. Anticoagulation was held on admission and managed with daily INR monitoring; warfarin was resumed at a reduced dose prior to discharge with outpatient monitoring. Rate control for atrial arrhythmia was achieved with diltiazem and metoprolol adjustments. Electrolyte repletion (magnesium sulfate) and supportive care were provided. He remained afebrile for 48 hours and inflammatory markers declined.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive sepsis workup with abnormal coagulation profile and imaging consistent with biliary obstruction. Procedures performed included vascular access placement for resuscitation and antibiotics (0FPB8DZ), percutaneous biliary decompression intervention (0F798DZ), and diagnostic abdominal imaging (0FC98ZZ). Influenza high-dose quadrivalent vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and tolerating oral intake. Ambulation is limited; requires assistance with transfers and gait (uses walker and assistance from caregiver). Home health is arranged for skilled nursing visits for medication administration oversight, IV/PO antibiotic adherence as indicated, wound/IV-site assessment, and fall-risk/functional mobility support.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharged on ciprofloxacin (per ID guidance), resumed warfarin with plan for frequent INR checks by home health and anticoagulation clinic, diltiazem and metoprolol for rate control, and scheduled 0.9% saline flush supplies as needed. Follow-up: PCP in 48–72 hours, Infectious Diseases in 7 days, hepatobiliary/oncology clinic within 2 weeks, and anticoagulation clinic per INR results. Patient/caregiver educated on signs of recurrent infection, bleeding, and when to seek urgent care.

Brief HPI: 59-year-old man with known cirrhosis and portal hypertension presented to the ED with progressive abdominal distension, dyspnea, hypoxia, fever and intermittent confusion. He was observed for suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), sepsis, and respiratory failure. Admission diagnosis: portal hypertension complicated by SBP, sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, ascites, and anemia.

Hospital course: Over a 4.7-day observation stay the patient underwent diagnostic and therapeutic large-volume paracentesis with fluid testing consistent with SBP. He received empiric IV ceftriaxone, albumin 25% after paracentesis, supportive IV fluids, and short course octreotide for variceal prophylaxis. He required supplemental oxygen and brief noninvasive respiratory support; oxygen requirement was weaned to baseline prior to discharge. He was transfused for acute posthemorrhagic anemia. Encephalopathy was treated with lactulose with improvement in mentation. Blood and ascites cultures were obtained; antimicrobial therapy will be adjusted per final cultures.

Key findings/procedures: diagnostic/therapeutic paracentesis, blood transfusion, respiratory support, IV antibiotic therapy, albumin administration. Imaging and labs showed decompensated cirrhosis with ascites, anemia and systemic inflammatory response consistent with sepsis/SBP.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home. He is hemodynamically stable, oxygenating on room air or low-flow O2 as tolerated, mentation improved to baseline but mildly deconditioned. Requires assistance with ambulation and ADLs; home health services arranged for nursing visits and physical therapy.

Medications at discharge (selected): IV ceftriaxone to be continued via home health infusion to complete prescribed course (plan: total 5–7 days or per cultures), lactulose titrate to 2–3 soft stools/day, ciprofloxacin per MD if oral step-down indicated, acetaminophen PRN, oxycodone short course for pain PRN, albuterol inhaler PRN. Influenza vaccine given during stay.

Follow-up: Hepatology/transplant clinic within 7 days, primary care within 48–72 hours, home health nursing for IV therapy, vitals, wound/line care and PT 2–3x weekly. Return precautions: fever, worsening abdominal pain/distension, melena/hematemesis, increased confusion, dyspnea or syncope—return to ED immediately.

76-year-old male with history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) not in remission, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, type 2 diabetes with diabetic retinopathy with macular edema, hypothyroidism, and prior long-term anticoagulant use presented to observation for acute left upper extremity swelling and pain. Imaging confirmed acute thrombus of the left upper extremity deep veins. Admission was for initiation and monitoring of anticoagulation and assessment of bleeding risk given bilateral retinal hemorrhages.

Hospital course: Patient was observed for 3.9 days. Hematology and cardiology were consulted. Therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin was initiated and tolerance was closely monitored (no clinical major bleeding events). Ibrutinib therapy for CLL was continued in coordination with hematology. Ophthalmology evaluated retinal hemorrhages and agreed anticoagulation could proceed with outpatient close follow-up. Blood glucose was managed with inpatient insulin adjustments; home levothyroxine and atenolol were continued. Prophylactic anti-infective measures (acyclovir, atovaquone) were continued per oncology recommendations. Methylprednisolone was given short course for symptomatic control as indicated by oncology.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging confirmed left upper extremity DVT. No clinical evidence of pulmonary embolism during stay. Procedure performed: intravenous/subcutaneous pharmacologic anticoagulation administration (ICD-10-PCS 6A550Z1 documented). Labs during admission: CBC and chemistries stable for discharge; platelet count acceptable for continued anticoagulation.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. He is alert and oriented, ambulates with steady gait but reports mild deconditioning and fatigue. Requires home health support for medication management (anticoagulant and insulin administration), blood glucose monitoring, and intermittent assistance with ADLs.

Medications and follow-up: Discharged on enoxaparin for anticoagulation, continued ibrutinib, insulin regimen, levothyroxine, atenolol, acyclovir, atovaquone and short steroid taper as prescribed. Follow-up arranged: Hematology within 1 week, Ophthalmology within 1 week, Cardiology in 1–2 weeks, and PCP within 3 days. Outpatient labs (CBC, CMP) in 3 days and as directed by hematology. Home health to provide medication administration, vitals and bleeding surveillance, glucose monitoring, and assistance with ADLs.

History of present illness: 82-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for symptomatic severe nonrheumatic aortic valve stenosis. She underwent planned surgical aortic valve replacement with cardiopulmonary bypass. Admission complicated by postoperative atrial fibrillation and acute posthemorrhagic anemia.

Hospital course: Patient remained 4.7 days inpatient. Operative course was uncomplicated from a surgical standpoint. She was extubated on return to the ICU after brief ventilatory support. Postoperatively she developed new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response on POD 1 that responded to rate control with metoprolol and careful fluid management. She experienced acute blood loss anemia requiring packed red blood cell transfusion with subsequent stabilization of hemoglobin. Pain controlled with acetaminophen and gabapentin; bowel regimen started (docusate, bisacodyl). She received influenza vaccination prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Preoperative echocardiogram consistent with severe aortic stenosis. Procedural codes indicate open aortic valve replacement with prosthetic valve and intraoperative cardiopulmonary support. Post-op telemetry demonstrated transient atrial fibrillation; no sustained ischemia. No evidence of wound infection. Estimated blood loss addressed with transfusion.
