Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, with adequate oral intake and pain controlled on oral regimen. Ambulates short household distances with a rolling walker and requires assistance for stair negotiation; baseline independence with basic ADLs preserved but with decreased endurance. Home health recommended for wound checks, vital sign and weight monitoring, medication administration assistance as needed, and support for ambulation/transfer safety.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include aspirin (enteric coated), metoprolol tartrate for rate control, furosemide as needed, acetaminophen PRN, gabapentin, docusate and bisacodyl, insulin per home regimen, and routine heparin flushes for IV access as indicated. Home health nursing to visit within 24–48 hours. Follow-up with cardiothoracic surgery in 1–2 weeks and PCP in 7 days; cardiology follow-up for rhythm/anticoagulation management as needed. Patient and caregiver educated on incision care, signs of bleeding, and when to seek urgent care.

History of Present Illness: 78-year-old female admitted to observation after acute onset severe headache with transient aphasia and witnessed brief shaking episode. Initial noncontrast CT head demonstrated subarachnoid hemorrhage. CTA/vascular imaging identified a cerebral aneurysm; no radiographic evidence of hydrocephalus or large territory infarction.

Hospital Course: Patient was observed for 2.8 days. Neurology and neurosurgery were consulted. She was monitored on continuous telemetry due to episodes of supraventricular tachycardia managed with nadolol and rate control as tolerated. Seizure activity was treated empirically with levetiracetam and no recurrent convulsive events occurred while inpatient. DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin was provided. Speech-language pathology evaluated persistent expressive aphasia and recommended continued outpatient SLP. Osteoporosis and carotid disease were noted in the chart; vascular surgery recommended outpatient carotid follow-up for definitive management.

Key Findings and Procedures: Noncontrast CT head positive for nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. CTA demonstrated a cerebral aneurysm without active extravasation. Continuous cardiac telemetry captured supraventricular tachycardia episodes. Procedures performed: diagnostic neuroimaging, continuous monitoring, and bedside assessments by neurology, neurosurgery, SLP, and PT.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is neurologically stable, hemodynamically stable, and afebrile at discharge. Residual expressive aphasia and mild gait instability remain; she requires assistance with some ambulation and moderate help with instrumental ADLs. Home health nursing and therapy are recommended for medication supervision, seizure precautions, fall-risk mitigation, and rehabilitative therapies.

Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen, atorvastatin, docusate sodium, heparin (as ordered), levetiracetam, nadolol, senna, vitamin D, and supportive nasal/saline products. Influenza and pneumococcal (PPSV23) vaccines were administered.

Follow-up: Neurosurgery within 1–2 weeks for aneurysm management discussion, outpatient neurology within 1 week, cardiology for SVT evaluation, vascular surgery for carotid stenosis, and primary care within 1 week for medication reconciliation and home health initiation. Home health referral placed for RN, PT, OT, and SLP services.

History of Present Illness: 41-year-old man presented to the emergency department with acute right-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea after a coughing episode. Chest radiograph and CT demonstrated a right-sided pneumothorax (primary diagnosis: other pneumothorax, ICD-10 J93.83). Past history notable for asthma (J45.909), sequelae of prior infectious disease (B94.8), and opioid dependence in remission (F11.21).

Hospital Course: Patient was admitted emergently for management of symptomatic pneumothorax. He underwent percutaneous drainage of the right pleural space with placement of a small-bore chest tube (ICD-10-PCS 0W9930Z) on hospital day 0. He received analgesia (hydromorphone PRN and ketorolac), topical lidocaine 5% patches, gabapentin for neuropathic-type pain, and acetaminophen as adjunct. Subcutaneous heparin was given for DVT prophylaxis. Serial chest radiographs demonstrated progressive re-expansion of the right lung; chest tube was removed on hospital day 2 after minimal air leak and radiographic stability. No evidence of recurrent pneumothorax prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Imaging-confirmed right pneumothorax with successful percutaneous pleural drainage and chest tube placement/removal. Vital signs remained stable off supplemental oxygen; oxygen saturation >94% on room air. No infectious complications.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulating with mild dyspnea on exertion, able to perform most activities of daily living independently with instruction to limit heavy lifting and avoid Valsalva maneuvers for two weeks. Home health referral placed for wound/chest tube site checks, medication reconciliation, and activity monitoring. Home health to monitor respiratory status and assist with arranging outpatient imaging.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen, gabapentin, intermittent hydromorphone (short course PRN), ketorolac PRN, lidocaine 5% patch PRN, montelukast daily, and heparin noted as inpatient DVT prophylaxis (no outpatient anticoagulation prescribed). Sodium chloride 0.9% flush for IV access as needed. Follow-up in thoracic surgery/pulmonology clinic in 5–7 days and primary care within 1 week. Repeat chest x-ray in 48–72 hours and sooner for increased dyspnea, fever, or chest pain.

History of present illness: 70-year-old man admitted emergently with progressive obstructive jaundice, pain, and a pathologic femoral fracture in the setting of known metastatic neuroendocrine tumor. Admission complicated by hyperglycemia, steroid exposure, and acute-on-chronic pain. Length of stay 12 days.

Hospital course: The patient underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with biliary stent placement for relief of obstructive biliary symptoms and subsequently had operative fixation of a pathologic femoral fracture. A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) was placed for systemic therapy and IV access. He received first-cycle systemic chemotherapy with carboplatin and etoposide with standard antiemetic prophylaxis (fosaprepitant, dexamethasone) and supportive IV fluids; enoxaparin was given for prophylaxis. His hyperglycemia was addressed with short-acting glycemic measures while inpatient. Pain was managed with multimodal analgesia. No inpatient infectious complications. Steroid-associated adverse effects were recognized and minimized prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging confirmed biliary obstruction secondary to metastatic disease. ERCP with biliary stent provided successful decompression. Orthopedic evaluation and operative fixation addressed the pathological femoral fracture. PICC line placed for chemotherapy administration.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, and pain is controlled on oral analgesics. Mobility is limited; ambulates short distances with a walker and requires assistance with transfers and ADLs. Home health nursing arranged for wound checks, PICC care and medication administration education; home physical therapy for gait and strength training is in place.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge meds include carboplatin and etoposide (outpatient oncology-administered cycles per oncology schedule), dexamethasone short course, fosaprepitant PRN per chemo protocol, aspirin, enalapril, enoxaparin (short-term prophylaxis), bisacodyl for bowel regimen, and glucose support as needed. Follow-up: oncology within 7 days for ongoing systemic therapy planning, orthopedics 7–10 days for wound check, primary care/cardiology for chronic disease management, endocrinology as outpatient for diabetes control, and home health nursing and PT as arranged. Return precautions reviewed.

History of Present Illness: 78-year-old male admitted electively for revision of a leaking aortic bifurcation graft (ICD-10 T82.330A). Past medical history notable for chronic kidney disease stage 4, atrial fibrillation, hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease with heart failure (diastolic), peripheral polyneuropathy, hyperlipidemia, and gout.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent endovascular revision of the aortic bifurcation graft (ICD-10-PCS 02UW4JZ) on hospital day 1 without intraoperative complications. Perioperative anticoagulation was managed intraoperatively with heparin and held postoperatively per vascular surgery recommendations. Postoperative recovery was uncomplicated: hemodynamics stable, pain controlled, and surgical site without evidence of ongoing bleeding or infection. Renal function remained at baseline for his CKD stage 4 with serial BMPs and urine output monitored. Rhythm remained atrial fibrillation; no acute ischemic changes on telemetry. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Successful endovascular revision of leaking aortic bifurcation graft. Imaging confirmed correction of graft leak. Postoperative labs and vitals were stable. No new neurologic deficits; baseline peripheral neuropathy unchanged.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is stable for discharge to home with home health services. Ambulates with a rolling walker and requires steadying assistance for longer distances; independent with bed-to-chair transfers with supervision. Needs assistance with medication management and wound care; home health to monitor incision site, daily weights, vitals (BP, pulse, O2 sat), and edema assessment.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharged on home regimen including aspirin, pravastatin, labetalol, furosemide, clonidine, acetaminophen PRN, allopurinol, calcitriol, docusate sodium, and artificial tears. Anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation is deferred pending outpatient vascular/cardiology discussion. He received influenza vaccine prior to discharge. Follow-up: vascular surgery in 10–14 days for wound check and imaging; nephrology within 7 days for CKD management and labs; cardiology in 1–2 weeks to reassess rhythm and anticoagulation; primary care within 7 days. Home health to begin immediately for wound care, medication reconciliation, BP and weight monitoring, and assistance with activities of daily living.

Brief history of present illness: 75-year-old female presented to the ED with acute onset severe vertigo, nausea, vomiting and unsteady gait. Symptoms began 48 hours prior to admission. She has a history of bilateral total knee arthroplasties, chronic kidney disease stage 3, polyneuropathy, glaucoma, and recurrent osteoarthritis. Primary working diagnosis: vestibular neuronitis (H81.20). Urinalysis suggested a urinary tract infection on presentation.

Hospital course: Observed 1.6 days. Neurologic exam showed spontaneous horizontal nystagmus and positive head impulse testing; no focal deficits or stroke signs. CT head was nonacute. Treated with IV isotonic fluids (0.9% NaCl), antiemetic (ondansetron) for symptom control, single-dose IV ceftriaxone for suspected UTI pending culture, and subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. Latanoprost ophthalmic and home trazodone continued. Influenza and pneumococcal vaccines were administered prior to discharge. Physical therapy evaluated balance and gait; recommended home-based therapy for fall prevention and strengthening. Urine culture pending; renal function stable for baseline CKD stage 3.

Key findings/procedures: noncontrast CT head negative for acute process; positive bedside vestibular findings consistent with peripheral vestibulopathy. No invasive procedures performed. PT assessment: moderate imbalance, requires single-point cane for short distances; assistance needed for toileting transfers.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged stable and afebrile, symptoms improved with reduced nausea and less severe vertigo. Ambulates short distances with a cane and requires assistance for some transfers and ADLs. Home health recommended for nursing visits and home physical therapy to reduce fall risk and assist with medication reconciliation.

Medications and follow-up plan: Continue latanoprost 0.005% ophthalmic nightly, trazodone at bedtime as needed, ondansetron PRN for nausea. Heparin and IV therapies discontinued. Urine culture pending; home health RN/PCP to review culture and initiate oral antibiotics if indicated. Follow up with PCP in 48–72 hours, ENT or neurology in 2 weeks, ophthalmology in 4 weeks, nephrology PRN for CKD. Home health nursing to visit within 24–48 hours and home PT to begin within 48–72 hours for balance training and home safety assessment.

History of Present Illness: 70-year-old male admitted electively for repair of an incisional hernia (ICD-10 K43.2). Preoperative complaints included an enlarging abdominal wall bulge without features of obstruction or ischemia. Significant comorbidities: hyperlipidemia, history of nicotine dependence, cardiomegaly, and prior episodes of urinary retention.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent operative repair under general anesthesia with intraoperative placement of prosthetic reinforcement (procedure codes 0WUF0JZ, 0KXL0ZZ, 0KXK0ZZ). Short perioperative urinary catheterization (00HU33Z) was performed and removed when voiding trial was satisfactory. Perioperative prophylaxis included heparin and standard antibiotics. Pain was managed with multimodal therapy (acetaminophen, short course IV/PO opioids as needed, local bupivacaine infiltration). There were no intraoperative or immediate postoperative complications. Labs and hemodynamics remained stable. Patient tolerated diet, ambulated with assistance, and had return of bowel function prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Incisional hernia without obstruction or gangrene repaired with prosthetic reinforcement; uncomplicated anesthetic course. Urinary catheter placed perioperatively for bladder management with successful voiding prior to discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and tolerating oral intake. Mobility: ambulates with a cane/assistance short distances and requires home health support for transfers and activity progression. Wound status: surgical incision clean and dry; requires dressing changes and wound checks by home health.

Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen scheduled and PRN; oxycodone IR short course for breakthrough pain; docusate sodium and polyethylene glycol for bowel regimen; pravastatin continued; tamsulosin resumed for urinary symptoms. Naloxone provided in the inpatient setting as needed; heparin prophylaxis discontinued on discharge.

Follow-up Plan: Surgical clinic in 7–10 days for wound check and suture removal as indicated. Primary care follow-up in 1 week; consider cardiology follow-up for cardiomegaly if not established. Home health referral for wound care, medication administration/education, vital sign monitoring, ambulation assistance, and voiding assessment. Return to ED for fever, increasing pain, wound drainage, inability to void, or progressive shortness of breath.

History of Present Illness: 86-year-old female admitted under observation after acute onset left upper quadrant abdominal pain and lightheadedness. Past medical history notable for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, mild cognitive impairment, peripheral neuropathy, prior breast cancer, and Charcot arthropathy of the left ankle. CT abdomen obtained on admission demonstrated a focal splenic infarction consistent with embolic phenomenon.

Hospital Course: Patient observed 3.7 days. Telemetry captured intermittent paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. She was anticoagulated with heparin during admission and transitioned to oral anticoagulation prior to discharge. Electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, low magnesium) were corrected. Pain was managed with acetaminophen; gabapentin resumed for baseline neuropathic pain. No surgical intervention was required. Influenza high-dose vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT abdomen showing splenic infarct (D73.5). Continuous cardiac monitoring demonstrating paroxysmal AF. Laboratory correction of hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. No evidence of hemodynamic instability or need for splenic intervention.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable, pain controlled on oral medications. Cognition at baseline for known mild cognitive impairment; requires assistance with medication management and moderate assistance for transfers/ambulation due to baseline neuropathy and Charcot joint. Ambulates with a walker with supervision. Home health services arranged for nursing and physical therapy to support safety and ADLs.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Discharge medications include apixaban (for presumed embolic splenic infarct and atrial fibrillation), aspirin (home medication), beta-blocker for rate control, HCTZ for BP, potassium chloride and oral magnesium supplementation, gabapentin, acetaminophen PRN, omeprazole PRN. Heparin discontinued. Home health to monitor vitals, bleeding signs, med reconciliation, and labs (BMP, CBC) within 48–72 hours. Follow-up with primary care within 48–72 hours, cardiology in 1 week for anticoagulation/rhythm management, and vascular/hematology or outpatient imaging in 4–6 weeks as indicated. Return precautions given for worsening abdominal pain, bleeding, syncope, or new neurologic deficits.

49-year-old female admitted under observation for 21.7 days with acute thoracic aortic dissection (I71.01) complicated by acute respiratory failure with hypoxia, coronary artery dissection, acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, acute post-hemorrhagic anemia, and acute kidney injury. She presented with acute chest/back pain and hemodynamic lability and underwent urgent endovascular repair of the thoracic aortic dissection. Additional procedures included central venous access placement and a period of invasive ventilatory support with successful weaning.

Hospital course: Post-procedure course was notable for brief intubation for hypoxemic respiratory failure, treated with ventilatory support and subsequent successful extubation. She received a short course of IV antibiotics (ampicillin-sulbactam) for suspected healthcare-associated pulmonary infection and diuresis for volume management related to acute on chronic diastolic heart failure. Renal function improved with conservative management and adjustment of diuretics; anemia was addressed with supportive care. Hemodynamics stabilized with antihypertensive management (including hydralazine as indicated). Neurologic status remained at baseline following evaluation for prior cerebrovascular disease.

Key findings/procedures: Imaging confirmed thoracic aortic dissection with successful endovascular repair. Echocardiogram demonstrated nonrheumatic aortic insufficiency and diastolic dysfunction. AKI and anemia improved; no new focal neurologic deficits identified.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge to home. She requires assistance with ambulation (uses walker) and needs help with some activities of daily living; mobility and endurance are improving with therapy. Home health nursing is arranged for skilled nursing visits for medication reconciliation, vital sign and weight monitoring, daily diuretic adjustment guidance, laboratory monitoring (BMP, CBC) and assistance with ADLs. Home PT/OT will continue gait training and functional strengthening.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include aspirin EC, furosemide (dose adjusted per weight and renal function), hydralazine PRN, acetaminophen PRN, docusate sodium and lactulose PRN for bowel management, and glucose gel PRN. Completed inpatient antibiotic course. Follow-up: cardiothoracic surgery and cardiology within 1 week, nephrology in 1 week for AKI monitoring, and primary care within 48–72 hours. Labs (BMP, CBC) in 48–72 hours or sooner if symptomatic.

History of Present Illness: 88-year-old female presented after a fall on stairs with right shoulder pain. Radiographs demonstrated an acute, closed, unspecified fracture of the proximal right humerus (S42.201A). She was observed for pain control, neurovascular monitoring, and medical optimization given multiple comorbidities including hypertensive heart disease with heart failure, atrial fibrillation on chronic anticoagulation, and hyperlipidemia.

Hospital Course: Observation admission 1.8 days. Orthopedics consulted; no emergent operative intervention indicated during this encounter. Fracture managed nonoperatively with shoulder immobilizer/sling, neurovascular checks remained intact, and repeat imaging deferred to outpatient ortho. Cardiac status monitored; no decompensated heart failure. Anticoagulation (apixaban) was resumed after risk/benefit discussion. Pain managed with multimodal regimen; short course of opioid for breakthrough pain provided and weaned prior to discharge. Vitals and basic labs were stable; no acute medical complications.

Key Findings and Procedures: Right proximal humerus fracture on X-ray; no open injury, no neurovascular deficit. Orthopedics evaluation without procedure performed. Imaging and clinical exam consistent with closed fracture; fall mechanism documented. No IV lines on discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Pain is controlled on oral medications. She ambulates with a rolling walker and requires assistance with transfers and bathing; home health services arranged for nursing and physical/occupational therapy to assist with mobility training, ADL support, fall prevention, and medication management. Home health to monitor incision/wound if needed and anticoagulation-related signs.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include acetaminophen (scheduled/PRN), apixaban (resume chronic dose for AF), metoprolol succinate XL, torsemide, amlodipine, atorvastatin, docusate sodium, lidocaine 5% patch PRN, short-course morphine sulfate or oxycodone IR for breakthrough pain. Sodium chloride 0.9% flush not required at home. Follow-up: Orthopedics in 7–10 days, primary care in 1 week (or sooner if concerns), cardiology as outpatient for AF/heart failure management. Home health to initiate within 48 hours.

History of Present Illness: 25-year-old G?P? female presented urgently at 39 weeks gestation with suspected fetal abnormality and concern for delivery. She underwent a spontaneous vaginal delivery of a single live term neonate. Delivery was complicated by a first-degree perineal laceration which was repaired in the delivery suite. Mother and infant remained stable during a 2.3-day postpartum stay.

Hospital Course: Maternal postpartum course was uncomplicated. Vital signs remained within expected limits; uterine involution noted and lochia appropriate for immediate postpartum period. Pain was managed with oral acetaminophen and ibuprofen as needed. Bowel regimen instituted (docusate and milk of magnesia as indicated; bisacodyl PRN) to reduce straining. Topical analgesia (Dermoplast) and simethicone for gas discomfort were provided. Intravenous fluids (Lactated Ringer’s) and routine IV saline flushes were used peri-delivery. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Term singleton live birth (ICD-10 Z37.0) at 39 weeks (Z3A.39). Primary diagnosis: maternal care for suspected fetal abnormality (O35.8XX0). First-degree perineal laceration during delivery (O70.0) with uncomplicated local repair. Relevant procedures performed include routine vaginal delivery and perineal repair with standard hemostasis and uterine assessment.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating oral intake, ambulating independently with steady gait, and able to perform basic activities of daily living though advised to limit heavy lifting and strenuous activity. Breastfeeding established with initial latch; patient requests home health support for lactation education and newborn care assistance.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications: acetaminophen and ibuprofen for analgesia, docusate sodium and milk of magnesia for constipation prevention/treatment, bisacodyl PRN, calcium carbonate as needed for reflux, simethicone for gas, Dermoplast topical spray for perineal pain. Follow-up: postpartum clinic/OB at 1–2 weeks and routine 6-week postpartum visit; home health nursing for wound checks, lochia and pain monitoring, lactation support, and medication reconciliation. Return precautions reviewed: fever >100.4°F, heavy bleeding, increasing perineal pain, wound drainage, or signs of infection.

Patient: 74-year-old male. Admission: Emergency; length of stay 5.5 days. Primary diagnosis: postprocedural hematoma of genitourinary organ (N99.840) with acute posthemorrhagic anemia (D62) and acute kidney injury (N17.9) on chronic kidney disease.

History of present illness: Patient developed a sizable postprocedural hematoma following a recent genitourinary procedure and presented to the ED with symptomatic anemia and hypotension. He has known CKD and history of TIA and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Hospital course: On admission the patient was hemodynamically stabilized with IV fluids and transfusion for acute posthemorrhagic anemia. Broad evaluation included serial CBCs and BMPs, imaging of the pelvis to define hematoma extent, and consultations with urology and nephrology. Interventional options were considered; conservative management with close observation was chosen as the patient stabilized and hematoma size was nonexpanding on repeat imaging. Renal function acutely worsened on admission consistent with AKI on CKD and improved with fluid optimization and avoidance of nephrotoxins. Pain was controlled with short-course opioid and adjunctive acetaminophen. Nausea was treated as needed. VTE prophylaxis and bowel regimen were instituted.

Key findings/procedures: Imaging-confirmed postprocedural pelvic hematoma without active extravasation. Received packed red blood cell transfusion(s) for symptomatic anemia. Nephrology recommended renal-protective measures and outpatient monitoring. Urology followed and recommended nonoperative management with outpatient surveillance.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulates short distances with assistance, and requires intermittent help for activities of daily living. Wound/hematoma site shows no active drainage; home health is arranged for wound checks, vital sign monitoring, medication administration, and assistance with ADLs.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, oxycodone (IR) PRN, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate XL, amlodipine, tamsulosin, levothyroxine, omeprazole, ondansetron PRN, senna, sodium bicarbonate, and others as reconciled. Labs (CBC, BMP) within 48–72 hours post-discharge. Follow-up: urology within 7 days, nephrology within 2 weeks, primary care within 7 days, and oncology as outpatient. Home health to coordinate wound care, vitals, medication adherence, and transport to appointments.

History of Present Illness: 23-year-old female admitted as a same-day surgical patient for operative management related to symptomatic, otherwise specified polyneuropathy (ICD-10 G62.89). She presented with progressive distal sensory loss and neuropathic pain refractory to outpatient measures. Significant comorbidities include severe obesity (BMI 45–49.9), obstructive sleep apnea, allergic rhinitis, bipolar disorder, and obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent planned surgical intervention (procedure codes 01UD07Z, 01ND0ZZ) without intraoperative complications. Perioperative cefazolin and intraoperative fluids (lactated Ringer’s, iso‑osmotic dextrose) were administered. Postoperatively she received short-interval IV analgesia (hydromorphone), antiemetic therapy (ondansetron), and DVT prophylaxis with heparin while inpatient. Overnight observation was performed due to history of OSA; respiratory status remained stable on baseline CPAP at home. She had mild postoperative nausea that resolved and reported acceptable pain control on transition to oral analgesics. Influenza quadrivalent vaccine was administered prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Pre- and post-operative neurological exam demonstrated persistent distal sensory deficits consistent with the underlying polyneuropathy; no new focal motor deficits. Surgical site clean, dry, and intact on examination at discharge. No evidence of wound infection or bleeding.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable. Ambulates short distances with supervision due to neuropathic symptoms and obesity; requires assistance with some ADLs and will benefit from home health support for mobility and wound care. Respiratory status stable on home CPAP; home health should monitor oxygenation and CPAP adherence.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen and oxycodone (PRN) for pain, ondansetron PRN for nausea, continuation of home psychotropic regimen (lamotrigine, clonazepam) as previously prescribed, and instructions regarding wound care and DVT prevention with early ambulation. Follow-up: surgical clinic in 7–10 days for wound check, neurology in 4 weeks for ongoing polyneuropathy management, primary care in 1 week, and outpatient sleep medicine/psychiatry as needed. Home health services arranged for wound care, medication reconciliation, vital sign/respiratory monitoring, and assistance with ADLs for 1–2 weeks.

Patient: 66-year-old male. Admission: OBSERVATION ADMIT, length of stay 4.8 days. Primary diagnosis: malignant neoplasm of liver (C22.9). Other active problems: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (C85.90), paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (I48.0), essential hypertension (I10), hyperlipidemia (E78.5), GERD without esophagitis (K21.9), type 2 diabetes without complications (E11.9), history of myocardial infarction (I25.2), history of venous thrombosis/embolism (Z86.718).

History of present illness: The patient presented with progressive fatigue, intermittent right upper quadrant discomfort, mild nausea, and new abnormal liver imaging concerning for hepatic mass. He has background of lymphoma and cardiovascular comorbidities. No overt GI bleed, hemodynamically stable on arrival.

Hospital course: Patient underwent image-guided diagnostic procedure of the liver (ICD-10-PCS 0FB03ZX) without immediate complication. Pain was managed with acetaminophen. Cardiac monitoring identified paroxysmal atrial fibrillation episodes; rate controlled with metoprolol tartrate. Electrolytes were monitored; magnesium supplemented as indicated. No transfusions required. Acyclovir was administered per oncology prophylaxis protocol. Gastroprotection continued with pantoprazole. Bowel regimen initiated with senna. Vitals and hemodynamics remained stable; blood glucose controlled with oral agents during stay. Oncology and cardiology consultants were involved; plan for definitive oncologic staging and management outpatient.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging and procedural pathology pending; preliminary report consistent with hepatic malignancy requiring outpatient oncology follow-up. Diagnostic percutaneous liver procedure performed without complication. Cardiac telemetry confirmed paroxysmal AF.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged stable, ambulatory with baseline assistance, independent with ADLs at home but fatigued and limited in activity tolerance. Home health recommended for wound checks, assistance with medication administration review, and monitoring of vital signs/weight twice weekly.

Medications at discharge: Acetaminophen PRN, metoprolol tartrate (for rate control), pantoprazole daily, rosuvastatin, ramelteon PRN at night, senna PRN, acyclovir per oncology plan. Advised to continue home medications for diabetes and hypertension.

Follow-up: Oncology clinic within 7–10 days for pathology/staging and treatment planning; cardiology within 1–2 weeks to reassess AF management and anticoagulation; primary care in 1 week. Labs (CBC, CMP, INR if applicable) within 48–72 hours. Return precautions reviewed.

Mr. [Patient], a 79-year-old man, was admitted under observation for chest pain and diagnosed with non–ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He has significant comorbidities including end-stage renal disease on chronic hemodialysis, known coronary artery disease, prior coronary artery dissection, systolic heart failure/cardiomyopathy, chronic anemia, and recent community-acquired pneumonia. Presenting troponin was elevated and ECG showed ischemic changes without ST elevation. He received guideline-directed medical therapy for NSTEMI and was monitored in the telemetry unit.

Hospital course: The patient underwent diagnostic left heart catheterization with percutaneous coronary intervention to address obstructive coronary lesions and achieved TIMI-3 flow post-intervention. He remained hemodynamically stable after the procedure. He received IV and oral antibiotics for pneumonia (completed a course including levofloxacin) with clinical improvement. Hemoglobin declined consistent with acute posthemorrhagic anemia and he received transfusion support with subsequent stabilization. Dialysis was continued on schedule throughout the stay. Echocardiography demonstrated reduced left ventricular systolic function (estimated EF ~35–40%). No in-hospital arrhythmias requiring intervention were noted.

Key findings and procedures: Elevated cardiac biomarkers consistent with NSTEMI, diagnostic coronary angiography with percutaneous coronary intervention and stent placement, treatment for pneumonia, RBC transfusion for acute anemia, ongoing maintenance hemodialysis.

Discharge condition and functional status: At discharge he is medically stable, hemodynamically controlled, and euvolemic. He ambulates with assistive device and requires assistance with some activities of daily living; home health nursing is arranged for medication reconciliation, daily weight and volume status checks, and dialysis coordination. Wound/catheter sites are clean and intact.

Medications on discharge: Aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol succinate, isosorbide mononitrate ER, hydralazine, nitroglycerin SL PRN, calcium acetate, ferric citrate, allopurinol, acetaminophen, levofloxacin (if ongoing per culture/ID), magnesium oxide, polyethylene glycol, nephrocaps as indicated. 

Follow-up: Cardiology within 7 days, nephrology per dialysis unit schedule, PCP in 1–2 weeks, and home health nursing to initiate within 24–48 hours. Return to ED for chest pain, dyspnea, syncope, or fever.

History of present illness: 81-year-old male admitted under observation for severe sepsis of unclear source (A41.9) with multi-organ dysfunction. He presented with hypotension and altered mentation and was found to have respiratory distress and acute kidney injury. Length of stay 18.9 days; stabilized and prepared for discharge to home with home health.

Hospital course: Patient required initial resuscitation with IV fluids and brief vasopressor support for septic shock and cardiogenic compromise. He developed acute-on-chronic diastolic heart failure and respiratory failure with periods of hypoxia and hypercapnia, requiring supplemental oxygen and intermittent noninvasive ventilatory support; he was successfully weaned to baseline oxygen requirements. Acute kidney injury improved with conservative management. He received broad-spectrum IV antibiotics with clinical improvement and was transitioned to tailored oral therapy prior to discharge. Arrhythmia management and rate control were optimized for history of atrial fibrillation; anticoagulation with apixaban continued. Wound/cellulitis areas were managed with local care; no operative procedures were required.

Key findings and procedures: Blood cultures and imaging consistent with systemic infection; elevated lactate and hemodynamic instability on presentation that resolved. Echocardiogram showed chronic diastolic dysfunction with reduced reserve. No invasive procedures required at discharge; urinary catheter removed and patient voiding.

Discharge condition and functional status: Medically stable for discharge, hemodynamically euvolemic, afebrile, and oxygenating on prescribed supplemental oxygen. Functional status: decreased endurance and deconditioning after prolonged hospitalization; requires assistance with transfers and ambulation and will benefit from skilled physical and occupational therapy. Wound care needs and medication management require nursing oversight at home.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge medications include acetaminophen, apixaban, bumetanide, midodrine, inhaled bronchodilator (albuterol), fluticasone inhaler and nasal steroid, omeprazole, polyethylene glycol, topical lidocaine, guaifenesin-dextromethorphan, senna, ramelteon, and artificial tears. Home health: RN visit within 24–48 hours for medication reconciliation, wound assessment, and oxygen assessment; PT/OT for mobility and ADL training; nursing to coordinate outpatient labs and home anticoagulation safety. Follow-up with primary care within 3–5 days, cardiology in 1–2 weeks, and nephrology as outpatient as indicated.

Brief history of present illness: 67-year-old male admitted to observation for progressive dyspnea, cough, decreased oral intake and lower-extremity edema. Past history notable for metastatic malignancy of the digestive system (C26.9) with known metastatic disease to lung and liver, congestive heart failure with hypertensive heart disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and recent acute kidney injury. Imaging demonstrated a large right-sided pleural effusion. Diagnostic thoracentesis/chest drainage was performed during this stay.

Hospital course: The patient was observed for 3.7 days. He underwent pleural drainage for symptomatic malignant pleural effusion with symptomatic improvement in respiratory status. He received intravenous diuretics with close monitoring of renal function; acute kidney injury partially corrected to near-baseline creatinine. He was treated symptomatically for cough and pain, received VTE prophylaxis, and had glycemic management with subcutaneous insulin. Cardiology input supported diuretic optimization for volume overload. No acute surgical interventions were required.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging consistent with malignant pleural effusion and metastatic disease to bilateral lungs and liver. Laboratory notable for transient acute kidney injury which improved with diuresis and fluid management. Procedures performed: thoracentesis/chest drainage with symptomatic relief (ICD-10-PCS 0W9B3ZZ, 0W9B3ZX).

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged in stable condition with improved respiratory symptoms but persistent deconditioning. He requires assistance with activities of daily living and has limited ambulation due to fatigue and recent deconditioning. Home health services arranged for nursing visits for wound/line care (if present), medication reconciliation, ADL support, and daily weight/edema monitoring to guide diuretic therapy.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include torsemide for outpatient diuresis, insulin regimen for diabetes, acetaminophen and trazodone as needed, benzonatate and guaifenesin-codeine for cough, stool softener (senna), heparin as inpatient only (stopped on discharge), and supplies for saline flushes as applicable. Arrange follow-up: oncology within 1–2 weeks, pulmonology for effusion reassessment, nephrology for kidney function check within 1 week, and primary care/cardiology in 7 days. Labs: BMP and CBC prior to first clinic visit or sooner if symptoms worsen. Home health to monitor vital signs, weights, glucose, and medication adherence.

Brief HPI: 63-year-old female admitted to observation status after an acute neurologic event following recent surgery. She developed acute neurologic deficits and was found to have a postprocedural cerebrovascular infarction. Presenting features included acute onset focal deficits with an NIHSS of 2 and chest pain. Imaging demonstrated cerebral infarction consistent with embolic etiology and dissection of the vertebral artery was identified as a contributing lesion.

Hospital Course: Patient was observed for 4.7 days. Initial evaluation included CT head and CTA neck/brain, which confirmed acute cerebral infarction and vertebral artery dissection. She was managed conservatively with blood pressure control, antiplatelet therapy, statin, and close neurologic monitoring. Heparin was used during early inpatient management per neurology recommendations and transitioned to dual antiplatelet therapy. Cardiac and vascular risk factors were evaluated and treated; glucose was monitored and managed with insulin as needed. No neurosurgical intervention was required. Pain and reflux symptoms were treated and stabilized.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT/CTA-confirmed cerebral infarction due to embolism (I63.40) and vertebral artery dissection (I77.74). NIHSS score documented as 2. Continuous telemetry without arrhythmia identified. No procedural cerebrovascular intervention performed.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged medically stable, alert and oriented, with mild residual neurologic deficit (NIHSS 2). Ambulates with steadying assistance and requires minimal assistance with some ADLs; home health recommended for safety and functional support. Cognitive status adequate for discharge with caregiver support; requires education for stroke warning signs and medication management.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, acetaminophen, gabapentin, pantoprazole (or ranitidine per allergy/tolerance), docusate, and insulin regimen with glucose-source items available (dextrose 50%, glucose gel, glucagon) as indicated. Heparin was discontinued prior to discharge. Home health nursing for medication administration, glucose and blood pressure monitoring, wound and neurologic checks, and coordination of PT/OT is arranged. Follow-up with neurology within 7 days, primary care within 1–2 weeks, and vascular surgery or interventionalist as outpatient if indicated.

History of Present Illness: 31-year-old G?P? F presented urgently at 37 weeks gestation with labor and known breech presentation and symptomatic submucous uterine leiomyoma. She was noted to have a positive test for Chlamydia trachomatis and baseline sickle-cell trait; anemia was identified in the peripartum period. Admission diagnosis included maternal care for breech presentation (O32.1XX0), chlamydial infection complicating childbirth (A56.8/O98.32), benign uterine tumor (O34.13), sickle-cell trait (D57.3), and anemia complicating childbirth (O99.02). Length of stay was 3.2 days.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent delivery with operative management of breech presentation and routine postpartum uterine management. Oxytocin was administered for uterine tone. Azithromycin was given for treatment of chlamydial infection. Analgesia included acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and a short course of oxycodone (immediate release) for breakthrough pain; ondansetron was available for nausea. Supportive IV fluids (Lactated Ringers, 0.9% sodium chloride) and perioperative flushes were used as indicated. Docusate and simethicone were provided for bowel regimen and gas control. Naloxone was available and used only per protocol if needed. There were no immediate surgical complications. Hemodynamically stable throughout admission; anemia addressed with monitoring and outpatient follow-up arranged.

Key Findings and Procedures: Delivery for breech presentation with procedural management documented (see operative report). Single live infant at 37 weeks delivered; neonatal course described in neonatal chart. Uterine tone responded to oxytocin; no retained products identified. Cultures/NAAT positive for Chlamydia; treated with azithromycin.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is stable, afebrile, pain controlled on oral medications, ambulating with minimal assistance, and caring for newborn with support. Home health recommended for postpartum assessment, wound/perineal checks, vital sign monitoring, assistance with ambulation and ADLs as needed, breastfeeding support, and medication education.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds: azithromycin (complete course), acetaminophen PRN, ibuprofen PRN, oxycodone IR short course PRN, ondansetron PRN, docusate PRN, simethicone PRN. Follow-up: OB postpartum visit within 48–72 hours and again at 2 weeks; CBC in 1 week to reassess anemia; STI re-testing per CDC guidelines and partner treatment; primary care for sickle-cell trait counseling. Home health referral placed for 1–3 visits; please see outpatient appointments and operative note for further details.

History of Present Illness: 69-year-old male admitted to observation for acute right-sided flank pain and obstructive uropathy. Imaging demonstrated hydronephrosis secondary to a renal/ureteral calculus (primary Dx N13.2). He has known chronic kidney disease stage 3 and baseline atherosclerotic coronary disease with prior coronary angioplasty.

Hospital Course: Patient observed 1.7 days. Initial evaluation notable for elevated creatinine consistent with acute kidney injury on CKD. Pain controlled with short-acting analgesics. Urology performed endoscopic decompression with ureteral stent placement for relief of obstruction (procedure 0T778DZ) without immediate complication. Renal function trended toward baseline after decompression and IV fluids. Hemodynamically stable throughout. No evidence of sepsis. Influenza high-dose vaccine administered per protocol.

Key Findings and Procedures: CT/US-confirmed hydronephrosis due to obstructing calculus; acute kidney injury (AKI) superimposed on CKD stage 3, improved after stent placement and hydration. Procedure: cystoscopic ureteral stent placement for decompression (ICD-10-PCS 0T778DZ). Cardiac history reviewed; no acute cardiac ischemia.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, pain controlled on oral medications. Baseline ambulation preserved; independent with activities of daily living but reports mild deconditioning. Home health services arranged for short-term skilled nursing to assist with medication management, vital sign and weight monitoring, reinforcement of activity and fall precautions, and wound/stent care education.

Medications at Discharge: Aspirin, Atorvastatin, Carvedilol, Torsemide, Amlodipine, Vitamin D. (Inpatient IV fluids and heparin discontinued at discharge.) Patient provided instructions on analgesics and stool softener as needed.

Follow-up Plan: Urology follow-up within 5–7 days for stent management and definitive stone plan; nephrology follow-up in 1–2 weeks for BMP and CKD/AKI reassessment; oncology and cardiology follow-up as outpatient per existing care. Labs: BMP within 48–72 hours and as directed by nephrology. Return to ED for fever, worsening flank pain, decreased urine output, chest pain, or other acute concerns.

Brief HPI: 50-year-old male admitted to observation for 6.8 days with progressive erythema, drainage, pain and intermittent fevers at the site of prior foot/ankle internal fixation. Imaging demonstrated displacement of fixation hardware of the foot/toes. Wound cultures returned positive for bacterial pathogens consistent with device-associated infection. Hospital Course: Patient was managed with operative irrigation and debridement with partial revision/removal of displaced hardware, placement of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) for long-term IV therapy, and serial wound care. He received IV daptomycin for presumed gram-positive device-related infection and oral ciprofloxacin as directed by Infectious Disease pending final susceptibilities. Alteplase was used once for catheter clearance; heparin flushes prescribed for PICC maintenance. Pain was managed with acetaminophen and short-course opioid as needed; asthma and Parkinson’s medications were continued (albuterol inhaler, amantadine). Psychiatric medications (aripiprazole) were continued with social work involvement for outpatient support. Key Findings and Procedures: Displaced internal fixation device of the foot, non-pressure chronic ulcer of the left ankle with surrounding cellulitis, positive wound cultures, operative irrigation and debridement with partial hardware revision/removal, and PICC placement for outpatient IV antibiotics. Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, pain controlled on oral regimen, and ambulates with a rolling walker. He requires assistance with dressing changes and PICC care but is otherwise able to perform basic ADLs with supervision. Home health will provide skilled nursing for IV antibiotic administration, wound dressing changes, PICC maintenance/heparin flushes, and physical therapy for gait and transfers. Medications at Discharge (selected): Daptomycin IV via home infusion (per ID plan), oral ciprofloxacin, acetaminophen PRN, albuterol inhaler, amantadine, aripiprazole, lorazepam/clonazepam as needed for anxiety, loperamide PRN. Follow-up Plan: Orthopedics in 7 days for definitive hardware management; Infectious Disease in 3–5 days for antibiotic plan and weekly labs (CBC, CMP, CK while on daptomycin); wound clinic weekly; primary care in 2 weeks; neurology/psychiatry as outpatient. Return to ED for fever, increasing pain, erythema, drainage, new neurologic deficits, or PICC complications.

History of Present Illness: 83-year-old man admitted under observation for 3 days with recurrent Clostridioides difficile enterocolitis (ICD-10 A04.71). He presented with profuse non-bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and volume depletion. Past medical history notable for hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease with diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation with pacemaker, chronic kidney disease, prior myocardial infarction, chronic hepatitis C, and rheumatoid disease on chronic immunomodulatory therapy.

Hospital Course: Stool testing confirmed C. difficile. He was started on oral vancomycin liquid for recurrent disease with supportive care including judicious IV fluids for prerenal azotemia and electrolyte repletion. Baseline and interval basic metabolic panels showed transient acute kidney injury that improved with hydration and temporary adjustment of diuretics; torsemide was resumed at a tailored dose prior to discharge. Cardiac status remained stable with rate control on metoprolol succinate; pacemaker function reviewed and unchanged. No surgical interventions were required. Urine studies demonstrated bacteriuria; culture pending/being followed by outpatient team.

Key Findings and Procedures: Positive stool assay for C. difficile; transient AKI that responded to fluids; EKG consistent with chronic atrial fibrillation without ischemic change. No invasive procedures performed. Pacemaker interrogation documented unchanged parameters.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake, and able to ambulates with his baseline assistive device but requires assistance with some activities of daily living — home health nursing recommended for initial visits to ensure safe medication administration and monitoring.

Medications and Follow-up Plan: Continue home chronic medications (atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate, torsemide, isosorbide mononitrate, potassium chloride, cyanocobalamin, prednisone/hydroxychloroquine regimen as previously prescribed) and complete oral vancomycin course as directed. Home health to provide medication supervision, vitals checks, and assistance with hydration. Labs: BMP within 48–72 hours and repeat as outpatient; urine culture follow-up. Appointments: Primary care within 7 days, GI for C. difficile follow-up in 1–2 weeks, nephrology as outpatient for AKI surveillance, cardiology/pacemaker clinic as scheduled.

Discharge disposition: Home with home health services and close outpatient follow-up.

History of Present Illness: 72-year-old male with prior aortocoronary bypass graft (Z95.1) and known coronary artery disease presented to the ED with acute-onset chest pressure. Initial evaluation demonstrated non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with positive cardiac troponin trend and ischemic changes on ECG. He was placed on telemetry and treated with antithrombotic therapy and anti-ischemic measures.

Hospital Course: Patient was observed for 1.9 days. He received heparin anticoagulation during the acute phase and was transitioned to apixaban on discharge given his clinical context and existing indications. Aspirin and high-intensity statin therapy (atorvastatin) were continued. Beta blockade (metoprolol tartrate) and ACE inhibitor (lisinopril) were initiated/continued for secondary prevention and blood pressure control. Nitroglycerin was provided PRN for recurrent ischemia; electrolyte and renal function remained stable. No recurrent chest pain or hemodynamic instability occurred on telemetry. Rhythm was monitored; no sustained ventricular arrhythmia noted.

Key Findings and Procedures: Diagnostic workup confirmed NSTEMI (serial troponins elevated). Procedure performed: ICD-10-PCS 5A2204Z (cardiac procedure performed during observation) without immediate complication. Diagnosis list includes subsequent NSTEMI (I22.2), hypertension (I10), prior CABG (Z95.1), hypercholesterolemia (E78.0), BPH (N40.0), atherosclerotic CAD with angina (I25.119), personal history of nicotine dependence, and long-term antithrombotic use.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is hemodynamically and clinically stable at discharge. He ambulates with mild exertional limitation and requires minimal assistance for community ambulation; generally independent with basic ADLs but reports fatigue. Home health services arranged for medication reconciliation, vital sign and symptom monitoring (BP/pulse, chest pain surveillance), reinforcement of activity progression and fall-risk assessment.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include apixaban, aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide as indicated, nitroglycerin SL PRN, and continuation of home supplements. Follow-up with cardiology within 3–7 days and primary care within 1 week. Outpatient labs (BMP, CBC, lipid panel) and possible noninvasive ischemia evaluation per cardiology recommendations. Patient educated on signs of recurrent ischemia and when to return to ED.

History of Present Illness: 70-year-old male with known COPD and metastatic lung adenocarcinoma on osimertinib presented to observation unit for acute worsening dyspnea, cough, purulent sputum and dizziness. Chest imaging and clinical exam consistent with left lower lobe pneumonia on background COPD exacerbation. Admission diagnosis: COPD with acute lower respiratory infection and pneumonia.

Hospital Course: Observed 3.7 days. Treated with nebulized bronchodilators (albuterol and ipratropium-albuterol), acetylcysteine and guaifenesin for secretion management, systemic corticosteroid (prednisone taper) for COPD exacerbation, and empiric antibiotics (azithromycin and oral cefpodoxime) for community-acquired pneumonia. Received DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin while inpatient. Influenza vaccine administered prior to discharge. Symptoms and inflammatory markers improved with therapy; he remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile for 24+ hours prior to discharge.

Key Findings/Procedures: Chest radiograph consistent with left lower lobe consolidation and chronic COPD changes. Basic labs showed leukocytosis on admission with downtrend after antibiotics. No invasive procedures were required. Neurologic symptoms (intermittent dizziness) evaluated; meclizine prescribed PRN. Oncology records confirmed ongoing osimertinib therapy which was continued on discharge.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Discharged in improved respiratory condition but with residual dyspnea on exertion. Ambulates at baseline with assistance for longer distances and requires support with stair negotiation due to exertional shortness of breath and recent dizziness. Home health recommended for medication reconciliation, monitoring of respiratory status, assistance with ADLs as needed, and fall-risk precautions given metastatic brain disease history.

Medications and Follow-up: Continue home medications including osimertinib. New/continued discharge meds: prednisone taper, fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, albuterol nebulizer PRN, ipratropium-albuterol neb PRN, acetylcysteine neb, guaifenesin, azithromycin and cefpodoxime (complete prescribed courses), meclizine PRN. Follow-up: Pulmonology within 1 week, Oncology within 1–2 weeks, PCP in 48–72 hours. Home health nursing to start within 24–48 hours for med administration, breathing treatments, wound/safety assessment and vitals/oxygen monitoring as indicated.

History of Present Illness: 44-year-old male with known rectal carcinoma (C20) and history of gout presented for planned surgical attention to his diverting ileostomy (Z43.2). He underwent a same-day admission for evaluation and surgical management of the stoma due to functional concerns and peri-stomal irritation.

Hospital Course: Patient taken to the OR and underwent ileostomy revision (ICD-10-PCS 0DBB0ZZ) without intraoperative complications. He received perioperative IV fluids (Lactated Ringers), standard DVT prophylaxis with heparin while inpatient, and intra/postoperative analgesia including ketorolac and oxycodone as needed. Allopurinol was continued for gout control. He received the seasonal influenza vaccine prior to discharge. Vitals and basic labs remained stable; there was no evidence of surgical site infection. Pain was controlled with oral medications and patient tolerated a regular diet prior to discharge.

Key Findings and Procedures: Operative findings: patent ileostomy with need for minor revision; stoma viable with healthy peristomal skin after procedure. Hemostasis achieved; no enteric leak or intra-abdominal complication identified. Wounds dressed and stoma appliance refitted. ICD-10 codes: Z43.2, C20, M10.9; procedure 0DBB0ZZ.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient discharged in stable condition, afebrile, hemodynamically stable. Ambulates with steadying assistance and is able to perform light activities of daily living with supervision. Requires home health for ostomy care education, wound assessment, and assistance with medication management and monitoring of fluid balance and ostomy output.

Medications at Discharge: Acetaminophen for analgesia; OxyCODONE (immediate release) for breakthrough pain PRN; Allopurinol continued for gout; Magnesium oxide for bowel regimen; instructions to discontinue inpatient-only IV medications (Lactated Ringers, ketorolac IV, heparin) unless otherwise directed. Ostomy supplies and NaCl 0.9% flush instructions provided.

Follow-up Plan: Home health RN visit within 24–48 hours for ostomy/wound care and BMP/CBC coordination. Colorectal surgery clinic in 7–10 days; oncology follow-up as outpatient per tumor board plan. Return for fever, worsening pain, increasing ostomy output, signs of infection, or inability to maintain oral intake.

History of present illness: 66-year-old male with known non-Hodgkin lymphoma (C85.99) and chronic hepatitis B was admitted under observation for administration of antineoplastic chemotherapy (Z51.11). He presented for scheduled infusion and developed port occlusion and electrolyte abnormalities during the course.

Hospital course: Patient received planned chemotherapy via implanted port with leucovorin rescue per protocol. He developed an occluded port line which was successfully cleared with alteplase (catheter clearance) and confirmed functional. He experienced nausea that responded to ondansetron. Laboratory monitoring identified hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia; these were treated with intravenous and oral potassium chloride and phosphorus repletion, and magnesium sulfate was administered for concomitant magnesium depletion. Enoxaparin was provided for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis during the observation stay. He received bowel regimen agents (polyethylene glycol, bisacodyl) as needed. He was continued on levetiracetam for seizure prophylaxis started during admission. No acute infusion reactions or bleeding complications were observed. Vital signs and clinical status remained stable throughout the 6.5‑day observation stay.

Key findings and procedures: Successful administration of chemotherapy (procedure 3E04305) with leucovorin rescue. Port thrombotic occlusion resolved after alteplase. Electrolyte abnormalities corrected (K+, PO4-, Mg2+). No evidence of acute hepatic decompensation or infectious complication related to chronic HBV during stay.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient discharged in stable condition, hemodynamically stable and ambulatory with a rolling walker for short distances; independent with most ADLs but requires assistance for port care and medication management. Home health recommended to support IV/port care, medication administration, and short‑interval lab monitoring.

Medications and follow-up: Discharge meds include potassium chloride oral replacement, phosphorus supplementation, oral magnesium as indicated, ondansetron PRN, polyethylene glycol and bisacodyl PRN, levetiracetam, and instructions for heparin port flushes per protocol. Enoxaparin given in hospital; outpatient anticoagulation plan to be determined. Close follow-up with oncology within 7–14 days and repeat labs (CBC, CMP with electrolytes, Mg, PO4, K) within 48–72 hours via home health. Hepatology/oncology to address HBV management and ongoing chemotherapy scheduling.

Brief history of present illness: 29-year-old man admitted electively for administration of antineoplastic therapy (primary reason: encounter for antineoplastic chemotherapy) for known primary malignant neoplasm of the right scapula/long bones with metastatic disease to bilateral lungs and regional lymph nodes. Past medical history notable for HIV on antiretroviral therapy (Biktarvy), essential hypertension, asthma, nicotine dependence, chronic pain. He presented for scheduled inpatient chemotherapy and developed asymptomatic hyponatremia during stay.

Hospital course: Patient underwent planned IV chemotherapy (etoposide) administered via peripheral/central venous access (ICD-10-PCS 3E04305). He received supportive medications including dexamethasone, scheduled acetaminophen for infusion-related symptoms, antiemetic prophylaxis, and IV maintenance fluids (0.9% NaCl/5% dextrose). Hyponatremia (hypo-osmolality) was identified and corrected with fluid management and monitoring; no neurologic deficits occurred. He remained afebrile without infectious complications. Pain and nausea were controlled with multimodal therapy. Port/line was flushed with heparin per protocol prior to discharge.

Key findings and procedures: Imaging and prior oncology records document metastatic disease to lungs and axillary nodes. No acute cardiopulmonary or neurologic deterioration during admission. Procedure: administration of antineoplastic agent (etoposide) with standard pre/post-infusion care; heparin flushes performed.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. He is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, pain controlled on oral regimen, ambulatory with minimal assistance for household mobility, and independent with most ADLs but reports fatigue and intermittent shortness of breath on exertion. Home health services arranged for IV/port care, medication reconciliation, and safety monitoring.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include Biktarvy (continue HIV regimen), etoposide per oncology outpatient plan, dexamethasone (short taper as prescribed), acetaminophen PRN, gabapentin for neuropathic pain, furosemide as indicated, stool regimen (docusate, bisacodyl PRN), fluticasone nasal spray, and heparin flush supplies for port care. Labs (CBC with differential, CMP) to be obtained 48–72 hours post-discharge and prior to next cycle. Oncology follow-up in 7 days (or sooner for symptoms). Return precautions: fever >38°C, new/worsening dyspnea, uncontrolled pain, bleeding, or signs of infection at port site.

History of Present Illness: 62-year-old male with metastatic malignancy with known secondary right lung lesion (C78.01) and prior malignancy history presented electively for scheduled antineoplastic chemotherapy (Z51.11). He has an above-knee amputation of the right leg with wheelchair dependence and a prior history of venous thromboembolism on chronic anticoagulation.

Hospital Course: Patient admitted for a planned 3.2-day stay for IV administration of cisplatin and doxorubicin with standard premedication (dexamethasone, fosaprepitant) and aggressive IV hydration (0.9% and 0.45% NaCl, 5% dextrose as indicated). Chemotherapy administration documented (ICD-10-PCS 3E03305). Port/PICC heparin flushes were given per protocol. He received supportive medications including antiemetics, stool softener (docusate), laxative (bisacodyl), gabapentin and duloxetine for neuropathic/phantom limb pain. Apixaban was continued for prior VTE. Vitals and hemodynamics remained stable; there were no bleeding events, no acute renal injury, and no febrile neutropenia during admission. Nausea was transient and controlled with antiemetics; pain regimen optimized.

Key Findings and Procedures: Chemotherapy infusion completed without immediate complication. Laboratory monitoring remained acceptable (CBC and BMP within acceptable limits for discharge). Port care and heparin flushes performed. No evidence of acute thromboembolic or hemorrhagic complication.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: Patient is medically stable for discharge. Pain is controlled on current regimen. Functionally he is dependent on wheelchair and requires assistance for transfers and ADLs; home health referral placed for skilled nursing support, medication administration oversight, port care, and wound/skin surveillance.

Medications and Follow-up: Discharge meds include apixaban (continue), gabapentin, duloxetine, short steroid/antiemetic taper as given, stool softener and laxative prn. Labs: obtain CBC, CMP, and creatinine within 48–72 hours and prior to next cycle. Follow-up with oncology in 7 days for treatment planning and with primary care in 1–2 weeks. Home health to monitor for fever, signs of infection at access site, bleeding, new/worsening pain, and medication adherence. Return to ED for fever >38.0°C, uncontrolled vomiting, new neurological deficit, or overt bleeding.

Brief history of present illness: 58-year-old male with multiple myeloma (status post stem cell transplant) admitted under observation for management in the setting of scheduled antineoplastic immunotherapy (Z51.12). He developed tumor lysis syndrome and progressive pancytopenia during the admission with associated mild protein-calorie malnutrition, anxiety, and insomnia.

Hospital course: The patient was treated over a 19.7-day observation stay with aggressive supportive care including IV fluids, allopurinol for TLS prophylaxis, antiviral prophylaxis with acyclovir, antiemetic therapy, and bowel regimen. He received antimicrobial prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. A symptomatic occlusion of his implanted central venous access device was managed with alteplase (catheter clearance) with successful restoration of patency. Nutritional status was addressed with dietary support and monitoring. There were no ongoing hemodynamic or infectious complications at discharge.

Key findings and procedures: persistent pancytopenia with recovery trends on serial CBCs; no acute bleeding; resolved catheter occlusion after alteplase instillation; procedural interventions included central venous access management and diagnostic/therapeutic measures related to transplant/oncologic care.

Discharge condition and functional status: Patient is discharged medically stable, afebrile, and hemodynamically stable. He remains deconditioned with decreased endurance and requires assistance with activities of daily living (needs help with bathing and mobility); home health is arranged for central line care (0.9% sodium chloride flushes per protocol), medication administration assistance, and monitoring for infection or bleeding. He has mild gait impairment and increased fall risk; home health to provide fall precautions and functional support.

Medications and follow-up plan: Discharge medications include acyclovir, allopurinol, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (SS), omeprazole, ondansetron PRN, oxycodone IR PRN, docusate/senna bowel regimen, lorazepam PRN, trazodone nightly, topical lidocaine 2% as needed, and supplies for saline flushes and alteplase for catheter care as indicated. Labs (CBC, CMP, coagulation) to be obtained within 48–72 hours and as directed by oncology. Clinic follow-up with hematology/oncology within 48–72 hours and transplant clinic within 7 days; primary care within 1–2 weeks. Home health referral placed for line/wound care, medication administration, ADL support, and vital sign monitoring.

History of Present Illness: 64-year-old male with known extranodal B‑cell lymphoma who presented via direct emergency admission with progressive weight loss, nausea, vomiting, and partial small bowel obstruction. He has history of chronic systolic heart failure, essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, GERD, and prior postherpetic neuralgia. Admission diagnosis: encounter for antineoplastic chemotherapy and management of partial intestinal obstruction.

Hospital Course: Over a 7‑day admission the patient was managed conservatively for partial intestinal obstruction with bowel rest, IV fluids (0.9% NaCl and 5% dextrose as needed), antiemetics, bowel regimen (docusate, bisacodyl), and serial abdominal exams. He received IV antineoplastic therapy (etoposide) per oncology plan with per‑protocol supportive medications including dexamethasone and prophylactic filgrastim. Acyclovir was given for postherpetic neuralgia prophylaxis/treatment. He received subcutaneous filgrastim for neutropenia prevention and inpatient heparin for VTE prophylaxis. Cardiac status was monitored given chronic systolic heart failure; he remained hemodynamically stable without evidence of acute decompensation.

Key Findings and Procedures: Patient tolerated IV chemotherapy administration (procedure codes 3E04305, 3E0R305). Imaging and clinical assessment were consistent with partial, non‑operative intestinal obstruction that resolved with conservative therapy. No acute cardiopulmonary events occurred. Pain related to postherpetic neuralgia improved with gabapentin and duloxetine.

Discharge Condition and Functional Status: At discharge the patient is clinically stable, afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and tolerating oral intake. He is ambulatory with assistance for longer distances due to deconditioning and will benefit from short‑term home health for medication administration and mobility support. He is independent with most basic ADLs but requires assistance for IV/SC medication administration and monitoring.

Medications and Follow‑up: Discharge medications include etoposide per oncology plan (to be administered outpatient or per oncology infusion center), filgrastim (SC) as instructed, acyclovir, gabapentin, duloxetine, dexamethasone taper, docusate, bisacodyl PRN, aluminum‑magnesium hydroxide‑simethicone, cetirizine, and others reconciled with outpatient regimen. Home health arranged for SC medication administration education, wound/skin and symptom monitoring, and mobility assistance. Follow up: Oncology within 3–7 days for chemotherapy planning, GI/surgery as outpatient for obstruction follow‑up, cardiology in 2 weeks (or sooner if symptoms), and PCP within 7 days for ongoing care and med reconciliation.
